Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of the City of Portsmouth, Virginia (2006)" and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as "Portsmouth City Code (2006)." 
(Code 1973, § 1-1; Code 1988, § 1-1; Ord. No. 1989-22, § 2, 3-14-1989) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to codify and recodify its ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433.  
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions, rules of construction. 
In the construction of this Code and all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intention of the council: 
Generally. The rules for the construction of statutes laid down by Code of Virginia, §§ 1-200—1-232, as the same are now or as they may be hereafter amended for the construction of the Code of Virginia and all statutes shall, so far as applicable, govern the construction of this Code. 
Charter. The term "Charter" shall mean the Charter of the city as it now exists and as it may be amended in the future. 
City. The term "city" shall be construed as if the term "of Portsmouth" followed it. 
Code. When the term "Code" is used without further qualification, it shall mean the "Code of the City of Portsmouth, Virginia (2006)." 
Code of Virginia. The term "Code of Virginia" or "Virginia Code" shall mean the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended from time to time. 
Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain time before a proceeding shall be had, there must be that time, exclusive of the day for such proceeding, but the day on which such notice is given or such act is done may be counted as part of the time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done within a certain time after any event or proceeding, that time shall be allowed in addition to the day on which the event or proceeding occurred. 
Council or city council. Whenever the terms "the council" or "the city council" are used, they shall be construed to mean the City Council of the City of Portsmouth, Virginia. 
Effect of Sunday or holidays on scheduled meetings, etc. Where any meeting or proceeding is directed by an ordinance to be held or to take place on a particular day of the month, or is adjourned from day to day, if that day happens to be a Saturday, Sunday, legal holiday or any day on which the city offices are closed, the same shall be held, or the proceeding take place, on the next day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, legal holiday or any day on which the city offices are closed. 
Gender. A term importing the masculine gender only may extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
Month. The term "month" shall be construed to mean a calendar month. 
Number. A term importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; and a term importing the plural number only may extend and be applied to one person or thing, as well as to several persons or things. 
Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
Occupant. The term "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall mean any person who holds a written or oral lease of, or actually occupies the whole or a part of, such building or land, either alone or with others. 
Officers, boards, etc. Whenever reference is made to a particular officer, board, commission, department or other agency, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the term "of the City of Portsmouth, Virginia." A reference to a specific officer shall also be construed as if followed by the term "or his duly authorized deputy, assistant, representative or agent," subject, however, to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1502. 
Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall mean the holder of the title in fee simple or any person in whose name tax bills on the property are submitted. The term "owner" shall also mean any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others: 
(1)  Shall have legal title to the property with or without accompanying actual possession thereof; or 
(2)  Shall have charge, care or control of the property as owner, executor, executrix, administrator, trustee, guardian of the estate of the owner, mortgagee or vendee in possession, assignee of rents, lessee or any other person having control of the property or his duly authorized agent. 
Person. The term "person" may extend and be applied to any individual, corporation, partnership, association, company, business, trust, joint venture or other legal entity. 
Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any public street, park, cemetery, schoolyard, public library, municipal building, museum, wharf or waterfront area owned by the city, or open space adjacent thereto. 
Roadway. The term "roadway" shall mean that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" shall mean that portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
State; commonwealth. The terms "the state," "this state," "the commonwealth" or "this commonwealth" shall mean the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
Street. The term "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the approaches thereto and other public thoroughfares in the city, and shall mean the entire width thereof between abutting property lines; it shall be construed to include a sidewalk or a footpath. 
Tense. Terms used in the past or present tense may include the future as well as the past and present. 
Written; in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
Year. Unless otherwise specified, the term "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1973, § 1-2; Code 1988, § 1-2; Ord. No. 1997-14, § 1, 3-11-1997) 
State Law reference— Similar definitions and rules of construction applicable to state law, Code of Virginia, § 1-200 et seq.  
Sec. 1-3. - Interpretation of Code. 
Where any provision of this Code imposes restrictions upon the subject matter differing from a general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction shall be deemed to be controlling. 
(Code 1973, § 1-3; Code 1988, § 1-3)  
Sec. 1-4. - Headlines of sections. 
The headlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the headlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1973, § 1-5; Code 1988, § 1-4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions as to sections of state code, Code of Virginia, § 1-217.  
Sec. 1-5. - Provisions of Code construed as continuation of existing ordinances. 
The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of "The Code of the City of Portsmouth, Virginia (1988) and ordinances adopted by the city council subsequent thereto and included herein, shall be construed as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1973, § 1-4; Code 1988, § 1-5)  
Sec. 1-6. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  Any ordinance granting any franchise or right; 
(3)  Any ordinance appropriating funds or relating to an annual budget and annual tax levy; 
(4)  Any ordinance authorizing, providing for or otherwise relating to any public improvement or any special assessment; 
(5)  Any ordinance adopted for purposes which have been consummated; 
(6)  Any ordinance pertaining to fees, rates, charges and deposits; 
(7)  Any ordinance rezoning property or amending the zoning map; 
(8)  Any ordinance regarding cable franchises, including Ordinance No. 1989-77; 
(9)  Any ordinance that is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 1-6)  
Sec. 1-7. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, or any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered, on or before the effective date of this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 1-7)  
Sec. 1-8. - Separability of parts of Code. 
If any part, section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code is for any reason declared to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 1-8; Code 1988, § 1-8)  
Sec. 1-9. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code may be prepared and printed when needed and when funds therefor are available. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed or replaced shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate headlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such headlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _______ to _______" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1988, § 1-9) 
State Law reference— Authority to supplement Code, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433.  
Sec. 1-10. - Copies of Code and supplements to be available for public inspection. 
At least one copy of this Code and every supplement thereto shall be kept in the office of the city clerk and shall there be available for public inspection during normal business hours. 
(Code 1988, § 1-10) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433.  
Sec. 1-11. - Classification of and penalties for violations; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or any other ordinance of the city it is provided that a violation of any provision thereof shall constitute a class 1, 2, 3 or 4 misdemeanor, such violation shall be punishable as follows: 
(1)  Class 1 misdemeanor: By a fine of not more than $2,500.00, or by confinement in jail for not more than 12 months, or by both such fine and confinement. 
(2)  Class 2 misdemeanor: By a fine of not more than $1,000.00, or by confinement in jail for not more than six months, or by both such fine and confinement. 
(3)  Class 3 misdemeanor: By a fine of not more than $500.00. 
(4)  Class 4 misdemeanor: By a fine of not more than $250.00. 
(b)  Whenever in any provision of this Code or in any other ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor, or the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided for the violation of such provision and such violation is not described as being of a particular class of misdemeanor, such violation shall be punishable upon conviction by confinement in jail for not more than 12 months and a fine of not more than $2,500.00, either or both. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section or any other section of this Code, no penalty shall be imposed for a violation of this Code or other ordinance of the city which is greater than the penalty prescribed by the general law of the commonwealth for a like offense. 
(d)  Each day any violation of this Code or any other ordinance, rule or regulation of the city shall continue shall constitute a separate offense, except where otherwise provided. 
(Code 1973, §§ 1-9, 21-1—21-5; Code 1988, § 1-11; Ord. No. 1990-61, § 1, 6-26-1990; Ord. No. 1991-14, § 1, 2-12-1991; Ord. No. 1991-60, § 1, 6-25-1991) 
Charter reference— Duty of commonwealth's attorney to prosecute ordinance violations, § 6.02. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to provide penalties for violation of ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1429; authority of court trying case, upon conviction, to require bond conditioned that the person convicted will not violate the ordinance for the breach of which he was convicted for a period of not more than one year, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1430; injunctive relief for continuing violations or ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1432; classification of misdemeanors and punishment therefor, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-9, 18.2-11.  
Sec. 1-12. - Punishment for common law offenses. 
A common law offense, for which punishment is prescribed by statute, shall be punishable only in the mode as prescribed. 
(Code 1973, § 21-7; Code 1988, § 1-12)  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Division of building inspections, § 7-32; elections, ch. 10; finance, ch. 12; department of finance, § 12-41 et seq.; municipal finance commission, § 12-141 et seq.; fire, rescue and emergency services department, § 13-31 et seq.; housing board of adjustments and appeals, § 17-41 et seq.; public library advisory board, § 19-21 et seq.; law library board, § 19-76 et seq.; parks and recreation department, § 25-26 et seq.; parks and recreation commission, § 25-46 et seq.; police department, § 27-1 et seq.; auxiliary police force, § 27-26 et seq.; retirement systems, ch. 30; board of trustees of supplemental retirement system, § 30-51 et seq.; board of trustees of fire and police retirement system, § 30-176 et seq.; board of equalization, § 35-76; wetlands board, § 39-46 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Portsmouth Risk Management and Insurance Fund. 
(a)  The Portsmouth Risk Management and Insurance Fund is hereby created for the purpose of providing a reserve source of funding for certain expenses pertaining to probable or possible losses. The fund is to provide for the protection of the assets of the city against the financial consequences of losses that are unexpected. The fund may be used to pay the expenses associated with claims management and payment of claims arising out of good faith actions of officers and employees of the city and members of commissions established by the city council within the scope of their duties on behalf of the city. The fund may also be used to pay insurance premiums and insurance pooling costs which may be obtained to provide protection from losses arising from claims covered by the fund. 
(b)  The city council shall make annual appropriations to the Portsmouth Risk Management and Insurance Fund if a contribution is determined to be necessary. The total contribution determined shall take into account limits, deductibles and aggregate levels of existing insurance policies and insurance pools, as well as reserve levels established to determine financial liability for incurred losses. Disbursements may be made from the fund to pay claims for such losses in excess of amounts budgeted, if any, in the city's operating budget, for insurance policies, insurance pool costs, claims or losses and costs associated with claims management. Any earnings from the investment of available funds in the fund shall be credited to such fund. Should it be determined that the fund balance exceeds the liabilities so reserved, the city may suspend its minimum contributions for so long as the fund balance remains above such reserve level deemed necessary. 
(c)  The city manager is hereby authorized to promulgate rules and regulations governing the Portsmouth Risk Management and Insurance Fund and to authorize payments from such fund in accordance with the provisions of this section. The city attorney shall approve the payment of any claim and shall consult with the city council before payment is made of any claim in excess of $100,000.00. The chief financial officer shall be the custodian of all the funds created by this section and shall keep such financial records of the fund as may be necessary. In addition, the city manager shall make a quarterly report to the city council of all claims paid in excess of $50,000.00 each. 
(Code 1973, § 2-19; Code 1988, § 2-2; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001) 
Cross reference— Finance generally, ch. 12.  
Sec. 2-2. - School board risk management and insurance fund. 
(a)  The school board risk management and insurance fund is hereby created for the purpose of providing a reserve source of funding for certain expenses of the public schools. The fund is to provide protection of the assets of the public schools against the financial consequences of losses that are unexpected. The fund may be used to pay the expenses associated with claims management and payment of claims arising out of the good faith actions of officers and employees of the Portsmouth public schools. The fund may also be used to pay insurance premiums and insurance pooling costs which may be obtained to provide protection from losses arising from claims covered by the fund. 
(b)  Annually, as part of the budget process, the city council shall appropriate for the purpose of education the total amount of all funds estimated to be available for the ensuing fiscal year in the school board risk management and insurance fund. Appropriations, to the extent they shall not have been expended or lawfully encumbered, shall lapse at the end of the period for which they were made. 
(c)  The city manager is hereby authorized to enter into an agreement with the superintendent of schools establishing rules and regulations governing the school board risk management and insurance fund and to authorize payments therefrom. The city attorney shall approve the payment of any claim and shall consult with the school board before payment is made of any claim in excess of $100,000.00. 
(Code 1973, § 2-20; Code 1988, § 2-3) 
Cross reference— Finance generally, ch. 12.  
Sec. 2-3. - Lease of city property to persons or organization which discriminate. 
The city shall not lease or grant any privilege or right of any kind to use any public property, including land, buildings or other facilities, to any person or organization which discriminates in its offering of goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, accommodations, memberships or activities on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, disability or sex. In the event such discriminatory policy or practice is discovered after execution of an agreement, the agreement shall be void. 
(Code 1973, § 1-12; Code 1988, § 2-3; Ord. No. 1988-13, § 1, 2-9-1988; Ord. No. 1993-79, § 1, 10-12-1993)  
Secs. 2-4—2-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— City council, § 3.01 et seq. 
Cross reference— Elections, ch. 10. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-26. - Designation. 
The city council as a body shall be known as "The Council of the City of Portsmouth, Virginia." 
(Code 1973, § 2-29; Code 1988, § 2-26)  
Sec. 2-27. - Committees. 
There shall be no standing committees of the city council, but the council may meet in a committee of the whole whenever it is deemed desirable so to do. The mayor may from time to time appoint such special committees as may be thought necessary to which may be referred such matters as may be proper, which shall consider the same and report their findings back to the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 2-30; Code 1988, § 2-27)  
Sec. 2-28. - Boards and commissions. 
(a)  Appointments. Unless otherwise specifically stated or otherwise required by state or federal law, any person appointed to a board or commission by the council and mayor shall be either a resident of the city, a property or business owner within the city or shall be employed in the city. 
(b)  Procedural rules. Boards and commissions appointed by the council and mayor shall be governed by the following procedural rules: 
(1)  No business shall be transacted until a quorum of the members is present. 
(2)  No member shall abstain from voting on any matter unless prohibited by applicable provisions of the State and Local Government Virginia Conflict of Interests Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3100 et seq. or under the circumstances the vote would constitute an act of impropriety. 
(3)  No matter shall be deemed approved by the members unless such matter has received the affirmative vote of a majority of the members voting and physically present at the time of voting. 
(4)  The rules of parliamentary practice set out in Robert's Rules of Order shall govern in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with this section. 
(Code 1973, § 2-65; Code 1988, § 2-28; Ord. No. 1990-129, § 1, 12-11-1990; Ord. No. 2019-54 , § 1, 7-23-2019)  
Sec. 2-29. - Procedure for adoption of ordinances and resolutions. 
(a)  Except for those ordinances and resolutions set forth in subsection (b) of this section, ordinances and resolutions may be adopted by the council on the date of their introduction. On the final vote on any ordinance or resolution, the name of each member voting and how he voted shall be recorded. Such ordinances and resolutions shall be passed by the affirmative vote of the majority of the councilmembers present. 
(b)  No ordinance or resolution relating to any zoning matter shall be finally adopted by the council at a meeting whereat such matter was first considered. Such ordinance or resolution previously approved on first reading unanimously by city council shall be listed under the consent agenda for a second reading; provided, however, that such ordinance or resolution shall be removed from the consent agenda and considered separately upon the request of any member of the council or upon receipt of a request from members of the general public to address city council on such ordinance or resolution in accordance with the requirements of section 2-68. 
(Code 1973, §§ 2-17, 11-4; Code 1988, § 2-29; Ord. No. 1991-74, § 1, 7-9-1991) 
Charter reference— Limitation on ordinances appropriating money, § 3.15; enactment of ordinances, § 3.16. 
State Law reference— Adoption of ordinances and resolutions, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1425—15.2-1429.  
Sec. 2-30. - Numbering and publication or posting of ordinances. 
(a)  All ordinances of the city shall be consecutively numbered in annual series, the number of a particular ordinance to consist of the year in which passed and the consecutive number of the ordinance. 
(b)  All ordinances passed by the city council shall be published or posted in accordance with the requirements of general law. 
(Code 1973, §§ 1-10, 1-11; Code 1988, § 2-30)  
Sec. 2-31. - Manner of amending or repealing ordinances. 
No city ordinance shall be amended, suspended or repealed, except by an ordinance, nor shall any city ordinance be revived or amended by reference to its title or chapter, but the ordinance revived, or the section amended, shall be reenacted and published at length. 
(Code 1973, § 1-6; Code 1988, § 2-31)  
Sec. 2-32. - Effect of repeal of ordinance. 
(a)  When an ordinance which has repealed another ordinance shall itself be repealed, the previous ordinance shall not be revived without express words to that effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1973, § 1-7; Code 1988, § 2-32) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions as to state statutes, Code of Virginia, §§ 1-239, 1-240.  
Sec. 2-33. - Interference with appointees of city manager. 
Neither the council nor any of its members shall direct or request the appointment of any person to or his removal from any office or employment by the city manager or by any of his subordinates or in any way take part in the appointment or removal of officers and employees of the city except as specifically provided in the Charter. Except for the purpose of inquiry, the council and its members shall deal with the administrative services solely through the city manager, and neither the council nor any member thereof shall give orders either publicly or privately to any subordinate of the city manager. Any councilman violating the provision of this section or voting for a motion, resolution or ordinance in violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall cease to be a councilman. 
(Code 1973, § 2-31; Code 1988, § 2-33) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 3.12.  
Sec. 2-34. - Appointees to appointed bodies to serve at the pleasure of council. 
(a)  The term "appointed body" shall mean any board, commission, committee or other body which is created by this Code, and for which the members are appointed by city council. 
(b)  For any appointed body for which this Code or the Code of Virginia sets forth the criteria and/or the procedures for city council to remove a member, said criteria and/or procedures shall govern. 
(c)  For any appointed body for which the criteria and/or the procedures for city council to remove a member are not set forth in this Code or the Code of Virginia, members shall serve at the pleasure of the city council, and any member may be removed by the city council at its pleasure. 
(Ord. No. 2005-94, § 1, 11-8-2005)  
Secs. 2-35—2-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Freedom of information act, open meetings, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3700 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-56. - Place. 
All regular and special meetings of the city council shall be held in the Council Chambers, 6th Floor, City Hall Building, 801 Crawford Street, unless the call of a special meeting or other notice with respect to a regular meeting specifying some other place of meeting shall have been delivered to each member of the council at least 24 hours prior to the time of such meeting, but nothing herein shall be construed as prohibiting the continuation of any meeting to any other place. 
(Code 1973, § 2-41; Code 1988, § 2-56)  
Sec. 2-57. - Day and time of regular meetings. 
(a)  There shall be regular meetings of the city council, unless otherwise provided by special resolution, beginning at 7:00 p.m. on the second and fourth Tuesdays in each month except in the month of December when the regular meeting shall be on the second Tuesday. 
(b)  There shall be a public work session of the city council beginning at 5:00 p.m. on the Monday preceding the second Tuesday in each month. Public hearings which the council is required to hold under Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2200 et seq. may be held at a meeting specified in this subsection, but nothing herein shall be construed as prohibiting the continuation of any such public hearing to any other time or place. 
(Code 1973, § 2-42; Code 1988, § 2-57; Ord. No. 1988-17, § 1, 2-9-1988)  
Sec. 2-58. - Call and notice of special meetings. 
(a)  Call of meetings. The mayor, any three members of the city council, or the city manager may call a special meeting of the council. 
(b)  Notice. The city clerk shall cause notice in writing of all special meetings of the city council to be delivered at least 24 hours prior to the time appointed for such meetings to each member of the city council personally or at such member's usual place of business or residence. In an emergency, by written consent of a majority of all of the members of the city council, a meeting may be held with less notice, provided that the city clerk, in writing, certifies that an attempt was made to notify each member of the city council at his usual place of business and residence. 
(Code 1973, §§ 2-43, 2-44; Code 1988, § 2-58) 
Charter reference— Call and notice of special meetings, § 3.14.  
Sec. 2-59. - Limitation on transaction of business at special meeting. 
No business shall be transacted at a special meeting of the city council which is not distinctly and specifically set forth in the notice of such meeting, except by consent of all members elected to the council. 
(Code 1973, § 2-45; Code 1988, § 2-59) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 3.14.  
Sec. 2-60. - Quorum. 
A majority of the members of the city council shall constitute a quorum at any meeting for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1973, § 2-46; Code 1988, § 2-60) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1415.  
Sec. 2-61. - Adjournment in absence of quorum; retirement of member before adjournment. 
If a quorum is not present at the time appointed for any meeting of the city council, the city clerk shall, at the time appointed for the meeting, enter upon the record the name of the members present. A majority of those members present may immediately adjourn, but no member in attendance shall retire before adjournment without the consent of the majority of those present. 
(Code 1973, § 2-47; Code 1988, § 2-61)  
Sec. 2-62. - Absence of member after being marked present. 
After a member of city council has been entered on the minutes as present at any council meeting, he shall not excuse himself from the council chamber for a longer period than ten minutes without being denoted by the city clerk as absent. 
(Code 1973, § 2-48; Code 1988, § 2-62)  
Sec. 2-63. - Order of business. 
Council shall provide in its Rules of Order and Procedure an order of business for council meetings. The order of business shall be for the purpose of ensuring the orderly conduct of meetings, so as best to deal with all matters affecting the public interest. The Rules of Order and Procedure shall be a public document maintained by the city clerk, and shall be available for inspection and copying by any member of the public. 
(Code 1973, § 2-49; Code 1988, § 2-63; Ord. No. 1992-83, § 1, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 1993-69, § 1, 9-14-1993; Ord. No. 1996-64, 12-17-1996)  
Sec. 2-64. - Mayor to preserve order and decide questions of order; appeals. 
The mayor shall preserve order and decide all questions of order, but any member of the city council may appeal to the council from the decision of the mayor on any question of order. 
(Code 1973, § 2-50; Code 1988, § 2-64)  
Sec. 2-65. - Sergeant at arms. 
The chief of police or a line officer of the police department designated by him shall act as sergeant at arms at all city council meetings. The sergeant at arms shall execute the council's commands, together with such process issued by its authority, as shall be directed to him by the mayor. The sergeant at arms shall, under the direction of the mayor, have charge of the council chamber and shall prevent any interruption of the business of the council by disorder within or without. 
(Code 1973, § 2-51; Code 1988, § 2-65)  
Sec. 2-66. - Members to address chair before speaking; scope of speech. 
When a member of the city council wishes to speak at a council meeting, he shall address the chair. After being recognized by the mayor, he may speak, but he shall confine his remarks to the question before the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 2-52; Code 1988, § 2-66)  
Sec. 2-67. - Mayor to recognize speaker. 
When two or more members of the city council ask to speak at the same time at a council meeting, the mayor shall name the person to speak. 
(Code 1973, § 2-53; Code 1988, § 2-67)  
Sec. 2-68. - Citizens addressing council. 
Council shall provide in its Rules of Order and Procedure a means by which citizens may address council. The means provided shall be for the purpose of ensuring the public of its right to address council, consistent with the need of council to conduct the public business in an open, orderly, and reasonable manner. The Rules of Order and Procedure shall be a public document maintained by the city clerk, and shall be available for inspection and copying by any member of the public. 
(Code 1973, § 2-56; Code 1988, § 2-68; Ord. No. 1992-83, § 2, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 1993-69, § 2, 9-14-1993; Ord. No. 1996-64, 12-17-1996)  
Sec. 2-69. - When motion, proposition to be written and read; question to be stated. 
Every motion or proposition made at any meeting of the city council shall be reduced to writing if desired by the mayor or by any member of the council, and shall be delivered to the clerk's table to be there read. The question shall be stated by the chair before the same shall be debated. 
(Code 1973, § 2-57; Code 1988, § 2-69)  
Sec. 2-70. - Introduction, recording of ordinances. 
An ordinance, when introduced, shall be entered on the minutes by its title and its final disposal recorded in the minutes; but all ordinances and all amendments to ordinances shall be carefully and accurately recorded in an ordinance book by the city clerk. 
(Code 1973, § 2-58; Code 1988, § 2-70)  
Sec. 2-71. - Introduction of ordinance, resolution after rejection of similar one. 
After the city council shall have finally rejected an ordinance or resolution, another of substantially the same import shall not be placed on the agenda by the city clerk or entertained by the city council unless five of the members of the city council petition for the same before the expiration of three months, after which time such rejection shall have no effect thereon. 
(Code 1973, § 2-59; Code 1988, § 2-71)  
Sec. 2-72. - Withdrawal of motion, proposition. 
Any motion or proposition may be withdrawn by the mover at any time before a decision, amendment or other action of the council upon it, with leave of his second. 
(Code 1973, § 2-60; Code 1988, § 2-72)  
Sec. 2-73. - Reconsideration of question. 
When a question has been decided, it may be reconsidered on the motion of any councilmember who voted with the prevailing side. When a motion is made to reconsider any action, it shall be finally disposed of on the same day unless then formally postponed to a definite time, and if not so disposed of or postponed on the same day, the action which was the subject of the motion shall be final. 
(Code 1973, § 2-61; Code 1988, § 2-73)  
Sec. 2-74. - Voting procedure; grounds for abstention. 
(a)  On all roll call votes, each member of the city council shall announce his vote as his name is called in alphabetical order, except that the mayor or other presiding officer shall vote last. The announcement shall be by electronic voting; provided, however, if necessary the city clerk shall orally obtain the vote of each member of the council. At the request of any member present the "ayes" and "nays" on any question shall be recorded. 
(b)  No member of council shall abstain from voting on any matter unless such vote is prohibited by applicable provisions of the State and Local Government Virginia Conflict of Interests Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3100 et seq. or would constitute an act of impropriety under the circumstances. In all cases of abstention, the member shall advise the chair of his intention to abstain and the specific and detailed reasons therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 2-62; Code 1988, § 2-74) 
State Law reference— Prohibited conduct, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3112.  
Sec. 2-75. - Rules of order and procedure; applicability of Robert's Rules of Order. 
The city council may adopt such rules of order and procedure as it shall deem necessary for the proper and efficient conduct of its business. Such rules of order and procedure shall govern the city council in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with the provisions of the Charter or this Code, and shall be adopted by a majority vote of all the members of council. Robert's Rules of Order shall govern the city council in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with the rules of the council. 
(Code 1973, § 2-63; Code 1988, § 2-75)  
Sec. 2-76. - Suspension of rules. 
No rule of the city council included within this division or adopted pursuant to section 2-75 shall be suspended without the approval of a majority of the members of council present. 
(Code 1973, § 2-64; Code 1988, § 2-76)  
Secs. 2-77—2-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES GENERALLY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Animal control officer, § 4-2; city treasurer, § 12-116 et seq.; obstructing or hindering city employees in discharge of their duty, § 24-246; giving false information to city employees conducting investigations, § 24-247; retirement systems, ch. 30; city assessor, § 35-61 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-101. - Appointment. 
The city council shall appoint the city manager, city attorney, city assessor, and city clerk. All other officers and employees shall be appointed by the city manager, except when otherwise specifically provided. 
(Code 1973, § 2-1; Code 1988, § 2-101; Ord. No. 2009-48 , § 1, 5-26-2009) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, §§ 4.01, 5.01, 5.02, 7.01. 
Cross reference— Appointment of employees of law library, § 19-53.  
Sec. 2-102. - Term of officers appointed by council. 
Every officer required to be appointed by the council shall hold his office during the pleasure of the council or until his successor shall be appointed and qualified, unless his term is fixed by law. 
(Code 1973, § 2-2; Code 1988, § 2-102)  
Sec. 2-103. - Appointment of substitutes for officers appointed by council. 
Except where otherwise provided, if any officer of the city appointed by the council is at any time unable, by reason of sickness or other unavoidable cause, to discharge the duties of his office, he may, in writing, appoint a substitute to act for him during such inability, and he and his sureties, if any, shall be liable for the conduct of such substitute in the office. No such appointment shall be valid until ratified by the council, and when so ratified, such ratification shall be reported with the proceedings of the council, and the certificate of appointment filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1973, § 2-3; Code 1988, § 2-103)  
Sec. 2-104. - Oath—Required. 
Every officer or employee of the city required by law to take an oath shall take the oath before entering upon the performance of his duties. 
(Code 1973, § 2-5; Code 1988, § 2-104) 
State Law reference— Oath required of city officers, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1522.  
Sec. 2-105. - Same—Form. 
Every person required to take an oath as an officer or employee of the city shall take and subscribe the following oath: "I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution of the United States, and the Constitution of the State of Virginia, and that I will faithfully and impartially discharge and perform all the duties incumbent on me as _______ according to the best of my ability, (so help me God)." 
(Code 1973, § 2-6; Code 1988, § 2-105) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 49-1.  
Sec. 2-106. - Effect of failure to take oath or give bond. 
Except where otherwise provided, if any person required by law to take oath or to give bond prior to taking office fails to do so within 30 days of receiving notice of his election or appointment, he shall be considered as having declined such office and the same shall be deemed vacant. 
(Code 1973, § 2-7; Code 1988, § 2-106)  
Sec. 2-107. - Residence requirements. 
(a)  All officers who are appointed by the city council shall be bona fide residents of the city or become such within six months after the effective date of their appointment unless such time period is extended by the city council. Upon failure to comply with this subsection, their employment shall immediately cease. 
(b)  For all city employees other than those covered by subsection (a) of this section, there shall be no residence requirement, except that the city manager may, in his discretion, require that any department head subject to his appointive power remain a resident of the city or become such within six months after the effective date of his appointment. 
(Code 1973, § 2-8; Code 1988, § 2-107; Ord. No. 2009-48 , § 1, 5-26-2009) 
State Law reference— Residency, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1505.  
Sec. 2-108. - Compensation. 
(a)  All city officers and employees shall be compensated for their services in accordance with the current classification and pay plan as adopted by the council. 
(b)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance adopting any plan referred to in subsection (a) of this section and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 2-9; Code 1988, § 2-108)  
Sec. 2-109. - Eight-hour day required. 
Except as otherwise provided, eight hours shall constitute a legal day's work for all employees of the city government. 
(Code 1973, § 2-10; Code 1988, § 2-109)  
Sec. 2-110. - Offices to be open every day; exceptions. 
All city offices for the transaction of public business shall be kept open every day, except Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. 
(Code 1973, § 2-14; Code 1988, § 2-110)  
Sec. 2-111. - Legal holidays. 
(a)  The following days shall be observed as holidays by the city on the same days of the year as observed by the Commonwealth: 
(1)  New Year's Day; 
(2)  Lee-Jackson Day; 
(3)  Martin Luther King, Jr. Day; 
(4)  George Washington Day; 
(5)  Memorial Day; 
(6)  Independence Day; 
(7)  Labor Day; 
(8)  Columbus Day; 
(9)  Veteran's Day; 
(10)  Thanksgiving Day; 
(11)  The day following Thanksgiving Day; 
(12)  Christmas Day; and 
(13)  Any other day or part thereof designated as a holiday by the Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, the President of the United States, the city manager, or the city council. 
(b)  In addition to the above holidays, each full-time city employee may take a holiday on his or her birthday or within 30 days thereafter. 
(c)  Whenever a holiday shall fall on a Saturday, it shall be observed on the preceding Friday. Whenever a holiday shall fall on a Sunday, it shall be observed on the following Monday. 
(Code 1973, § 2-13; Code 1988, § 2-111; Ord. No. 1991-45, § 1, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1995-31, § 1, 3-28-1995; Ord. No. 2007-108, § 1, 12-11-2007, eff. 1-1-2008; Ord. No. 2010-12, § 1, 2-23-2010)  
Sec. 2-112. - Annual leave. 
(a)  Officers and full-time regular employees of the city shall accrue annual leave in accordance with the schedule listed below. 
General Employees 
Service Months 	Hourly Amount 	Pay Period Amount 	Annual Amount 
0—60 	0.0542 	4.336 	112.736 
61—108 	0.0577 	4.616 	120.016 
109—168 	0.0658 	5.264 	136.864 
169—228 	0.0733 	5.864 	152.464 
229—999 	0.0808 	6.464 	168.064 
 
Fire Suppression Employees (27-day cycle) 
Service Months 	Hourly Amount 	Pay Period Amount 	Annual Amount 
0—60 	0.0614 	6.5084 	169.2184 
61—108 	0.0653 	6.9218 	179.9668 
109—168 	0.0745 	7.8970 	205.3220 
169—228 	0.0832 	8.8192 	229.2992 
229—999 	0.0914 	9.6884 	251.8984 
 
Annual leave earned will be credited per pay period. When an officer or employee does not work (or take accrued leave for) a full schedule during a pay period, the annual leave accrued for that period shall be calculated by multiplying the applicable hourly amount above by the number of hours the employee worked or took accrued leave during the period. Officers and employees will have an accounting of their annual leave printed on their pay check stubs. 
(b)  Annual leave may be taken at any time with the written approval of the department head concerned. During the period of December 16 through December 31, department heads shall not take annual leave except with the prior written approval of the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  Annual leave taken shall only be charged against the normal working days of the officer or employee concerned. 
(d)  All annual leave taken must be reported to the finance department at the end of each period, and such shall be deducted from the leave account of the person taking such leave. 
(e)  The amount of annual leave which any officer or employee is granted may be accumulated and carried over from year to year; provided, however, that all accumulated unused annual leave in excess of 44 days of annual leave entitlement remaining in the leave account of the officer or employee as of December 31 of each year shall be automatically canceled on that date. 
(f)  If any officer or employee leaves the service of the city after giving reasonable notice of his intention to do so, he shall be entitled to terminal leave pay; provided, however, if he is dismissed for personal delinquency or if he resigns in the face of dismissal or other disciplinary action, he may forfeit his right to terminal leave pay. Terminal leave pay shall not exceed 44 days of annual leave entitlement or the actual number of leave days in the leave account of the officer or employee, whichever is less. 
(g)  The council shall have the right to vary the application of subsection (f) of this section in establishing conditions of employment for officers and employees appointed by the council. This provision shall be applicable to all contracts of employment heretofore or hereafter made. 
(h)  Constitutional officer and city council positions are not eligible for annual leave under this section. 
(i)  The city manager is authorized to promulgate policies and procedures governing the granting and administration of annual leave and the compensation of employees while on leave, and otherwise implementing the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 2-112; Ord. No. 1995-45, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 2017-06 , § 1, 1-24-2017)  
Sec. 2-113. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Officers and full-time regular employees of the city other than fire suppression employees shall accrue 3.696 hours of sick leave per pay period, and fire suppression employees shall accrue 5.536 hours of sick leave per pay period. Sick leave earned will be credited per pay period. When an officer or employee does not work (or take accrued leave for) a full schedule during a pay period, the sick leave accrued for that period shall be calculated by multiplying the number of hours the employee worked or took accrued leave during the period by (i) .0462 in the case of officers and full-time regular employees other than fire suppression employees or (ii) .0692 in the case of fire suppression employees. 
(b)  No officer or employee shall be entitled to or receive compensation for sick leave unless he is employed by the city at the time he becomes sick. No officer or employee shall be entitled to any compensation for unused sick leave, either while still employed or upon termination of employment with the city. 
(c)  Constitutional officer and city council positions are not eligible for sick leave under this section. 
(d)  The city manager is authorized to promulgate policies and procedures governing the granting and administration of sick leave and the compensation of employees while on leave, and otherwise implementing the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 2-11; Code 1988, § 2-113; Ord. No. 2017-06 , § 2, 1-24-2017)  
Sec. 2-114. - Political activities restricted. 
(a)  Application of section. The provisions of this section shall apply to all pay and classification plan employees of the city, the city manager and all department heads and employees appointed by him, officers appointed by the city council, and all staff assistants in those departments (including the city clerk, city attorney, and real estate assessor). The provisions of this section shall not apply to members of boards and commissions who are not pay and classification plan employees of the city nor to members of the city council. 
(b)  Publicly addressing officers and employees during working hours prohibited; private expression of opinions protected. It shall be unlawful for any person to address groups of officers or employees of the city supporting or opposing the candidacy of any person for public office while such officers or employees are at work during a regularly assigned period of duty or otherwise engaged in carrying out the official business and functions of the city; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit or prevent any officer or employee of the city from exercising his rights as a citizen to privately express his opinions on any political subject. 
(c)  Right to vote and participate in political activities protected. The restrictions of this section are designed to protect every employee's right to vote and to participate in political activities and to keep this right free from interference, solicitation or dictation by any fellow employee, supervisor, official or candidate. 
(d)  Use of status or prestige. No person to whom this section applies shall use the status or prestige of his position with the city on behalf of or in opposition to any candidate for elective office, including oneself. 
(e)  Use of city funds, supplies, equipment or uniforms. No person to whom this section applies shall use any city funds, supplies or equipment for political purposes, nor shall any such person wear his city uniform while participating in any manner in political activities. 
(f)  Holding elected office while employed by city prohibited. No person to whom this section applies may continue to serve as a city employee if the person is elected or appointed to, and thereafter assumes office, in any of the following elected positions: Mayor, Member of Portsmouth City Council, Sheriff, Commonwealth's Attorney, Treasurer, Commissioner of Revenue, Clerk of Circuit Court, Member of the Senate of Virginia, or Member of the Virginia House of Delegates. Upon assuming any such office, the person's employment shall be deemed terminated by action of law, unless the person has previously resigned. 
(g)  Enforcement of these provisions. The provisions of this section shall be enforced in concert with applicable city and departmental policies and procedures. 
(h)  Dismissal on violation. Violation of this section shall constitute a cause for immediate dismissal from city employment. 
(Code 1973, § 2-15; Code 1988, § 2-114; Ord. No. 1991-112, § 1, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 2008-26, § 1, 4-8-2008)  
Sec. 2-115. - Demand and receipt of fee, etc., greater than that provided for official duty. 
If any officer for performing an official duty, for which a fee or compensation is allowed or provided by law, knowingly demands and receives a greater fee and compensation than is so allowed or provided, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 2-16; Code 1988, § 2-115) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 2-116. - Payroll deductions for the Southern States Police Benevolent Association, Inc. 
Upon written request of any employee, the chief financial officer shall cause to be made a payroll deduction payable to the Southern States Police Benevolent Association, Inc. in the amount authorized by the employee. Any such deduction may be terminated or modified by written authorization of the employee. 
(Ord. No. 2010-76, § 1, 9-28-2010)  
Sec. 2-117. - Criminal history and other background checks of applicants, employees, and volunteers. 
(a)  It is the intent of the city council in enacting this section to comply with the provisions of §§ 15.2-1503.1, 15.2-1505.1 and 19.2-389 of the Code of Virginia, as amended, to enable the city manager and the director of human resource management, in the interest of public welfare and safety, to require fingerprinting and to access the state and national criminal history record information regarding applicants for certain positions and volunteers, as set forth below. The director of human resource management shall determine the type and scope of the criminal history record checks and any other background checks required for the affected positions. 
(b)  The human resource management department shall require a criminal history record information investigation on all applicants for police and fire department positions. Applicants shall include those for initial hire, and those current employees who laterally transfer, promote, or demote to such a position, and volunteers. 
(c)  In addition to [subsection] (b) above, the human resources department shall require a criminal history record information investigation for finalists identified in the personnel selection and placement process for all applicants, including volunteers, for individual positions or activities identified by the city manager as affecting public welfare or safety. Applicants shall include finalists for initial hire, and those current employees who laterally transfer, promote, or demote to such a position, and volunteers. 
(d)  Current employees and volunteers. The director of human resource management may require a periodic criminal history record information investigation and other background checks, and determine their type and scope, for current employees and volunteers when authorized by federal or state law. 
(e)  Any applicant, employee, or volunteer described in this section shall, if required, submit to fingerprinting and provide personal descriptive information and any other necessary paperwork to be forwarded along with the fingerprints through the Virginia State Police Central Criminal Records Exchange to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for the purpose of obtaining state and national criminal history record information regarding such applicant, employee, or volunteer. 
(f)  The criminal history information provided in accordance with this section shall be used solely to assess eligibility for public employment or service, and shall not be disseminated to any person not involved in the assessment process. 
(g)  Past criminal conduct shall not automatically disqualify applicants from employment or volunteer service and the criminal history information obtained pursuant to this section is to be considered only when it is specifically relevant to the particular employment or volunteer position sought. 
( Ord. No. 2016-06, § 1, 1-26-2016)  
Secs. 2-118—2-135. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CIVIL SERVICE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference— Civil service, § 11.01 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-136. - Application of system. 
All employees of the police and fire departments of the city, except the chiefs of such departments, and all employees of other departments electing to come under civil service under the Charter, shall be subject to the civil service provisions of the Charter, and all appointments to such departments shall be made under such provisions of the Charter. 
(Code 1973, § 2-76; Code 1988, § 2-136) 
Cross reference— Members of the auxiliary police force not subject to civil service system, § 27-27.  
Sec. 2-137. - Establishment and composition of commission. 
There shall be in the city a civil service commission which shall be composed of three members. 
(Code 1973, § 2-77; Code 1988, § 2-137) 
Charter reference— Civil service commission, § 11.01 et seq.  
Sec. 2-138. - Appointment, compensation, qualifications and terms of commission members. 
The members of the civil service commission shall be appointed by the judges of the circuit court of the city. The members of the civil service commission shall serve without compensation, and shall be citizens of the United States, residents of this city and be otherwise qualified as required by the Charter. The terms of office of the members of the civil service commission shall be for four years, except that the first three members of the commission shall be appointed for different terms, that is, one shall be appointed for a term of two years from December 1, 1936, one for a term of three years from December 1, 1936, and one for a term of four years from December 1, 1936. 
(Code 1973, § 2-78; Code 1988, § 2-138)  
Sec. 2-139. - Removal of commission members. 
Any member of the civil service commission may be removed from office for incompetency, incompatibility or dereliction of duty or malfeasance in office, or other good cause, as provided in the Charter; provided, however, that no member of the commission shall be removed until charges have been preferred in writing, due notice given and a full hearing had. 
(Code 1973, § 2-79; Code 1988, § 2-139)  
Sec. 2-140. - Time and attention required of commission members. 
The members of the civil service commission shall devote due time and attention to the performance of the duties imposed upon them. 
(Code 1973, § 2-80; Code 1988, § 2-140)  
Sec. 2-141. - Quorum for commission. 
Two members of the civil service commission shall constitute a quorum, and the votes of any two members of such commission concurring shall be sufficient for the decision of all matters and the transaction of all business to be decided or transacted by the commission. 
(Code 1973, § 2-81; Code 1988, § 2-141)  
Sec. 2-142. - Commission powers and duties under Charter. 
The civil service commission shall have all powers and duties and be subject to all of the provisions of the Charter. 
(Code 1973, § 2-82; Code 1988, § 2-142)  
Secs. 2-143—2-165. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CITY MANAGER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference— City manager, §§ 5.01—5.03. 
 
Sec. 2-166. - General powers and duties; absence or inability to act. 
(a)  The city manager shall have such powers and duties as are now or may hereafter be prescribed in the Charter and the laws of this state, and such other duties as may be imposed upon the city manager by the city council. 
(b)  The city manager shall establish and organize all city departments necessary to perform city governmental functions and administrative duties, and shall employ officers and employees needed to operate such departments. The city manager shall periodically advise the city council of the city's departmental organization and any changes thereto and shall maintain a list of all city departments for public information. 
(c)  In the event of the inability of the city manager to perform the duties of his office by reason of absence, vacation, sickness or other disability, the city manager shall appoint an acting city manager. The acting city manager shall have such powers and perform such duties as are prescribed for the city manager. If for any reason the city manager is unable to appoint an acting city manager, the city council shall make the appointment. 
(Code 1973, § 2-94; Code 1988, § 2-166; Ord. No. 1990-128, 12-11-1990) 
Charter reference— General powers and duties of city manager, § 5.02.  
Sec. 2-167. - Authority to offer rewards; ineligible persons; payment. 
The city manager shall be authorized, whenever it appears to him that property of the city has been damaged or defaced by parties unknown, to offer a monetary reward to any person for information sufficient to procure conviction of the person responsible for such damage in a court of appropriate jurisdiction; provided, however, that no law enforcement officer paid in whole or in part from public funds or employee of the city shall be eligible to receive such reward. All such rewards shall be paid from funds appropriated for such purpose and shall not exceed $25.00 paid to any one person for information leading to any one conviction. 
(Code 1973, § 2-95; Code 1988, § 2-167) 
Cross reference— Damaging city property generally, § 24-318.  
Secs. 2-168—2-191. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - CITY CLERK[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference— City clerk, §§ 4.01—4.03. 
 
Sec. 2-192. - Deputy clerk. 
(a)  The city council may appoint deputy city clerks who shall assist the city clerk in the performance of his duties and shall act under his direction and control. 
(b)  Whenever the city clerk is absent from his office, the deputy city clerk may perform the duties of the city clerk and sign whatsoever papers the clerk would be required to sign if present for duty. 
(Code 1973, § 2-114; Code 1988, § 2-192)  
Sec. 2-193. - Attendance of council meetings; recording proceedings. 
The city clerk shall attend all meetings of the city council, and record accurately its proceedings in well-bound books kept for that purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 2-108; Code 1988, § 2-193) 
Charter reference— Clerk to keep journal of council proceedings, § 4.02.  
Sec. 2-194. - Filing, preservation of records. 
The city clerk shall file and carefully preserve in his office all books, records, official bonds and all other papers which may come into his hands as city clerk; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to apply to title deeds. 
(Code 1973, § 2-109; Code 1988, § 2-194)  
Sec. 2-195. - Indexing of books. 
All books that the city clerk is required to maintain shall be properly indexed by him as to all matters therein contained. 
(Code 1973, § 2-110; Code 1988, § 2-195)  
Sec. 2-196. - Records to be open to inspection by councilmembers, city officers, public. 
All records that the city clerk is required to maintain shall be open to the inspection of any member of the city council, any officer of the city and any member of the general public during the office hours of the city clerk. 
(Code 1973, § 2-111; Code 1988, § 2-196) 
Charter reference— Records open to public inspection, § 4.02.  
Sec. 2-197. - Failure of city officers to file reports to be reported to council. 
The city clerk shall report to the city council the failure of any officer of the city to make such reports as are now or may hereafter be required to be made by him. 
(Code 1973, § 2-112; Code 1988, § 2-197)  
Sec. 2-198. - Duties when council required to give notice. 
Whenever the city council shall be required by law to give notice before holding a public hearing or taking action on any matter presented to it or to be presented to it by any officer, board or commission of the city, the city clerk, without prior authorization by the council, shall cause such matter to be placed on the agenda for the earliest practicable regular council meeting permitted by law and shall cause the required notice thereof to be published as required by law. 
(Code 1973, § 2-113; Code 1988, § 2-198)  
Secs. 2-199—2-220. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - CITY ATTORNEY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference— Department of law and city attorney, §§ 7.01—7.04. 
 
Sec. 2-221. - Duty to represent city in civil cases and proceedings before boards and commissions. 
The city attorney shall represent the interest of the city in all civil cases arising in the courts and in all proceedings before boards and commissions. 
(Code 1973, § 2-126; Code 1988, § 2-221) 
Charter reference— Duty of city attorney to represent city in civil cases, § 7.03(d).  
Sec. 2-222. - Collection and disposition of fees. 
All fees allowed the city attorney by law for acting as attorney in suits, actions and proceedings to which the city is a party shall be collected by him and paid into the city treasury. 
(Code 1973, § 2-127; Code 1988, § 2-222)  
Secs. 2-223—2-345. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SERVICES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-346. - Established. 
There is hereby established a department of the city government known and designated as the department of social services. 
(Code 1973, § 2-222; Code 1988, § 2-346)  
Sec. 2-347. - Composition. 
The department of social services shall consist of the director of social services and such other officers and employees organized into such boards, divisions and other units as may be provided by state law or ordinance or by the orders of the city manager consistent therewith. 
(Code 1973, § 2-223; Code 1988, § 2-347)  
Secs. 2-348—2-370. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DIRECTOR 
 
Sec. 2-371. - Appointment; subject to direction and control of city manager. 
The director of social services shall be appointed by the city manager and shall be subject to the city manager's direction and control. 
(Code 1973, § 2-231; Code 1988, § 2-371)  
Sec. 2-372. - General powers and duties. 
The director of social services shall exercise all powers and perform all duties conferred upon and required of local boards of public welfare by state law, this Code or other city ordinance. The director of social services shall also perform such other duties as may be assigned to him by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 2-232; Code 1988, § 2-372)  
Sec. 2-373. - Accountable for expenditure of funds; incurring indebtedness beyond appropriation. 
The director of social services shall be responsible and accountable to the city for the proper expenditure and account of all funds appropriated by the city for the department of social services and no indebtedness shall be incurred by him beyond the amount appropriated by the city council for such purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 2-233; Code 1988, § 2-373)  
Sec. 2-374. - Reports. 
The director of social services shall make, on or before the tenth day of each month, a written report to the city manager, of the activities of the department of social services for the preceding month. The director of social services shall also furnish from time to time such additional reports and information as may be required by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 2-234; Code 1988, § 2-374)  
Sec. 2-375. - Appointment, term of employees. 
The director of social services, subject to the approval of the city manager, shall appoint such social service employees as may be necessary who shall hold office at the pleasure of the director of social services and the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 2-235; Code 1988, § 2-375)  
Secs. 2-376—2-395. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SOCIAL SERVICES DEPARTMENT ADVISORY COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference— Local advisory commission, Code of Virginia, § 63.2-305. 
 
Sec. 2-396. - Definition. 
As used in this division, the word "commission" means the social services department advisory commission established by this division. 
(Code 1988, § 2-396)  
Sec. 2-397. - Established. 
There is hereby established an advisory commission to be known as the social services department advisory commission. 
(Code 1973, § 2-236; Code 1988, § 2-397)  
Sec. 2-398. - Composition; appointment and terms of members. 
(a)  The commission shall consist of seven members who shall be appointed by city council. The members of the commission shall be appointed for terms of four years; provided, however, that of those first appointed, three shall be appointed for two years, two for three years, and three for four years, for terms commencing on July 1, 1977. No person shall serve more than two consecutive terms. 
(b)  The director of social services shall be an ex officio member, without vote, of the commission. 
(Code 1973, §§ 2-237, 2-242; Code 1988, § 2-398)  
Sec. 2-399. - Filling of vacancies; removal of members. 
All vacancies on the commission shall be filled by the city council for the unexpired portion of the term. Any member of the commission may be removed by the city council at any time. 
(Code 1973, § 2-238; Code 1988, § 2-399)  
Sec. 2-400. - Election of officers; adoption of rules, regulations and bylaws. 
The commission shall annually elect a chairman and secretary from among its members. The commission shall adopt such rules, regulations and bylaws as it shall deem necessary for the proper and efficient conduct of its business. 
(Code 1973, § 2-239; Code 1988, § 2-400)  
Sec. 2-401. - Meetings. 
The commission shall hold regular meetings at least bimonthly on such days and at such hours as may be fixed by the commission. Special meetings may be held at such other times as may be fixed by the commission or upon the call of the chairman or on the petition of at least one-half of the members. 
(Code 1973, § 2-240; Code 1988, § 2-401)  
Sec. 2-402. - Powers and duties. 
The powers and duties of the commission shall be as follows: 
(1)  To interest itself in all matters pertaining to the social welfare of the people of the city; 
(2)  To monitor the formulation and implementation of social welfare programs in the city; 
(3)  To meet with the officer in charge of the department of social services at least four times a year for the purpose of making recommendations on policy matters concerning the department; 
(4)  To make an annual report to the city council, concurrent with the budget presentation of the department, concerning the administration of the social services department; and 
(5)  To submit to the city council, from time to time, other reports that the commission deems appropriate. 
(Code 1973, § 2-241; Code 1988, § 2-402)  
Secs. 2-403—2-420. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference— Local health departments and directors, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-30 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-421. - Operation by state board of health. 
Until otherwise provided by the city council, the department of public health shall be operated by the state board of health. 
(Code 1973, § 16-22; Code 1988, § 2-421) 
State Law reference— Contract for operation of local health department by state board of health, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-31.  
Sec. 2-422. - Appointment of director. 
The director of public health shall be appointed with the joint concurrence of the city manager and the state board of health. 
(Code 1973, § 16-23; Code 1988, § 2-422)  
Sec. 2-423. - Director designated city health officer. 
The director of public health shall be the health officer of the city and shall perform all the duties and functions of such office. 
(Code 1973, § 16-24; Code 1988, § 2-423)  
Sec. 2-424. - Duties of director as local registrar of vital records and health statistics. 
The director of public health shall be the local registrar of vital records and health statistics for the city. The director of public health shall supply forms, issue permits, require proper certificates and keep records as may be provided by state law, and shall perform such other duties as are prescribed by state law, the council or the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 16-25; Code 1988, § 2-424) 
State Law reference— Local registrars of vital records and health statistics, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-254 et seq.  
Sec. 2-425. - Right of entry of director and department officers and employees. 
The director of public health and all officers and employees of the health department of the city and their agents shall have the power and it shall be their duty to enter all lots, outhouses, dwellings, stables, wharves, warehouses and other premises for the purpose of examining such premises as to their general sanitary condition. 
(Code 1973, § 16-26; Code 1988, § 2-425)  
Sec. 2-426. - Authority to order abatement of nuisances; noncompliance. 
If, upon entering any premises pursuant to section 2-425, the director of public health or other officer or employee of the health department shall find any condition that is detrimental to the health of the inhabitants or people living or employed in such premises, he shall order the occupant, owner or his agent or other person who, under the terms of the lease or rental, is responsible for the upkeep of the same to abate the nuisance within a reasonable time. If such order is not complied with within the time specified in such notice, the occupant, the owner or his agent, or other person who under the terms of the lease or rental is charged with the duty of maintaining and keeping the premises in repair shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 16-27; Code 1988, § 2-426) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11; nuisances generally, ch. 23; lien for nuisance abatement expenses incurred by city, §§ 23-4, 23-5; abatement by director of public health of nuisance resulting from failure to connect to public sewer, § 38-35.  
Secs. 2-427—2-525. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-535. - Adoption of rules and regulations.

Sec. 2-537. - Right of entry of members. 
The members of the planning commission and its officers and employees, in the performance of their functions and duties, may enter upon any land in the city and make examinations and surveys and place and maintain necessary monuments and marks thereon. 
(Code 1973, § 26-13; Code 1988, § 2-538)  
Sec. 2-538. - Records to be kept.

ARTICLE XI. - MUSEUM AND FINE ARTS COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-566. - Established. 
There is hereby established a commission to be known as the museum and fine arts commission. 
(Code 1973, § 2-281; Code 1988, § 2-566)  
Sec. 2-567. - Composition; appointment and terms of members. 
The museum and fine arts commission shall consist of 15 members who shall be appointed by the city council. Members of the museum and fine arts commission shall be appointed for terms of three years. The members of the museum and fine arts commission shall hold office during their respective terms and until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1973, § 2-282; Code 1988, § 2-567; Ord. No. 1990-129, § 2, 12-11-1990)  
Sec. 2-568. - Filling of vacancies. 
All vacancies on the museum and fine arts commission shall be filled by appointment by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1973, § 2-284; Code 1988, § 2-568)  
Sec. 2-569. - Removal of members. 
Any member of the museum and fine arts commission may be removed by the city council for inefficiency, neglect of duty, misfeasance or malfeasance of office. 
(Code 1973, § 2-285; Code 1988, § 2-569)  
Sec. 2-570. - Compensation of members. 
The members of the museum and fine arts commission shall serve as such without compensation. 
(Code 1973, § 2-283; Code 1988, § 2-570)  
Sec. 2-571. - Selection and term of chair; creation and filling of other offices. 
The museum and fine arts commission shall choose one of its members to be chair for a one-year term, who may serve no more than two terms as chair. The museum and fine arts commission may create and fill such other offices as determined by the commission's bylaws. 
(Code 1973, § 2-293; Code 1988, § 2-572)  
Sec. 2-572. - General powers and duties. 
(a)  The museum and fine arts commission shall be the official consultant and advisor to the city government and city council on all museums and fine arts activities and programs. 
(b)  The museum and fine arts commission shall: 
(1)  Make a continuing survey and analysis of the cultural needs of the citizens of the city. 
(2)  Cooperate with other cultural groups, public and private. 
(3)  Assist and cooperate with the school board of the city in improving the cultural opportunities of students in the public schools of the city. 
(4)  Assist and cooperate, when called upon by other agencies, in developing, establishing, maintaining, preserving and publicizing places of historical, architectural and cultural significance. 
(5)  Accept grants, gifts and appropriations from whatsoever source and expend funds to enrich the cultural life of the community by the awarding of grants. 
(6)  Provide advice on accessions and deaccessions of objects at the request of the museum director. 
(Code 1973, §§ 2-296, 2-297, 2-300—2-302; Code 1988, § 2-575; Ord. No. 1995-101, § 1, 10-24-1995)  
Sec. 2-573. - Adoption of bylaws, rules and regulations. 
The museum and fine arts commission shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for its guidance as may be deemed necessary and expedient. 
(Code 1973, § 2-288; Code 1988, § 2-576)  
Sec. 2-574. - Date of regular meetings. 
The museum and fine arts commission shall hold regular monthly meetings on a date to be fixed by the commission. 
(Code 1973, § 2-289; Code 1988, § 2-577)  
Sec. 2-575. - Calling of special meetings. 
Special meetings of the museum and fine arts commission may be called at any time on the call of the chairman or any two members of the commission. 
(Code 1973, § 2-290; Code 1988, § 2-578)  
Sec. 2-576. - Meetings to be public. 
All meetings of the museum and fine arts commission shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1973, § 2-291; Code 1988, § 2-579)  
Sec. 2-577. - Quorum. 
A majority of the members of the museum and fine arts commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1973, § 2-287; Code 1988, § 2-580)  
Sec. 2-578. - Record of proceedings. 
The museum and fine arts commission shall keep a record of all of its proceedings, which shall be a public record. 
(Code 1973, § 2-292; Code 1988, § 2-581)  
Sec. 2-579. - Reports. 
(a)  The museum and fine arts commission shall furnish an annual report to the city council by the end of each fiscal year, which shall include grant and monument fund activities. 
(b)  The museum and fine arts commission shall furnish the city manager, whenever requested by him, such information as may be desired with respect to its operation and management. 
(Code 1973, § 2-305; Code 1988, § 2-583)  
Sec. 2-580. - Review of commission actions by council. 
All actions of the museum and fine arts commission shall be subject to review by the city council, which may take such action thereon as it deems advisable. 
(Code 1973, § 2-306; Code 1988, § 2-584)  
Secs. 2-581—2-605. - Reserved.
