ARTICLE XIII. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2006-76, § 1, adopted Aug. 22, 2006, amended Art. XIII, in its entirety, to read as herein set out in §§ 2-656—2-662. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Art. XIII, §§ 2-656—2-658, and was entitled, "Emergency Services Agency." See also the Code Comparative Table 
State Law reference— Emergency management, Code of Virginia, § 44-146.13 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-656. - Created; director, coordinator. 
In accordance with the Commonwealth Emergency Services and Disaster Law of 2000, Chapter 3.2 of Title 44 (§ 44-146.13 et seq.) of the Code of Virginia, and also Section 2.15 of the Portsmouth City Charter, the emergency management agency is created. The city manager shall be director of emergency management (within this article, the "director"). A coordinator of emergency management shall be appointed by the city manager, with the consent of city council. The coordinator of emergency management (within this article, the "coordinator"), shall report to the director and shall have such powers as are set forth in this article unless restricted by the director, or as may otherwise be assigned or delegated by the director. 
(Ord. No. 2006-76, § 1, 8-22-2006)  
Sec. 2-657. - General powers and duties of director. 
(a)  In collaboration with other public and private agencies within the Commonwealth, the director shall develop or cause to be developed mutual aid arrangements for reciprocal assistance in case of a disaster too great to be dealt with unassisted. 
(b)  The director shall prepare or cause to be prepared and kept current one or more local or interjurisdictional emergency plans for the area, for dealing with disasters of different types and scopes. The plan or plans shall include, but not be limited to, responsibilities of all local agencies, and they shall establish a chain of command according to the National Incident Management System. Plans shall be reviewed and updated annually, with documentation. 
(c)  The Director shall have such other powers and duties as provided for in the Commonwealth Emergency Services and Disaster Law of 2000 (Code of Virginia § 44-146.13 et seq.), and any and all other applicable laws, plus all powers reasonably and necessarily implied from any express grant of authority. 
(Ord. No. 2006-76, § 1, 8-22-2006)  
Sec. 2-658. - Declaration of emergencies. 
(a)  The director may declare a local emergency. 
(b)  The director or the coordinator shall designate a command and control center. 
(c)  Prior to the declaration of a local emergency, the director shall attempt to obtain the prior formal or informal consent of city council. However, if such consent is not reasonably practical under the circumstances, then the declaration shall nevertheless be legally valid and of full legal force and authority. 
(d)  The declaration shall be in writing. It shall remain in effect for 14 days, or until confirmed, modified, extended, or cancelled by official recorded vote of city council, whichever occurs first. If city council extends the declaration, it shall state the length of the extension and the conditions and procedures under which it shall be ended, if practicable. If city council is unable to meet within 14 days, then the declaration may be renewed or extended by the director for an indefinite period of time unless and until later modified or cancelled by the director or city council. 
(e)  To the greatest extent practicable, the director or the coordinator shall maintain a written record of all official actions taken hereunder, for later review by applicable state, federal, and local agencies. 
(Ord. No. 2006-76, § 1, 8-22-2006)  
Sec. 2-659. - Emergency powers. 
When a local emergency has been declared by the director pursuant to section 2-658, or by order of the Governor, pursuant to Code of Virginia § 44-146.17: 
(a)  All departments and agencies of city government shall cooperate in full with all directives from the director or the coordinator. All independent agencies and officials within the City of Portsmouth, including without limitation the Portsmouth Public School Division, the Sheriff's Office, the Portsmouth Health Department, and the South Hampton Roads Regional Jail shall also cooperate as fully as reasonably possible and act under the overall direction of the director or the coordinator. 
(b)  The director or the coordinator may: 
(1)  Implement any applicable emergency plans and mutual aid agreements. 
(2)  Suspend all normal procurement requirements in whole or in part. 
(3)  Regulate the distribution of food, fuel, water, emergency supplies, and other resource systems and provide emergency assistance to individuals and groups as needed. 
(4)  Establish shelters as he determines necessary. If any private property is declared to be a shelter, the owner thereof shall have the right to just compensation upon conclusion of the emergency, but he may not lawfully resist or interfere with the use of said property as a shelter during the emergency. 
(5)  Commandeer and appropriate automobiles, boats, other vehicles, or other personal property if needed to protect the public. The owner of any such personal property shall have the right to just compensation upon conclusion of the emergency, but he may not lawfully resist or interfere with the taking of his property to protect the public. 
(6)  Direct any city employees to work at such hours and to perform such duties as are reasonably necessary to help protect and serve the public, and it shall be their duty to perform as directed. 
(7)  Request the assistance of the superintendent of schools, the sheriff, the director of public health, the director of the regional jail, or any other public official to make employees, officials, facilities, and equipment available to assist as needed with emergency efforts. 
(8)  Order an emergency curfew pursuant to section 2-831 et seq. 
(9)  Direct the evacuation of areas of the city. It shall be the duty of each citizen to obey any evacuation order made hereunder, unless the citizen has good cause for not doing so. There shall be no criminal sanction for a citizen who chooses not to evacuate. 
(10)  Provide support or cooperation for the Portsmouth Director of Public Health for any actions taken by that official. 
(c)  The building official or any official of the Portsmouth Department of Fire, Rescue, and Emergency Services may order the evacuation of buildings pursuant to section 13-62. Any sworn officer may order evacuation because of an explosive device. Failure to evacuate shall comprise obstruction or hindrance of a city employee in the discharge of his duty, in violation of section 24-246, and disorderly conduct, in violation of Code of Virginia § 18.2-415 and shall be punishable as a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(d)  The director or the coordinator shall provide all reasonable assistance to the state health commissioner in the enforcement of any order of quarantine or order of isolation issued pursuant to Code of Virginia, Title 32.1, Article 3.02 ("Quarantine and Isolation of Persons with Communicable Diseases of Public Health Threat"). 
(Ord. No. 2006-76, § 1, 8-22-2006)  
Sec. 2-660. - Emergency succession. 
If a local emergency has been declared, and the director is for any reason incapacitated, disabled, or for any other reason unable to perform his duties, his powers shall pass to a successor official, in the following order: 
(1)  The coordinator, if one has been appointed. 
(2)  The chief of the department of fire, rescue, and emergency services. 
(3)  The deputy emergency management coordinator. 
(4)  The chief of police. 
(5)  The deputy city manager for public safety. 
(6)  The deputy city manager for operations. 
(7)  The city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2006-76, § 1, 8-22-2006)  
Sec. 2-661. - Legal determinations. 
Any question involving the interpretation of this article shall be decided by the city attorney or, in his absence, a deputy city attorney, whose decision shall be final and binding. 
(Ord. No. 2006-76, § 1, 8-22-2006)  
Secs. 2-662—2-680. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIV. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE ADVISORY COMMISSION[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference— Emergency medical services, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.1. 
 
Sec. 2-681. - Definition. 
As used in this article, the term "commission" means the commission established by section 2-682. 
(Code 1988, § 2-681)  
Sec. 2-682. - Established. 
There is hereby established a commission to be known as the Portsmouth Emergency Medical Service Advisory Commission. 
(Code 1973, § 2-340; Code 1988, § 2-682)  
Sec. 2-683. - Composition, appointment and term of members. 
The commission shall consist of 11 members who shall be appointed by the city council for a term of three years. Of these 11 members, a minimum of six shall be appointed from representatives of the following organizations: the Portsmouth Academy of Medicine, the hospital emergency room physicians, the hospital emergency room nurses, the administrator of Maryview Hospital, the administrator of Portsmouth General Hospital, the administrator of the Naval Hospital, a community psychiatrist and the American Red Cross. In addition to those six members, at least three members shall be either residents, property or business owners within the city or shall be employed in the city. These members shall hold office during their respective terms and until their successors are appointed or they are removed under the provisions of section 2-684. 
(Code 1973, § 2-341; Code 1988, § 2-683; Ord. No. 1990-129, § 3, 12-11-1990)  
Sec. 2-684. - Removal of members. 
The city council may remove any member of the commission at any time if it finds that the best interest of the commission would be served by such action. 
(Code 1973, § 2-343; Code 1988, § 2-684)  
Sec. 2-685. - Filling of vacancies. 
All vacancies on the commission shall be filled by the city council for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(Code 1973, § 2-342; Code 1988, § 2-685)  
Sec. 2-686. - Election of officers. 
The commission shall elect annually a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary from among its members. 
(Code 1973, § 2-347; Code 1988, § 2-686)  
Sec. 2-687. - Function. 
The commission shall have as its function the following objectives: 
(1)  Survey emergency medical resources available to citizens and visitors of the city. 
(2)  Make recommendations regarding hospital emergency departments, ambulance services, training programs, facilities and communications systems and legislation of a related nature. 
(3)  Serve in an advisory role to the city council. 
(4)  Review and comment on federal, state and local fund requests for improvement of emergency medical service capabilities. 
(5)  Serve as a catalyst to effect cooperative arrangements for improving and best utilizing emergency medical resources in the city. 
(6)  Develop and implement a comprehensive city emergency medical service plan. 
(7)  Make an annual report to the city council concerning its activities during the year. 
(Code 1973, § 2-344; Code 1988, § 2-687)  
Sec. 2-688. - Adoption of rules, regulations and bylaws. 
The commission shall adopt such rules, regulations and bylaws as it shall deem necessary for the proper and efficient conduct of its business. 
(Code 1973, § 2-345; Code 1988, § 2-688)  
Sec. 2-689. - Meetings generally. 
The commission shall hold regular meetings at such intervals and on such days and at such hours as may be determined by the commission. Special meetings may be held at any time on the call of the chairman, or any two members of the commission. 
(Code 1973, § 2-346; Code 1988, § 2-689)  
Sec. 2-690. - Member's right to vote. 
Each member of the commission appointed pursuant to section 2-683 shall have the right to vote in exercising the functions and duties enumerated in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 2-341; Code 1988, § 2-690)  
Sec. 2-691. - Representatives from certain departments to attend meetings. 
As an adjunct to the commission, one representative of each of the following city departments will attend the commission meetings in a nonvoting capacity: One member from emergency management agency, one member from the police department, one member from the fire department, one member from the city administration, one member from the department of public health and one member from the public school administration. 
(Code 1973, § 2-341; Code 1988, § 2-691)  
Secs. 2-692—2-719. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XV. - BEHAVIORAL HEALTHCARE SERVICES ADVISORY BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-720. - Established. 
There is hereby established an advisory board to be known as the behavioral healthcare services advisory board. 
(Code 1988, § 2-720; Ord. No. 1998-41, § 1, 8-11-1998)  
Sec. 2-721. - Composition; appointment of the board. 
The behavioral healthcare services advisory board shall have nine members appointed by the city council. Appointments to the board shall be broadly representative of the community. Three members of the board shall be consumers of behavioral healthcare services or family members of consumers. Of those three members, at least one shall be a consumer receiving such services. Members of the board shall serve without compensation. The director of the department of behavioral healthcare services shall serve as the executive director of the board. 
(Code 1988, § 2-721; Ord. No. 1998-41, § 1, 8-11-1998)  
Sec. 2-722. - Terms of members. 
The term of office of each member of the board of behavioral healthcare services shall be for three years from July 1 of the year of appointment. The members shall hold office during their representative terms and until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1988, § 2-722; Ord. No. 1998-41, § 1, 8-11-1998)  
Sec. 2-723. - Filling of vacancies; limitations on members of the board of directors serving successive terms. 
Vacancies on the behavioral healthcare services advisory board shall be filled for unexpired terms in the same manner as original appointments. No person shall be eligible to serve more than two successive terms; provided, that any persons heretofore or hereafter appointed to fill vacancies may serve two additional successive terms. 
(Code 1988, § 2-723; Ord. No. 1998-41, § 1, 8-11-1998)  
Sec. 2-724. - Election of officers. 
The behavioral healthcare services advisory board shall annually elect a chair, vice-chair, and secretary from among its members. 
(Code 1988, § 2-724; Ord. No. 1998-41, § 1, 8-11-1998)  
Sec. 2-725. - Adoption of rules, regulations, and bylaws. 
The behavioral healthcare services advisory board shall adopt such rules, regulations, and bylaws as it shall deem necessary for the proper and efficient conduct of its business. 
(Code 1988, § 2-725; Ord. No. 1998-41, § 1, 8-11-1998)  
Sec. 2-726. - Removal of members of the board. 
The city council may remove any member of the behavioral healthcare services advisory board at any time if it finds that the best interest of the board would be served by such action. 
(Code 1988, § 2-726; Ord. No. 1998-41, § 1, 8-11-1998)  
Sec. 2-727. - Powers and duties. 
The behavioral healthcare services advisory board shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Advise the city council regarding rules, policies, and regulations for the rendition or operation of services and facilities by the department. 
(2)  Review and evaluate the operations of the department and advise the city council of its findings. 
(3)  Review the services developed by the department and advise city council of its findings. 
(4)  Review and comment on the annual performance contract, quarterly and annual performance reports, and comprehensive state plan proposals developed by the department. The board's comments shall be attached to the performance contract, the performance reports, and the comprehensive state plan proposals prior to their submission to city council. 
(5)  Advise the city council as necessary and appropriate actions to maximize the involvement of consumers and family members of consumers in policy formulation and services evaluation. 
(6)  Advise the city manager in the selection and the annual performance evaluation of the director. 
(7)  Carry out such other duties and responsibilities as assigned by city council. 
(Code 1988, § 2-727; Ord. No. 1998-41, § 1, 8-11-1998)  
Secs. 2-728—2-789. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVI. - COMMUNITY CRIMINAL JUSTICE BOARD[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference— Criminal justice board, Code of Virginia, § 9.1-178 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-790. - Established; membership; qualifications. 
There is hereby established by the city council a board to be known as the community criminal justice board. The appointments to the board shall be made by the city council. The community criminal justice board shall not exceed 22 members and shall be composed of a judge of the general district court; a circuit court judge; a juvenile and domestic relations district court judge; the chief magistrate; a member from the city council or the city manager or a deputy city manager appointed by the city council; the chief of police; an attorney for the commonwealth; a public defender and/or an attorney who is experienced in the defense of criminal matters; the sheriff; the superintendent of the Hampton Roads Regional Jail; a local educator; a behavioral healthcare services advisory board administrator; the chief of adult probation and parole; the director of juvenile court services; the director of community corrections and pretrial services; the director of social services; and up to six citizens of the city. The community criminal justice board shall possess the powers and duties granted to it by Code of Virginia, § 9.1-178 et seq. 
(Code 1988, § 2-790; Ord. No. 1995-64, § 2, 5-23-1995; Ord. No. 1995-73, § 2, 6-13-1995; Ord. No. 2000-40, § 1, 10-10-2000; Ord. No. 2001-26, § 1, 6-12-2001; Ord. No. 2018-86 , § 1, 9-25-2018)  
Secs. 2-791—2-799. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVII. - CLEAN COMMUNITY COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-800. - Established. 
There is hereby established a commission to be known as the clean community commission. 
(Code 1988, § 2-800; Ord. No. 1997-57, § 1, 10-14-1997)  
Sec. 2-801. - Membership of commission; terms. 
The clean community commission shall be appointed by city council and shall consist of not less than nine members, who shall be citizens of the city or business or property owners in the city. The members of the clean community commission shall be appointed for terms of three years. Members of the clean community commission shall hold office during their respective terms at the pleasure of the city council and until their successors are appointed. 
(Code 1988, § 2-801; Ord. No. 1997-57, § 1, 10-14-1997; Ord. No. 1999-35, § 1, 11-23-1999)  
Sec. 2-802. - Purpose and duties of the commission. 
The clean community commission shall have the purpose and duty of enhancing community quality and liveability by the encouragement and promotion of programs to clean up and beautify neighborhoods throughout the city. 
(Code 1988, § 2-802; Ord. No. 1997-57, § 1, 10-14-1997)  
Sec. 2-803. - Ex officio member. 
The director of the department of public utilities or the director's designee shall be an ex officio member, without vote, of the commission and shall serve as executive coordinator and assist the commission in the performance of its duties. 
(Code 1988, § 2-803; Ord. No. 1997-57, § 1, 10-14-1997; Ord. No. 2020-10 , § 1, 2-11-2020)  
Secs. 2-804—2-809. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVIII. - HISTORY COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-810. - Established. 
There is hereby established a commission to be known as the history commission. 
(Code 1988, § 2-810; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-811. - Composition; appointment and terms of members. 
The history commission shall consist of 13 members who shall be appointed by the city council. Members of the history commission shall be appointed for terms of three years. The members of the history commission shall hold office until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1988, § 2-811; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-812. - Filling of vacancies. 
All vacancies on the history commission shall be filled by appointment by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1988, § 2-812; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-813. - Removal of members. 
Any member of the history commission may be removed by the city council for inefficiency, neglect of duty, misfeasance or malfeasance of office. 
(Code 1988, § 2-813; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-814. - Compensation of members. 
The members of the history commission shall serve as such without compensation. 
(Code 1988, § 2-814; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-815. - Selection and term of chairman; creation and filling of other offices. 
The history commission shall choose annually one of its members to be chair for a term of one year and until a successor is chosen and qualified. The history commission may create and fill such other offices as it may determine are necessary. 
(Code 1988, § 2-815; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-816. - General powers and duties. 
(a)  The history commission shall be the official consultant and advisor to the city government and city council on all matters pertaining to the city's history. 
(b)  The history commission shall: 
(1)  Act as an advisor to the city council and the department of museums on matters related to the city's history and heritage. 
(2)  Assist and cooperate with public and private groups and agencies in developing, establishing, maintaining, preserving and publicizing places of historical significance. 
(3)  Assist and cooperate with the school board of the city in improving the opportunities of students in the city public schools to engage in the study of Portsmouth's history and to develop an appreciation of the city's contributions to the commonwealth and to the nation. 
(Code 1988, § 2-816; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-817. - Adoption of bylaws, rules and regulations. 
The history commission shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for its guidance as may be deemed necessary and expedient. 
(Code 1988, § 2-817; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-818. - Meetings. 
The history commission shall hold regular monthly meetings on a date to be fixed by the commission and such special meetings as it deems necessary. 
(Code 1988, § 2-818; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-819. - Reports. 
(a)  The history commission shall provide an annual report to the city council by the end of each fiscal year concerning the commission's activities. 
(b)  The history commission shall furnish the city manager or his designee, whenever requested, such information as may be desired with respect to its operation and management. 
(Code 1988, § 2-820; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-820. - Review of commission actions by council. 
All activities of the history commission shall be subject to review by the city council, which may take such actions as it deems advisable. 
(Code 1988, § 2-821; Ord. No. 2001-04, § 1, 1-23-2001)  
Sec. 2-821. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XX. - EMERGENCY CURFEW[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt curfew ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-926. 
 
Sec. 2-831. - Authority to order curfew. 
Whenever an emergency has been declared in the city in a manner authorized by law, then an emergency curfew may be ordered by the city manager for the purpose of protecting public safety, public welfare, public and private property, and good order, as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1988, § 2-831; Ord. No. 2003-55, § 1, 9-23-2003) 
State Law reference— Curfew hours, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-926.  
Sec. 2-832. - Effective date and time; duration. 
An emergency curfew shall be effective immediately upon the city manager declaring it in writing. An emergency curfew may not remain in effect for longer than 14 days without approval by vote of city council. An emergency curfew shall in any event be confirmed, extended, modified, or ended by city council not later than the next regularly scheduled council meeting after it has been declared. An emergency curfew shall not be permanent, and it shall not extend past the time at which the applicable authority determines, in its sole discretion, that the emergency no longer exists. 
(Code 1988, § 2-832; Ord. No. 2003-55, § 1, 9-23-2003)  
Sec. 2-833. - Terms and conditions. 
An emergency curfew may contain such terms and conditions as are deemed necessary and proper to deal with the emergency at hand, including, without limitation, geographic scope within the city, curfew hours, application to businesses as well as individuals, and exceptions. 
(Code 1988, § 2-833; Ord. No. 2003-55, § 1, 9-23-2003)  
Sec. 2-834. - Required condition for violation; penalty. 
A person must be informed of an emergency curfew and given an opportunity to comply with it before being in violation. Violation of an emergency curfew shall be a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 2-834; Ord. No. 2003-55, § 1, 9-23-2003)  
Chapter 3 - AMUSEMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Boats and waterways, ch. 6; license tax on various amusements, §§ 20-8, 20-9, 20-13; parks and recreation, ch. 25; swimming pools, ch. 34; amusement admissions tax, § 35-371 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 3-1. - Hours of operation of pool rooms, billiard rooms. 
All public pool rooms, billiard rooms and establishments containing pool tables, billiard tables or like or similar devices or equipment shall be closed from 12:00 midnight every night until sunrise of the succeeding morning and no games shall be allowed therein during the hours when such rooms and establishments are required to be closed. A violation of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 3-1; Code 1988, § 3-1) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 3-2. - Minors playing, loitering in pool rooms, billiard rooms. 
(a)  No person under 18 years of age shall frequent, play in or loiter in any public pool room or billiard room; nor shall the proprietor of any public pool room or billiard room or his agent permit any minor to frequent, play in or loiter in any such place; provided, however, that this subsection shall not be construed to include an establishment in which not more than three miniature pool tables that operate on the coin-in-the-slot-principle are exclusively kept or played; provided, further, that this subsection shall not apply in any establishment known as a family billiard center, which is defined as a licensed establishment for the playing of billiards when such place of business: 
(1)  Is not licensed under the alcoholic beverage control laws of the state, and is not operated in conjunction with any other licensed dispenser of alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  Is illuminated throughout its interior at a level of 40 footcandles. 
(3)  Has no partitioned or closed off areas other than those for toilet facilities, office space, or storerooms; and all playing areas and billiard tables shall be visible from a public way or street. 
(4)  Has a window or windows open to view from a public way or street, having a minimum of 100 square feet of glass area, which windows shall not be permanently covered or otherwise obstructed. 
(5)  Contains only regulation size (minimum measurements: 4½ feet by nine feet) billiard tables, which shall not be of the "coin-operated" type, and such center shall contain a minimum of ten such tables. 
(6)  Has separate restroom facilities for both sexes. 
(7)  Is located on the ground level floor of the building in which it is situated. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 3-2; Code 1988, § 3-2) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11; curfew for minors, § 24-3. 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-432.  
Secs. 3-3—3-75. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COMMERCIAL RECREATION CENTERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— License tax on amusement parks, § 20-9. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 3-76. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Amusement game machine means a coin-operated machine or device which, whether mechanical, electrical or electronic, shall be ready for play by the insertion of a coin, slug or token and may be operated by the public for use as a game, entertainment or amusement. It shall include, but not be limited to, devices such as pinball machines, foosball tables, miniature bowling alleys, miniature shuffle boards, target shoots, picture-taking machines and other amusement devices which reproduce symbolic figures and lines intended to be representative of real games or activities. 
Commercial recreation center or center means any establishment where a group of more than two amusement game machines is displayed for public patronage. 
(Code 1973, § 3-31; Code 1988, § 3-76) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 3-77. - Violations of article. 
Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 3-40; Code 1988, § 3-77) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 3-78. - Exemptions from article. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to establishments licensed and regulated by the Virginia Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. 
(Code 1973, § 3-31; Code 1988, § 3-78)  
Sec. 3-79. - Admission of minors. 
No person holding a permit under this article or any of his agents or employees shall allow any person under the age of 18 years to remain in the center between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. the following morning. In addition, persons under the age of 16 years shall not be permitted to remain in the center during normal school hours. The permittee shall post signs to this effect printed in bold face letters in conspicuous places within the center. 
(Code 1973, § 3-38; Code 1988, § 3-79) 
Cross reference— Curfew for minors, § 24-3. 
State Law reference— Restrictions and curfew for minors, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-926.  
Sec. 3-80. - Operating requirements. 
The following operating requirements shall apply to all commercial recreation centers: 
(1)  The center shall be illuminated throughout its interior at a level of 40 footcandles. 
(2)  The center shall have no partitioned or closed off areas other than those for restroom facilities, office space or storerooms. 
(3)  The center shall have separate restroom facilities for both sexes. 
(4)  The center shall be located on the ground level floor of the building in which it is situated; and shall also have a window or windows with a total of not less than 100 square feet of glass, which shall not be covered or otherwise obstructed during hours of business; provided that for hotels or multistoried shopping centers, the center may be located above the second floor level. 
(5)  The center may not be open for business between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(6)  The center shall be at all times under the management and control of a person at least 18 years of age. The center shall be arranged so that the management attendant is within the room where machines are located or such that the management attendants outside the room can easily see and supervise the interior of the room. 
(7)  Adequate space shall be provided for each machine so as to allow its use without overcrowding and to prevent interference with pedestrian circulation on the rest of the premises. 
(Code 1973, § 3-39; Code 1988, § 3-80)  
Secs. 3-81—3-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 3-101. - Required. 
No person shall operate a commercial recreation center without first obtaining a permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 3-32; Code 1988, § 3-101)  
Sec. 3-102. - Filing, contents and notice of application. 
(a)  Form and contents of application. The application for a permit to operate a commercial recreation center shall be made to the city manager upon a form supplied for that purpose. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the applicant, age, date and place of birth, and where pertinent, the relationship of the applicant to the company or corporation owning or managing the center. If a corporation, this information for the corporate officer signing the application, plus name and address of the registered agent, date of incorporation and state of incorporation, and names of officers and directors thereof. Name and address of the owner of the machines and owner of the premises if different from that of the above. 
(2)  The location of the center and the business, if any other, conducted at the location. 
(3)  Maximum number of patrons center will accommodate. 
(4)  Maximum number of machines center will accommodate and submission of necessary information in order to determine if there is sufficient space for such machines to prevent overcrowding of users or interference with pedestrian circulation on the rest of the premises. 
(5)  A certification by the applicant that all requirements of this article have been complied with. 
(6)  A list of all employees who are expected to serve in a managerial capacity in the center. Prior convictions of the applicant and managerial employees as well as any pending criminal cases involving such persons. 
(7)  A brief set of house rules which the managerial personnel shall enforce, both within the center and in the immediate area outside the center, such rules being designed to promote good order and peaceful behavior by the patron of the center. 
(8)  Authorization from each person named in the application permitting the city manager to conduct a criminal records investigation of that individual. 
(b)  Continuing responsibility to provide information. The responsibility to provide the information requested herein is regarded as continuing beyond the date of the application and the applicant is required to provide, by filing an amended application, any additional information which will augment or otherwise modify the information provided with the application. Such information shall be provided to the city manager within ten days after any change from the information previously furnished. 
(c)  Notifications. Every applicant for a permit under this division shall, not more than ten days after filing the application for such permit, post a notice of such application on the front door of the building where he proposes to operate the center, and publish a copy of such notice at least once in a newspaper published in or having a general circulation in the city. Such notice shall be upon a form supplied for this purpose and a certification of publication shall be furnished the city manager prior to final action on the application. 
(Code 1973, § 3-33; Code 1988, § 3-102)  
Sec. 3-103. - Action by city manager on application; application fee. 
Upon receipt of an application for a permit, the city manager shall immediately cause an investigation to be made concerning the qualifications of the applicant and whether the proposed center is in compliance with this article. The city manager shall grant or deny such permit, and shall notify the applicant in writing of his action within 21 days after receipt of the certification of publication required in section 3-102(c) by the city manager. If the city manager denies such permit, he shall state in writing his reasons for such action. Every application shall be accompanied by a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code which shall not be refundable. 
(Code 1973, § 3-34; Code 1988, § 3-103)  
Sec. 3-104. - Grounds for denial. 
(a)  The following factors shall constitute grounds for denial of a permit for operation of a center: 
(1)  A finding by the city manager that the applicant has falsified his application in a material manner. 
(2)  A finding by the city manager that the applicant or any of his designated managerial employees has a criminal record which reveals any convictions for violation of any drug or alcoholic beverage control laws, gambling laws, sex offenses, selling or distribution of pornographic material, or any pattern of criminal misconduct as evidenced by a series of convictions. 
(3)  A finding by the city manager that the proposed use of the property shall not comply with all provisions of law or that same will adversely affect the health or safety of persons residing or working in the neighborhood of the proposed use or will be detrimental to the public welfare or that there is an undue concentration of such complexes in the area requested. 
(4)  A finding by the city manager that there is insufficient space for the number of machines requested. 
(5)  A finding by the city manager that the applicant consistently and habitually fails to cooperate with law enforcement personnel in the exercise of their official duties. 
(6)  A finding by the city manager that the application is not properly completed as required by this article. 
(7)  A finding by the city manager that the proposed center fails to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  No other matters shall be sufficient grounds for denial of an application for such permit. 
(Code 1973, § 3-35; Code 1988, § 3-104)  
Sec. 3-105. - Not assignable. 
No permit issued under this division shall be assignable to any other person. 
(Code 1973, § 3-37; Code 1988, § 3-105)  
Sec. 3-106. - Effect of cessation of business. 
When any permittee under the provisions of this division shall cease to operate the center for a period of 30 days, the permit shall be void. 
(Code 1973, § 3-37; Code 1988, § 3-106)  
Sec. 3-107. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Generally. The city manager may revoke or suspend the permit for the operation of a commercial recreation center if he finds: 
(1)  That the premises have been declared a common nuisance by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  That circumstances exist which would have justified a denial of such permit at the time of its issuance. 
(3)  That the permittee has consistently failed in some material respect to operate the center on an orderly basis in accordance with the provisions of this article or the approved house rules. 
(4)  That the permittee has failed to take prompt and vigorous action against violations of criminal statutes occurring on his premises and known to the permittee. 
(b)  Notice and hearing. A permittee shall be entitled to a hearing before the city manager before such permit is revoked. The city manager shall give the permittee ten days' notice of his intention to revoke such permit. Notice shall be served by certified mail, return receipt requested. The city manager shall, as part of such notice, provide the permittee with a written statement of the grounds for revocation or suspension and advise him of his right to a hearing. The hearing shall be held not less than ten days, nor more than 20 days after the giving of notice, but the permittee may waive the ten-day limitation. The permittee shall have the right to be represented by counsel at such hearing and may present evidence in his own behalf. 
(Code 1973, § 3-36; Code 1988, § 3-107)  
Secs. 3-108—3-299. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - BODY ART 
 
Sec. 3-300. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Body art means body piercing and/or tattooing. 
Body art studio means a place in which a person offers, works, or practices as a body artist. 
Body art studio operator means a person who controls, operates, conducts, or manages a body art studio. 
Body art studio owner means a person who serves as the body art studio's proprietor and ensures the continuous presence of someone who is responsible for monitoring and managing all establishment operations and who is authorized to take actions to ensure compliance with the regulations in this article. 
Body artist means a person who practices body art. 
Body piercer means a person who performs body piercing for compensation. 
Body piercing means the act of penetrating a person's skin to make a hole into or through which an item of jewelry or some other decorative article may be inserted and/or mounted so as to be visible above the skin. Body piercing does not include the use of a mechanized, pre-sterilized ear-piercing system that penetrates the outer perimeter or lobe of a person's ear or both, nor does it include any medical procedure engaged in by a state-licensed physician or a health care professional under the direct supervision of a state-licensed physician or by a registered nurse or other medical services personnel licensed pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 54.1-100 et seq. in the performance of their duties. 
Body piercing studio means a place in which a person offers, works, or practices as a body piercer. 
Hazardous waste means waste or material that may present a threat of infection to humans, including without limitation: 
(1)  Blood, blood products, body fluids, body parts; and 
(2)  Absorbent materials or devices or equipment contaminated with any item listed in subsection (1) of this section. 
Health department means the Portsmouth Health District. 
Health director means the Director of the Portsmouth Health District. 
Permit holder means collectively, any person holding a permit under this chapter, whether as a body art operator or as a body artist. 
Sexually private area means for a male, the genitals, pubic area, or buttocks; for a female, the genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or the breast below the aureole. 
Tattoo artist means a person who performs the work of tattooing. 
Tattoo studio means a place in which a person offers, works or practices as a tattoo artist. 
Tattooing means the process of placing any design, letter, scroll, figure, symbol or any other mark upon or under the skin of any person with ink or any other substance resulting in the permanent coloration of a person's skin, including permanent make-up or permanent jewelry, by the use of a needle, or any other instrument designed to touch or puncture the skin and inject or leave colored dye in the skin. The term "tattoo" shall also mean the mark, design, or coloration itself which is thus created. The term shall not include any medical procedure engaged in by a state-licensed physician or a health care professional under the direct supervision of a state-licensed physician or by a registered nurse or other medical services personnel licensed pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 54.1-100 et seq. in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1988, § 3-300; Ord. No. 2005-67, § 2, 8-23-2005)  
Sec. 3-301. - Permit requirements. 
(a)  No person shall operate a body art studio without a valid permit from the health department. 
(b)  No person shall be a body artist or a body art studio owner or operator without first obtaining an applicable permit from the health department. 
(c)  No permit shall be issued unless the applicant has complied with all applicable health requirements of this chapter and all applicable requirements of the Virginia Board for Barbers and Cosmetology and any other state agency of competent jurisdiction. Permits from the health department shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of issue and displayed in an area easily viewed by the public. 
(d)  The annual body art studio permit or renewal application for each permit holder shall include the following information: business name and address, permit number, owner name, home address, and phone number, proof of state licensure, and a list and assigned location of all body artists working in the body art studio. Body artist permits will be issued and renewed annually as a subapplication or appendix under the body art studio permit, at no additional charge. Body art studio owners or operators shall also submit building plans for review. The body art studio owner or operator shall notify the health department immediately upon any addition or termination of a body artist or body art operator. Upon closure of the body art studio, the body art studio owner shall return all applicable permits to the health department. All other information shall be updated within seven calendar days for any changes during the year. 
(e)  A new permit application must be filed for a change in business location or ownership and a new building plan review must be done for any significant structural changes, impacting facility requirements. 
(f)  The health department shall charge the fees set out in appendix A to this Code for the following: 
(1)  Issuance of a permit to operate a body art studio, per calendar year (prorated for partial years and inclusive of artist permits). 
(2)  Plan review for initial opening of a body art studio or for any changes requiring review of construction plans. 
(g)  The body art studio operator is not required to hold a body artist permit unless he also works as a body artist. However, the body art studio operator is required to receive annual training under section 3-302(b)(3) to ensure knowledge of all health, sanitation, and safety requirements under this article. 
(h)  A body art studio must be in a permanent building or portion of a building. No permits shall be issued for mobile locations. 
(Code 1988, § 3-301; Ord. No. 2005-67, § 2, 8-23-2005)  
Sec. 3-302. - Inspections; operating requirements related to health. 
(a)  Inspections. Every body art studio shall be subject to unannounced inspections by the health department, to be conducted in the reasonable discretion of the health department. All areas of the body art studio shall be accessible for inspection. Without limitation, the health department may also inspect sterilizing and cleaning equipment for proper maintenance and functioning, and it may require reasonable testing of such equipment, with documentation. 
(b)  Operating requirements. Every permit holder shall at all times comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  General health and safety requirements. All tattooing-related and piercing-related procedures shall be carried out in a clean, safe and sanitary manner as approved by the health department so as to minimize the potential of disease transmission. All procedures should be performed using aseptic technique, observing universal precaution standards. There shall be no smoking, eating, or drinking in the area in which body art is performed, except for individually packaged food or drink for client's use in order to sustain optimal physical condition. 
(2)  Compliance with federal, state, and local laws generally. All areas of the body art studio shall be constructed and maintained in a clean, safe and sanitary manner in compliance with all applicable statutes, laws, regulations, codes and ordinances of the city, the commonwealth (including without limitation the state board for barbers and cosmetology), and applicable federal agencies (including without limitation the Center for Disease Control). 
(3)  Training and vaccination requirements. All permit holders shall be required to complete annual health education training in bloodborne pathogens, universal precautions, sterilization, aseptic techniques, first aid, and CPR. Training shall be as approved by the health director. Permit holders shall also provide documentation of hepatitis B vaccination (or laboratory evidence of immunity) and annual TB screening. 
(4)  Floors, walls, and ceilings. All walls, ceilings and floors shall be a light color, maintained in a condition free of dirt, body fluids or any hazardous material and shall be smooth and easily cleaned. The floors shall not be carpeted, and neither rugs nor fabrics of any kind shall be placed on the floors. Walls and ceilings shall be painted a light color and maintained in a condition free of dirt, body fluids, or any hazardous waste. Ceilings shall be kept clean and free from dust and debris. Walls, ceilings or floors shall not be generally swept or cleaned while tattooing is occurring, except that individual and visible unsanitary debris items or conditions are to be corrected at the earliest practicable opportunity. 
(5)  Work station requirements. Multiple body art booths shall be separated by walls or wall-like partitions, and each body artist shall have an assigned work area. Booths shall not be shared during work shifts. There shall be sufficient work and counter space to maintain sterile fields and to separate dirty and contaminated materials from sanitized tools, instruments, and materials. Sharps containers and foot-operated waste receptacles shall be located in every booth and in the sterilization room. Sterilization shall occur in an area adequately separated from booths, patrons, and the public. 
(6)  Animals, insects, vermin, and rodents. No animals shall be allowed, except for guide or service animals accompanying persons with disabilities; except that nonmammalian animals in enclosed glass containers, such as aquariums will be allowed in waiting areas and administrative offices. Effective measures for prevention and control of insects, vermin, and rodents shall be taken, including without limitation screened openings and automatic door closures. 
(7)  Light, ventilation and dust. Adequate light, ventilation, and dust control shall be provided. 
(8)  Toilet and hand-washing facilities. There shall be adequate toilet and hand-washing facilities with germicidal soap and hot and cold running water, connected to public water under pressure. Hand-washing facilities shall also be equipped with single-use towels or mechanical hand-drying devices. Every booth shall have a sink, preferably with foot controls. There shall be a separate room for sterilization, with a sharps container and a sink, preferably with foot controls. Facilities for personal use shall be separate and isolated from the business area in which body art is performed. Toilets and washing facilities shall be maintained in a sanitary condition at all times. 
(9)  Tattoo supplies. All inks, dyes, pigments, needles and equipment used in tattooing shall be specifically manufactured for performing tattooing and shall be used in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. The mixing of approved tattooing inks, dyes or pigments or their dilutions with potable water shall be permitted. Immediately before a tattoo is applied, the quantity of the dye to be used shall be transferred from the dye bottle and placed into single-use paper or plastic cups. Upon completion of the procedure, the cups and their contents shall be discarded in a proper manner and in compliance with any applicable state or federal guidelines or requirements. 
(10)  Single-use items. Single-use items shall not be used on more than one client for any reason. All materials for tattooing to be applied directly to the human skin shall be single use articles or transferred from bulk containers to single use containers. After use, all single-use needles, razors, and other sharps shall be immediately disposed of in accordance with applicable regulations. 
(11)  Cleaning and sterilization of nondisposable instruments. Reusable instruments shall be promptly soaked in a germicidal or soap solution after use, whenever practicable, to prevent drying of contaminated material. All nondisposable instruments used in connection with body art shall be sterilized before each use by rinsing, then scrubbing with appropriate soap/disinfectant in hot water and then preferably placed in an ultrasonic cleaner, prior to sterilization in a steam autoclave approved by the health department. Sterilization shall be performed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, a copy of which shall be submitted, with contact information, as part of the permit application. Establishments shall have a backup plan to be used in the event of sterilization equipment failure. 
(12)  Sterilization documentation. The body art operator shall be responsible for maintaining a log which indicates that the autoclave or other sterilizer has been checked during each cycle and has been sterilized in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. It shall include monthly tests to demonstrate monthly spore destructions tests, with satisfactory results. The log shall be maintained in a manner that is traceable to the client on which the clean instrument is next used. 
(13)  Proper storage and disposal. All cleaned and ready-to-use needles and instruments shall be stored in a protective manner to prevent subsequent contamination. Sterile equipment shall not be used after the expiration date or if the package has been breached. If disposable instruments are used, those instruments shall be disposed of in accordance with applicable laws. All hazardous waste, body fluids, and medical waste of any kind shall be disposed of in accordance with the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality's Regulated Medical Waste Regulations, 9 VAC 20-120-10 et seq., as amended, or any successor regulation. 
(14)  Jewelry/ornamentation. All jewelry used in body piercing shall be made only of surgical implant grade stainless steel, solid 14K or 18K white or yellow gold, niobium, titanium, platinum, or dense and low-porosity plastic. All jewelry shall be free of nicks, scratches or irregular surfaces and shall be in a properly sterilized condition when used. 
(15)  Hand washing and gloves. The body artist shall wash his hands with liquid germicidal soap or use a sanitizing solution between customers, between tattooing or piercing different parts of the body on the same person, and whenever gloves are changed. Hands should be washed when visibly soiled. The body artist shall wear protective, disposable latex or vinyl gloves while tattooing, and shall wear a new pair of gloves for each client and when tattooing or piercing different parts of the same client. Gloves shall also be changed for any interruption of service, each time gloves become torn or perforated, or whenever the ability of the gloves to function as a barrier is compromised. 
(16)  Communicable diseases. No tattoo may be administered by any person having a communicable disease until they have provided a written statement to the department of professional and occupational regulation from a health care practitioner that the artist's condition no longer poses a threat to public health. Body artists having draining lesions on their hands or face will not be permitted to work until cleared by a health care professional. Body art should not be performed on any skin surface which manifests any evidence of unhealthy conditions such as rashes, boils, infections, or abrasions. 
(17)  Client screening and disclosure. Before performing any body art procedure, the body artist shall inform the client that the performance of a body art procedure may involve health risks if the client has any of the following conditions or medical history: 
a.  History of diabetes or other immune disorders; 
b.  History of hemophilia or other bleeding disorders; 
c.  History of skin diseases, skin lesions, keloidal scarring, or skin sensitivities to soaps, disinfectants, etc.; 
d.  History of allergies, adverse reaction to pigments or dyes, latex, or other skin sensitivities; 
e.  History of epilepsy, seizures, fainting, or narcolepsy; 
f.  Current or recent medications such as anticoagulants that thin the blood or interfere with blood clotting; and 
g.  Any other information that may affect the client's capacity to heal from body art. 
If the body artist becomes aware that the client has any of the above conditions, or if any information is disclosed which creates reasonable questions about the client's capacity to safely undergo a body art procedure; then the body artist should recommend that the client seek medical advice prior to receiving a body art procedure. 
(18)  After care instructions. Immediately after performing body art on a patron, the body artist shall provide oral and written instructions advising the patron of proper care of the affected area and shall instruct the patron to consult a physician at the first sign of infection. 
(19)  Exposure control plan. Each establishment shall be required to develop an exposure control plan for the protection of workers and patrons from bloodborne infections. This plan shall include documentation of required immunizations, notification, documentation and procedures for care of workers in the event of an exposure. This plan shall be subject to approval by the health director, and it shall not be approved unless it meets with reasonable public health standards. 
(Code 1988, § 3-302; Ord. No. 2005-67, § 2, 8-23-2005)  
Sec. 3-303. - Operating requirements related to business practices and public policy. 
(a)  No person shall work as a body artist in any location other than a body art studio. 
(b)  Each body artist shall provide each client, prior to performing body art, a legible written disclosure stating substantially as follows: 
(1)  Body art is an invasive procedure in which the skin is penetrated by a foreign object; 
(2)  If proper sterilization and antiseptic procedures are not followed by body artists, there is a risk of transmission of bloodborne pathogens and other infections, including, but not limited to, human immunodeficiency viruses and hepatitis B or C viruses; 
(3)  Body art may cause allergic reactions in persons sensitive to dyes or the metals used in ornamentation; 
(4)  Body art may involve discomfort or pain for which appropriate anesthesia cannot be legally made available by the tattoo artist unless such person holds the appropriate license from a Virginia Health Regulatory Board. 
(c)  Records for each patron, and all other written records required by this chapter, shall be maintained by the body art studio operator for a minimum period of four years. At such time as the body art studio ceases doing business or is removed from the city or has a change in ownership, copies of all such records shall be provided to the health department. The records shall be subject to inspection by the health department at any time and shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, telephone number, sex, age, date of birth, and type and copy of identification provided by the person receiving body art; 
(2)  Date of body art; 
(3)  Physical location and description of body art; 
(4)  Name, address and telephone number of the person performing the body art; 
(5)  For tattooing, name and address of the manufacturer of the dyes used as well as identifying information about the dye solutions and types of dyes used. For piercing, the content and type of body jewelry used. If a customer has need for this information, then the body art operator shall release it to the customer without charge; 
(6)  Sterilization log number (in client record) of all re-usable instruments used on the client; 
(7)  Consent form with signatures of the artist, client, and if applicable, parent or guardian, and a statement that the client has received a copy of applicable written care instructions, and that the client has read and understands the instructions; 
(8)  Any report of an adverse event or adverse reaction during or following body art procedure. 
(d)  No body art shall be done in any location, which, even though inside a body art studio, is visible from a public way, street, or sidewalk. 
(e)  No person shall perform body art, and no body art studio, shall be open for business earlier than 7:00 a.m. or later than 2:00 a.m. Provided, however, that if body art is commenced prior to 2:00 a.m., then it may be completed, even if after 2:00 a.m. In any such case, the burden shall be upon the body artist to prove that the body art was commenced at a legal time. 
(f)  There shall be no sale, offering for sale, display, or exhibit in a body art studio of any drug paraphernalia, including without limitation such items as rolling papers, rolling machines, bongs, roach clips, water pipes, crack pipes, and hookahs. 
(g)  No person shall state or imply in any advertisement or publication, written or oral and prepared or uttered for the purpose of soliciting business, that a body art studio is endorsed, regulated or approved by the city or by any of its departments or is conducted in compliance with the terms of this section. 
(h)  No tattoo artist shall tattoo, and no body piercer shall pierce, any sexually private area of a member of the opposite sex. 
(Code 1988, § 3-303; Ord. No. 2005-67, § 2, 8-23-2005)  
Sec. 3-304. - Unlawful acts and practices. 
It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)  To perform or administer body art without a permit, or in violation of any other requirement of this chapter. 
(2)  To be a body art studio operator of any body art studio which does not have: 
a.  Current zoning clearance under chapter 40; 
b.  A current permit from the health department; 
c.  A current business license from the city; and 
d.  A current certificate of occupancy for use as a body art studio, as applicable, issued by the building official. 
(3)  To perform or administer body art to any person less than 18 years of age, knowing or having reason to believe such person is less than 18 years of age except: (i) in the presence of the person's parent or guardian, or (ii) when done by or under the supervision of a medical doctor, registered nurse or other medical services personnel licensed pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 54.1-100 et seq. in the performance of their duties. 
(4)  To perform or administer body art to any person who is under the influence of alcohol, or who is under the influence of drugs, or who is so mentally retarded, challenged, or disoriented as to be unable to make an intelligent decision, or who is acting under coercion of any type, or who for any reason is not capable of making an informed, intelligent, and voluntary decision to obtain body art. 
(5)  To perform or administer body art while under the influence of alcohol or while under the influence of drugs, or following diagnosis of a communicable disease prior to obtaining a written statement from a health care practitioner that the condition no longer poses a threat to public health. 
(6)  To perform branding, scarification, or implant any metal, plastic, or other solid device under a person's skin so that it is largely or completely concealed by the skin. 
(Code 1988, § 3-304; Ord. No. 2005-67, § 2, 8-23-2005)  
Sec. 3-305. - Penalties and enforcement. 
(a)  Violations of section 3-302. Any first violation of section 3-302 (operating requirements related to health) shall constitute cause for revocation of the permit of any responsible party by the health director. Revocation shall be for a fixed period not to exceed two years. The health director may in lieu of revocation impose other sanctions, including without limitation suspension of permit for a fixed period of time not to exceed two years, suspension with reinstatement permit only on certain conditions, and operation under probation with or without conditions. For a second or subsequent offense, the health director may impose any of said sanctions without limit as to time and may also make the permit holder ineligible for re-licensure. 
(b)  Violations of section 3-303. Any first violation of section 3-303 (operating requirements related to business practices and public policy) shall constitute cause for revocation for up to two years of the business license of the permit holder and/or the zoning clearance of the body art studio by the city manager or his designee. The city manager or his designee may also impose other sanctions, including without limitation suspension of business license and/or zoning clearance for a fixed period of time not to exceed two years, and operation under probation with or without conditions. For a second or subsequent offense, the city manager or his designee may impose permanent revocation. 
(c)  Violations of section 3-304. Any violation of section 3-304 (unlawful acts and practices) shall be a class 2 misdemeanor for a first offense, and a class 1 misdemeanor for any second or subsequent offense. A final conviction shall also constitute cause for the health director to impose any of the sanctions set forth in subsection (a) of this section, or for the city manager or his designee to set forth the sanctions set forth in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Injunctive relief. In addition to, and not in lieu of, the other sanctions set forth in this section, the city shall, upon proper application, be entitled to injunctive relief to prevent any subsequent or recurring violation of any section of this chapter by any person. The city shall not be required to show the absence of an adequate remedy at law in order to be entitled to injunctive relief. 
(Code 1988, § 3-305; Ord. No. 2005-67, § 2, 8-23-2005)  
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Keeping of live animal or fowl in food establishment, § 15-77; application of traffic regulations to persons driving or riding animals, § 22-6; prohibition against keeping animals which cause unnecessary noise, § 24-255(b)(3); riding horses in parks, § 25-107; hunting or molesting wildlife in parks, § 25-109; animals not permitted within public swimming pool, § 34-68; protection from animals of trees and shrubs growing on city property, § 36-34. 
State Law reference— Comprehensive animal laws, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.66 et seq.; authority of city to adopt ordinances paralleling animal laws, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.94. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  Words defined by statute. The words and phrases used in this chapter shall, for the purposes of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6500 as in effect on July 1, 2015, and any subsequent amendments thereto, except in those instances where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
(b)  General definitions. For the purposes of this chapter, unless otherwise expressly stated, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
Dangerous dog means a canine or canine crossbreed that has bitten, attacked, or inflicted injury on a person or companion animal, or killed a companion animal; however, when a dog attacks or bites another dog, the attacking or biting dog shall not be deemed dangerous: (i) if no serious physical injury as determined by a licensed veterinarian has occurred to the other dog as a result of the attack or bite, or (ii) both dogs are owned by the same person. No dog shall be found to be a dangerous dog as a result of biting, attacking or inflicting injury on another dog while engaged with an owner or custodian as part of lawful hunting or participating in an organized, lawful dog handling event. 
Destructive animal means any animal that damages, destroys or attacks any building, fence, cage, enclosure, livestock, fowl, animal or any other thing not the property of the owner or keeper of the dog. 
Exotic animal means any live monkey (nonhuman primate), wolf-hybrid, hybrid-feline, ratite, porcine or any other warm-blooded animal or any reptile six feet or longer in length, which can normally be found in the wild state or any other member of the crocodilian, including, but not limited to, alligators, crocodiles, caimans, and gavials. Ferrets and birds which are normally purchased through pet stores (with the exception of ratites), nonpoisonous reptiles less than six feet in length, domestic rabbits and domestic rodents which have been bred in captivity and which never have known the wild shall be excluded from this definition. 
Vicious animal means any animal that has bitten any person or an animal that repeatedly attacks or attempts to bite any person. 
Vicious dog means a canine or canine crossbreed that has: (i) killed a person; (ii) inflicted serious injury to a person, including multiple bites, serious disfigurement, serious impairment of health, or serious impairment of a bodily function; or (iii) continued to exhibit the behavior that resulted in a previous finding by a court, as authorized by local ordinance, that it is a dangerous dog, provided that its owner has been given notice of that finding. 
(Code 1988, § 4-16; Ord. No. 1990-57, § 2, 6-12-1990; Ord. No. 2016-13, § 1, 2-23-2016) 
State Law reference— Definitions, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.66.  
Sec. 4-2. - Animal control officer. 
(a)  The city manager shall appoint an animal control officer for the city. The manager may appoint such deputy animal control officers as he deems necessary to assist the animal control officer in the performance of his duties. The animal control officer and his deputies shall hold office at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(b)  The animal control officer and his deputies shall have the power to enforce this chapter, the Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6500 et seq. and all ordinances and state laws for the protection of domestic animals. The animal control officer and his deputies shall have the power to issue a summons as authorized by Code of Virginia, § 3.2-6555. 
(Code 1973, § 4-11; Code 1988, § 4-2; Ord. No. 2016-13, § 2, 2-23-2016) 
State Law reference— Duty to appoint animal control officer, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.104.  
Sec. 4-3. - City designated bird sanctuary; signs. 
(a)  The city, within its corporate limits, shall be a bird sanctuary for the protection of all birds protected by the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, adopted by the Congress of the United States. This provision shall not include starlings, English sparrows or pigeons. 
(b)  Signs stating that the city is a bird sanctuary may be erected in the city. Such signs shall be of such type and erected at such public places as may be approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 4-4; Code 1988, § 4-3)  
Sec. 4-4. - Killing, molesting birds. 
It shall be unlawful and a class 1 misdemeanor for any person to kill or injure any birds or destroy or injure the nest or eggs of any birds for which the city is a bird sanctuary. 
(Code 1973, §§ 4-5, 4-51; Code 1988, § 4-4) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 4-5. - Livestock or poultry running at large. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to allow horses, cows, goats, sheep, swine or other livestock or poultry to run at large in the city. 
(Code 1973, §§ 4-6, 4-51; Code 1988, § 4-8) 
Cross reference— Animals at large in parks, § 25-108. 
State Law reference— Authority to prohibit animals and fowl from running at large, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.93.  
Sec. 4-6. - Vicious or destructive animals running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any animal belonging to him or under his control, and known by him to be dangerous, mischievous, vicious or destructive, to run at large in the city. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of the section shall be deemed guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, §§ 4-3, 4-51; Code 1988, § 4-9; Ord. No. 1990-57, § 1, 6-12-1990) 
State Law reference— Authority to prohibit animals from running at large, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.93.  
Sec. 4-7. - Cruelty to animals. 
(a)  Any person who: (i) overrides, overdrives, overloads, tortures, ill-treats, abandons, willfully inflicts inhumane injury or pain not connected with bona fide scientific or medical experimentation, or cruelly or unnecessarily beats, maims, mutilates, or kills any animal, whether belonging to himself or another; (ii) deprives any animal of necessary food, drink, shelter or emergency veterinary treatment; (iii) sores any equine for any purpose or administers drugs or medications to alter or mask such soring for the purpose of sale, show, or exhibition of any kind, unless such administration of drugs or medications is within the context of a veterinary client-patient relationship and solely for therapeutic purposes; (iv) willfully sets on foot, instigates, engages in, or in any way furthers any act of cruelty to any animal; (v) carries or causes to be carried in or upon any vehicle, vessel or otherwise any animal in a cruel, brutal, or inhumane manner, so as to produce torture or unnecessary suffering; or (vi) causes any of the above things, or being the owner of such animal permits such acts to be done by another, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the dehorning of cattle. 
(c)  The word "animal," as used in this section, shall be construed to include birds and fowl. 
(Code 1973, §§ 4-1, 4-51; Code 1988, § 4-10) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11; mistreatment or interference with police animals, § 24-282. 
State Law reference— Specific authority to adopt above section, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.94; general authority of city to prevent cruelty to animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.115; cruelty to animals, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.122.  
Sec. 4-8. - Disposal of dead animals and fowl generally. 
(a)  When the owner of any animal or grown fowl which has died knows of such death, such owner shall forthwith have its body cremated or buried and, if he fails to do so, the judge of the general district court, after notice to the owner if he can be ascertained, shall cause such dead animal or fowl to be cremated or buried by an officer or other person designated for the purpose. Such officer or other person shall be entitled to recover of the owner of every such animal so cremated or buried the actual cost of the cremation or burial, not to exceed the amount set out in appendix A to this Code, and of the owner of every such fowl so cremated or buried the actual cost of the cremation or burial, not to exceed the amount set out in appendix A to this Code, to be recovered in the same manner as officers' fees are recovered, free from all exemptions in favor of such owner. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to require the burial or cremation of the whole or portions of any animal or fowl which is to be used for food or in any commercial manner. 
(c)  This section shall also apply to dead dogs and other companion animals. 
(Code 1988, § 4-12; Ord. No. 1993-47, § 1, 6-22-1993) 
Cross reference— Collection of small dead animals by city and charge therefor, §§ 16-34(d), 16-67; large dead animals not to be collected by city, § 16-39. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-510.  
Sec. 4-9. - Standards for keeping animals and household pets; harboring stray animals. 
(a)  All animals, including household pets, shall be kept or maintained so as not to constitute a public nuisance by concentration or number, causing production of insects, excessive odor, dust, noise, or other conditions detrimental to the community health and welfare. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to fail to provide any animal with adequate space. "Adequate space" means sufficient space to allow each animal to (i) easily stand, sit, lie, turn about, and make all other normal body movements in a comfortable, normal position for the animal and (ii) interact safely with other animals in the enclosure. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to chain, stake out, or tether any animal on any premises in such a manner that the animal may go beyond its own property line unless such person has permission from the owner of the affected property. At no time shall an animal be allowed to be staked out, chained or tethered in a manner, which allows the animal to cross onto city property. 
(d)  Animals, which are staked out, chained, or tethered outside on any property, shall be 15 feet away from the property line, and at no time shall an animal be permitted to be chained, staked out or tethered outside on a balcony that is above ground level. 
(e)  When an animal is tethered, "adequate space" means a tether that permits the above actions and is appropriate to the age and size of the animal. The tether must be attached to the animal by a properly applied collar, halter, or harness configured so as to protect the animal from injury and prevent the animal or the tether from becoming entangled with other objects or animals, or from extending over an object or edge that could result in the strangulation or injury of the animal. For dogs, the tether must be at least three times the length of the dog, as measured from the tip of its nose to the base of its tail, except when the dog is being walked on a leash or is attached by a tether to a lead line. When freedom of movement would endanger the animal, temporarily and appropriately restricting movement of the animal according to professionally accepted standards is considered to be provision of adequate space. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful to tether a dog or to leave a dog tethered unless the dog is attended at all times. For purposes of this section, a dog is attended only if the owner is both outdoors with the dog and within 35 feet of the dog. 
(g)  Without having first reported finding a lost or stray companion or domestic animal to the city's animal control unit or Portsmouth Humane Society or other entity serving as the city's public animal shelter, it shall be unlawful for any person, to allow the animal to remain on their property, harbor or keep such lost or stray animal for a period in excess of seven days. After seven days the person allowing the above actions shall be considered to be the owner/custodian of that animal and shall be responsible for that animal. 
(h)  Only the Portsmouth Humane Society or other entity serving as the city's public animal shelter is authorized to keep such lost or stray animals for any period in excess of seven days. 
(Code 1988, § 4-13; Ord. No. 1989-26, § 1(4-2), 4-11-1989; Ord. No. 2012-55, § 1, 9-25-2012; Ord. No. 2016-13, § 3, 2-23-2016; Ord. No. 2017-73 , § 1, 8-22-17) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.66.  
Sec. 4-10. - Keeping of dogs and cats. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain an accessory structure for the housing of dogs or cats on land zoned for residential use in the city that exceeds, in floor area, one-half percent of the lot area. Neither the building nor any fence-enclosed roaming area shall be located closer than 15 feet from a property line. The accessory structure, pen or enclosed roaming area shall be located only in rear yards. 
(b)  No more than five dogs above the age of six months may be kept in any one dwelling unit or premises within the city limits. 
(Code 1988, § 4-14; Ord. No. 1989-26, § 1(4-14), 4-11-1989) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-796.94:1.  
Sec. 4-11. - Wild, dangerous or carnivorous animals, or dangerous or poisonous reptiles or serpents. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep within this city an elephant, bear, leopard, lion, tiger, panther, bobcat, wolf, raccoon, skunk, fox, opossum or any dangerous or carnivorous wild animal, or dangerous or poisonous reptiles or serpents.
