The use of cutouts is prohibited, except for motorboats competing in a regatta or boat race approved as provided in section 6-63 and for such motorboats while on trial runs, during a period not to exceed 48 hours immediately preceding such regatta or race and for such motorboats while competing in official trials for speed records during a period not to exceed 48 hours immediately following such regatta or race. The use of cutouts is prohibited, except as approved by the state or the U.S. Coast Guard. 
(Code 1973, § 23-500; Code 1988, § 6-64) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 29.1-737.  
Sec. 6-65. - Speed limits for motorboats. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating any motorboat to pass under any bridge in the city at a speed in excess of five miles per hour. No motorboats shall be operated in any area designated as a "No Wake" area by the city manager at such speed as to create more than a minimum wake. 
(b)  No person shall be convicted of violating this section until appropriate signs indicating the speed limit of five miles per hour or "No Wake" have been posted so as to give notice of such restrictions. The city manager is hereby authorized to have posted such signs as may be required by this section. 
(Code 1973, § 23-508; Code 1988, § 6-65; Ord. No. 1998-22, § 1, 4-28-1998) 
State Law reference— Application and placement or removal of no-wake buoys, etc., Code of Virginia, § 29.1-744.  
Sec. 6-66. - Observer required in towing boat unless skier wears life preserver. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorboat on any waters in this city for towing a person on water skis, surfboard or other device, unless another person is in such motorboat, in addition to the operator, in a position to observe the progress of the person being towed, or unless the person being towed wears a life preserver. 
(Code 1973, § 23-501; Code 1988, § 6-66) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 29.1-742.  
Sec. 6-67. - Skiing prohibited during certain hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorboat on any waters in this city towing a person on water skis, surfboard or similar device between the hours from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise, and it shall be unlawful for any person to engage in water skiing or a similar activity on any of the waters in the city during these hours. 
(Code 1973, § 23-502; Code 1988, § 6-67) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 29.1-742.  
Sec. 6-68. - Exceptions from sections 6-66 and 6-67. 
The provisions of sections 6-66 and 6-67 shall not apply to a performer engaged in a professional exhibition or to a person engaged in an activity authorized by section 6-63. 
(Code 1973, § 23-502; Code 1988, § 6-68) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 29.1-742.  
Sec. 6-69. - Passing too close to capsized boats. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating any motorboat towing water skis, or a surfboard or similar device, or for the person being towed, to pass within 100 feet of any motorboat, sailboat or other watercraft which has capsized, unless such boat is effecting a rescue or rendering aid or assistance, or unless such boat is operated wholly within a marked channel and if such boat has reduced its speed to five miles per hour. 
(Code 1973, § 23-512; Code 1988, § 6-69)  
Sec. 6-70. - Passing too close to swimmers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating a motorboat or a motorboat towing water skis, a surfboard or similar device, or for the person being towed, to pass within 100 feet of any swimmer. For the purpose of this section, a fallen water skier or surfboarder shall be considered a swimmer. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any person operating a motorboat while effecting a rescue or rendering aid or assistance, or to any motorboat operating wholly within a marked channel, if such boat has reduced its speed to five miles per hour. 
(Code 1973, § 23-510; Code 1988, § 6-70)  
Sec. 6-71. - Skiing near piers, shores, bulkheads, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating a motorboat and towing a person on water skis, a surfboard or similar device, or for the person being towed, to pass within 50 feet of any pier, shoreline, bulkhead, bridge or anchored or drifting boat or vessel unless such motorboat is operated wholly within a marked channel or unless such person is "taking off" on water skis, surfboard or other similar device or "landing" from water skis, surfboard or other similar device from private property with the consent of the owner. 
(Code 1973, § 23-509; Code 1988, § 6-71)  
Sec. 6-72. - Motorboat following too close to skiers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating any motorboat to follow any person on water skis or a surfboard or similar device closer than 100 feet. 
(Code 1973, § 23-511; Code 1988, § 6-72)  
Sec. 6-73. - Causing skis or person thereon to collide with object or person. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or manipulate any motorboat, tow rope or other device by which the direction or location of water skis, surfboards and similar devices may be affected or controlled in such a way as to cause the water skis, surfboards or similar devices, or any person thereon, to collide with any object or person. 
(Code 1973, § 23-503; Code 1988, § 6-73) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 29.1-742.  
Sec. 6-74. - Flags for skin and scuba divers. 
(a)  No person shall engage in skin diving or scuba diving from a boat in the waters of the city which are open to boating or assist in such diving, without displaying a diver's flag from a mast, buoy or other structure at the place of diving, and no person shall display such flag, except when diving operations are under way or in preparation or display a diver's flag in a location which will unreasonably obstruct vessels from making legitimate navigational use of the water. 
(b)  The diver's flag required by this section shall be square, not less than 12 inches on a side, and shall be of red background with a diagonal white stripe, of a width equal to one-fifth of the flag's height, running from the upper corner adjacent to the mast downward to the opposite outside corner. 
(c)  No operator of a vessel under way in the waters of the city shall permit such vessel to approach closer than 25 yards to any structure from which a diver's flag is then being displayed as required by this section. 
(Code 1988, § 6-74) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 29.1-734.1.  
Sec. 6-75. - Reckless operation of boat or manipulation of skis, etc. 
(a)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motorboat or other vessel, or manipulate any water skis, surfboard or similar device or engage in any spearfishing while skin diving or scuba diving, on any of the waters in the city in a reckless manner so as to endanger the life, limb or property of any person. 
(b)  Penalty for violation generally. A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(c)  Operating boat in an improper manner; penalty. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, upon the trial of any person charged with reckless boating where the degree of culpability is slight, the court, in its discretion, may find the accused not guilty of reckless boating but guilty of improper boating. Improper boating shall be punishable as a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, §§ 23-505, 23-506; Code 1988, § 6-75; Ord. No. 1988-62, § 2, 6-28-1988; Ord. No. 1991-63, § 1, 6-25-1991) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 29.1-738.  
Sec. 6-76. - Operating boat while under influence of intoxicants or drugs. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motorboat or vessel on any of the waters of the city while under the influence of alcohol, any narcotic drug or other self-administered intoxicant or drug of whatsoever nature, or any combination of such alcohol, intoxicants or drugs, as provided in Code of Virginia, § 29.1-738 et seq. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 23-506; Code 1988, § 6-76; Ord. No. 1988-62, § 2, 6-28-1988) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 29.1-738.  
Sec. 6-77. - Creation of loud, unreasonable, etc., noise by persons aboard boat. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, while aboard any motorboat, vessel, barge or any other watercraft, whether under way, drifting, berthed or at anchor, to make or create any loud, disturbing or unreasonable noise of such character, intensity or duration as to be detrimental to the health or life of any person or to unreasonably disturb or annoy the quiet, comfort or repose of any person. 
(Code 1973, § 23-513; Code 1988, § 6-77)  
Sec. 6-78. - Disregarding signal by law enforcement officer to stop. 
Any person who, having received a visible or audible signal of a flashing light or siren from any game warden or other law enforcement officer to bring his motorboat or other vessel to a stop, fails to do so promptly shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 6-78; Ord. No. 1993-48, § 1, 6-22-1993)  
Chapter 7 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Erosion and sediment control, excavations, ch. 11; fire prevention and protection generally, ch. 13; fire suppression systems required for certain buildings, § 13-1; smoke detectors for buildings, § 13-131 et seq.; flood protection, ch. 14.1; litter receptacles required for construction sites, § 16-7(b)(6); control of trash, debris, etc., at construction sites, § 16-8; construction debris not to be collected by city, § 16-39; housing and community development, ch. 17; minimum standards for nonresidential structures, § 17-101 et seq.; vacant buildings, § 17-131 et seq.; purchase of secondhand building material, § 18-76 et seq.; license tax on contractors and persons constructing for their own account for sale, § 20-14; license tax on rental of residential property, § 20-68; mobile homes, ch. 21; prohibition against construction activities at night in residential districts, § 24-255(b)(11); security alarms, ch. 31; streets and sidewalks and local improvements, ch. 32; establishment and verification of street lines upon erection of structure, § 32-4; sidewalk barriers required for certain repair work on buildings, § 32-15; maintenance of cellar doors or vaults in sidewalks, § 32-16; building setback lines, § 32-91 et seq.; subdivisions, ch. 33.1; swimming pools, ch. 34; water, sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 38; wetlands, ch. 39; zoning, ch. 40.1. 
State Law reference— General authority of city relative to building regulations, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-117, 36-105—36-105.3. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 7-1. - Violations of chapter. 
Except as otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this chapter, including any provision of the building code adopted by section 7-96, shall constitute a misdemeanor. Any owner or any other person, firm, or corporation convicted of such a violation shall be punished by a fine of not more than $2,500.00. In addition, each day the violation continues after conviction has expired shall constitute a separate offense. If the violation remains uncorrected at the time of the conviction, the court shall order the violator to abate or remedy the violation. Except as otherwise provided by the court for good cause shown, any such violator shall abate or remedy the violation within six months of the date of conviction. Each day during which the violation continues after the court-ordered abatement period has ended shall constitute a separate offense. Any person convicted of a second offense committed within less than five years after a first offense under this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $2,500.00. Any person convicted of a second offense committed with a period of five to ten years of a first offense under this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $500.00 nor more than $2,500.00. Any person convicted of a third or subsequent offense involving the same property committed within ten years of an offense under this chapter after having been at least twice previously convicted shall be punished by confinement in jail for not more than ten days and a fine of not less than $2,500.00 nor more than $5,000.00, either or both. No portion of the fine imposed for such third or subsequent offense committed within ten years of an offense under this chapter shall be suspended. 
(Code 1988, § 7-1; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, 4-8-2003) 
State Law reference— Penalty for building code violations, Code of Virginia, § 36-106.  
Sec. 7-2. - Contractor's registration and bond. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every building, electrical, mechanical or plumbing contractor who makes contracts for work for which a permit is required, and every contractor or subcontractor making such contracts and subletting the same or any part thereof, to register, with the building official, giving his full name and the addresses of his residence and place of business. In case of a change in either such address, he shall have a corresponding change made in such register. It shall be the further duty of every such contractor or subcontractor not licensed by the Virginia Department of Professional and Occupational Regulation to give good and sufficient bond, in the sum of $5,000.00, to be approved by the department of law of the city, payable to the city with surety conditioned to indemnify and save harmless the city as well as any other person from all expense and damage that may be caused by any negligent, defective or inadequate work done in the city under his certificate, license or direction and to secure the payment of all required fees and to secure and ensure his compliance with the regulations of the building official and the building code and other ordinances or laws of the city. 
(b)  When any work done by a contractor or subcontractor not licensed by the Virginia Department of Professional and Occupational Regulation is deemed defective or inadequate by the inspector from the building inspection division of the department of permits and inspections and the contractor or subcontractor fails to revise or put such work in proper condition to the satisfaction of the inspector within ten days after written notification to do so sent to the address shown in the register provided for in subsection (a) of this section, the bond posted pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall be forfeited and the principal and surety thereon shall be and become liable for and shall pay so much on account of such bond as may be necessary in order to perfect such work and, in addition thereto, shall pay any and all damages which may be occasioned to any person by reason of such defective or inadequate work. 
(Code 1973, § 6-18; Code 1988, § 7-2; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, 4-8-2003; Ord. No. 2010-51, § 1, 6-22-2010) 
Cross reference— License tax on contractors and persons constructing for their own account for sale, § 20-14.  
Sec. 7-3. - Bond for moving contractors. 
It shall be the duty of the moving contractor engaged in moving buildings to give good and sufficient bond in the penal sum of $50,000.00, to be approved by the department of law, payable to the city with surety conditioned to indemnify and save harmless the city from all expense and damage that may be caused by any negligent, defective or inadequate work or any act done as a result of the moving of any building or structure and against any and all claims, actions or causes of action which may accrue as a result thereof, and to secure and ensure such moving contractor's compliance with the regulations of the building official and the building code and other ordinances or laws of the city. In addition to liability for any damages or indemnification to the city or to any person by reason of such negligence or defective or inadequate work, when any work done by a moving contractor is deemed defective or inadequate or to be not in compliance with the regulations of the building official or the building code or other ordinances or laws of the city, and the contractor shall fail to revise or put such work in proper condition or comply with any regulation, code, ordinance or law to the satisfaction of the building official within seven days after written notification to the contractor's address as provided by the contractor at the time of making application for a certificate of use and occupancy for the new location, the bond shall be forfeited, and the principal and surety on such bond shall be and become liable to the city or to any person for damages sustained, for the sum of $50,000.00. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-3)  
Sec. 7-4. - Numbering of buildings. 
(a)  All buildings within the limits of the city shall be numbered in accordance with a plan heretofore or hereafter adopted and established by the city council. The owner shall number every building using such number as may be designated by the building official. With each permit issued for the erection of the new building, the building official shall designate the number for the building. 
(b)  The building official may, from time to time, to eliminate confusion, change the numbers of buildings by giving written notice of such change to the owner or tenant, the post office and utility companies. The owner or tenant shall, within seven days of receipt of such notice, affix the new number and remove the old number. 
(Code 1973, § 6-10; Code 1988, § 7-4) 
State Law reference— Authority to require numbering of buildings, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-22024.  
Secs. 7-5—7-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DEPARTMENT OF PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 
 
Sec. 7-31. - Created; appointment, removal, etc., of building official. 
The department of permits and inspections is hereby created and the executive official in charge thereof shall be known as the building official, who shall be appointed by the city manager. The building official shall not be removed from office except for cause, and after full opportunity has been granted him to be heard on specific and relevant charges by and before the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 6-7(a); Code 1988, § 7-31; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, 4-8-2003)  
Sec. 7-32. - Division of building inspection. 
(a)  The building official shall have general supervision of the division of building inspections of the department of permits and inspections. The division of building inspection of the department of permits and inspections shall be immediately supervised by the assistant to the building official/plans examiner, who shall have such assistants as may, from time to time, be authorized by the city manager and appointed by the building official. 
(b)  The assistant to the building official/plans examiner shall have any combination equivalent to five years of experience in the field of building construction and including two years of experience as a building inspector. 
(c)  Each building inspector shall have at least four years' experience in the field of building construction. 
(Code 1973, § 6-7(e); Code 1988, § 7-32; Ord. No. 1990-41, § 3, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, 4-8-2003)  
Secs. 7-33—7-95. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 7-96. - Adopted. 
There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, repair, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy of buildings and structures, including permits and penalties, that certain code known as the "Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code," and the accumulative supplements thereto and the amendments thereto, save and except such portions as are hereinafter amended or deleted, as permitted in the enabling legislation, and building regulations adopted and promulgated pursuant thereto, and the same are hereby adopted and referred to herein as the building code of the city as fully as if set out at length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 6-1; Code 1988, § 7-96; Ord. No. 1988-19, § 1, 2-23-1988; Ord. No. 1994-54, § 1, 6-14-1994; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998) 
Cross reference— Volume II of Uniform Statewide Building Code adopted as city's housing code, § 17-22. 
State Law reference— Uniform Statewide Building Code, Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq.  
Sec. 7-97. - Reserved.  
Sec. 7-98. - Continuation of existing use and occupancy. 
The legal use and occupancy of any existing structure which have been heretofore approved, may be continued without change, except as may be specifically covered in the code adopted by this article or in the property maintenance section of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code or as may be deemed necessary by the building official for the general safety and welfare of the occupants and the public. 
(Code 1973, § 6-6; Code 1988, § 7-98; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, 4-8-2003) 
Cross reference— Housing code, § 17-21 et seq.  
Sec. 7-99. - Conflicts with other ordinances. 
In the event that there is any conflict between any provision of the building code adopted in this article and any other ordinance of this city, the more stringent provisions shall control. 
(Code 1973, § 6-4; Code 1988, § 7-99)  
Sec. 7-100. - Availability of copies. 
Copies of the building code adopted by this article may be obtained at the state department of housing and community development, Richmond, Virginia. 
(Code 1973, § 6-5; Code 1988, § 7-100)  
Sec. 7-101. - Inspections of work. 
The inspections required under the provisions of the building code shall be performed by an inspector from the department of permits and inspections, or by a third party designated by the building official upon notification from the permit holder or such holder's agent. Such inspector shall either approve that portion of the work as completed or shall notify the permit holder or his agent where such work fails to comply with the building code or departmental regulation. Additional inspections may be required by the inspector where, in the inspector's judgment, such inspections are necessary because of the scope or complexity of the work to be installed or performed. Except as provided in section 7-136, a reinspection fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be paid prior to each reinspection unless waived by the building official. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-101; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, 4-8-2003) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 7-102. - Failure to obtain permit; inspection, certificate of occupancy, etc. 
If any person commences any work on a building or structure or any of the component parts thereof, including but not limited to electrical, plumbing and mechanical features or fixtures, or signs, before obtaining the necessary permit from the department of permits and inspections; or after obtaining such permit executes the work without calling for and receiving inspections from the appropriate division of the department of permits and inspections; or after obtaining such permit, deviates from the plan approved by such department without receiving written approval from the building official; or allows the occupancy of the building or structure for which the permit was obtained before a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the building official; then such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the penalty prescribed by section 7-1. In addition to any criminal penalties and sanctions, where the unlawful acts described above have been identified before a permit is obtained, an administrative fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be paid by such person to the city, as well as the permit fee due. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-9102; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, 4-8-2003) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 7-103. - Fee for certificate of occupancy and commercial reinspection. 
(a)  The fee for a certificate of occupancy required by the building code for an existing structure shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. When a certificate of occupancy is issued pursuant to the satisfactory completion of final inspections pursuant to a building permit issued, no fee shall be required for the certificate of occupancy. 
(b)  The fee for a temporary certificate of occupancy issued by the building official before the completion of the work covered by a permit shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(c)  The fee for the first renewal of a temporary certificate of occupancy shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. No fee shall be charged for subsequent renewals. 
(d)  Before a commercial property is occupied by a new tenant or owner, or by the same tenant or owner, if the property undergoes a change of occupancy as defined by the building code and a building permit is not required, or is vacant for a period of 90 days or more a commercial reinspection including plumbing, mechanical, electrical and building inspections shall be required. The fee for a commercial reinspection shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 7-103; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1990-41, § 3, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 2015-24, § 1, 5-12-2015 ) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 7-104. - Fees for review of construction plans. 
In addition to the permit fees prescribed in this article, there shall be a fee for the review of construction plans for all matters for which permits are mandated by the building code, including, but not limited to, building permits, electrical permits, plumbing permits and mechanical permits, in accord with the fee schedule set forth in appendix A to this Code for the following categories: 
(1)  New construction and additions to one-family and two-family buildings: 
a.  Under 2,000 square feet. 
b.  Over 2,000 square feet. 
(2)  All other structures: 
a.  Zero to 2,499 square feet. 
b.  Two thousand five hundred square feet to 4,999 square feet. 
c.  Five thousand square feet to 9,999 square feet. 
d.  Ten thousand square feet to 74,999 square feet. 
e.  Seventy-five thousand and up. 
(3)  Existing structures when altered or enlarged. 
A fee for the review of construction plans may be waived at the discretion of the building official for minor residential projects where the permit fee is less than $100.00. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-104; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2015-24, § 2, 5-12-2015 ) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 7-105. - Appeal fee. 
A fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code for each appeal of a decision of a building and/or code official shall be paid by the appellant to the city at the time application for the appeal is made. 
(Code 1988, § 7-105; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, 4-8-2003; Ord. No. 2015-24, § 3, 5-12-2015 ) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 7-105.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-24, § 4, adopted May 12, 2015 , deleted § 7-105.1, which pertained to administrative fee and derived from Code 1988, § 7-105.1; Ord. No. 1990-41, § 3, adopted May 15, 1990; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, adopted Apr. 28, 1998; and Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, adopted Apr. 8, 2003.  
Sec. 7-106. - Fire limits designated. 
The fire limits of the city shall comprise the areas containing congested business, commercial, manufacturing and industrial uses or in which such uses are developing. The limits of such areas are described as follows: 
Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of Queen Street (projected) with the pierhead line in the southern branch of the Elizabeth River as established by the U.S. Army Engineers; thence southerly along said pierhead line as it meanders along the southern branch of the Elizabeth River to its intersection with the centerline of Henry Street (projected); thence westerly along said centerline to the centerline of First Street; thence northerly along said centerline to its intersection with the centerline of Crawford Street; thence northerly along said centerline to the centerline of County Street; thence west along said centerline to the centerline of property belonging to the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad; thence southeast along said railroad property 275 feet to a point; thence southerly along the west property line of the Ida Barbour Public Housing Project to the north right-of-way of Clifford Street; thence west along said right-of-way 150 feet + and thence running west along the north boundary of the Swanson Homes Public Housing Project 800 feet +; thence south 300 feet +; thence southwest 115 feet +; thence west 370 feet + along the rear property line of properties fronting Rose Avenue; thence southerly to the south right-of-way line of Interstate Highway 264; thence westerly along said right-of-way to its intersection with the centerline of property belonging to Norfolk and Portsmouth Belt Line Railroad; thence north along said railroad property to its intersection with the centerline of High Street; thence east along said centerline to the centerline of the Martin Luther King Expressway; thence north along said centerline for 106 feet; thence east along said line to its intersection with the centerline of Jamestown Avenue; thence northerly along centerline to the centerline of Queen Street; thence east along said centerline to its intersection (projected) with the pierhead line on the southern branch of the Elizabeth River, the point of origin. 
(Code 1973, § 6-9; Code 1988, § 7-106)  
Sec. 7-107. - Compliance with other regulations. 
Before a building permit may be issued for the construction of any new building, or the addition to an existing building, plans must be approved for compliance with the following ordinances or parts thereof of the city Code: 
Chapter 40—Zoning Ordinance; 
Chapter 9.1—Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Overlay District; 
Chapter 36, Article III—Tree Planting and Replacement; 
Chapter 39—Wetlands; 
and where necessary Sections 105.10 and 121.0 of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1988, § 7-107; Ord. No. 1992-65, § 8, 7-28-1992)  
Secs. 7-108—7-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT AND INSPECTION FEES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14. 
 
Sec. 7-131. - Application of division. 
This division shall apply to the fees for permits and inspections required by the building code. 
(1)  The minimum fee for any permit shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(2)  Additional inspections may be required by the inspector, where, in the inspector's judgment, such inspections are necessary. Each reinspection shall require a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code to be paid prior to said reinspection. 
(Code 1988, § 7-131; Ord. No. 1990-41, § 3, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2015-24, § 5, 5-12-2015 )  
Sec. 7-132. - Schedules—Building permits. 
The fees for building (general construction) permits shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code for the following categories: 
(1)  All Commercial Buildings: 
a.  For 100 square feet up to and including 999 square feet, a fee per 100 square feet or fraction thereof. 
b.  For 1,000 square feet up to and including 4,999 square feet, a fee for the first 1,000 square feet plus an additional amount per 100 square feet or fraction thereof. 
c.  For 5,000 square feet or more, a fee for the first 5,000 square feet plus and additional amount per 100 square feet or fraction thereof without limit. 
(2)  Use Group O—Residential Garages, Porches, Decks and Similar Accessory Residential Buildings: 
a.  For up to and including 999 square feet, a fee per 100 square feet or fraction thereof. 
b.  For 1,000 square feet or more, a fee for the first 1,000 square feet and an additional amount per 100 square feet or fraction thereof. 
(3)  Residential Use Group R5—Single-Family Residence, Duplex, or Townhome: 
a.  For up to and including 1,999 square feet, a fee per 100 square feet, or fraction thereof. 
b.  From 2,000 square feet up to and including 4,999 square feet, a fee for the first 2,000 square feet plus an additional amount per 100 square feet or fraction thereof. 
c.  For 5,000 square feet or more, a fee for the first 5,000 square feet, plus an additional amount per 100 square feet or fraction thereof, without limit. 
(4)  Use Group T— 
a.  Alterations, repairs, private piers, wharves, bulkheads, pools, walls, bay windows, dormers, roofing, siding, commercial interior finish, miscellaneous structures: 
1.  Minimum fee. 
2.  For a valuation up to $4,999.00 a fee per $1,000.00 or fraction thereof. 
3.  For a valuation from $5,000.00, up to and including $19,999.00 a fee for the first $5,000.00 plus an additional amount for each additional $1,000.00 or fraction thereof. 
4.  For a valuation from $20,000.00 up to and including $99,999.00, a fee for the first $20,000.00 plus an additional amount for each additional $1,000.00 or fraction thereof. 
5.  For a valuation of over $100,000.00, a fee for the first $100,000.00 plus an additional amount for each additional $1,000.00 or fraction thereof, without limit. 
b.  Tents, mobile homes and other temporary structures: 
1.  For tents and other temporary structures, each. 
2.  For the new placement of mobile homes on a site including the tie-down and foundation. 
3.  For the replacement of mobile homes on a site including the tie-down and foundation. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-132; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1990-41, § 3, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2015-24, § 6, 5-12-2015 )  
Sec. 7-133. - Same—Electrical permits and inspections. 
(a)  The fees for electrical permits shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code for the following categories: 
(1)  Minimum permit fee. 
(2)  a.  Temporary service, 60 amperes. 
b.  Temporary service, 100 amperes. 
c.  Temporary service for construction regardless of amperage. 
(3)  a.  Fees for new services whether single- or three-phase include all circuits, motors, generators and other derivations of an electrical system. Single-phase per 50 amperes. 
b.  Three-phase service per 50 amperes for first 1,000 amperes and an additional amount per 50 amperes for remaining amperes after 1,000. 
(4)  a.  Changes of service: For single-phase service. Fees for changes of service (pay for change of service and any additional circuits added or worked on) per 50 amperes for single-phase. For circuit fee, see additions or repairs schedule below. 
b.  Changes of service: For three-phase service. Fees for changes of service per 50 amperes for the first 1,000 amperes and an additional amount per 50 amperes for the remaining amperes after 1,000. 
(5)  Additions or repairs: For each piece of equipment connected and for each circuit or feeder installed, extended, relocated or repaired the fee shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(6)  Miscellaneous: 
Pool inspection. 
Pool grounding. 
Inspection for temporary release. 
Mobile homes or trailers, see addition or repair schedule and services. 
(b)  The fees referred to in this section shall be charged based upon amperage for each piece of electrical apparatus inspected and not on the aggregate number of amperes. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-133; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1990-41, § 3, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1992-65, § 9, 7-28-1992; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2015-24, § 7, 5-12-2015 )  
Sec. 7-134. - Same—Plumbing permits and inspections. 
(a)  For each plumbing permit issued, the permit fee shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(b)  In addition to the permit fee required in subsection (a) of this section, there shall be inspection fees as set forth in appendix A to this Code for the following: 
(1)  For each plumbing fixture or trap placed or replaced, or removed from one place to another, and for each place roughed-in for a fixture. 
(2)  For each house sewer. 
(3)  For renewal or replacement of existing house sewer. 
(4)  For each house water service. 
(5)  For renewal or replacement of existing house water service. 
(6)  For each water heater. 
(7)  For replacement of water heaters. 
(8)  For roof drains or internal rain leaders. 
(9)  A per trip fee will be charged for site work inspections. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-134; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1992-65, § 10, 7-28-1992; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998)  
Sec. 7-135. - Same—Mechanical permits and inspections. 
(a)  For the installation in new construction of mechanical systems or equipment, storage tanks for flammable liquids or gases, and fire suppression systems, the permit fee shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(b)  For the replacement, repair or alteration of mechanical systems or equipment, storage tanks for flammable liquids or gases, or fire suppression systems, in existing buildings or structures, or the removal of storage tanks, the fee shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(c)  For the installation of one kitchen hood vent and not more than three bathroom vents in a single-family dwelling, the fee shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(d)  For the installation of standpipes, the fee shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code for each riser, plus an additional amount for each floor served by that riser. 
(e)  For amusement ride permits and inspections, the fees shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code and the categories of fees shall be construed with general reference to the Virginia Amusement Device Regulations. All fees shall be reduced by 75 percent if the applicant provides an approved certified third party inspector for the amusement devices. These fees shall be collected for each ride inspected. For all other structures at carnivals the permit fee shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code per structure with inspection required. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-135; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1992-65, § 11, 7-28-1992; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2015-24, § 8, 5-12-2015 ; Ord. No. 2017-33 , § 1, 5-9-2017)  
Sec. 7-136. - Same—Elevator permits and inspections. 
For periodic inspections made on elevators, dumbwaiters, moving stairs, moving walks and manlifts in accordance with the building code, a processing fee and the following inspection fees as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall apply unless otherwise provided: 
(1)  Six-month inspection. 
(2)  Annual hydraulic inspection. 
(3)  Annual traction inspection. 
(4)  Three-year inspection. 
(5)  Five-year inspection. 
(6)  Acceptance test for new construction. 
(7)  Reinspection (no additional processing fee). 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-136; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1990-41, § 3, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 2, 4-8-2003)  
Sec. 7-137. - Same—Moving permits. 
(a)  The fee for a permit to move a building shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code for the following: 
(1)  From without the city to a site within the city. 
(2)  From within the city to a site out of the city. 
(3)  From one location to another within the city. 
(4)  Through the city. 
(5)  Moving on the same parcel within the city. 
(b)  An additional fee shall be paid pursuant to section 7-138(b). 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-137; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 1, 4-25-1995)  
Sec. 7-138. - Same—Demolition permits and inspections. 
(a)  The fee for demolition permits for single-family structures and for any other structure shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(b)  The person obtaining a demolition or moving permit shall be responsible for watertight sealing of the building or structure's sanitary sewer lateral at the curb, at the edge of the street pavement if there is no curb, or at the point of connection to the city installed portion of the sanitary sewer lateral. Such seal shall be constructed with a flexible, expandable synthetic or natural rubber sewer plug specifically designed for such purpose and backed with 3,000 psi (minimum) compression strength concrete in accordance with the department of public utilities standards. A fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be paid for the inspection of the seal by the city. The responsibility for safeguarding the excavation made for sealing the lateral until inspection and for adequately backfilling, compacting and restoring such excavation after inspection and acceptance shall be borne by the demolition permit holder. The person obtaining a demolition permit may elect to have the city seal the building or structure's sanitary sewer lateral at a cost as set forth in appendix A to this Code, subject to the availability of city personnel. If such election is made, and if city personnel are available to seal the lateral and the cost fee is paid, the sanitary lateral sealing inspection fee will be waived. 
(c)  The person obtaining a demolition permit shall comply with the provisions of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-138; Ord. No. 1990-41, § 3, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1992-65, § 12, 7-28-1992; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1998-23, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2002-26, § 1, 5-14-2002)  
Sec. 7-139. - Same—Sign permits. 
(a)  Permit fees for the erection, painting, placing, replacing, hanging and rehanging of signs not otherwise specified in this division shall be based on the area of the sign and shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code for the following categories: 
(1)  Under 100 square feet. 
(2)  100 to 299 square feet. 
(3)  300 square feet and over. 
(b)  The permit fee for repainting a duly authorized sign in place when the sign will not be changed shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(c)  The fee for the permit for the repair of each billboard shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(d)  Application fees for a certificate of compliance, or a use permit, shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-139; Ord. No. 1988-50, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1992-65, § 13, 7-28-1992)  
Sec. 7-140. - Payment. 
The fees for all permits shall be paid at the time the permit is issued. No permit shall be valid unless all prescribed fees are paid, nor shall an amendment to a permit be approved until the additional fees, if any, are paid to the city. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 7-141)  
Sec. 7-141. - Refunds. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, shall apply to any refund of permit fees. 
(b)  There will be no refunds of permit fees of $100.00 or less. All refunds will be subject to a processing fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code and must be approved by the building official. When the permit holder requests a refund in writing from the building official stating the reason for the request, the table below indicates the percentage of refund permissible in each situation.

Sec. 7-142. - State levy fee. 
In addition to the fees cited within this division, the amount as specified in the Virginia Statewide Building Code, designated as a fee to be levied by localities to be used to support the training program of the Virginia Building Code Academy, shall be collected at the time of payment for fees required under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1988, § 7-143; Ord. No. 1995-40, § 2, 4-25-1995)  
Sec. 7-143. - Rental inspection fees. 
The per unit fees as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall apply to residential rental dwelling unit inspections for the following: 
(1)  Initial inspection. 
(2)  Follow-up inspection (first). 
(3)  Second and subsequent follow-up inspection. 
(4)  Periodic inspection. 
(Code 1988, § 11.1-4; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 3, 6-28-2005)  
Chapter 9 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Cemeteries generally, Code of Virginia, § 57-22 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 9-1. - Establishment or enlargement prohibited. 
(a)  No cemetery shall be established or enlarged in the city except as otherwise permitted by city council through a rezoning of the subject property to a Preservation P-1 zoning district. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 7-1; Code 1988, § 9-1; Ord. No. 2009-31, § 1-, 4-14-2009) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 9-2. - Permissible places of burial. 
(a)  No person shall bury or cause to be buried, without permission of the director of public health, the remains of any person in any private lot or at any other place within the city except in Cedar Grove Cemetery, Oak Grove Cemetery, Olive Branch Cemetery, Olive Branch Annex Cemetery, Lincoln Memorial Park, Saint Paul Cemetery, Evergreen Memorial Park, the cemeteries on Paradise Creek belonging to the congregations of Gomley Chesed Synagogue and Chevra Thilim Synagogue, and the cemetery belonging to Olive Branch Baptist Church and Oak Grove Baptist Church; provided, however, that the remains of no person shall be buried in the cemetery belonging to Olive Branch Baptist Church within 60 feet of the centerline of Airline Boulevard. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 7-2; Code 1988, § 9-2) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11; retaining or exposing dead bodies, § 24-2.  
Sec. 9-3. - City cemetery fees and charges. 
(a)  The schedule of fees and charges is hereby established for opening and closing graves for ground burials in city cemeteries. The fees and charges for the following categories shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code: 
(1)  Adult graves: Monday through Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(2)  Adult graves: Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(3)  Adult graves: Sunday and state and federal holidays, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(4)  Child graves: Monday through Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., for a grave not exceeding a length of 48 inches, a width of 40 inches, and a depth of 48 inches. 
(5)  Child graves: Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., for a grave not exceeding a length of 48 inches, a width of 40 inches, and a depth of 48 inches. 
(6)  Child graves: Sunday and state and federal holidays, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., for a grave not exceeding a length of 48 inches, a width of 40 inches, and a depth of 48 inches. 
(7)  Cremation graves: Monday through Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(8)  Cremation graves: Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(9)  Cremation graves: Sunday and state and federal holidays, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(10)  Additional fee: For services where the funeral party is not present at the graveside by 4:00 p.m. 
(b)  The fees and charges for the above categories as set out in appendix A to this Code shall be paid before the work is performed and a receipt shall be issued therefore. 
(Code 1988, § 11.1-9; Ord. No. 2005-99, § 3, 11-22-2005)  
Sec. 9-4. - Malicious mischief. 
(a)  If any person shall: 
(1)  Destroy, mutilate, deface, injure or remove any tomb, monument, gravestone or other structure placed within any cemetery, graveyard or other place of burial or any lot belonging to any memorial or monumental association within the city or any fence, railing, or other work for the protection or ornament of any tomb, monument, gravestone or other structure aforesaid, or any cemetery lot within any cemetery; 
(2)  Destroy, remove, cut, break or injure any tree, shrub or plant within any cemetery or lot of any monumental or memorial association; 
(3)  Destroy, mutilate, injure or remove and carry away any flowers, wreaths, vases or other ornaments placed upon or around any grave, tomb, monument or lot in any cemetery, graveyard or other place of burial; or 
(4)  Obstruct proper ingress or egress to and from any cemetery or lot belonging to any memorial association; 
he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any work which is done by or under the supervision of the person in charge of a city cemetery, or by the authorities in charge of a private cemetery in the maintenance or improvement of any burial ground or cemetery under his or their management or control. 
(Code 1973, §§ 7-4, 21-119; Code 1988, § 9-4) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11; authority of city manager to offer reward in cases involving damage to city property, § 2-167. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-127.  
Secs. 9-5—9-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY CEMETERIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to provide and operate cemeteries, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1111, 15.2-1121. 
 
Sec. 9-26. - Burial grounds, city cemeteries designated. 
(a)  The burial ground at Glasgow Street and Fort Lane shall be known as "Cedar Grove Cemetery." The burial ground at London Boulevard and Peninsula Avenue shall be known as "Oak Grove Cemetery." The burial grounds adjoining City Park and Clifford Street shall be known as "Olive Branch Cemetery," and "Olive Branch Annex Cemetery." The burial ground located on Pulaski Street in the Prentis Park neighborhood shall be known as the "Mount Calvary Cemetery Complex" and shall include Mount Calvary Cemetery, Fisher's Hill Cemetery, the Pauper's Field Cemetery, and Mount Olive Cemetery. 
(b)  Cedar Grove Cemetery, Oak Grove Cemetery, Olive Branch Cemetery and the Mount Calvary Cemetery Complex are hereby designated as city cemeteries. For the purposes of this chapter, the term "city cemeteries" shall mean only those cemeteries so designated in this section. 
(Code 1973, § 7-16; Code 1988, § 9-26; Ord. No. 1995-33, § 1, 4-11-1995; Ord. No. 2005-99, § 1, 11-22-2005; Ord. No. 2014-82, § 1, 9-23-2014 ; Ord. No. 2016-60 , § 1, 8-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-82, § 2, adopted Sept. 23, 2014 , repealed § 9-27, which pertained to application of article and derived from Code 1973, § 7-17; and Code 1988, § 9-27.  
Sec. 9-28. - Violations of article. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 9-28) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 9-29. - Perpetual care of city cemeteries; cemetery trust fund. 
(a)  The city shall, in perpetuity, maintain in good order, free from weeds and undergrowth, the city cemetery grounds of Cedar Grove Cemetery, Oak Grove Cemetery, Olive Branch Cemetery, and the Mount Calvary Cemetery Complex. The city shall also maintain the monuments and stones of said city cemeteries in an upright position so long as the same continue intact. 
(b)  There is hereby established a cemetery trust fund having an initial nonexpendable corpus of $1,000,000.00. The amount of the nonexpendable corpus may be increased at any time. There shall also be added to the trust fund all sums from burial permit fees, donations, legacies, and other funds received from any other source for the care of city cemeteries. 
(c)  The nonexpendable portion of the cemetery trust fund shall be invested in securities authorized pursuant to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 26-40 for funds administered by fiduciaries. The income derived from such investment of these funds shall be paid as received into the treasury of the city. The investment income and any funds not included in the nonexpendable corpus of the trust shall be utilized solely for capital improvements to the city cemeteries. 
(d)  The city treasurer shall have custody of such funds and shall be responsible for the same under his official bond. The city treasurer and the chief financial officer shall keep separate records of such funds and the amount of income from such investments that has been paid into the city treasury. 
(Code 1973, § 7-18; Code 1988, § 9-29; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001; Ord. No. 2005-99, § 1, 11-22-2005; Ord. No. 2014-82, § 1, 9-23-2014 )  
Sec. 9-29.1. - Burial permit fee. 
A burial permit fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be paid for each adult burial in a city cemetery identified in section 9-26. No burial permit fee shall be charged for the burial of children in child graves having the dimensions established in section 9-3 or for the burial of individuals verified as indigent by the department of social services. A burial permit fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be paid for the burial of cremated remains. The person or entity responsible for the opening and closing of graves shall collect and remit the fee to the city treasurer no later than the 15th of the month following the burial. The city treasurer shall deposit funds so collected into the cemetery trust fund established pursuant to section 9-29. 
(Code 1988, § 9-29.1; Ord. No. 2005-99, § 2, 11-22-2005)  
Sec. 9-30. - Record of sales of lots; transfer of ownership. 
The person in charge of a city cemetery shall keep suitable books and record therein the sale of all lots, half lots or spaces sold, with the date of sale, price received therefor, the number of the lot or designation of the half lot or space, and the name of the purchaser. In case of transfer of ownership, a proper entry shall be made thereof, and the lot, half lot or space again registered in the name of the new owner. Such person shall make a good faith effort to ensure, prior to interment, that the ownership of the cemetery lot is vested in the decedent's estate or that permission for the interment has been granted by the person holding such ownership. 
(Code 1973, § 7-22; Code 1988, § 9-31; Ord. No. 1991-64, § 1, 6-25-1991)  
Sec. 9-31. - Right to use lot; reverter for nonuse. 
The person to whom a receipt of purchase has been issued with reference to a lot, half lot, space or section in a city cemetery, or his assignee shall be entitled to the lot, half lot, space or section so paid for, as a burying place for himself or for any person who is a member of his family or one of his descendants or friends. When a lot, half lot or space shall remain without any interment therein for 50 years, and the purchaser or his assignee shall have died or relocated from the city, and no relative is known to reside in the city, the city council may give notice thereof once a week for four weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. If no relative of the purchaser or his assignees appears within 30 days from the last day of such publication, then the lot, half lot or space, as the case may be, shall revert to the city. Whether there is such reverter or not, the city council may, at any and all times, regulate the interments in the cemetery, or any part thereof, as may seem to it proper. 
(Code 1973, § 7-23; Code 1988, § 9-34; Ord. No. 1995-33, § 1, 4-11-1995)  
Sec. 9-32. - Devolution of rights upon death of lot owner. 
In case of death of the purchaser of any portion of a city cemetery, the purchaser's spouse shall be recognized as the owner thereof if they were living together at the time of the purchaser's death. At the death of the spouse, the heirs at law of the purchaser shall be so recognized. 
(Code 1973, § 7-24; Code 1988, § 9-35)  
Sec. 9-33. - Opening and closing hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to go onto or enter upon any portion of any city cemetery during the hours when the cemetery is designated as closed. Hours of opening and closing shall be designated by the city manager and posted therein for public information. 
(Code 1973, § 7-25; Code 1988, § 9-36; Ord. No. 1988-23, 3-8-1988)  
Sec. 9-34. - When burials may take place. 
Under ordinary circumstances, all burials in city cemeteries shall take place between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. The person in charge of the cemetery may, however, in an emergency or under extraordinary circumstances permit burials at other hours. Burials after 4:00 p.m. on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays are prohibited. 
(Code 1973, § 7-26; Code 1988, § 9-37)  
Sec. 9-35. - Proof of purchase upon opening of grave. 
The proof of purchase issued with reference to a lot, half lot, space or section in a city cemetery shall be exhibited to the person in charge of the cemetery when ordering a grave to be opened, should he deem it necessary to establish the authority of the person giving the order. 
(Code 1973, § 7-27; Code 1988, § 9-38; Ord. No. 1995-33, § 1, 4-11-1995)  
Sec. 9-36. - Second interments. 
Nothing in this division shall be construed to prohibit or prevent, in a city cemetery, the opening of a grave in which a previous interment has been made for the purpose of making a second interment therein; provided that the same shall be done with the approval and consent of the owner of the section or grave and with the approval and in a manner satisfactory to the person in charge of the cemetery in which the same is proposed to be made. Any person aggrieved by the determination of any such person in charge may appeal to the city manager for redress, whose determination shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1973, § 7-28; Code 1988, § 9-39)  
Sec. 9-37. - Record of burials. 
The person in charge of a city cemetery shall keep a record of all burials made in the cemetery and he shall enter in a suitable book the name, age, residence of the person deceased, the dates of his birth and death, date of burial, and number of lot and number of space therein, or number of space in a single grave portion in which the deceased has been interred. Such entries shall be consecutively numbered, and an alphabetical index of the deceased persons' names shall be kept. 
(Code 1973, § 7-29; Code 1988, § 9-40; Ord. No. 1995-33, § 1, 4-11-1995)  
Sec. 9-38. - Charges for work performed. 
The fees and charges for worked performed in city cemeteries shall be as established in section 9-3 and as set out in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 7-30; Code 1988, § 9-41; Ord. No. 1991-42, § 1, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1995-57, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 2005-99, § 1, 11-22-2005) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14. 
State Law reference— Authority for above charges, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1121.  
Sec. 9-39. - Removal of dirt, rubbish upon completion of work. 
All dirt, bricks or rubbish used or accumulated in doing any work in a city cemetery shall be removed therefrom by the contractor under whose supervision the work was done immediately after the completion thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 7-32; Code 1988, § 9-43; Ord. No. 1995-33, § 1, 4-11-1995)  
Sec. 9-40. - Mausoleums. 
No mausoleum shall be erected in any city cemetery except upon a site fronting on a roadway of sufficient size to permit the handling of material and equipment and except in compliance with the following conditions and specifications: 
(1)  The exterior walls shall be of the best quality marble or granite, at least eight inches thick at the base, and no other materials or veneer construction shall be permitted. The joints shall be so formed and pointed that deterioration of mortar will not weaken the stability of the structure. 
(2)  The foundation shall be excavated to a depth of firm soil with a minimum of four feet under the main walls of the building, with footings at least eight inches thick of poured, well-mixed concrete. 
(3)  The floors shall be constructed of concrete or of stone laid on concrete slab. 
(4)  The roof shall be of the same kind of material as the outside walls, and shall be either a solid stone of sufficient size to cover the entire structure, or shall be a series of stones running the length of the building with no vertical joints, and overlapping one another at least six inches at the joints. The joints under the overlap shall be flushed with mastic setting compound or waterproof cement, pointed up solid to prevent leaks. 
(5)  All door and window frames shall be of bronze. All glass windows shall be covered with exterior protecting shatterproof glass. 
(6)  All ventilators shall be of bronze or aluminum alloy with fine bronze wire screen on the inside. 
(7)  All crypt shelves shall be of marble or stone and no prefabricated slabs or concrete shall be used. 
(8)  The steps shall be placed on an adequate foundation sufficient to prevent frost heaving or settling. 
(9)  A space at least five feet wide shall be left open between the walls and the edge of the lot or site. 
(Code 1973, § 7-33; Code 1988, § 9-44)  
Sec. 9-41. - Monuments. 
(a)  Not more than one monument may be erected in any lot in any city cemetery. Any stone that projects more than 24 inches above the grade of a lot shall be deemed to be a monument. 
(b)  In no city cemetery shall any monument be permitted in any lot or fractional part of any lot having a surface area of less than 128 square feet. 
(c)  In city cemeteries, all monuments shall be set in the center of the lot. 
(d)  Foundations for monuments must be of solid masonry, solid concrete or a concrete cap over concrete columns (to be installed in accordance with an administrative directive of the city manager) of a sufficient number to sustain the weight of the monument. All such foundations for monuments must be laid not less than four feet below the grade of the lot. 
(e)  The area of the top of all such foundations shall be at least equal to that of the base of the superstructure. 
(Code 1973, § 7-34; Code 1988, § 9-45)  
Sec. 9-42. - Gravestones. 
No gravestone in any city cemetery shall be less than four nor more than 12 inches thick, nor more than 24 inches in width, nor shall any such stone project more than six inches above the grade of the lot in which it is set, or be set so as to rest on the brickwork of the grave, nor shall more than one stone be permitted for any grave. Every such stone shall be set on a foundation of solid masonry or solid concrete or a concrete cap over concrete columns (to be installed in accordance with an administrative directive of the city manager) of a sufficient number to sustain the weight of the gravestone, and the area of the top surface of such foundation shall be at least equal to that of the base of the superstructure. All such foundations must be laid to a depth of not less than four feet. 
(Code 1973, § 7-35; Code 1988, § 9-46)  
Sec. 9-43. - Burial vaults. 
Every grave opening shall contain a burial container or vault, which burial container or vault shall be so constructed of metal, stone, or reinforced concrete, and so installed as to effectively prevent settling of the ground, lot or grave site. 
(Code 1973, § 7-35.1; Code 1988, § 9-47)  
Sec. 9-44. - Mounds. 
No grave in any city cemetery shall have its mound more than four inches above the grade level, after a reasonable time for settling of the dirt has elapsed. 
(Code 1973, § 7-36; Code 1988, § 9-48)  
Sec. 9-45. - Grade of lots. 
The grade of all lots in city cemeteries shall be established by the director of public works, and no change may be made in any grade so established. 
(Code 1973, § 7-37; Code 1988, § 9-49)  
Sec. 9-46. - Lot boundaries. 
The boundaries of all lots in city cemeteries shall be defined by means of corner posts. Such posts will be six inches square, and shall be set within lot lines at ground level. The number of each lot will be designated on one of such corner posts. 
(Code 1973, § 7-38; Code 1988, § 9-50)  
Sec. 9-47. - Enclosures around lots, graves. 
No enclosure, flower bed, hedge or border of any kind will be permitted around, or alongside of, any lot or grave in any city cemetery. 
(Code 1973, § 7-39; Code 1988, § 9-51)  
Sec. 9-48. - Decorations. 
No ornament or decoration other than cut or artificial flowers shall be placed on any grave in any city cemetery, except that on Decoration Day and Memorial Day, established by law, flags may be placed on graves, subject to the right of the keeper to remove the same after the expiration of five days. Floral designs may be used at burials in city cemeteries, but shall be removed from lots within ten days thereafter. 
(Code 1973, § 7-40; Code 1988, § 9-52)  
Sec. 9-49. - Signs, notices. 
No sign, notice or advertisement of any kind shall be permitted upon any part of the grounds of any city cemetery. The keeper shall cause the immediate removal of all such signs, notices or advertisements. 
(Code 1973, § 7-41; Code 1988, § 9-53)  
Sec. 9-50. - Seating accommodations in lots. 
No chair or other seating accommodation may be placed in any lot in any city cemetery. 
(Code 1973, § 7-42; Code 1988, § 9-54)  
Sec. 9-51. - Maximum speed limit. 
The maximum speed in any city cemetery shall be 15 miles an hour. 
(Code 1973, § 7-43; Code 1988, § 9-55) 
Cross reference— Speed limits generally, § 22-395.  
Sec. 9-52. - Riding or driving on lawn or walkway. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive on any lawn or walkway of any city cemetery. 
(Code 1973, § 7-44; Code 1988, § 9-56)  
Sec. 9-53. - Entering, exiting. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or leave the grounds of any city cemetery except by way of the roads. 
(Code 1973, § 7-45; Code 1988, § 9-57)  
Sec. 9-54. - Hunting or fishing. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt or fish within the grounds of any city cemetery. 
(Code 1973, § 7-46; Code 1988, § 9-58)  
Sec. 9-55. - Discharging fireworks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any fireworks within the grounds of any city cemetery. 
(Code 1973, § 7-47; Code 1988, § 9-59) 
Cross reference— Fireworks generally, § 13-101 et seq.  
Sec. 9-56. - Dogs prohibited, except as provided herein. 
No person shall permit a dog to go into any city cemetery except: 
(1)  An individual who is on the cemetery property for the purpose of visiting a gravesite, attending a burial, or another similar purpose may be accompanied by a guide dog, service dog or other dog accorded special status under federal or state disability or accommodation laws or regulations; and 
(2)  The city manager or the city manager's designee may authorize the presence of specially trained dogs on the cemetery property for property maintenance activities conducted by or at the direction of the city, provided that all such activities shall be performed in compliance with all applicable state and federal laws. 
(Code 1973, § 7-48; Code 1988, § 9-60; Ord. No. 2016-87 , § 1, 10-25-2016) 
Cross reference— Dogs generally, § 4-31 et seq.  
Sec. 9-57. - Duty of person in charge as to violations of certain sections. 
Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the person in charge of any city cemetery, or any of his assistants, that any person is about to violate any of the provisions of sections 9-41 through 9-56, such person shall be by him warned against such violation and, if necessary, shall be notified of such threatened violation. In every case where any such violation has actually occurred, it shall be the duty of the keeper and his assistants to report the same at once. 
(Code 1973, § 7-49; Code 1988, § 9-61)  
Chapter 9.1 - CHESAPEAKE BAY PRESERVATION AREA OVERLAY DISTRICT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Boats and waterways, ch. 6; erosion and sediment control, excavation, ch. 11; flood protection, ch. 14; parks and recreation, ch. 25; streets, sidewalks and local improvements, ch. 32; subdivisions, ch. 33; water, sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 38; wetlands, ch. 39; zoning, ch. 40. 
State Law reference— Chesapeake Bay Preservation Act, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-2100 et seq. 
 
Sec. 9.1-1. - Findings of fact. 
(a)  The Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries is one of the most important and productive estuarine systems in the world, providing economic and social benefits to the citizens of the City of Portsmouth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The health of the Bay is vital to maintaining the city's economy and the welfare of its citizens. 
(b)  The Chesapeake Bay waters have been degraded significantly by many sources of pollution, including nonpoint source pollution from land uses and development. Existing high quality waters are worthy of protection from degradation to guard against further pollution. Certain lands that are proximate to shorelines have intrinsic water quality value due to the ecological and biological processes they perform. Other lands have severe development constraints from flooding, erosion, and soil limitations. With proper management, they offer significant ecological benefits by providing water quality maintenance and pollution control, as well as flood and shoreline erosion control. These lands together, designated by the city council as Chesapeake Bay Preservation Areas (hereinafter "CBPAs"), need to be protected from destruction and damage in order to protect the quality of water in the Bay and consequently the quality of life in the City of Portsmouth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
(Code 1988, § 9.1-1; Ord. No. 2004-02, § 1, 1-13-2004)  
Sec. 9.1-2. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  This chapter is enacted to implement the requirements of Code of Virginia, § 10.1-2100 et seq., the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Act. The intent of the city council and the purpose of the overlay district is to: 
(1)  Protect existing high quality state waters; 
(2)  Restore all other state waters to a condition or quality that will permit all reasonable public uses and will support the propagation and growth of all aquatic life, including game fish, which might reasonably be expected to inhabit them; 
(3)  Safeguard the clean waters of the commonwealth from pollution; 
(4)  Prevent any increase in pollution; 
(5)  Reduce existing pollution; and 
(6)  Promote water resource conservation in order to provide for the health, safety, and welfare of the present and future citizens of the city. 
(7)  Control and regulate runoff at the source to protect against and minimize pollution and deposition of sediment in city wetlands and streams that are tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay. 
(b)  This district shall be in addition to and shall overlay all other zoning districts where they are applied so that any parcel of land lying in the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Overlay District shall also lie in one or more of the other zoning districts provided for by chapter 40, Zoning. Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, the review and approval procedures provided for in chapters 7, 11, 14, 33, 39 and 40 of this Code, and all other applicable ordinances shall be followed in reviewing and approving development, redevelopment, and uses also regulated by this chapter. 
(c)  This chapter is enacted under the authority of 9 VAC 10-20 et seq., the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Designation and Management Regulations, and Code of Virginia, § 10.1-2100 et seq., Chesapeake Bay Preservation Act and Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2283. 
(Code 1988, § 9.1-2; Ord. No. 2004-02, § 1, 1-13-2004; Ord. No. 2009-88, § 1, 8-25-2009)  
Sec. 9.1-3. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms used in the overlay district have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. Words and terms not defined in this chapter but defined in the zoning ordinance as set out in chapter 40 shall be given the meanings set forth therein. 
Agricultural lands means those lands used for the planting and harvesting of crops or plant growth of any kind in the open; pasture; horticulture; dairying; floriculture; or raising of poultry and/or livestock. 
Best management practice or BMP means a practice, or a combination of practices that is determined by a state or designated area-wide planning agency to be the most effective, practical means of preventing or reducing the amount of pollution generated by nonpoint sources to a level compatible with water quality goals. 
Buffer area means an area of natural or established vegetation managed to protect other components of a resources protection area and state waters from significant degradation due to land disturbances. 
Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area or CBPA means any land designated by the city council pursuant to Part III of the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area Designation and Management Regulations, 9 VAC 10-20-70 et seq., and Code of Virginia, § 10.1-2107. A Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area shall consist of a resource protection area and a resource management area. 
Construction footprint means the area of all impervious surface including, but not limited to, buildings, roads and drives, parking areas, and sidewalks and all land disturbances on the site including access areas necessary for construction of such improvements. 
Development means the construction, or substantial alteration of residential, commercial, industrial, institutional, recreation, transportation, or utility facilities or structures. 
Diameter at breast height or DBH means the diameter of a tree measured outside the bark at a point 4.5 feet above ground. 
Dripline means a vertical projection to the ground surface from the furthest lateral extent of a tree's leaf canopy. 
Highly erodible soils means soils (excluding vegetation) with an erodibility index (EI) from sheet and rill erosion to or greater than eight. The erodibility index for any soil is defined as the product of the formula RKLS/T, where K is the soil susceptibility to water erosion in the surface layer; R is the rainfall and runoff; LS is the combined effects of slope length and steepness; and T is the soil loss tolerance. 
Highly permeable soils means soils with a given potential to transmit water through the soil profile. Highly permeable soils are identified as any soil having a permeability equal to or greater than six inches of water movement per hour in any part of the soil profile to a depth of 72 inches (permeability groups "rapid" and "very rapid") as found in the "National Soil Survey Handbook" of November 1996 in the "Field Office Technical Guide" of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Natural Resources Conservation Service. 
Impervious cover means a surface composed of any material that significantly impedes or prevents natural infiltration of water into the soil. Impervious surfaces include, but are not limited to: roofs, buildings, streets, parking areas, and any concrete, asphalt, or compacted gravel surface. 
Intensely developed area or IDA means a portion of a resource protection area and a resource management area designated by the where development is concentrated and little of the natural environment remains as provided for in subsection 9.1-4(b)(3). 
Land disturbance means any land change which may result in soil erosion from water or wind and the movement of sediments into state waters or onto lands in the state, including, but not limited to, clearing of vegetation, grading, excavating, transporting, and filling of land. Land change shall include, but not be limited to, any activity that causes, contributes to or results in the destruction, removal or covering of the vegetation upon such land including, but limited to, clearing dredging, filling, grading, or excavating. Land change shall not include minor activities such as home gardening, individual home landscaping, and home maintenance. 
Nonpoint source pollution means pollution consisting of constituents such as sediment, nutrients, and organic and toxic substances from diffuse sources, such as runoff from agriculture and urban land development and use. 
Nontidal wetlands means those wetlands other than tidal wetlands that are inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions, as defined by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to Section 404 of the Federal Clean Water Act, in 33 CFR 328.3b. 
Noxious weeds means weeds that are difficult to control effectively, including, but not limited to, Johnson Grass, Kudzu, and multiflora rose. A complete list is contained in the Department of Conservation and Resources Division of Natural Heritage publication entitled Invasive Plant Species of Virginia. 
Plan of development means the process for site plan or subdivision plat review to ensure compliance with Code of Virginia, § 10.1-2109 and this chapter, prior to any clearing or grading of a site or the issuance of a building permit. 
Public road means a publicly owned road designed and constructed in accordance with water quality protection criteria at least as stringent as requirements applicable to the state department of transportation, including regulations promulgated pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 10.1-560 et seq. (the Erosion and Sediment Control Law) and Code of Virginia, § 10.1-603.1 et seq. (the Virginia Stormwater Management Act). This definition includes those roads where the Virginia Department of Transportation exercises direct supervision over the design or construction activities, or both, and cases where secondary roads are constructed or maintained in accordance with the standards of the city. 
Redevelopment means the process of developing land that is or has been previously developed. 
Resource management area or RMA means that component of the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area that is not classified as the resource protection area. An RMA includes land types that, if improperly used or developed, have the potential for causing significant water quality degradation or for diminishing the functional value of the resource protection area as provided for in subsection 9.1-4(b)(2). 
Resource protection area or RPA means that component of the Chesapeake Bay Preservation Area comprised of lands adjacent to water bodies with perennial flow that have an intrinsic water quality value due to the ecological and biological processes they perform or that are sensitive to impacts which may result in significant degradation to the quality of state waters as provided for in subsection 9.1-4(b)(1). 
State waters means all waters, on the surface or underground, wholly or partially within or bordering the commonwealth or within its jurisdictions, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 10.1-560. 
Substantial alteration means expansion or modification of a building or development that would result in a disturbance of land exceeding an area of 2,500 square feet in the RMA only.
