Chapter 11 - EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL, EXCAVATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Building regulations, ch. 7; flood protection, ch. 14.1; housing and community development, ch. 17; streets, sidewalks and local improvements, ch. 32; subdivisions, ch. 33.1; water, sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 38; wetlands, ch. 39; zoning, ch. 40.1. 
State Law reference— Erosion and Sediment Control Law, Code of Virginia, §§ 10.1-560—10.1.571; local control programs, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-562. 
 
ARTICLE I. - EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL 
 
Sec. 11-1. - Title and purpose; authority. 
(a)  Title and purpose. This article shall be known as the "Erosion and Sediment Control Ordinance of the City of Portsmouth." The purpose of the article is to prevent degradation of properties, stream channels, waters and other natural resources of the City of Portsmouth by establishing requirements for the control of soil erosion, sediment deposition and nonagricultural runoff and by establishing procedures whereby these requirements shall be administered and enforced. 
(b)  Authority. This article is authorized by Code of Virginia, § 10.1-560 et seq., known as the Virginia Erosion and Sediment Control Law. 
(Code 1988, § 11-1; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 11-22-2005)  
Sec. 11-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Agreement in lieu of a plan means a contract between the plan-approving authority and the owner that specifies conservation measures that must be implemented in the construction of a single-family residence; this contract may be executed by the plan-approving authority in lieu of a formal site plan. 
Applicant means any person submitting an erosion and sediment control plan for approval or requesting the issuance of a permit, when required, authorizing land-disturbing activities to commence. 
Board means the Virginia Soil and Water Conservation Board. 
Certified inspector means an employee or agent of a program authority who: 
(1)  Holds a certificate of competence from the board in the area of project inspection; or 
(2)  Is enrolled in the board's training program for project inspection and successfully completes such program within one year after enrollment. 
Certified plan reviewer means an employee or agent of a program authority who: 
(1)  Holds a certificate of competence from the board in the area of plan review; 
(2)  Is enrolled in the board's training program for plan review and successfully completes such program within one year after enrollment; or 
(3)  Is licensed as a professional engineer, architect, certified landscape architect or land surveyor pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 54.1-400 et seq. 
Certified program administrator means an employee or agent of a program authority who: 
(1)  Holds a certificate of competence from the board in the area of program administration; or 
(2)  Is enrolled in the board's training program for program administration and successfully completes such program within one year after enrollment. 
City means the City of Portsmouth. 
Clearing means any activity which removes the vegetative ground cover including, but not limited to, root mat removal or top soil removal. 
Department means the Virginia Department of Conservation and Recreation. 
Development means a tract of land developed or to be developed as a single unit under single ownership or unified control, which is to be used for any business or industrial purpose or is to contain three or more residential dwelling units. 
Director means the director of the department of conservation and recreation. 
Erosion and sediment control plan or plan means a document containing material for the conservation of soil and water resources of a unit or group of units of land. It may include appropriate maps, an appropriate soil and water plan inventory, and management information with needed interpretations and a record of decisions contributing to conservation treatment. The plan shall contain all major conservation decisions to assure that the entire unit of land will be so treated to achieve the conservation objectives. 
Erosion impact area means an area of land not associated with current land-disturbing activity but subject to persistent soil erosion resulting in the delivery of sediment onto neighboring properties or into state waters. This definition shall not apply to any lot or parcel of land of 10,000 square feet or less used for residential purposes or to shorelines where the erosion results from wave action or other coastal processes. 
Excavating means any digging, scooping or other methods of removing earth materials. 
Filling means any depositing or stockpiling of earth materials. 
Grading means any excavating or filling of earth material or any combination thereof, including the land in its excavated or filled conditions. 
Land-disturbing activity means any land change which may result in soil erosion from water or wind and the movement of sediments into state waters or onto lands in the commonwealth, including, but not limited to, clearing, grading, excavating, transporting and filling of land, except that the term shall not include: 
(1)  Minor land-disturbing activities such as home gardens and individual home landscaping, repairs and maintenance work; 
(2)  Individual service connections; 
(3)  Installation, maintenance, or repair of any underground public utility lines when such activity occurs on an existing hard-surfaced road, street or sidewalk provided such land-disturbing activity is confined to the area of the road, street or sidewalk which is hard-surfaced; 
(4)  Septic tank lines or drainage fields unless included in an overall plan for land-disturbing activity relating to construction of the building to be served by the septic tank system; 
(5)  Surface or deep mining; 
(6)  Exploration or drilling for oil and gas including the well site, roads, feeder lines, and off-site disposal areas; 
(7)  Tilling, planting, or harvesting of agricultural, horticultural, or forest crops, or livestock feedlot operations; including engineering operations and agricultural engineering operations as follows: construction of terraces, terrace outlets, check dams, de-silting basins, dikes, ponds not required to comply with the Virginia Dam Safety Act, ditches, strip cropping, lister furrowing, contour cultivating, contour furrowing, land drainage, and land irrigation; however, this exception shall not apply to harvesting of forest crops unless the area on which harvesting occurs is reforested artificially or naturally in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1100 et seq. or is converted to bona fide agricultural or improved pasture use as described in Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1163(B); 
(8)  Repair or rebuilding of the tracks, rights-of-way, bridges, communication facilities and other related structures and facilities of a railroad company; 
(9)  Disturbed land areas of less than 2,500 square feet in size; 
(10)  Installation of fence and signposts or telephone and electric poles and other kinds of posts or poles; 
(11)  Shoreline erosion control projects on tidal waters when all of the land-disturbing activities are within the regulatory authority of and approved by local wetlands boards, the Marine Resources Commission or the United States Army Corps of Engineers; however, any associated land that is disturbed outside of this exempted area shall remain subject to this article; and 
(12)  Emergency work to protect life, limb or property, and emergency repairs; provided that if the land-disturbing activity would have required an approved erosion and sediment control plan, if the activity were not an emergency, then the land area disturbed shall be shaped and stabilized in accordance with the requirements of the plan-approving authority. 
Land-disturbing permit means a permit issued by the city for the clearing, filling, excavating, grading, transporting of land or for any combination thereof or for any purpose set forth herein. 
Local erosion and sediment control program or local control program means an outline of the various methods employed by the city to regulate land-disturbing activities and thereby minimize erosion and sedimentation in compliance with the state program and may include such items as local ordinances, policies and guidelines, technical materials, inspection, enforcement, and evaluation. 
Natural channel design concepts means the utilization of engineering analysis and fluvial geomorphic processes to create, rehabilitate, restore, or stabilize an open conveyance system for the purpose of creating or recreating a stream that conveys its bankfull storm event within its banks and allows larger flows to access its bankfull bench and its floodplain. 
Owner means the owner or owners of the freehold of the premises or lesser estate therein, a mortgagee or vendee in possession, assignee of rents, receiver, executor, trustee, lessee or other person, firm or corporation in control of a property. 
Peak flow rate means the maximum instantaneous flow from a given storm condition at a particular location. 
Permittee means the person to whom the permit authorizing land-disturbing activities is issued or the person who certifies that the approved erosion and sediment control plan will be followed. 
Person means any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private institution, utility, cooperative, county, city, town or other political subdivision of the commonwealth, any interstate body, or any other legal entity. 
Plan-approving authority means the department of public utilities/public works, through the stormwater administrator or their designee, responsible for determining the adequacy of a plan submitted for land-disturbing activities on a unit or groups of units of land and for approving plans. 
Program authority means the city, which has adopted a soil erosion and sediment control program approved by the board. 
Responsible land-disturber means an individual from the project or development team, who will be in charge of and responsible for carrying out a land-disturbing activity covered by an approved plan or agreement in lieu of a plan, who: 
(1)  Holds a responsible land-disturber certificate of competence; 
(2)  Holds a current certificate of competence from the board in the areas of combined administration, program administration, inspection, or plan review; 
(3)  Holds a current contractor certificate of competence for erosion and sediment control; or 
(4)  Is licensed in the state as a professional engineer, architect, certified landscape architect or land surveyor pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 54.1-400 et seq. 
Runoff volume means the volume of water that runs off the land development project from a prescribed storm event. 
Single-family residence means a noncommercial dwelling that is occupied exclusively by one family. 
State erosion and sediment control program or state program means the program administered by the Virginia Soil and Water Conservation Board pursuant to the Code of Virginia including regulations designed to minimize erosion and sedimentation. 
State waters means all waters on the surface and under the ground wholly or partially within or bordering the commonwealth or within its jurisdictions. 
Transporting means any moving of earth materials from one place to another place other than such movement incidental to grading, when such movement results in destroying the vegetative ground cover either by tracking or the buildup of earth materials to the extent that erosion and sedimentation will result from the soil or earth materials over which such transporting occurs. 
Water quality volume means the volume equal to the first one-half inch of runoff multiplied by the impervious surface of the land development project. 
(Code 1988, § 11-2; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 11-22-2005; Ord. No. 2009-33 , § 1, 4-28-2009)  
Sec. 11-3. - Erosion and sediment control program. 
(a)  The regulations, references, guidelines, standards and specifications promulgated by the board for the effective control of soil erosion and sediment deposition to prevent the unreasonable degradation of properties, stream channels, waters and other natural resources are hereby adopted. Said regulations, references, guidelines, standards and specifications for erosion and sediment control are included in but not limited to the "Virginia Erosion and Sediment Control Regulations" and the Virginia Erosion and Sediment Control Handbook, as amended. 
(b)  Before adopting or amending regulations, the city shall give due notice and conduct a public hearing on the proposed regulations or amendments, except that a public hearing shall not be required when the city is amending its program to conform to revisions in the state program. A public hearing shall be held if the city proposes adoption or amendment of regulations that will be more stringent than the state program. 
(c)  An erosion control plan shall not be approved until it is reviewed by a certified plan reviewer. A certified inspector shall conduct inspections of land-disturbing activities. The erosion control program of the city shall contain a certified program administrator, a certified plan reviewer, and a certified inspector, who may be the same person. 
(d)  The department of public utilities/public works, through the stormwater administrator or their designee, shall be the plan-approving authority. 
(e)  The program and regulations provided for in this article shall be made available for public inspection at the office of the department of public utilities/public works. 
(f)  In accordance with, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-561, stream restoration and relocation projects that incorporate natural channel design concepts are not man-made channels and shall be exempt from any flow rate capacity and velocity requirements for natural or man-made channels. 
(g)  In accordance with Code of Virginia, § 10.1-561, any land-disturbing activity that provides for stormwater management intended to address any flow rate capacity and velocity requirements for natural or manmade channels shall satisfy the flow rate capacity and velocity requirements for natural or manmade channels if the practices are designed to (i) detain the water quality volume and to release it over 48 hours; (ii) detain and release over a 24-hour period the expected rainfall resulting from the one year, 24-hour storm; and (iii) reduce the allowable peak flow rate resulting from the one and one-half-, two-, and ten-year 24-hour storms to a level that is less than or equal to the peak flow rate from the site assuming it was in a good forested condition, achieved through multiplication of the forested peak flow rate by a reduction factor that is equal to the runoff volume from the site when it was in a good forested condition divided by the runoff volume from the site in its proposed condition, and shall be exempt from any flow rate capacity and velocity requirements for natural or manmade channels. 
(Code 1988, § 11-3; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 11-22-2005; Ord. No. 2009-33 , § 2, 4-28-2009)  
Sec. 11-4. - Submission and approval of plans; contents of plans. 
(a)  Except as provided herein, no person may engage in any land-disturbing activity until he has submitted to the city an erosion and sediment control plan for the land-disturbing activity and such plan has been approved by the plan-approving authority. Where land-disturbing activities involve lands under the jurisdiction of more than one local control program, an erosion and sediment control plan, at the option of the applicant, may be submitted to the board for review and approval rather than to each jurisdiction concerned. Where the land-disturbing activity results from the construction of a single-family residence, an "agreement in lieu of a plan" may be substituted for an erosion and sediment control plan if executed by the plan-approving authority. Any person who commences land-disturbing activities prior to the approval of an erosion and sediment control plan or an agreement in lieu of a plan may be liable for a civil charge in an amount not to exceed $1,000.00 per day. 
(b)  The standards contained within the "Virginia Erosion and Sediment Control Regulations" and the Virginia Erosion and Sediment Control Handbook shall be used by the applicant when making a submittal under the provisions of this article and in the preparation of an erosion and sediment control plan. The plan-approving authority, in considering the adequacy of a submitted plan, shall be guided by the same standards, regulations and guidelines. When the standards vary between the publications, the state regulations shall take precedence. Three copies of the erosion and sediment control plan shall be submitted to the city. The plan shall include all information required by the Virginia Erosion and Sediment Control Handbook. 
(c)  The plan-approving authority shall review erosion and sediment control plans submitted to it and grant written approval within 45 days of the receipt of the plan if it determines that the plan meets the requirements of the board's regulations and if the person responsible for carrying out the plan certifies that he will properly perform the conservation measures included in the plan and will conform to the provisions of this article. In addition, as a prerequisite to engaging in the land-disturbing activities shown on the approved plan, the person responsible for carrying out the plan shall provide the name of an individual holding a certificate of competence, to the program authority, who will be in charge of and responsible for carrying out the land-disturbing activity. Failure to provide the name of an individual holding a certificate of competence prior to engaging in land-disturbing activities may result in revocation of the approval of the plan, and the person responsible for carrying out the plan shall be subject to the penalties provided in this article. 
(d)  The plan shall be acted upon within 45 days from receipt thereof by either approving said plan in writing or by disapproving said plan in writing and giving specific reasons for its disapproval. When the plan is determined to be inadequate, the plan-approving authority shall specify such modifications, terms and conditions that will permit approval of the plan. If no action is taken within 45 days, the plan shall be deemed approved and the person authorized to proceed with the proposed activity. 
(e)  An approved plan may be changed by the plan-approving authority when: 
(1)  The inspection reveals that the plan is inadequate to satisfy applicable regulations; or 
(2)  The person responsible for carrying out the plan finds that because of changed circumstances or for other reasons the approved plan cannot be effectively carried out, and proposed amendments to the plan, consistent with the requirements of this article, are agreed to by the plan-approving authority and the person responsible for carrying out the plans. 
(f)  In order to prevent further erosion, the city may require approval of a plan for any land identified in the local program as an erosion impact area. 
(g)  When land-disturbing activity will be required of a contractor performing construction work pursuant to a construction contract, the preparation, submission, and approval of an erosion and sediment control plan shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
(h)  Electric, natural gas and telephone utility companies, interstate and intrastate natural gas pipeline companies and railroad companies shall file general erosion and sediment control specifications annually with the board for review and written comments. The specifications shall apply to: 
(1)  Construction, installation or maintenance of electric, natural gas and telephone utility lines, and pipelines; and 
(2)  Construction of the tracks, rights-of-way, bridges, communication facilities and other related structures and facilities of the railroad company. 
Individual approval of separate projects within subsections (h)(1) and (h)(2) of this section is not necessary when board approved specifications are followed, however, projects included in subsections (h)(1) and (h)(2) of this section must comply with board approved specifications. Projects not included in subsections (h)(1) and (h)(2) of this section shall comply with the requirements of the city erosion and sediment control program. 
(i)  Any excavation activities within the Abex Superfund Site Operable Unit 1 (OU1) Area, as defined in article II of this chapter, shall also comply with the requirements of article II of this chapter. 
(j)  State agency projects are exempt from the provisions of this article, except as provided for in Code of Virginia, § 10.1-564. 
(k)  In accordance with the procedure set forth by Code of Virginia, § 10.1-563(E), any person engaging in the creation and operation of wetland mitigation banks in multiple jurisdictions, which have been approved and are operated in accordance with applicable federal and state guidance, laws, or regulations for the establishment, use, and operation of mitigation banks, pursuant to a permit issued by the Department of Environmental Quality, the Marine Resources Commission, or the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, may, at the option of that person, file general erosion and sediment control specifications for wetland mitigation banks annually with the board for review and approval consistent with guidelines established by the board. 
(Code 1988, § 11-4; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 11-22-2005; Ord. No. 2009-33 , § 3, 4-28-2009; Ord. No. 2009-36 , § 1, 5-12-2009, eff. 7-1-2009)  
Sec. 11-5. - Permits; fees; security for performance. 
(a)  Agencies authorized under any other law to issue grading, building, or other permits for activities involving land-disturbing activities may not issue any such permit unless the applicant submits with his application an approved erosion and sediment control plan and certification that the plan will be followed. 
(b)  No person may engage in any land-disturbing activity until he has acquired a land-disturbing permit, unless the proposed land-disturbing activity is specifically exempt from the provisions of this article, and has paid the fees and posted the required bond. 
(c)  The applicant shall pay an administrative review fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code at the time of submission of the erosion and sediment control plan. Except no fee shall be charged for the following: 
(1)  The review of an erosion and sediment control plan for the development of an individual single-family residential lot; or 
(2)  If the plan is submitted in conjunction with a commercial or industrial site plan review. 
(d)  No land-disturbing permit shall be issued until the applicant submits with his application an approved erosion and sediment control plan and certification that the plan will be followed. 
(e)  The applicant shall pay a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code for the cost of land disturbing permit processing, permit issuance, and inspections for the following categories: 
(1)  Development of an individual single-family lot involving over 2,500 square feet of land-disturbance. 
(2)  Demolition of a single-family structure involving over 2,500 square feet of land disturbance. 
(3)  Multifamily residential development. 
(4)  Demolition of multifamily structures. 
(5)  Commercial development and subdivisions involving less than one acre of land disturbance. 
(6)  Commercial development and subdivisions involving one to five acres of land disturbance. 
(7)  Commercial development and subdivisions involving more than five acres of land disturbance. 
(8)  Demolition of commercial structures. 
(f)  All applicants for permits shall provide to the city a performance bond, cash escrow, or an irrevocable letter of credit acceptable to the plan-approving authority, to ensure that measures could be taken by the city at the applicant's expense should the applicant fail, after proper notice, within the time specified to initiate or maintain appropriate conservation measures required of him as a result of his land-disturbing activity. The amount of the bond or other security for performance shall not exceed the total of the estimated cost to initiate and maintain appropriate conservation action based on unit prices for new public or private sector construction in the city and a reasonable allowance for estimated administrative costs and inflation which shall not exceed 25 percent of the cost of the conservation action. Should it be necessary for the city to take such conservation action, the city may collect from the applicant any costs in excess of the amount of the surety held. Within 60 days of adequate stabilization, as determined by the plan-approving authority in any project or section of a project, such bond, cash escrow or letter of credit, or the unexpended or unobligated portion thereof shall be either refunded to the applicant or terminated, based upon the percentage of stabilization accomplished in the project or project section. 
(g)  These requirements are in addition to all other provisions relating to the issuance of permits and are not intended to otherwise affect the requirements for such permits. 
(Code 1988, § 11-5; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 11-22-2005; Ord. No. 2020-34 , § 9, 5-12-2020)  
Sec. 11-6. - Monitoring, reports, and inspections. 
(a)  The city may require the person responsible for carrying out the plan to monitor the land-disturbing activity. The person responsible for carrying out the plan will maintain records of these inspections and maintenance, to ensure compliance with the approved plan and to determine whether the measures required in the plan are effective in controlling erosion and sedimentation. 
(b)  The plan-approving authority shall periodically inspect the land-disturbing activity in accordance with applicable regulations to ensure compliance with the approved plan and to determine whether the measures required in the plan are effective in controlling erosion and sedimentation. The owner, permittee, or person responsible for carrying out the plan shall be given notice of the inspection. If the plan-approving authority determines that there is a failure to comply with the plan, notice shall be served upon the permittee or person responsible for carrying out the plan by registered or certified mail to the address specified in the permit application or in the plan certification, or by delivery at the site of the land-disturbing activities to the agent or employee supervising such activities. The notice shall specify the measures needed to comply with the plan and shall specify the time within which such measures shall be completed. Upon failure to comply within the specified time, the permit may be revoked and the permittee or person responsible for carrying out the plan shall be deemed to be in violation of this article and shall be subject to the penalties provided by this article. 
(c)  Upon determination of a violation of this article, the plan-approving authority may, in conjunction with or subsequent to a notice to comply as specified in this article, issue an order requiring that all or part of the land-disturbing activities permitted on the site be stopped until the specified corrective measures have been taken. If land-disturbing activities have commenced without an approved plan, the plan-approving authority may, in conjunction with or subsequent to a notice to comply as specified in this section, issue an order requiring that all of the land-disturbing activities be stopped until an approved plan or any required permits are obtained. Where the alleged noncompliance is causing or is in imminent danger of causing harmful erosion of lands or sediment deposition in waters within the watersheds of the commonwealth, or where the land-disturbing activities have commenced without an approved plan or any required permits, such an order may be issued without regard to whether the permittee has been issued a notice to comply as specified in this section. Otherwise, such an order may be issued only after the permittee has failed to comply with such a notice to comply. The order shall be served in the same manner as a notice to comply, and shall remain in effect for a period of seven days from the date of service pending application by the enforcing authority or by the permit holder for appropriate relief to the Portsmouth Circuit Court. If the alleged violator has not obtained an approved plan or any required permits within seven days from the date of service of the order, the plan-approving authority may issue an order to the owner requiring that all construction and other work on the site, other than corrective measures, be stopped until an approved plan and any required permits have been obtained. Such an order shall be served upon the owner by registered or certified mail to the address specified in the permit application or the land records of the city. The owner may appeal the issuance of an order to the Portsmouth Circuit Court. Any person violating or failing, neglecting or refusing to obey an order issued by the plan-approving authority may be compelled in a proceeding instituted in the Portsmouth Circuit Court to obey same and to comply therewith by injunction, mandamus or other appropriate remedy. Upon completion and approval of corrective action or obtaining an approved plan or any required permits, the order shall immediately be lifted. Nothing in this section shall prevent the plan-approving authority from taking any other action authorized by this article. 
(Code 1988, § 11-6; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 11-22-2005; Ord. No. 2009-36 , § 2, 5-12-2009, eff. 7-1-2009; Ord. No. 2020-34 , § 9, 5-12-2020)  
Sec. 11-7. - Violations, penalties, legal remedies. 
(a)  [Reserved.] 
(b)  The plan-approving authority or the owner of property which has sustained damage or which is in imminent danger of being damaged, may apply to the circuit court to enjoin a violation or a threatened violation of this article, without the necessity of showing that an adequate remedy at law does not exist. However, an owner of property shall not apply for injunctive relief unless: 
(1)  He has notified in writing the alleged violator, and the program authority, that a violation of the local program has caused, or creates a probability of causing, damage to his property; and 
(2)  Neither the alleged violator nor the program authority has taken corrective action within 15 days to eliminate the conditions which have caused, or create the probability of causing, damage to his property. 
(c)  In addition to any civil penalties provided under this article, any person who violates any provision of this article may be liable to the city in a civil action for damages. 
(d)  Without limiting the remedies which may be obtained in this article, any person violating or failing, neglecting, or refusing to obey any injunction, mandamus or other remedy obtained pursuant to this section shall be subject, in the discretion of the court, to a civil penalty not to exceed $2,000.00 for each violation. The city may bring a civil action for such violation or failure. Any civil penalties assessed by a court shall be paid into the treasury of the city, except that where the violator is the locality itself, or its agent, the court shall direct the penalty to be paid into the state treasury. 
(e)  With the consent of any person who has violated or failed, neglected or refused to obey any regulation or condition of a permit or any provision of this article, such person shall pay a civil charge in an amount identified at the time of the issuance of the land-disturbing permit. Such charge shall be not less than $100.00 nor more than $2,000.00 for each violation or noncompliance with any regulation or condition of a permit or any provision of this article. Such civil charge shall be instead of any appropriate civil penalty that could be imposed under subsection (d) of this section. 
(f)  The commonwealth's attorney shall, upon request of the city or the permit issuing authority, take legal action to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(g)  Compliance with the provisions of this article shall be prima facie evidence in any legal or equitable proceeding for damages caused by erosion, siltation or sedimentation that all requirements of law have been met, and the complaining party must show negligence in order to recover any damages. 
(Code 1988, § 11-7; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 11-22-2005; Ord. No. 2009-36 , § 3, 5-12-2009, eff. 7-1-2009)  
Sec. 11-8. - Appeals and judicial review. 
(a)  Any applicant who is aggrieved by any action of the city or its agent in disapproving plans submitted pursuant to this article shall have the right to apply for and receive a review of such action by the public utilities/public works director or his designee provided an appeal is filed with the public utilities/public works director or his designee within 30 days from the date of the action. The public utilities/public works director or his designee shall conduct an appeal hearing within 30 days from receiving a request for such hearing. In reviewing the agent's actions, the public utilities/public works director or his designee shall consider credible evidence and professional opinions presented by the aggrieved applicant and the city's agent. After considering the credible evidence and professional opinions, the action may be affirmed, reversed or modified. The public utilities/public works director's or his designee's decision shall be in writing, setting forth factual findings and conclusions, and shall be final, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  The decision of the public utilities/public works director or his designee shall be subject to review by the circuit court, provided an appeal is filed within 30 days from the date of any written decision adversely affecting the rights, duties, or privileges of the person engaging in or proposing to engage in land-disturbing activities. 
(Code 1988, § 11-8; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 11-22-2005)  
Sec. 11-9. - Variances. 
The plan-approving authority may waive or modify any of the regulations in this section that are deemed inappropriate or too restrictive for site conditions by granting a variance. A variance may be granted under these conditions: 
(1)  At the time of plan submission, an applicant may request a variance to become part of the approved erosion and sediment control plan. The applicant shall explain the reasons for requesting variances in writing. Specific variances that are allowed by the plan-approving authority shall be documented in the plan. 
(2)  During construction, the person responsible for implementing the approved plan may request a variance in writing from the plan-approving authority. The plan-approving authority shall respond in writing either approving or disapproving such a request. If the plan-approving authority does not approve a variance within ten days of receipt of the request, the request shall be considered to be disapproved. Following disapproval, the applicant may resubmit a variance request with additional documentation. 
(3)  The plan-approving authority shall consider variance requests judiciously, keeping in mind both the need of the applicant to maximize cost effectiveness and the need to protect off-site properties and resources from damage. 
(Code 1988, § 11-9; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 11-22-2005)  
Sec. 11-10. - Plan contents; number of copies. 
The plan shall include all information required by the handbook referred to in section 11-3 and required for subdivision preliminary layouts by the subdivision ordinances, excluding commercial and industrial developments. The plan for commercial and industrial developments shall conform to the requirements of the handbook and the general requirements for parking lots as set forth in the zoning ordinance in chapter 40 of this Code. Three copies of the erosion and sedimentation control plan, along with a topographic survey and a plan showing the proposed development use, including but not limited to, subdivision, housing project, commercial or industrial development, condominium or planned unit development, shall be submitted to the plan-approving authority. 
(Code 1988, § 11.1-8; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 3, 11-22-2005; Ord. No. 2006-103, § 6, 12-12-2006)  
Secs. 11-11—11-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATION REQUIREMENTS FOR ABEX SUPERFUND SITE 
 
Sec. 11-41. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abex Superfund Site Operable Unit 1 (OU1) Area means the area generally bounded by Fifth Street on the east, Effingham Street on the west, Lincoln Street on the south, and Race Street on the north and inclusive of the area within a 350-foot radius of the corner of Seventh and Harrison Streets. 
Excavate means any disturbance or removal of any soils, including, but not limited to, soils beneath existing permanent covers (e.g., sidewalks, streets and any other paved areas), building or other permanent structures within the Abex Superfund Site Operable Unit 1 (OU1) Area. 
Person means an individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership, consortium, joint venture, commercial entity, United States Government, state, municipality, commission, political subdivision of a state, or any interstate body. 
(Code 1988, § 11-41; Ord. No. 1995-56, § 3, 10-15-1996)  
Sec. 11-42. - Environmental compliance excavation permit required; Abex Superfund Site Operable Unit 1 (OU1) Area. 
No person shall excavate any soils located within the Abex Superfund Site Operable Unit 1 (OU1) Area, as defined in section 11-41, prior to obtaining an environmental compliance excavation permit for such excavation from the city engineer or his designee. 
(Code 1988, § 11-42; Ord. No. 1995-56, § 3, 10-15-1996)  
Sec. 11-43. - Environmental compliance excavation permit; application procedures. 
(a)  No environmental compliance excavation permit for excavation of soils within the Abex Superfund Site Operable Unit 1 (OU1) Area shall be issued to any person unless such person has submitted an application for such a permit to the city engineer or his designee. An applicant for such a permit shall submit the following information, in writing to the city engineer or his designee: 
(1)  A description of the purpose and location of such excavation; the dates on which such excavation shall take place; the depth of such excavation; and the equipment to be used to conduct such excavation; 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of such applicant; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of any person who will perform the excavation (if other than the applicant); 
(4)  The professional or other qualifications, if any, of applicant or such other person who will perform the excavation; 
(5)  Proof of receipt of written notice of the information described in subsections (a)(1) through (a)(4) of this section, by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Region III, Director, Hazardous Waste Management Division, 1640 Arch Street, Philadelphia, PA 19103-2029; 
(6)  Proof of publication of a notice in at least one local newspaper of general circulation of a brief description of the purpose and location of such excavation and the name of the applicant and the person who will perform the work, if different from the applicant. 
(b)  The city engineer or his designee shall notify EPA and the public in writing or his intention to issue a permit under this section no later than five days prior to issuance of such permit. Notification of the public shall be accomplished by publication of such notice of such intent in a local newspaper of general circulation. Such notice shall: 
(1)  State the city's intention to issue such permit; 
(2)  Include the name of the applicant and the person who will perform the work, if different; and 
(3)  Provide a description of the purpose and location of such excavation. Applicant shall pay the cost of publication. 
(c)  An environmental compliance excavation permit shall not be issued to any person until a complete application containing all of the information described in subsection (a) of this section has been submitted by such person to the city engineer or his designee. 
(Code 1988, § 11-43; Ord. No. 1995-56, § 3, 10-15-1996; Ord. No. 2002-37, § 1, 7-9-2002)  
Sec. 11-44. - Environmental compliance excavation permit; terms and conditions. 
An environmental compliance excavation permit issued pursuant to this article shall include the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  All excavation activities shall be conducted in accordance with applicable requirements of OSHA and federal and state solid and hazardous waste management laws and regulations; 
(2)  All excavation activities shall be conducted in a manner which is consistent with the remedy and performance standards set forth in the Amended Record of Decision for OU1 of the Abex Superfund Site (signed August 15, 1994) and the Explanation of Significant Differences (ESD) signed October 5, 1995. Both documents are contained in the Abex Administrative Record, which is located at the Portsmouth Public Library, Reference Section, and the offices of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, 1650 Arch Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19103-2029; 
(3)  No excavation activities shall be conducted in a manner which may present an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health or welfare or the environment due to the release or threatened release of any hazardous substance, pollutant or contaminant. 
(Code 1988, § 11-44; Ord. No. 1995-56, § 3, 10-15-1996; Ord. No. 2002-37, § 1, 7-9-2002)  
Sec. 11-45. - Violations; penalties. 
Each of the following acts or omissions are prohibited and shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor: 
(1)  Excavation within the Abex Superfund Site Operable Unit 1 (OU1) Area without an environmental compliance excavation permit. 
(2)  Excavation by a permittee within the Abex Superfund Site Operable Unit 1 (OU1) Area in violation of the terms and conditions of an environmental compliance excavation permit. 
(3)  Excavation within the Abex Superfund Site Operable Unit 1 (OU1) Area in a manner inconsistent with the requirements or prohibitions contained in section 11-44. 
(Code 1988, § 11-45; Ord. No. 1995-56, § 3, 10-15-1996)  
Sec. 11-46. - Additional remedies for violations. 
The city engineer may issue a stop work order to and/or revoke the environmental compliance excavation permit issued to any person who engages in an activity in violation of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 11-46; Ord. No. 1995-56, § 3, 10-15-1996)  
Sec. 11-47. - Violations deemed public nuisance. 
Each act or omission described in section 11-45 shall constitute a public nuisance. 
(Code 1988, § 11-47; Ord. No. 1995-56, § 3, 10-15-1996)  
Sec. 11-48. - Forfeiture of bond for violations. 
A permittee who violates a term or condition of an environmental compliance permit issued under this section shall be subject to forfeiture of any bond required under section 11-5 and payment of all costs incurred by the city in abatement of the nuisance created thereby, including handling, analysis, treatment, storage and/or disposal of any excavated materials, as well as security and administrative costs. 
(Code 1988, § 11-48; Ord. No. 1995-56, § 3, 10-15-1996)  
Sec. 11-49. - Required notices. 
All notices required by this article to be provided to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency shall be provided to: 
Director 
Hazardous Waste Management Division 
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency 
Region III 
1650 Arch Street 
Philadelphia, PA 19103-2029 
(Code 1988, § 11-49; Ord. No. 1995-56, § 3, 10-15-1996; Ord. No. 2002-37, § 1, 7-9-2002)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year for the city shall begin on July 1 of each year. 
(Code 1973, § 11-1; Code 1988, § 12-1) 
State Law reference— Uniform fiscal year for all cities, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2500.  
Sec. 12-2. - System of accounts. 
The system of accounts and procedures employed with respect to funds of the city shall conform to regulations promulgated by the chief financial officer in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2509. 
(Code 1973, § 11-2; Code 1988, § 12-2; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001) 
State Law reference— Uniform system of bookkeeping and accounting, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2509.  
Sec. 12-3. - Certification as to availability of funds. 
No appropriation shall be encumbered and no expenditure shall be made unless the chief financial officer or his duly appointed assistant shall certify that there is an unencumbered balance of appropriated and available funds. 
(Code 1973, § 11-3; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-4. - Lapse of appropriations. 
Appropriations, to the extent they shall not have been expended or lawfully encumbered, shall lapse at the end of the period for which they were made. Grant appropriations made as a result of the operating budget shall lapse upon termination of the grant period, which shall include any extensions granted subsequent to the date of appropriation. 
(Code 1973, § 11-5; Code 1988, § 12-4; Ord. No. 1998-19, § 1, 4-28-1998)  
Sec. 12-5. - Transfers of appropriations. 
(a)  The chief financial officer may, at any time, transfer any encumbered appropriation balance or portion thereof within the same general classification of expenditures or within an office, department or agency. 
(b)  Should the city council make appropriations for an emergency contingency fund, the city manager may thereafter transfer any or all of the unencumbered portion thereof to any item of expense contained in the city budget, reporting such action and reason therefor to the city council at its next regular meeting. 
(c)  The city manager may, at any time during the fiscal year, transfer any unencumbered appropriation balance not to exceed $100,000.00 from one department, project, program or purpose to another department, project, program or purpose within the same accounting fund. The city manager shall make a monthly report to the city council of all transfers greater than $50,000.00. 
(Code 1973, § 11-6; Code 1988, § 12-5; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 1997-25, § 1, 5-6-1997; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-6. - Depositories and security for city funds other than funds of the department of public utilities. 
(a)  All funds of the city, except funds of the department of public utilities, shall be deposited to the credit of the city in such banks of the city as may from time to time be designated. 
(b)  All deposits of funds of the city, except funds of the department of public utilities, shall be secured in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Virginia Security of Public Deposits Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4400 et seq. 
(Code 1973, § 11-7; Code 1988, § 12-6) 
State Law reference— Security for deposits act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4400 et seq.  
Sec. 12-7. - Withdrawal of city funds. 
Funds placed in city depositories pursuant to section 12-6 shall be withdrawn only as appropriated by the city council. The city treasurer, or designee, shall sign automated vendor checks. Such checks shall be drawn only upon a payment voucher approved by the department heads, constitutional officers and appointed officials, or their designees, stating the particular fund and appropriation to which the same is chargeable and the vendor to whom payable. The city treasurer or his designee shall sign all payroll checks. The city treasurer and the chief financial officer, or their designees, shall sign all manual checks. 
(Code 1973, § 11-8; Code 1988, § 12-7; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-8. - Depositories and security for funds of the department of public utilities. 
(a)  All funds of the city received by or on behalf of the department of public utilities shall be deposited to the credit of the department in such bank as may be designated by the council from time to time. 
(b)  All deposits of funds of the city received by or on behalf of the department of public utilities shall be secured in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Virginia Security of Public Deposits Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4400 et seq. 
(Code 1973, § 11-9; Code 1988, § 12-8)  
Sec. 12-9. - Duty of persons collecting city revenue. 
Every officer and employee of the city that collects or receives any moneys due the city shall remit such moneys over to the city treasurer at such times as may be directed by the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city or by the city manager. At the time of remittance to the city treasurer, such officer or employee shall submit a report to the city treasurer of each transaction. 
(Code 1973, § 11-11; Code 1988, § 12-10; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-10. - Port Facilities and Economic Development Fund. 
All funds received by the city pursuant to paragraph 6 of the Port Unification Agreement dated March 30, 1971, as amended by an addendum thereto dated April 18, 1973, shall be transferred and paid over into a separate fund known as the "Port Facilities and Economic Development Fund." Such funds shall be applied as appropriated from time to time, by the city council for any of the following purposes: 
(1)  Debt service on and retirement of an outstanding bond issue for the construction of a terminal facility as referred to and required by paragraph 6 of the addendum of the Port Unification Agreement. 
(2)  Economic development of the city through purchase of land and capital improvements. 
(Code 1973, § 11-12.1; Code 1988, § 12-11)  
Sec. 12-11. - Setoff of indebtedness due city. 
Before disbursing funds of the city all indebtedness owed to the city shall be deducted from any payments. 
(Code 1973, § 11-13; Code 1988, § 12-12)  
Sec. 12-12. - Notes to meet appropriations for current year—Authorized. 
The city manager and the chief financial officer are authorized to make notes, through the proper officers, to borrow money for the purpose of meeting appropriations made for the then current year in anticipation of the collection of the taxes and revenues of such fiscal year, and within the amount of such appropriations, and to renew any such notes becoming due, when such renewals are necessary. Such loans shall mature and be paid within one year from the date of their issue. Provisions shall be made in the annuals budget of each year for the payment of all unpaid loans predicated upon the taxes and revenues of the previous fiscal year. No extension of such notes shall be valid and no additional notes shall be issued under this section until all notes issued under this section during preceding fiscal years shall have been paid. 
(Code 1973, § 11-14; Code 1988, § 12-13; Ord. No. 1991-65, § 1, 6-25-1991; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001) 
State Law reference— Notes to meet appropriations for current year, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2629.  
Sec. 12-13. - Same—Accompanying certificate. 
The following certificate shall accompany each note for the borrowing of funds issued pursuant to section 12-12. Such certificate shall be, as appropriate in either of the following forms:

This instruction is given in accordance with section 12-12 of the Code of the City of Portsmouth, Virginia (2006).

Sec. 12-14. - Notes in anticipation of bond issue—Authorized. 
(a)  In anticipation of the issuance of bonds and of the receipt of the proceeds of the sale of such bonds, the city manager and the chief financial officer are authorized to make notes, through the proper officers, to borrow money for the purposes for which such bonds have been authorized and within the maximum authorized amount of the bond issue, and to renew any such notes becoming due, when such renewals are necessary. Each such loan shall mature and be paid within two years from the date of its original issue; provided that on or after such maturity any loan now outstanding or hereafter made may be extended from time to time; provided, further, that no such extension shall mature and be paid later than one year from the date of the renewal of said loan. 
(b)  Any such loans may be retired by means of current revenues, special assessments or other funds, in lieu of retiring them by means of bonds; provided, that the maximum amount of bonds that has been authorized shall be reduced by the amount of such loans retired in such manner. 
(Code 1973, § 11-16; Code 1988, § 12-15; Ord. No. 1991-65, § 2, 6-25-1991; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001) 
State Law reference— Authority to issue notes which mature and be paid within five years, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2626.

The certificate hereinafter set shall accompany each note for the borrowing of funds issued pursuant to section 12-14 above. Such certificate shall be, as appropriate, in either of the following forms:

(Code 1973, § 11-17; Code 1988, § 12-16; Ord. No. 1990-99, § 1, 9-18-1990; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-16. - Disposition of certain paid and cancelled bonds and interest coupons. 
(a)  All bonds and interest coupons which have been paid and cancelled for more than ten years which are surrendered on bonds registered both as to principal and interest, shall be destroyed by the chief financial officer in the presence of two witnesses. A certificate, signed by the chief financial officer and the witnesses, showing the numbers and amounts of the bonds and coupons and the date of issue shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  The city council, by resolution, may approve the retention of certain paid and cancelled bonds which have historical significance for display, presentation and distribution purposes. Such resolution shall set forth the type, issue date and serial number of the bonds to be retained as well as the purpose for such retention. The chief financial officer shall certify prior to the release from his custody of any such bonds that all such bonds have been cancelled by perforation. 
(Code 1973, § 11-19; Code 1988, § 12-17; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 3, 2-13-2001) 
State Law reference— Destruction of bonds and coupons after payment in full, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2622.  
Sec. 12-17. - Compensation of jurors. 
A juror may direct in writing that compensation due him for his services as a juror be paid to the Portsmouth Behavioral Healthcare Services, the Portsmouth Department of Social Services, or the Portsmouth Juvenile and Domestic Relations District Court Services Unit, or to any combination of these agencies. 
(Code 1988, § 12-18; Ord. No. 1991-83, § 1, 8-27-1991) 
State Law reference— Compensation of jurors, Code of Virginia, § 17.1-619.  
Sec. 12-18. - Delinquencies; penalty and interest imposed. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this Code or by contract or agreement, in the event any payment on delinquent accounts due the city is not made when due, there shall be added thereto a penalty of ten percent of the amount of the unpaid payment due or $10.00, whichever is greater, but the penalty shall not exceed the amount of the unpaid payment due. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this Code or by contract or agreement, any person failing to pay any sum of money due the city by the date due shall incur, in addition to a penalty thereon, interest on that sum plus interest on any penalty assessed. Interest at a rate of ten percent per annum from the first day following the day such sum is due and said penalty is assessed shall be collected upon the principal and penalties of all such amounts due but remaining unpaid, and shall continue to accrue and be due until such sums are paid in full. 
(c)  Any provision of this Code notwithstanding, there is hereby imposed upon each person chargeable with a delinquent account, fees to cover the administrative costs and reasonable attorney's or collection agency's fees actually contracted for. The attorney's or collection fees shall not exceed 20 percent of the delinquent sum so collected. The administrative costs shall be in addition to all other penalties and interest, and shall be as set forth in Appendix A to this Code for taxes or other charges collected subsequent to 30 or more days after notice of delinquency but prior to the taking of judgment with respect to such delinquent account, and as set forth in Appendix A to this Code for taxes or other charges collected subsequent to judgment. 
(Ord. No. 2007-68, § 1, 6-26-2007, eff. 7-1-2007)  
Secs. 12-19—12-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 12-41. - Established; functions. 
There is hereby established a department of the city government known and designated as the department of finance, which shall include the functions of budgeting, accounting and retirement, and such other functions as may be provided by the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city or by order of the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 11-31; Code 1988, § 12-41)  
Sec. 12-42. - Documents in office subject to examination. 
The financial records, payment vouchers, contracts, bonds, cash receipts and other documents maintained in the department of finance shall be subject to the examination of the members of the city council, the city manager and the city's external auditors. 
(Code 1973, § 11-32; Code 1988, § 12-42)  
Secs. 12-43—12-61. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER 
 
Sec. 12-62. - Appointment and control. 
The city manager shall designate a chief financial officer who shall be subject to his direction and control. 
(Code 1973, § 11-42; Code 1988, § 12-62; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 3, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-63. - Absences of the chief financial officer. 
Whenever from sickness or other cause, the chief financial officer is absent from his office or otherwise not able to perform the duties thereof, the chief financial officer may designate persons who shall be authorized to sign whatsoever documents the chief financial officer would be required to sign if present for duty. 
(Code 1973, § 11-49; Code 1988, § 12-63; Ord. No. 1995-77, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-64. - General powers and duties. 
(a)  Functions. The chief financial officer shall have authority and shall be responsible for the department of finance in order to discharge the following functions: 
(1)  Revenue and expense estimates. Compile the revenue and expense estimates for the budget and appropriation ordinances for the city manager. 
(2)  Capital estimates. Compile the capital estimates for the budget and appropriation ordinances for the city manager. 
(3)  Administer disbursements. Administer the disbursement of all moneys and exercise control over all expenditures to ensure that appropriations are not exceeded. 
(4)  Accounting system. Maintain an accounting system for the city government and each of its offices, departments and agencies; maintain financial records for and exercise financial and budgetary control over each office, department and agency; keep separate accounts for the items of expense contained in the city budget, which shall show the amount of the appropriation, the amounts paid thereon, the unpaid obligations against it and the unencumbered balance; and require reports of cash receipts and disbursements from each receiving and spending agency of the city government to be made daily or at such intervals as he may deem expedient. 
(5)  Quarterly statement. Submit to the city council through the city manager a quarterly statement of all receipts, disbursements and encumbrances of funds in sufficient detail to show the exact financial condition of the city. 
(6)  Annual statements and reports. Prepare, as of the end of each fiscal year, a complete set of financial statements and reports. 
(b)  Powers of chief financial officer. The chief financial officer shall have the power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Prescribing forms. Prescribe the forms of reports, cash receipts, payment vouchers, invoices or claims to be used by all the offices, departments and agencies of the city government. 
(2)  Examination, approval of documents. Examine and approve all contracts, purchase orders and other documents by which the city government incurs financial obligations, having previously ascertained that funds have been appropriated and will be available when the obligation shall become due and payable. 
(3)  Review and approval of claims. Review and approve before payment all bills, invoices, payrolls and other evidences of claims, demands or charges against the city government and, with the advice of the city attorney, determine the regularity, legality and correctness of such claims, demands or charges. 
(4)  Uncollectible taxes and receivables. Write off uncollectible taxes and other uncollectible receivables owed to the city up to the sum of $300.00 or which have been owed for more than three years for each such sum owed; in accordance with the procedures in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3910 et seq. 
(5)  Internal audits and reviews. Make periodic internal audits or reviews of all funds and all departments for proper charges, appropriations and expenditures and of all departments, officers and agencies collecting charges, fees, fines and other revenues for the city. These periodic internal audits or reviews shall be accomplished in such a manner and with such frequency as to ensure compliance with general law and adherence to internal control policies and procedures. In case of any discrepancies, the chief financial officer shall report any material discrepancies to the city manager and the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 11-43; Code 1988, § 12-64; Ord. No. 1995-77, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 1995-113, § 1, 11-28-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 3, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-65. - Duty regarding officers receiving revenue. 
It shall be the duty of the chief financial officer to monitor the receipt of revenues or moneys pursuant to section 12-9. 
(Code 1973, § 11-44; Code 1988, § 12-65; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-66. - Recovery from officers failing to make proper settlement. 
If any officer required by section 12-65 to submit reports, with vouchers and receipts, shall neglect to make an adjustment of his accounts when so required, and to pay over such moneys so received, it shall be the duty of the chief financial officer to issue notice in writing, directed to such officer and his sureties, requiring him, or them, within ten days, to make settlement of his account with the chief financial officer, and to pay over the balance of the money found to be due and in his hands belonging to the city according to the city's accounting records as overseen by the chief financial officer. In case of the refusal or neglect of such officer to adjust his accounts or pay over the balance to the city treasurer, as required, it shall then be the duty of the chief financial officer to make report of the delinquency of such officer to the mayor and the city manager, the latter of whom shall suspend him at once from office, proceed forthwith to institute the necessary proceedings for the removal of such officer from office, and immediately on his removal institute suit in the name of the city against him and his sureties to recover the balance of moneys so found to be due and belonging to the city. 
(Code 1973, § 11-45; Code 1988, § 12-66; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-67. - Duties as to leases and ground rents. 
The chief financial officer shall keep a list of all leases and ground rents and shall charge the amount of the same to the city treasurer. 
(Code 1973, § 11-46; Code 1988, § 12-67; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-68. - Maintenance of schedules generally. 
The chief financial officer shall keep a complete schedule of all mortgages, contracts, judgments, notes, bonds and other indebtedness belonging to the city and confided to his custody. 
(Code 1973, § 11-47; Code 1988, § 12-68; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-69. - Schedule of bad checks, drafts and debits; fee to be charged. 
The city treasurer shall maintain a complete list of all checks or drafts issued, published or passed to the city, and legally authorized debits, for payment of taxes or sums due which are subsequently returned because of insufficient funds, no account or account closed. The person issuing, publishing or passing such check or draft, or authorizing a debit to his account, shall, in addition to the sum due and all civil liabilities incurred by reason of said check, draft or legally authorized debt, pay to the city a fee not to exceed that authorized by the Code of Virginia, § 15.2-106. 
(Code 1973, § 11-47.1; Code 1988, § 12-69; Ord. No. 1990-101, § 1, 9-25-1990; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 1998-36, § 1, 7-28-1998) 
Cross reference— Giving bad check for payment of taxes, § 35-16. 
State Law reference— Authority for above fee, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-106.  
Sec. 12-70. - Preservation of effects of office; succession. 
The financial records and schedules supplied to the chief financial officer shall be maintained in an orderly and systematic manner and, at the expiration of his term of service, shall be turned over to the custody of his successor. 
(Code 1973, § 11-48; Code 1988, § 12-70; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 3, 2-13-2001)  
Secs. 12-71—12-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CITY TREASURER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Election, term and general duties of city treasurer, §§ 6.01, 6.03. 
Cross reference— Nuisance abatement lien docket book to be maintained in city treasurer's office, § 23-5. 
 
Sec. 12-116. - Office established. 
The office of city treasurer is hereby established. 
(Code 1973, § 11-72; Code 1988, § 12-116)  
Sec. 12-117. - Deputy treasurers. 
The city treasurer shall have in his office one or more deputy city treasurers who, in the absence or disability of the city treasurer, shall act in his stead. The city treasurer and his sureties shall be responsible for the acts of such deputies while in the performance of such duties. 
(Code 1973, § 11-76; Code 1988, § 12-117)  
Sec. 12-118. - Collection of revenue. 
Subject to the supervision of the chief financial officer in all matters pertaining to funds of the city, the city treasurer shall collect and receive all taxes, levies, assessments, license taxes, fees, accounts, claims, fines, costs and all other revenue or moneys accruing to the city, except as may otherwise especially provided by the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 11-73; Code 1988, § 12-118; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-119. - Deposit of funds. 
All money received by the city treasurer shall be deposited daily intact by the city treasurer as promptly as practical after its receipt in a bank or savings institution authorized to act as depository therefore and he shall obtain from the bank two deposit certificates, one of which shall be filed with the chief financial officer. All deposits made pursuant to this provision shall be made in the name of the city. The treasurer may designate any bank or savings and loan association authorized to act as a depository to receive any payments due to the city directly, either through a processing facility or through a branch office. 
(Code 1973, § 11-74; Code 1988, § 12-119; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995)  
Sec. 12-120. - Record of cash receipts and disbursements. 
The city treasurer shall keep an accurate account of all cash receipts and disbursements and shall not make payment of any sums except in accordance with the provisions of section 12-7. The system of accounts, receipt forms and procedures employed with respect to funds of the city shall conform to regulations promulgated by the chief financial officer. 
(Code 1973, § 11-75; Code 1988, § 12-120; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 12-121. - Fee for the construction, renovation or maintenance of the courthouses, jail or court-related facilities. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed for the construction, renovation or maintenance of the courthouses or jail and court-related facilities an assessment in the amount as set forth in appendix A to this Code, as part of the costs incident to civil, criminal or traffic cases filed in the circuit court and district courts located within the boundaries of the city. The assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed and remitted to the treasurer. Disbursements shall be as authorized by the city council for the construction, renovation or maintenance of courthouses or jail and court-related facilities and to defray increases in the cost of heating, cooling, electricity and ordinary maintenance. 
(b)  The Virginia Department of General Services, having certified that the city circuit and district courthouses in operation between January 1, 2008, and September 21, 2012, were not in compliance with the safety and security guidelines contained in the Virginia Courthouse Facility Guidelines, an additional fee as set out in appendix A shall be assessed as part of the costs in each civil action filed in the district or circuit courts and in each criminal or traffic case in the district or circuit courts. Such additional fee shall not be assessed in any civil action if the amount in controversy is $500.00 or less. Any assessment so collected shall be expended solely for the construction, reconstruction, renovation, or adaptive reuse of a structure or structures to replace the courthouses so certified as not in compliance. 
(c)  The assessments provided for in subsections (a) and (b) of this section are in addition to the amount of clerk's fees or court costs already imposed or assessed for traffic or criminal cases and shall be in addition to any other fees prescribed by law. 
(Code 1988, § 12-121; Ord. No. 1991-44, § 1, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1992-45, § 1, 6-9-1992; Ord. No. 2010-17, § 1, 3-9-2010; Ord. No. 2012-65, § 1, 11-13-2012)  
Sec. 12-122. - Local criminal justice training academy fee imposed on certain individuals. 
(a)  In addition to any other fee prescribed by law, the clerks of the circuit court and general district court, shall charge and collect a local criminal justice training academy fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code each time a fee is charged pursuant to Virginia Code, §§ 16.1-69.48:1, 17.1-275.1, 17.1-275.2, 17.1-275.3, 17.1-275.4, 17.1-275.7, 17.1-275.8 or 17.1-275.9, as each may be amended. 
(b)  Each such clerk shall remit such fees to the city treasurer. 
(c)  The treasurer shall hold such fees subject to disbursements authorized by the city council. All funds from such fee shall support the city's criminal justice training academy. 
(Code 1988, § 12-122; Ord. No. 2003-43, § 1, 7-22-2003)  
Secs. 12-123—12-140. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC PROCUREMENT[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Virginia Public Procurement Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-4300 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 12-171. - Purpose of article. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to increase public confidence in purchasing by the city, to encourage competition in public purchasing among vendors and contractors, to administer fairly and equitably purchasing policies among bidders, and to obtain high quality goods and services for the city at reasonable cost. 
(b)  It is the intent of the general assembly that competition be sought to the maximum feasible degree, that procurement procedures involve openness and administrative efficiency, that individual public bodies enjoy broad flexibility in fashioning details of such competition, that the rules governing contract awards be made clear in advance of the competition, that specifications reflect the procurement needs of the purchasing body rather than being drawn to favor a particular vendor, and that the purchaser and vendor freely exchange information concerning what is sought to be procured and what is offered. Public bodies may consider best value concepts when procuring goods and nonprofessional services, but not construction or professional services. The criteria, factors, and basis for consideration of best value and the process for the consideration of best value shall be as stated in the procurement solicitation. 
(Code 1973, § 11-100; Code 1988, § 12-171; Ord. No. 2002-22, § 1, 5-14-2002)  
Sec. 12-172. - Application of article; compliance with federal or state law or terms of grant, gift, etc. 
(a)  This article applies to contracts for the procurement of goods, services, insurance and construction entered into by the city and the school board of the city involving every expenditure for public purchasing irrespective of its source. This article also applies to any other public body whose situs is in the city and whose board or commission elects to be included hereunder (hereinafter referred to as "city"). 
(b)  When the procurement involves the expenditures of federal or state assistance or contract funds, the procurement shall be conducted in accordance with any applicable mandatory federal or state laws and regulations which are not reflected in this article. Nothing in this article shall prevent any public agency from complying with the terms and conditions of any grant, gift or bequest which are otherwise consistent with law. 
(Code 1973, § 11-101; Code 1988, § 12-172)  
Sec. 12-173. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Best value, as predetermined in the solicitation, means the overall combination of quality, price, and various elements of required services that in total are optimal relative to a public body's needs. 
Brand name or equal specification means a specification limited to one or more items by manufacturer's names or catalog numbers to describe the standard quality, performance and other salient characteristics needed to meet the requirements of the city and which provides for the submission of equivalent products. 
Brand name specification means a specification limited to one or more items by manufacturer's names or catalog numbers. 
Business means any corporation, partnership, limited liability company, association, or sole proprietorship operated for profit, or any other private legal entity. 
Construction means building, altering, repairing, improving or demolishing any structure, building or highway, and any draining, dredging, excavation, grading or similar work upon real property. 
Contract means all types of city agreements, regardless of what they might be called, for the procurement of goods, services, insurance or construction. 
Contract modification means any written alteration in specifications, delivery point, rate of delivery, period of performance, price, quantity, or other provision of any contract accomplished by mutual action of the parties of the contract. 
Contractor means any person having a contract with the city or a using agency thereof. 
Goods means all material, equipment, supplies, printing and automated data processing, hardware and software. 
Informality means a minor defect or variation of a bid or proposal from the exact requirements of an invitation to bid, or the request for a proposal, which does not affect the price, quantity, quality or delivery schedule for the goods, services or construction being procured. 
Insurance means a contract whereby, for a stipulated consideration, one party undertakes to compensate the other for loss on a specified subject by specified perils. 
Invitation for bids means all documents, whether attached or incorporated by reference, utilized for soliciting sealed bids. 
Job order contracting means a method of procuring construction services by establishing a book of unit prices and then obtaining a contractor to perform work as needed using the prices, quantities, and specifications in the book as the basis of its pricing. The contractor may be selected through either competitive sealed bidding or competitive negotiation depending on the needs of the city. A minimum amount of work may be specified in the contract. The contract term and the project amount shall not exceed the limitations specified in Code of Virginia, §§ 2.2-4302.2 or 2.2-4303, as amended, restated or moved from time to time. 
Life cycle costing means an evaluation that takes into account all costs incidental to the planning, design, construction, operation, maintenance, and disposal of a system or facility calculated in terms of present value or annual owning and operating costs. 
Nonprofessional services means any services not specifically identified as professional services in this article. 
Professional services means work performed by an independent contractor within the scope of the practice of accounting, actuarial services, architecture, land surveying, landscape architecture, law, dentistry, medicine, optometry, pharmacy, or professional engineering. 
Public body means any legislative, executive, or judicial body, agency, office, department, authority, post, commission, committee, institution, board, or political subdivision created by law to exercise some sovereign power or to perform some governmental duty and empowered by law to undertake the activities described in this article. 
Request for proposals means all documents, including addendums and amendments, whether attached or incorporated by reference, utilized for soliciting proposals for goods or services. 
Responsible bidder or offeror means a person who has the capability, in all respects, to perform fully the contract requirements and the moral and business integrity, and reliability, which will assure good faith performance, and who has been prequalified, if required. 
Responsive bidder means a person who has submitted a bid which conforms in all material respects to the invitation to bid. 
Reverse auctioning means a procurement method wherein bidders are invited to bid on specified goods or nonprofessional services through real-time electronic bidding, with the award being made to the lowest responsive and responsible bidder. During the bidding process, bidders' prices are revealed and bidders shall have the opportunity to modify their bid prices for the duration of the time period established for bid opening.
