(4)  Floors, walls, and ceilings shall be in good repair and kept clean. 
(5)  Approved dispensers, soap and single-use paper towels shall be made available to accommodate hand washing. 
(6)  Live animals shall be allowed in the facility but shall not be fed using the same equipment or utensils that are used to feed humans. 
( Ord. No. 2011-48, § 2, 7-12-2011)  
Chapter 16 - GARBAGE AND REFUSE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Deposit of trash, debris, etc., in city waters, § 6-1; garbage and trash receptacles for food establishments, § 15-79; garbage and refuse disposal in mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions, § 21-31; accumulation of debris constituting nuisances, § 23-26 et seq.; disposal of garbage and refuse in parks, § 25-100; trash receptacles required on mobile vending unit, § 32-179. 
State Law reference— Virginia Waste Management Act, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1400 et seq.; general authority of city relative to collection and disposal of garbage and refuse, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-927, 15.2-928. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in articles I and II of this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approved container means a storage and collection receptacle or container required for the storage and collection of solid waste or recyclables issued by the city and used in the automated solid waste collection program. 
Automated refuse collection means collection service provided to residences equipped with a city-furnished 65-gallon or 105-gallon automated collection container. 
Bulk refuse means the term "bulk refuse" shall include bulky items such as household construction debris not generated by a contractor, household construction debris not generated by a contractor, furniture, tree trimmings, cuttings, shrubbery and the like. 
Business or commercial establishments means any premises wherein: 
(1)  There is carried on any business, profession or occupation subject to the license tax ordinance of the city; or 
(2)  There is carried on any broadcasting, publishing, manufacturing or commercial activity or process, including the renting of residential property; or 
(3)  There are multifamily units of four or more including condominium units. 
Construction site means any area in which construction of any type is conducted, including roads, buildings and all other places actively being constructed or renovated by public or private owners or the agent, employees or contractors thereof. 
Director shall mean the director of general services of the city or the director's authorized representative. 
Dwelling means any building which is wholly or partly used or intended to be used for living or sleeping by human occupants. 
Dwelling unit means any room or group of rooms located within a dwelling and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
Hazardous wastes means those wastes that can cause serious injury or disease during the normal storage, collection of disposal process, including, but not limited to, flammable, explosive, pathological or infectious wastes, radioactive materials and dangerous chemicals. 
Industrial waste shall include building material waste resulting from erecting, removing, repairing, remodeling or razing buildings; used parts from vehicles and tires of a size 800 by 20 and greater; ashes from boilers, incinerators, or other trash or matter originating in a business or manufacturing establishment intended not for use or sale. 
Operator means the person operating any business or commercial establishment as distinguished from the owner of the premises involved. 
Recyclables means items, including but not limited to, newspapers, cardboard, junk mail, and catalogs, papers; clear glass bottles and jars; plastic containers #1 and #2; aluminum cans, aluminum foil and steel/tin food cans. 
Refuse means any putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body waste), including garbage, rubbish, trash, ashes and other similar wastes. 
Small dead animals means dead cats, dogs, small household pets and other animals of similar size. 
Tires shall mean a privately owned vehicle tire of a size less than 800 by 20. 
Trash means the accumulation of waste paper, rags, bottles, cans or other similar matter. 
White goods shall mean large household appliances such as refrigerators, water heaters and washing machines. 
Yard waste means material derived from leaves, shrubbery trimmings, and lawn trimmings. 
(Code 1973, § 14-1; Code 1988, § 16-1; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 2(14-1), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1992-14, § 1, 2-25-1992; Ord. No. 1992-84, § 1, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 3, 3-11-1997; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 1, 9-26-2006; Ord. No. 2013-32, § 1, 5-28-2013 ) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 16-2. - Violations of chapter. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. Additionally, any person in violation of any provision of this chapter shall be liable for all damage, loss and expense suffered or incurred by the city as a result of such violations. 
(b)  When a violation of the refuse provisions of this chapter has occurred the person listed as responsible for payment of the refuse bill for that address shall be presumed to be the person causing the violation. Such presumption shall be rebuttable by competent evidence as determined by the director of general services or his designee. 
(c)  In accordance with § 15.2-298 of the Code of Virginia, the first violation under this chapter excluding the provisions of section 16-35 shall result in a violation notice being sent to the owner or occupant of the property. For a second violation within 12 months, a fine of $25.00 shall be imposed and shall be added to the refuse bill. A third violation within 12 months shall be punishable by a fine of $50.00 which shall be added to the refuse bill. Further violations within 12 months shall be punishable by a fine of $100.00 which shall be added to the refuse bill. 
(d)  Dwellings or businesses that have been granted an exemption from the refuse bill in accordance with section 16-62 of this chapter are still subject to the penalties noted in section 16-2(c). For violations of this chapter, fines for violations shall be added to the refuse section of the water bill. In addition, the provisions of section 16-31 may also be applied. 
(Code 1988, § 16-2; Ord. No. 1996-68, § 1, 12-17-1996; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 2, 9-26-2006) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 16-3. - Unlawful disposal generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or dispose of any refuse in any place in the city except in a licensed private landfill or at a site designated for such purpose and operated by the Southeastern Public Service Authority of Virginia. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or dump any refuse generated outside of the corporate limits of the city at any place within the corporate limits of the city except such site as may be designated for such purpose and operated by the Southeastern Public Service Authority of Virginia. 
(Code 1973, §§ 14-2, 14-6; Code 1988, § 16-3) 
Cross reference— Deposit of trash in city waters, § 6-1.  
Sec. 16-4. - Littering. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit any garbage, trash or rubbish upon the floor or platform of buses, public elevators, public halls, or the floor or other interior portion of any public building in this city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, drop or deposit on any premises or vacant property within the city any waste, including, but not limited to, refuse, garbage, trash, ashes, rubbish, building rubbish, dead animals, putrescible matter and anything injurious to health; provided, however, that the prohibition contained in this subsection shall not apply to the deposit of waste not injurious to health on a public landfill where permission to make such deposit is granted by the director of general services and done in accordance with the regulations established by the director of general services pertaining to the use of such public landfills, nor to the filling in or grading of property with earth, mud, ashes, and similar materials. 
(Code 1973, § 14-7; Code 1988, § 16-4; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 3(14-7(b)), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997)  
Sec. 16-5. - Dumping trash, refuse, garbage, debris or other unsightly matter prohibited. 
(a)  Any person shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor who shall dump or otherwise dispose of trash, garbage, refuse, debris or other unsightly matter on any public property, including a public highway or right-of-way and property adjacent to such highway or right-of-way, or on private property in the city without the written consent of the owner thereof or his agent. A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $250.00 or more than $2,500.00 and confinement in jail for not more than 12 months, either or both. In lieu of the imposition of confinement in jail, the court may order the defendant to perform community service in litter abatement activities. 
(b)  When any person is arrested for a violation of this section and the matter alleged to have been dumped or disposed of has been ejected from a motor vehicle, the arresting officer may comply with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-936 in making such arrest. 
(c)  When a violation of the provisions of this section has been observed by any person and the matter dumped or disposed of has been ejected or removed from a motor vehicle, the owner or operator of such motor vehicle shall be presumed to be the person ejecting or disposing such matter. Such presumption shall be rebuttable by competent evidence. 
(d)  When a person is convicted of a violation this section, the court may suspend the imposition of any sentence upon such person, on the condition that the defendant volunteer his services for such period of time as the court may designate to remove trash, garbage, refuse, debris or other unsightly matter from public or private property as designated by the court. 
(e)  Police officers and fire marshals are authorized and designated to enforce the provisions in sections 16-3 and 16-5. 
(Code 1973, § 39-17; Code 1988, § 16-5; Ord. No. 2004-9, § 1, 2-10-2004; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Litter control, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1414 et seq.; similar provisions and authority of city to adopt above section, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-346.  
Sec. 16-6. - Storage containers generally. 
(a)  Except as provided for in paragraph (b) herein, it shall be unlawful for garbage or trash to be placed, deposited or allowed to remain on any premises within the city unless same is placed or kept in covered containers or a rigid, tapered, galvanized steel or plastic receptacle. The cover on such receptacles or containers shall be kept on same at all times, except when the receptacle is being filled or emptied. Plastic or polyethylene bags shall be used only as liners in such receptacles and it shall be unlawful to use same as the sole means of storage of garbage or refuse on any premises within the city. 
(b)  For residences receiving automated refuse collection it shall be unlawful for garbage and trash to be placed, deposited or allowed to remain on any premises within the city unless same is placed in a 65- or 105-gallon container furnished by the city. The cover on such receptacle shall be kept on same at all times, except when the receptacle is being filled or emptied. Plastic or polyethylene bags shall be used only as liners in such receptacles and it shall be unlawful to use same as the sole means of storage of garbage or refuse on any premises within the city. 
(c)  For dwellings and businesses using dumpsters, it shall be unlawful for garbage or trash to be placed, deposited or allowed to remain on any premises within the city unless same is placed or kept inside the dumpster. The dumpster shall remain closed at all times. 
(Code 1973, § 14-3; Code 1988, § 16-6; Ord. No. 1992-14, § 2, 2-25-1992; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006)  
Sec. 16-7. - Litter receptacles in public places. 
(a)  As used in this section, a litter receptacle shall mean those containers acceptable to the director of general services and which may be standardized as to size, shape, capacity, color, and cover design which shall bear the state antilitter symbol. The term "litter" as used in this section shall mean paper, waste materials, bottles, and cans, but shall not include garbage, refuse, or bulk refuse. Large containers known as "dumpsters" may be used as receptacles for the deposit of litter if such use is approved by the director. 
(b)  Requirements. Litter receptacles shall be required in the following public places. The minimum number of litter receptacles for each public place shall be specified herein. Additional receptacles may be required by the building official or his representative as determined by the needs of a particular location. 
(1)  Sidewalks in business districts. The need for receptacles and their placement, and the responsibility for their maintenance and service, shall be controlled by the director or his representative. 
(2)  Shopping centers. Receptacles shall be located along pedestrian travel routes normally taken by persons using such facility. The number and placement of receptacles shall be determined by the operator, or group responsible for the operation of such facility; except no less than one receptacle shall be placed at each entrance to the building. All parking lots and establishments with parking lots shall provide litter receptacles distributed within the parking area. 
(3)  Drive-in restaurants and fast food restaurants. One receptacle per establishment, plus additional receptacles as necessary to contain litter generated by the facility. 
(4)  Self-service refreshment areas. One receptacle for each separate area, provided each separate area contains two or more machines for dispensing, or serving food and/or drink. 
(5)  Gasoline service stations. One receptacle per service island. 
(6)  Construction sites. Receptacles sufficient to contain workmen's litter, plus those construction wastes capable of being spread by wind or water; the wind and water from hurricanes, tornados, and floods excepted. No less than one receptacle shall be placed at each site. Dirt, mud, construction materials or other debris deposited upon any public or private property as a result of construction or demolition, shall be immediately removed by the contractor. 
(7)  Marinas, boat moorage and fueling stations, public and private piers which are operated for public use. One receptacle on each pier plus additional receptacles as necessary to contain litter generated by the facility. 
(8)  Boat launching areas. At least one receptacle shall be placed as needed consistent with use of the area and the need for a litter deposit. 
(9)  Sporting events, fairgrounds, carnivals, circuses, festivals and other similar events. Receptacles shall be placed sufficient in number to contain the litter generated at such event and spaced so as to be reasonably accessible in those areas. The placement and need for such receptacles shall be determined by the operator, sponsor, or group operating such event; except no less than one receptacle shall be placed at each event. 
(10)  Public buildings, including schools. One receptacle at or reasonably near each entrance to each building. 
(11)  Trailer parks, recreational facilities and recreational areas, including parks, campgrounds, beaches and bathing areas. One receptacle for each facility or area at which food or drink is sold, plus additional receptacles as necessary to accommodate the need for litter depository. 
All litter containers shall be weighted or attached to the ground as necessary to prevent spillage. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or manager of the above-enumerated facilities to collect the refuse deposited and store material in an approved location and container for collection. 
(Code 1973, § 14-9; Code 1988, § 16-7; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006)  
Sec. 16-8. - Control of trash, etc., at construction sites. 
(a)  Construction sites shall be maintained in such a manner as to prevent trash and construction-related debris from accumulating thereon unrestrained or being allowed to blow or be transported onto other property. A suitable trash receptacle shall be maintained on the site at all times during construction. 
(b)  Dirt, sand, gravel and similar construction materials shall be stored on construction sites in such a manner so as not to be deposited or tracked on public streets or rights-of-way. 
(c)  Any violation of this section may be abated in the manner prescribed by section 16-31. 
(Code 1973, § 14-29; Code 1988, § 16-8) 
Cross reference— Building regulations, ch. 7.  
Sec. 16-9. - Picking over, sorting, etc., garbage, refuse, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to sort or remove any garbage, trash, litter, refuse, or rubbish from trash or recycling receptacles on the streets of the city, or rake, pick, sort over or gather material from any place where garbage, trash or refuse is dumped or distributed in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 14-8; Code 1988, § 16-9; Ord. No. 2013-32, § 2, 5-28-2013)  
Sec. 16-10. - Refuse collection requirements. 
(a)  Refuse containers such as dumpsters or other approved receptacles shall be required for mobile home parks and for multifamily, commercial and industrial developments. The number, size, design, and location of such containers shall be approved by the director of general services or his designee. 
(b)  Refuse containers shall be located on a site so that service vehicles will have a convenient access to them while minimizing encroachment on parking places, vehicular circulation drives, sidewalks, and public right of ways. Dumpsters and their enclosure shall not be closer than 50 feet to any residential structure and shall be set back a minimum of five feet from the property line. 
(c)  Commercial high volume refuse generators on sites with sufficient outside area to accommodate refuse enclosures with adequate capacity shall provide for indoor refuse storage. Compaction devices may be a part of such an accommodation. 
(d)  Refuse containers shall be located on a paved area or concrete pad constructed in accordance with all applicable health department standards. They shall be hidden from general view by means of fencing, masonry walls, landscaping, or other such method deemed necessary and acceptable by the director of general services. 
(e)  All refuse containers shall be adequately sized to handle the needs of the facility or development. The director of general services may require a developer to demonstrate adequate refuse capacity by calculation using waste industry standards. Materials and waste which may be edible or attractive to rodents or insects shall only be stored in completely closed containers. 
(f)  If centralized refuse containers are used in residential developments, they shall be located in an area or areas conveniently accessible to all residents. The containers shall be enclosed on three sides by a solid wood or masonry wall with a solid opaque gate provided on the fourth side. Landscaping shall be incorporated to improve the visual appearance. Support posts, gate frames, hinges and latches should be of sufficient size and strength to allow gates to function without sagging or becoming an eyesore. 
(g)  If individual refuse containers are used for the units in a residential development, the site plan shall provide adequate storage space and outdoor access to such storage for the occupant or each residential structure to store the refuse container in a side or rear yard. 
(Ord. No. 2006-85, § 4, 9-26-2006)  
Secs. 16-11—16-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY COLLECTIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 16-31. - Abatement of violations of division. 
If an owner or occupant fails, refuses or neglects to comply with any provision of this division after delivery or posting of reasonable notice of violation of this division, the director may invoke the provisions of sections 16-2 or 16-5, and/or cause the nuisance or the condition which is in violation of this division to be abated and may transmit to the city treasurer a statement of all costs incurred thereby. Included in such costs shall be a $150.00 fee to cover the administrative expense incurred and a fee of $250.00 per load or portion thereof for the use of the city's waste management vehicles and equipment. All such costs shall be added to the taxes assessed against the real estate on which the nuisance or condition in violation of this division existed or the real estate abutting the alley, sidewalk or street on which the nuisance or condition in violation of this division existed, for the ensuing tax year and shall be collected with such taxes by any manner prescribed by law for the collection of city taxes. All costs incurred thereby shall be docketed as a lien against such real property, in the nuisance abatement lien docket book maintained in the office of the city treasurer, which lien shall exist in the office of the city treasurer until removed by payment of such costs in full. 
(Code 1973, § 14-30; Code 1988, § 16-31; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 3(14-30), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1996-68, § 1, 12-17-1996; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006) 
Cross reference— Nuisances generally, ch. 23; nuisance abatement lien docket book, § 23-5.  
Sec. 16-32. - Type of containers required. 
(a)  For areas receiving automated refuse and recycling collection it shall be unlawful for garbage or trash to be set out for collection unless the same is placed in an approved container furnished by the city. 
(b)  In areas receiving automated refuse collection, as defined in section 16-1, yard waste must be set out for collection placed in clear plastic bags. Such bags must not exceed 40 gallons or 25 pounds each. Customers are limited to 20 bags per collection. Customers shall not mix any other form of trash, refuse or garbage with yard waste. Yard waste too bulky to be placed in clear plastic bags shall be included for collection as bulk refuse. 
(c)  The type of containers required in each area shall be determined by the director. 
(Code 1973, § 14-22; Code 1988, § 16-32; Ord. No. 1992-14, § 3, 2-25-1992; Ord. No. 1992-84, § 2, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006; Ord. No. 2013-32, § 2, 5-28-2013)  
Sec. 16-33. - Substances permitted in containers. 
No substance other than garbage, trash or recyclables shall be placed in the approved containers required by section 16-32. 
(Code 1973, § 14-23; Code 1988, § 16-33; Ord. No. 1992-14, § 4, 2-25-1992; Ord. No. 2013-32, § 2, 5-28-2013)  
Sec. 16-34. - Preparation of certain materials for collection. 
(a)  Paper. It shall be unlawful for any person to place any paper for collection by the city without placing the same in a receptacle or refuse bag complying with section 16-32 or having the same securely bundled so that the paper cannot be blown or scattered about the street. 
(b)  Cartons, boxes. It shall be unlawful for any person to place for collection by the city any empty or discarded corrugated cartons or paper or pasteboard boxes of any kind without first preparing them by flattening and securely tying them in bundles not exceeding 25 pounds in weight, with strong, stout cord. 
(c)  Yard waste. It shall be unlawful for any person to place for collection by the city, yard waste containing dirt, rocks or other material not included in the definition of yard waste. Material shall be placed in clear plastic bags complying with section 16-32. It shall be unlawful to rake, sweep or place yard waste into or onto the street, curb, gutter or drainage structure. 
(d)  Small dead animals. Small dead animals will be collected by the city during normal operating hours provided the body is placed in a properly sealed plastic or polyethylene refuse bag and placed as near to the curb as possible or between the sidewalk and the curb. 
(e)  Tires. Tires shall be placed as close to the curb as possible or between the sidewalk and the curb in accordance with section 16-36. A limit of four tires per 12-month period shall be collected. If more than four tires are placed out for collection within any 12-month period the property owner or occupant of the property shall be subject to a charge of $5.00 per additional tire and the provisions of section 16-31. All tires must be clean and rimless. 
(f)  White goods. White goods shall be placed as close to the curb as possible. Refrigerators and freezers must be empty and have the door removed before placed for collection. 
(Code 1973, § 14-24; Code 1988, § 16-34; Ord. No. 1992-14, § 5, 2-25-1992; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006)  
Sec. 16-35. - Collection of bulk refuse generally. 
Bulk refuse shall be picked up from residential dwellings at such time, and in accordance with such procedures as may be established by the director of general services. Such items shall not be placed for collection as part of the regular collection process for garbage, trash or refuse. Tree branches, tree limbs, parts of trees, bushes, shrubbery and cuttings, or clippings and the like, which cannot be placed in receptacles or refuse bags as required under section 16-34(c), shall be cut into lengths of between four feet and six feet and stacked neatly at curbside in a pile not to exceed eight feet by ten feet by eight feet in height. Tree parts greater than 18 inches in diameter will not be picked up by the city and will be the responsibility of the home owner or tenant for disposal. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or tenant of the premises involved to remove all tree trimmings, cuttings, shrubbery and the like that do not meet these specifications or those contained in section 16-34(c). Tree and shrubbery branches, limbs and trimmings cut by landscape or tree service contractors will not be collected by the city. Owners or tenants placing items for collection cut by tree and landscape contractors will be subject to the charges and penalties of section 16-31 of this division. Bulk refuse shall not be collected by the city from vacant lots, business and commercial establishments, including multifamily residential complexes. 
(Code 1973, § 14-21; Code 1988, § 16-35; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 3(14-21), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1996-68, § 1, 12-17-1996; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006)  
Sec. 16-36. - Frequency, times and dates containers and bulk refuse to be placed for collection. 
(a)  Garbage and household trash accumulated at residences shall be collected by the city one (1) time each week, except when otherwise designated by the city manager or his designee. 
(b)  Recyclables shall be collected every other week on the same day as waste collection, except when otherwise designated by the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  Normally, in the areas receiving automated refuse and recycling collection, residents may place the container for collection at any time after 5:00 p.m. the day before and by 7:00 a.m. on days of collection or as specified by the director. Such receptacles should be removed from the collection site as soon as possible after collection and stored beside or behind the dwelling or at a site acceptable to the director. Receptacles must be removed by the evening of collection day. Yard waste packaged in clear plastic bags shall be placed out for collection at the same time as the automated refuse container. 
(d)  Bulk refuse collection shall normally be on the same day as garbage collection. Residents may place bulk refuse for collection any time the day before scheduled collection but not after 7:00 a.m. on the day of collection, or as specified by the director. Tires, white goods, and cardboard set out for collection must be separated from bulk refuse. 
(Code 1973, § 14-25; Code 1988, § 16-36; Ord. No. 1992-14, § 6, 2-25-1992; Ord. No. 1996-68, § 1, 12-17-1996; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006; Ord. No. 2013-32, § 2, 5-28-2013)  
Sec. 16-37. - Positioning of materials for collection. 
All garbage, trash, paper, corrugated cartons, paper or pasteboard boxes, and other waste, to be removed by the city under this article shall be placed on the sidewalk as near to the curb as possible or between the sidewalk and the curb, except where public alleys are provided, in which instance, refuse for collection shall be placed in such alley. Bulk refuse shall always be placed as near to the curb as possible or between the sidewalk and the curb and shall not be placed in public alleys even where same are provided. Bulk refuse must be placed clear of water meters, TV cable boxes, power lines, utility poles and tree limbs. 
(Code 1973, § 14-261; Code 1988, § 16-37; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006)  
Sec. 16-38. - Receptacles from multifamily structures to be identifiable. 
Every rental dwelling unit shall be supplied with approved containers and covers for the storage of refuse and garbage, and the owner, operator or agent in control of such dwelling unit shall be responsible for supplying the necessary number of containers per residential dwelling unit and for marking on the receptacle the number of the residential dwelling unit that uses that specific receptacle. 
(Code 1973, § 14-27; Code 1988, § 16-38; Ord. No. 1992-84, § 1, 10-27-1992)  
Sec. 16-39. - Certain items unacceptable. 
The following items shall not be removed by the city and shall not be placed for collections. It shall be the responsibility of the person generating such items to transport and dispose of the same: 
(1)  Industrial wastes; 
(2)  Debris from construction, remodeling, razing and repair operations on residential and commercial buildings and other structures; or any material generated by a contractor; 
(3)  Hazardous wastes; and 
(4)  Large dead animals. 
(Code 1973, § 14-28; Code 1988, § 16-39; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006)  
Sec. 16-40. - Special pickup for moving. 
Special collection will be provided by the department of general services for residents either moving into or vacating a dwelling. In order to arrange such service, a 24-hour notice must be given to the waste management division of the department of general services of the city. Residents must separate bulk refuse from other garbage and trash. 
(Code 1988, § 16-40; Ord. No. 1992-14, § 7, 2-25-1992; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997)  
Secs. 16-41—16-59. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CHARGES 
 
Sec. 16-60. - Evictions. 
After 24 hours from the time of eviction a landlord shall remove material placed at the curb as a result of the eviction. If the landlord fails to remove these items, the city's waste management division may remove these items. The charges and fees in section 16-31 shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2006-85, § 4, 9-26-2006)  
Sec. 16-61. - Imposed; responsibility for payment. 
(a)  The service charges prescribed in this division are imposed and shall be collected for all business and commercial establishments and for all dwelling units within the city. For business and commercial establishments, such charges shall be paid by the owner or operator, and for dwelling units, such charges shall be paid by the owner or tenant, unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(b)  The charges prescribed in this division are imposed on any entity using the services and facilities of the city for the collection of garbage and trash, including specifically, but without limitation, the Portsmouth Redevelopment and Housing Authority. 
(Code 1973, §§ 14-36, 14-43; Code 1988, § 16-61) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 16-62. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The director may exempt a business or commercial establishment from the payment of the service charges prescribed by this division upon receipt of a written request therefor, if the establishment has an alternate method of transporting and disposing of garbage and refuse that is acceptable to the director. 
(b)  Industrial waste and similar refuse or garbage for which the city does not have the capability for collecting and disposing shall be excluded from the service charges of this division and it shall be the responsibility of the person generating such matter to transport and dispose of the same. 
(c)  No exemptions or refunds shall be granted for services not utilized. 
(Code 1973, § 14-37; Code 1988, § 16-62; Ord. No. 1992-84, § 1, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 1996-68, § 1, 12-17-1996; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006)  
Sec. 16-63. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2006-85, § 5, adopted September 26, 2006, repealed § 16-63, which pertained to basis of rates. See also the Code Comparative Table.  
Sec. 16-64. - Monthly rates for collection and disposal of trash and garbage; generally. 
The service charge for the collection and disposal of trash and garbage shall be as set out in Appendix A to this Code and any subsequent amendments thereto. The charges imposed under this section shall be billed with the statement rendered for water and sewer charges. 
(Code 1973, § 14-39; Code 1988, § 16-64; Ord. No. 1988-44, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1989-34, § 1, 5-15-1989; Ord. No. 1990-35, § 1, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1991-37, § 1, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1992-33, § 1, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 1994-29, § 1, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 1995-43, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1996-32, § 1, 4-23-1996; Ord. No. 1997-33, § 1, 5-6-1997; Ord. No. 2001-21, § 1, 5-22-2001; Ord. No. 2002-20, § 1, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2006-33, § 1, 4-25-2006; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006; Ord. No. 2007-05, § 1, 1-9-2007; Ord. No. 2007-51, § 1, 4-24-2007; Ord. No. 2008-32, § 1, 5-13-2008, eff. 7-1-2008; Ord. No. 2009-56 , § 1, 6-9-2009) 
Editor's note— Pursuant to Ord. No. 2009-56 , the rate set forth in § 16-64 shall take effect July 1, 2009.  
Sec. 16-65. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2006-33, § 2, adopted April 25, 2006 and Ord. No. 2006-85, § 5, adopted September 26, 2006, repealed § 16-65, which pertained to rates for standard containers. See also the Code Comparative Table.  
Sec. 16-66. - Rates for automated containers in the downtown commercial business district. 
(a)  The downtown commercial business district shall be defined as the area north of Interstate 264, south of London Boulevard, east of Elm Avenue, and west of the Elizabeth River's Southern Branch. 
(b)  Where garbage and refuse are stored in automated 105-gallon refuse containers in the downtown commercial business district, the monthly rate charged for service shall be as set out in Appendix A to this Code and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
(c)  For each additional pick-up, a charge shall be assessed, as set out in Appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 16-66; Ord. No. 1992-84, § 3, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 1994-29, § 2, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 1995-43, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1996-32, § 1, 4-23-1996; Ord. No. 1997-33, § 1, 5-6-1997; Ord. No. 2000-11, § 1, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 2001-21, § 1, 5-22-2001; Ord. No. 2002-20, § 1, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2006-33, § 1, 4-25-2006; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006; Ord. No. 2007-51, § 1, 4-24-2007; Ord. No. 2008-32, § 1, 5-13-2008, eff. 7-1-2008; Ord. No. 2009-56 , § 1, 6-9-2009) 
Editor's note— Pursuant to Ord. No. 2009-56 , the rate set forth in § 16-66 shall take effect July 1, 2009.  
Sec. 16-67. - Rates for disposal of small dead animals. 
Whenever small dead animals are to be disposed of by the city from business or commercial establishments, or from persons other than residents of the city, a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code, per animal delivered to the animal crematory or collected by the city, shall be charged. Such small dead animals shall be placed in a properly sealed plastic or polyethylene refuse bag or other suitable container. 
(Code 1973, § 14-42.1; Code 1988, § 16-67; Ord. No. 1989-38, § 1, 5-15-1989; Ord. No. 1993-32, § 1, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 2002-38, § 1, 7-9-2002)  
Sec. 16-68. - Billing procedure. 
The minimum service charges under sections 16-65 and 16-66 may be billed on a monthly or bimonthly basis. Where the service under sections 16-65 and 16-66 exceeds the minimum, additional bills will be rendered at the end of each month for the excess service. 
(Code 1973, § 14-45; Code 1988, § 16-68; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 4(14-45), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1992-84, § 1, 10-27-1992)  
Sec. 16-69. - Payment of bills; delinquent charges; discontinuance of service. 
(a)  All charges imposed in this division billed with the statement rendered for water and sewer charges are due and payable as provided for in section 38-93 of this Code. 
(b)  All other bills rendered under this division are due and payable at the office of the city treasurer upon presentation and shall be considered delinquent if not paid within 15 days of the date issued. If any bill is not paid within such 15-day period, an additional charge of one percent per billing period on the unpaid charges shall be added thereto and collected therewith to cover costs of collection. 
(c)  The director shall discontinue collecting refuse from a delinquent operator, owner or tenant after giving 15 days' written notice thereof. A copy of the notice shall be delivered to the city attorney, the health department, the city treasurer and the director of public utilities. The city treasurer shall include the delinquent charges with other taxes or fees to be collected from the operator, owner or tenant, and the director of public utilities may, in addition, discontinue water and sewer service to the delinquent operator, owner or tenant. 
(Code 1973, § 14-46; Code 1988, § 16-69; Ord. No. 1998-29, § 1, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006)  
Sec. 16-70. - Charges for automated refuse containers. 
The automated refuse containers issued by the city are the property of the city. The property owner or person paying the collection charge is responsible for the care of the container and shall purchase another container from an authorized vendor designated by the city if for any reason the container is unavailable for use or unusable. 
(Code 1988, § 16-70; Ord. No. 1992-84, § 3, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 2006-85, § 3, 9-26-2006)  
Secs. 16-71—16-170. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SOLID WASTE 
 
Sec. 16-171. - Definitions. 
Unless a different meaning is required by the context, the following terms as used in this article shall have the meanings as respectively ascribed to them in this section. 
Person means any nonresidential generator of solid waste and any company, business or other party which collects, transports, processes or recycles solid waste. 
Recycle means to sell, donate or otherwise transfer solid waste material to any other person located outside of the city so that such waste material may be processed and used again as raw material for a product which may or may not be similar to the original product; or to process a given waste material at a location within the city so that such material may be used again as a raw material for a product which may or may not be similar to the original product. 
Solid waste means any garbage, refuse, sludge and other discarded material, including solid, liquid, semisolid or contained gaseous material, resulting from industrial, commercial, residential, mining and agricultural operations, or community activities but does not include solid or dissolved material in domestic sewage, solid or dissolved material in irrigation return flows or in industrial discharges which are sources subject to a permit from the state water control board, or source, special nuclear, or byproduct material, as defined by the Federal Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended. 
(Code 1988, § 16-171; Ord. No. 1991-3, § 1(16-161), 1-8-1991)  
Sec. 16-172. - Annual recycling reports required. 
(a)  Any person located within the city who recycles solid waste shall submit an annual report to the director of general operations of the city or his designee. Each report shall cover the 12-month period beginning January 1 and ending December 31. Each report required hereunder shall be submitted not later than 30 days following the close of the 12-month period. 
(b)  Any person who recycles solid waste at or from locations both within and without the city and who is not reasonably able to identify the quantity of solid waste recycled at or from each location may submit a consolidated report to the city. Any such consolidated report shall state that it reflects quantities of solid waste recycled at or from all locations of the person within the city. 
(c)  Each annual report required to be submitted under this article shall include the name and address of the reporting person, the name and telephone number of the individual who may be contacted on behalf of the reporting person for the period covered by the report, and the total quantity of solid waste recycled by the reporting person during the period. 
(Code 1988, § 16-172; Ord. No. 1991-3, § 1(16-162), 1-8-1991)  
Sec. 16-173. - Quantities of solid waste to be measured by weight. 
All quantities of solid waste required to be reported under this article shall be measured by weight. When the reporting person is unable to accurately determine quantity by weight, such quantities shall be reported based upon carefully estimated data. Each reporting person shall identify in his report all information which is based upon estimated data. 
(Code 1988, § 16-173; Ord. No. 1991-3, § 1(16-163), 1-8-1991)  
Sec. 16-174. - Reporting forms. 
Any person required to submit a report under this article shall use forms prepared by the city. Any person desiring such forms may obtain them from the department of general operations. 
(Code 1988, § 16-174; Ord. No. 1991-3, § 1(16-164), 1-8-1991)  
Sec. 16-175. - Failure to furnish required reports. 
Failure to furnish any report required under this article shall be a class 1 misdemeanor for each such violation. 
(Code 1988, § 16-175; Ord. No. 1991-3, § 1(16-165), 1-8-1991)  
Sec. 16-176. - When report not required. 
Nothing under this article shall be construed to require any person to report information of a proprietary nature. Where any person fails to report any information otherwise required hereunder, based upon the determination that such information is of a proprietary nature, the person shall specify in his report the nature of the information withheld and the basis for his determination that such information is of a proprietary nature. 
(Code 1988, § 16-176; Ord. No. 1991-3, § 1(16-166), 1-8-1991)  
Secs. 16-177—16-186. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PRIVATE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-107, § 2, adopted November 27, 2007, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as a new Art. IV, §§ 16-167—16-171. Inasmuch as provisions already exist so designated, Ord. No. 2007-107 has been codified herein as Art. IV, §§ 16-187—16-191 at the discretion of the editor. Also, it should be noted that these provisions become effective January 1, 2008. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
 
Sec. 16-187. - Permit required for private solid waste collection. 
No person shall operate a private solid waste collection business within the city without first obtaining a permit from the director of public works or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 2, 11-27-2007)  
Sec. 16-188. - Private solid waste to be disposed of only at publicly owned and operated facilities. 
(a)  All solid waste generated or collected within the city shall be disposed of only at the facilities of the Southeastern Public Service Authority of Virginia or such other publicly owned and operated facilities designated in writing by the director of public works or his designee. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Solid waste generated, purchased or utilized by an entity engaged in the business of manufacturing, mining, processing, refining or conversion except for an entity engaged in the production of energy or solid waste-derived fuels for sale to a person other than any entity controlling, controlled by or under the same control as the manufacturer, miner, processor, refiner or converter. 
(2)  Recyclable materials, which are those materials that have been source-separated by any person or materials separated from solid waste by any person for utilization in both cases as a raw material to be manufactured into a product other than fuel or energy. 
(3)  Construction debris to be disposed of in a landfill. 
(4)  Waste oil. 
(c)  This section shall not prevent or prohibit disposal of solid waste at any facility which was issued a solid waste management facility permit by an agency of the Commonwealth on or before July 1, 1991, or for which a Part A permit application for a new solid waste management facility permit, including local governing body certification, was submitted to the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality in accordance with Code of Virginia § 10.1-1408.1 B. on or before December 31, 1991. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 2, 11-27-2007)  
Sec. 16-189. - Other disposal sites prohibited; revocation of permit. 
No person may dispose of solid waste generated or collected within the city at any place other than those designated pursuant to section 16-188. The director of public works or his designee following a hearing may revoke a permit to operate a private solid waste collection business obtained under section 16-187 for failure to comply with this section. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 2, 11-27-2007)  
Sec. 16-190. - Operating without a permit unlawful. 
Operating a private solid waste collection business without a permit as required herein shall be a Class 3 misdemeanor. Upon conviction hereunder, punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00, or such fine as may be fixed by Code of Virginia § 18.2-11 or any successor statute. Each day in violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 2, 11-27-2007)  
Sec. 16-191. - Injunctive relief. 
In addition to the other remedies and penalties imposed under this article, the city shall have the power to seek injunctive relief from a court of competent jurisdiction to enjoin continuing or future violations of section 16-189 and/or 16-190, without any requirement of showing irreparable harm. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 2, 11-27-2007)  
Chapter 17 - HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations generally, ch. 7; special requirements for housing for the elderly, § 7-5; fire prevention and protection, ch. 13; smoke detectors for certain dwellings, § 13-131 et seq.; flood protection, ch. 14.1; garbage and refuse, ch. 16; license tax on persons engaged in business of renting residential property, § 20-79; mobile homes, ch. 21; subdivisions, ch. 33.1; swimming pools, ch. 34; water, sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 38; zoning, ch. 40.1. 
State Law reference— Housing Authorities Law, Code of Virginia, § 36-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 17-1. - Dangerous buildings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for the owner or occupant of any land or lot in the city to permit any structure, house or dwelling place thereon to be habitually kept or maintained in such a manner as to be unsafe, unsanitary or otherwise dangerous to human life, or which, in relation to existing use, constitutes a hazard to safety or health by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence or abandonment. 
(b)  Whenever the code official shall find any structure, house or dwelling place or portion thereof to be unsafe as defined in subsection (a) of this section, he shall give the owner, agent for the owner or person in control of such building or structure, and lienholder in control of such building or structure, written notice. This notice shall require the owner, agent for the owner or person in control of such building within a stated time to complete improvements or demolish or remove the building, structure or portion thereof. The notice shall be in a form prescribed in section 105 of the Virginia Maintenance Code. For purposes of this section, written notice shall be mailed by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, sent to the last known address of the property owner and published in a newspaper having general circulation in the city in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1426 and 15.2-1427. No action shall be taken by the code official for at least 30 days following the later of the return of the receipt or newspaper publication. 
(c)  If an owner, agent for the owner or person in control of such building fails, refuses or neglects to comply with the notice provided for in subsection (b) of this section, the code official shall ascertain the cost to demolish and remove the building, structure or portion thereof and shall cause such building, structure or portion thereof to be demolished and removed from the lot or property. The code official shall thereafter transmit to the city treasurer a statement of all costs incurred including a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code to cover the administrative expenses of the code official, which costs shall be added to the taxes assessed against the real property on which the nuisance existed and shall be collected with such taxes by any manner prescribed by law for the collection of city taxes. Such costs shall also be docketed in the nuisance abatement lien docket book maintained in the office of the city treasurer as a lien against the real property on which the nuisance existed, and shall rank on a parity with liens for unpaid local taxes, which lien shall exist until removed by payment of such costs in full. In lieu of causing the building, structure or portion thereof to be demolished, the director may institute legal proceedings as may be deemed necessary for the failure, refusal or neglect to comply with his order or notice. 
(d)  If any owner, agent for the owner, or person in control of such building or structure refuses, fails or neglects to complete improvements or demolish or remove the building, structure or portion thereof in compliance with the notice provided for in subsection (b) of this section, such failure shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than $2,500.00. Additionally, if the violation remains uncorrected at the time of the conviction, the court shall order the violator to abate or remedy the violation in order to comply with the Code. Unless otherwise provided by the court for good cause shown, any such violator shall abate or remedy the violation within six months of the date of conviction. 
(Code 1973, §§ 6-25—6-31; Code 1988, § 17-1; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 1(6-30), (6-31), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1992-53, § 1, 6-23-1992; Ord. No. 1995-49, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1995-76, § 1, 6-13-1995; Ord. No. 2004-32, § 1, 6-15-2004; Ord. No. 2009-80 , § 1, 8-11-2009) 
Cross reference— Nuisances generally, ch. 23. 
State Law reference— Authority to require removal, repair of buildings and other structures, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-906.  
Sec. 17-2. - Authority to require removal, repair, etc., of buildings that are declared to be derelict. 
(a)  Any owner of property located in the City of Portsmouth shall at such time or times as the city may prescribe submit a plan to demolish or renovate any building that has been declared a "derelict building." For purposes of this section, "derelict building" shall mean a residential or nonresidential building or structure, whether or not construction has been completed, that might endanger the public's health, safety, or welfare and for a continuous period in excess of six months, it has been (i) vacant, (ii) boarded up in accordance with the building code, and (iii) not lawfully connected to electric service from a utility service provider or not lawfully connected to any required water or sewer service from a utility service provider. 
(b)  If a building qualifies as a derelict building pursuant to this ordinance, the city shall notify the owner of the derelict building that the owners is required to submit to the city a plan, within 90 days, to demolish or renovate the building to address the items that endanger the public's health, safety, or welfare as listed in the written notification provided by the city. Such plan shall be on a form provided by the city and shall include a proposed time within which the plan will be commenced and completed. The plan may include one or more adjacent properties of the owner, whether or not all of such properties may have been declared derelict buildings. The plan shall be subject to approval by the city. The city shall deliver the written notice to the address listed on the real estate tax assessment records of the city. Written notice sent by first-class mail, with the city obtaining a U.S. Postal Service Certificate of Mailing shall constitute delivery pursuant to this section. 
(c)  If the city delivers written notice and the owner of the derelict building has not submitted a plan to the city within 90 days as provided in subsection (b), the city may exercise such remedies as provided in this section or as otherwise provided by law. 
(d)  The owner of a building may apply to the city and request that such building be declared a derelict building for purposes of this section. 
(e)  The city upon receipt of the plan to demolish or renovate the building, at the owner's request, shall meet with the owner submitting the plan and provide information to the owner on the land use and permitting requirements for demolition or renovation. 
(f)  If the property owner's plan is to demolish the derelict building, and such plan is approved by the city, the building permit application of such owner shall be expedited. If the owner has completed the demolition within 90 days of the date of the building permit issuance, the city shall refund any building and demolition permit fees. This section shall not supersede any ordinance adopted relative historic districts. 
(g)  If the property owner's plan is to renovate the derelict building, and no rezoning is required for the owner's intended use of the property, and such plan is approved by the city, the site plan or subdivision application and the building permit, as applicable, shall be expedited. The site plan or subdivision fees may be refunded, all or in part, but in no event shall the site plan or subdivision fees exceed the lesser of 50 percent of the standard fees established by the ordinance for site plan or subdivision applications for the proposed use of the property, or $5,000.00 per property. The building permit fees may be refunded, all or in part, but in no event shall the building permit fees exceed the lesser of 50 percent of the standard fees established by the ordinance for building permit applications for the proposed use of the property, or $5,000.00 per property. 
(h)  Prior to the commencement of a plan to demolish or renovate the derelict building, at the request of the property owner, the real estate assessor shall make an assessment of the property in its current derelict condition. On the building permit application, the owner shall declare the costs of demolition, or the costs of materials and labor to complete the renovation. At the request of the property owner, after demolition or renovation of the derelict building, the real estate assessor shall reflect the fair market value of the demolition costs or the fair market value of the renovation improvements, and reflect such value in the real estate tax assessment records. Real estate taxes on an amount equal to the costs of demolition or an amount equal to the increase in the fair market value of the renovations shall be abated in accordance with the provisions of section 35-191 of the Code of the City of Portsmouth. 
(i)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, the city may proceed to make repairs and secure the building under section 17-1 of the City Code, or the city may proceed to abate or remove a nuisance under Section 15.2-900, et seq., of the Code of Virginia. In addition, the city may exercise such remedies as may exist under the Uniform Statewide Building Code and such other remedies available under general and special law. 
( Ord. No. 2009-80 , § 2, 8-11-2009)  
Secs. 17-3—17-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES MAINTENANCE CODE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 17-21. - Declaration of policy and purpose. 
(a)  It is hereby found and declared that there exist in the city buildings and structures which are, or may become in the future, substandard with respect to structure, equipment or maintenance; or further that such conditions including but not limited to structural deterioration, lack of maintenance and appearance of exterior of premises, infestation, lack of essential heating, plumbing, storage or refrigeration equipment, lack of maintenance or upkeep of essential utilities and facilities, existence of fire hazards, inadequate provisions for light and air, unsanitary conditions and overcrowding constitute a menace to the health, safety, morals, welfare and reasonable comfort of the citizens and inhabitants of the city. It is further found and declared that by reason of lack of maintenance and progressive deterioration, certain properties have the further effect of creating blighting conditions and initiating slums, and that if the same are not curtailed and removed, the aforesaid conditions will grow and spread and will necessitate in time the expenditure of large amounts of public funds to correct and eliminate the same, and that by reason of timely regulations and restrictions as herein contained, the growth of slums and blight may be prevented and the neighborhood and property values thereby maintained, the desirability and amenities of residential and nonresidential uses and neighborhoods enhanced and the public health, safety and welfare protected and fostered. 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety, morals and welfare by establishing minimum standards governing the maintenance, appearance, condition and occupancy of buildings and structures; to establish minimum standards governing utilities, facilities and other physical-components and conditions essential to make the aforesaid facilities fit for human habitation, occupancy and use; to fix certain responsibilities and duties upon owners and operators, and distinct and separate responsibilities and duties upon occupants; to authorize and establish procedures for the inspection of premises; to fix penalties for the violations of this article; and to provide for the repair, demolition or vacation of premises unfit for human habitation, occupancy or use. This article is hereby declared to be essential for the public interest and it is intended that this article be liberally construed to effectuate the purposes as stated herein. 
(Code 1973, §§ 6-20, 6-21; Code 1988, §§ 17-102, 17-103)  
Sec. 17-22. - Applicability of article. 
Every building and structure and the premises on which it is situated shall comply with the provisions of this article, regardless of when such building was constructed, altered or repaired and irrespective of any permits or licenses which have been issued for the use or occupancy of the building or premises, for the construction or repair of the building, or for the installation or repair of equipment or facilities. This article establishes minimum standards for the initial and continued occupancy and use of all such buildings, and does not replace or modify standards otherwise established for the construction, repair, alteration or use of the building, equipment or facilities contained therein. 
(Code 1973, § 6-22; Code 1988, § 17-104)  
Sec. 17-23. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this subsection: 
Accessory structure means a structure the use of which is incidental to that of the main building and which is attached thereto or located on the same premises. 
Board means the housing board of adjustments and appeals. 
Building means a structure adapted to permanent or continuous occupancy or use for public, institutional, business, industrial or storage purposes. The term "building" shall be construed as if followed by the words "or part thereof." 
Debris means dead or dying standing weeds, dead or dying standing trees, any tree or parts of a tree which have fallen due to natural causes or otherwise, trash, junk, discarded or abandoned parts of vehicles, appliances or machinery, and shall include, but not be limited to the open outdoor storage of personal property of any kind such as appliances or appliance parts, furniture, interior or exterior equipment or machinery, which is no longer used, including antiques, collectables, glassware and crockery, or any other material or substance which may provide a harbor for snakes or rats or anything or any condition which may be a fire menace or breeding place for mosquitoes, give off obnoxious or offensive odors or endanger the health or safety of the residents of the city. Debris shall not include any of the above property openly stored in a junkyard as defined and permitted pursuant to the zoning ordinance. 
Deterioration means the condition of a building or part thereof, characterized by holes, breaks, rot, crumbling, cracking, peeling, rusting or other evidence of physical decay or neglect, lack of maintenance or excessive use. 
Director means the director of permits and inspections. 
Fire hazard means: 
(1)  Any device or condition likely to cause fire and which is so situated as to endanger either persons or property. 
(2)  The creation, maintenance or continuance of any physical condition by reason of which there exists a use, accumulation or storage of combustible or explosive material sufficient in amount or so located or in such a manner as to put in jeopardy, in event of ignition, either persons or property. 
(3)  The obstruction to or of fire escapes, ladders, stairways, aisles, exits, doors, windows, passageways or halls or other conditions that would likely interfere with the operations of the fire department or of the safe and ready egress of occupants. 
Garbage means all animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
Infestation means the presence of insects, rodents, vermin or other pests on the premises. 
Operator means any person who has charge, care or control of a premises, or a part thereof, whether with or without the knowledge and consent of the owner. 
Plumbing means the practice, materials and fixtures used in the installation, maintenance, extension and alteration of all piping, fixtures, appliances and appurtenances in connection with any of the following: Sanitary drainage or storm drainage facilities, the venting system and the public or private water supply systems, within or adjacent to any building, structure or conveyance; also the practice and materials used in the installation, maintenance, extension or alteration of stormwater, liquid waste or sewerage and water supply systems of any premises to their connection with any point of public disposal or other acceptable terminal. 
Premises means a lot, plot or parcel of land including the buildings or structures thereon. 
Restroom means an enclosed space containing one or more toilets and one or more lavatories or fixtures serving similar purposes. 
Rubbish means all combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage; and the term shall include, but not be limited to, the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible material, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, dust, crockery and abandoned automobiles. 
Structure means any combination of any materials, whether fixed or portable, forming a construction, including buildings. 
Ventilation means supply and removal of air to and from any space by natural or mechanical means. 
Ventilation, mechanical means ventilation by power-driven devices. 
Ventilation, natural means ventilation by opening to outer air through windows, skylights, doors, louvers or stacks with or without wind-driven devices. 
Virginia Maintenance Code means the code adopted by section 17-24. 
Weathering means deterioration, decay or damage caused by exposure to the elements. 
(b)  The following words and terms, when used in the code adopted in this article, shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  The words "local governing body," "local government" or "enforcing agency" means the City of Portsmouth. 
(2)  The term "code official" or "housing official" means the director of permits and inspections. 
(3)  The word "debris" means dead or dying standing weeds, dead or dying standing trees, any tree or parts of a tree which have fallen due to natural causes or otherwise, trash, junk, discarded or abandoned parts of vehicles, appliances or machinery or any other material or substance which may provide a harbor for snakes or rats or anything or any condition which may be a fire menace or breeding place for mosquitoes, give off obnoxious or offensive odors or endanger the health or safety of the residents of the city. 
(4)  The term "director" shall refer to the director of permits and inspections. 
(Code 1973, §§ 6-19, 17-19, 17-20; Code 1988, §§ 17-21, 17-101; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 5(17-19), (17-20), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1991-13, § 1, 2-12-1991; Ord. No. 2008-11, § 1, 2-12-2008) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 17-24. - Adopted; availability of copies. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the maintenance, rehabilitation, development and reuse of existing buildings and structures, that certain code known as the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, Part III, Maintenance, referred to as the Virginia Maintenance Code, and those additional maintenance codes which are incorporated by reference therein, and the accumulative supplements and the amendments thereto, save and except such portions as are hereinafter amended or deleted, as permitted in the enabling legislation, and building regulations adopted and promulgated pursuant thereto, and the same are hereby adopted and referred to herein as the Virginia Maintenance Code of the city as fully as if set out at length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Copies of the Virginia Maintenance Code adopted herein may be obtained from the department of permits and inspections. 
(Code 1973, § 17-16; Code 1988, § 17-22; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 5(17-16(b)), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1994-54, § 2, 6-14-1994) 
Cross reference— Adoption of Volume I of Uniform Statewide Building Code, § 7-96. 
State Law reference— Uniform Statewide Building Code, Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq.  
Sec. 17-25. - Conflicts with other ordinances. 
In the event that there is any conflict between any provision of the Virginia Maintenance Code and any other ordinance of the city, the more stringent provisions shall control. 
(Code 1973, § 17-17; Code 1988, § 17-23)  
Sec. 17-26. - Enforcement; rules and regulations of director. 
(a)  Generally. The director of permits and inspections is hereby designated as the code official and is authorized to enforce the Virginia Maintenance Code. The director, with the approval of the board, may make and adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary for the administration and enforcement of the Virginia Maintenance Code. Such rules and regulations shall not be in conflict with or an enlargement of any of the provisions of the Virginia Maintenance Code. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such rules and regulations so adopted. 
(b)  Compliance with other ordinances. No license or permit or other certification of compliance with this article shall constitute a defense to any violation of any other ordinance of the city applicable to any structure or premises, nor shall any provision herein relieve any owner, operator or occupant from complying with any such other provision, nor any official of the city from enforcing any such other provision. 
(Code 1973, §§ 6-25, 17-19, 17-20; Code 1988, §§ 17-25, 17-108; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 5(17-19), (17-20), 12-13-1988)  
Sec. 17-27. - Violations; procedures for abatement of nuisances. 
(a)  Any person who violates or fails to comply with the provisions of this article or the Virginia Maintenance Code shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each violation of a separate and distinct provision shall be a separate offense and each such offense shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $2,500.00. If the violation remains uncorrected at the time of the conviction, the court shall order the violator to abate or remedy the violation in order to comply with the Code. Except as otherwise provided by the court for good cause shown, any such violator shall abate or remedy the violation within six months of the date of conviction. Each day during which the violation continues after the court-ordered abatement period has ended shall constitute a separate offense. Any person convicted of a second offense committed within less than five years after a first offense under this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $2,500.00. Any person convicted of a second offense committed within a period of five to ten years of a first offense under this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $500.00 nor more than $2,500.00. Any person convicted of a third or subsequent offense involving the same property committed within ten years of an offense under this chapter after having been at least twice previously convicted shall be punished by confinement in jail for not more than ten days and a fine of not less than $2,500.00 nor more than $5,000.00, either or both. No portion of the fine imposed for such third or subsequent offense committed within ten years of an offense under this chapter shall be suspended. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this article, whenever in the judgment of the code official there exists upon any land or premises or in any dwelling unit any condition that constitutes a nuisance or menace to health that should be remedied, abated or removed immediately, the code official may proceed in accordance with the provisions of sections 2-425 and 2-426. 
(c)  Any owner or any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article relating to the removal or the covering of lead-based paint which poses a hazard to health of pregnant women or children under the age of six years who occupy the premises shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties provided in subsection (a) of this section. Upon a reasonable showing to the court by a landlord, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 55-248.4 that such landlord is financially unable to abate the lead-based paint hazard, the court shall order any rental agreement related to the affected premises terminated effective 30 days from the entry of the court order. For the purposes of the preceding sentence, termination of the rental agreement shall not be deemed noncompliance by the landlord pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 55-248.21. 
(Code 1973, § 17-23; Code 1988, § 17-26; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 5(17-22), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1991-66, § 1, 6-25-1991; Ord. No. 1992-53, § 2, 6-23-1992; Ord. No. 1992-85, § 1, 10-27-1992; Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 1-24-2006) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 36-106.  
Sec. 17-28. - Occupants and families with children not to be evicted to avoid correction of violation of lead-based paint provisions of code. 
No owner or landlord found to be in violation of the provisions of the Virginia Maintenance Code relating to the use of lead-based paint may evict, or cause to be evicted, any person, occupant, occupant with children, or family or families with children for the purpose of avoiding corrective maintenance ordered by the director, a court or other appropriate authority to eliminate hazardous lead exposures. Any person, occupant, occupant with children, or family or families with children shall be permitted to continue their occupancy in accordance with their lease or rental agreement executed prior to discovery of the hazardous conditions or commencement of corrective action, unless otherwise ordered by a court as provided in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 17-50; Code 1988, § 17-27; Ord. No. 1991-66, § 2, 6-25-1991)  
Sec. 17-29. - Sale of residential structure with lead-based paint; penalty. 
(a)  Whenever any property owner has been notified by any representative of the department of permits and inspections, the local building official, or any representative of the city health department that any residential premises has levels of lead-based paint in violation of the Uniform Statewide Building Code, such property owner shall notify prospective purchasers in writing of the presence of unacceptable levels of lead-based paint in such premises and the requirements concerning the removing of the same. Such notification shall include a copy of any notice the property owner received from any representative of the department of permits and inspections, the local building official, or any representative of the city health department advising of the presence of unacceptable levels of lead-based paint in such premises. 
(b)  The notice required herein shall be provided to prospective purchasers prior to the signing of a purchase or sales agreement or, if there is no purchase or sales agreement, prior to the signing of a deed. The requirement shall not apply to purchase and sales agreements or deeds signed prior to July 1, 1991. Transactions in which sellers have accepted written offers prior to July 1, 1991, but have not signed a purchase or sales agreement or a deed prior to July 1, 1991, shall be subject to these notice requirements. 
(c)  Any person who fails to comply with the provisions of this section shall be liable for all damages caused by his failure to comply and shall, in addition, be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $1,000.00. 
(Code 1988, § 17-28; Ord. No. 1991-66, § 3, 6-25-1991) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 36-107.1.  
Sec. 17-30. - Police powers for enforcement of chapter. 
The director, the environmental safety coordinator, the code official, the zoning administrator, the zoning manager and all inspectors in the department of permits and inspections are hereby invested with such police powers as are necessary for the service of any summons for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 17-29; Ord. No. 1996-22, § 1, 3-26-1996)  
Sec. 17-31. - Obstructing or interfering with enforcement of chapter. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or to interfere with any public official engaged in the enforcement of this chapter and any such person shall be subject to punishment in accordance with section 17-27 upon conviction. 
(Code 1988, § 17-30; Ord. No. 1996-22, § 1, 3-26-1996)  
Sec. 17-32. - Duties of owner, operator and occupant independent of each other; contrary agreements. 
(a)  Owners and operators of any building within the purview of this article shall have all the duties and responsibilities as prescribed in section 17-33 and the regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, and no such owner or operator shall be relieved from any such duty and responsibility nor be entitled to defend against any charge of violation thereof by reason of the fact that the occupant of such building is also responsible therefor and in violation thereof. 
(b)  Occupants of any building within the purview of this article shall have all the duties and responsibilities as prescribed in section 17-34 and all the regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, and such occupant shall not be relieved from any such duty and responsibility nor be entitled to defend against any charge of violation thereof by reason of the fact that the owner or operator of such building is also responsible therefor and in violation thereof. 
(c)  Unless expressly provided to the contrary in this article, the respective obligations and responsibilities of the owner and operator of any building within the purview of this article on the one hand, and the occupant of such building on the other, shall not be altered or affected by any agreement or contract by and between any of the aforesaid or between them and other parties. 
(Code 1973, § 6-26; Code 1988, § 17-110)  
Sec. 17-33. - Duties of owner and operator enumerated. 
The following duties and responsibilities are hereby imposed upon every owner and operator of any building covered by the provisions of this article: 
(1)  The exterior of the premises and all structures thereon shall be kept free of all nuisances and any hazards to the safety of occupants, pedestrians and other persons utilizing the premises, and free of unsanitary conditions, and any of the foregoing shall be promptly removed and abated by the owner or operator. The items prohibited hereby shall include, but not be limited to: Brush, weeds, broken glass, stump roots, obnoxious growths, filth, garbage, trash, refuse, debris, dead and dying trees and limbs or other natural growth, loose and overhanging objects and ground surface hazards. 
(2)  Foundation walls shall be kept structurally sound, free from defects and damage and capable of bearing imposed loads safely. 
(3)  Chimneys and all flue and vent attachments thereto shall be maintained structurally sound, free from defects and so maintained as to capably perform at all times the functions for which they were designed. Chimneys, flues, gas vents or other draft-producing equipment shall provide sufficient draft to develop the rated output of the connected equipment, shall be structurally safe, durable, smoketight and capable of withstanding the action of flue gases. 
(4)  Exterior porches, landings, balconies, stairs and fire escapes shall be provided with banisters or railings properly designed and maintained to minimize the hazard of falling, and the same shall be kept structurally sound, in good repair and free from defects. 
(5)  The exterior of the premises and the condition of accessory structures shall be maintained so that the appearance of the premises and all buildings thereon shall reflect a level of maintenance in keeping with the standards of the neighborhood. 
(6)  Premises shall be kept landscaped, and lawns, hedges and bushes shall be kept trimmed.
