(7)  All permanent signs and billboards exposed to public view permitted by reason of other ordinances or laws shall be maintained in good repair. Any signs which have excessively weathered or faded or those upon which the paint has excessively peeled or cracked shall, with their supporting members, be removed forthwith or put into a state of good repair. 
(8)  All display windows or storefronts constructed of plate glass shall be kept clean and free of cracks, and no storage shall be permitted therein unless shielded from public view. 
(9)  All storefronts shall be kept in good repair, painted where required and shall not constitute a safety hazard or nuisance. In the event repairs to a storefront become necessary, such repairs shall be made with the same or similar materials used in the construction of the storefront in such a manner as to permanently repair the damaged area. Any cornice visible above a storefront shall be kept painted, where required, and in good repair. 
(10)  Except for "For Rent" and "For Sale" signs, any temporary sign or other paper advertising material glued or otherwise attached to a window, or otherwise exposed to public view shall be removed at the expiration of the event or sale for which it is erected or within 60 days after erection, whichever shall occur first. 
(11)  Any awnings or marquees and their accompanying structural members which extend over any street, sidewalk or other portion of the premises shall be maintained in good repair and shall not constitute a nuisance or a safety hazard. In the event such awnings or marquees are not properly maintained in accordance with the foregoing, they shall, together with their supporting members, be removed forthwith. In the event such awnings or marquees are made of cloth, plastic or of similar materials, such cloth or plastic where exposed to public view shall be maintained in good condition and shall not show evidence of excessive weathering, discoloration, ripping, tearing or other holes. Nothing herein shall be construed to authorize any encroachment on streets, sidewalks or other parts of the public domain. 
(12)  The exterior of every structure or accessory structure shall be kept in good repair and kept painted where necessary for purposes of preservation and appearance. All surfaces shall be maintained free of broken glass, loose shingles, crumbling stone or brick, excessively peeling paint or other condition reflective of deterioration or inadequate maintenance. 
(13)  Restrooms shall be surfaced with waterproof floors and shall be kept dry, clean and sanitary at all times. Sufficient restrooms shall be installed and maintained for each sex commensurate with the use of the premises. Every restroom shall be provided with a permanently installed artificial lighting fixture and a wall switch therefor which is free from danger of short circuiting. 
(14)  All premises shall be properly connected to and provided with electric power. All such connections and electrical equipment shall be installed and maintained in conformity with the provisions of the electrical code of the city and other applicable ordinances. 
(15)  Maximum fuse sizes consistent with safety shall be posted conspicuously, and no fuse shall be installed in a fuse box in excess of the stated maximum except that owners and operators shall not be responsible for violation in fuse installations without their knowledge where the correct maximum is stated and the fuse box is located within any part of the premises which is in the exclusive possession of occupants other than the owner, in which case such occupant shall be responsible for such violations. 
(Code 1973, § 6-27; Code 1988, § 17-111)  
Sec. 17-34. - Duties of occupant enumerated. 
The following duties and responsibilities are hereby imposed upon every occupant of any building covered by the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Upon discovery by an occupant of any condition on the premises which constitutes a violation of the provisions of this article, the occupant shall report the same to the director of public health immediately. 
(2)  All parts of the premises under the control of the occupant shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(3)  Storage bins, rooms and areas shall not be used for the accumulation of garbage or refuse. 
(4)  Every occupant shall be responsible for the elimination of infestation in and on the premises subject to his control. 
(5)  No occupant shall install electrical fuses in a fuse box in excess of the posted limit. 
(Code 1973, § 6-28; Code 1988, § 17-112)  
Secs. 17-35—17-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - HOUSING BOARD OF ADJUSTMENTS AND APPEALS 
 
Sec. 17-41. - Created. 
There is hereby created by the city council a board to be known as the housing board of adjustments and appeals. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-41)  
Sec. 17-42. - Composition; appointment and terms of members; filling of vacancies. 
The housing board of adjustments and appeals shall consist of not less than three members appointed by the city council. Members of the board shall be appointed for three-year terms. A vacancy on the board shall be filled by the council for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-42; Ord. No. 1990-129, § 7, 12-11-1990)  
Sec. 17-43. - Members not compensated. 
The members of the housing board of adjustments and appeals shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-43)  
Sec. 17-44. - Removal of members. 
Any member of the housing board of adjustments and appeals shall be subject to removal or replacement by the city council at any time. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-44)  
Sec. 17-45. - Election of officers. 
The housing board of adjustments and appeals shall elect a chair, vice-chair and secretary at the annual meeting of the board. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-45)  
Sec. 17-46. - Meetings generally. 
The housing board of adjustments and appeals shall hold regular meetings each month at which meetings all appeals on file shall be considered and acted upon by the board. Regular or special meetings may be called by the chairman at any time. Reasonable notice of the place, time and date of such meetings shall be given all members of the board and all interested parties in each case to be heard by the board. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-46)  
Sec. 17-47. - Minutes as public record; general duties of secretary. 
All minutes of housing board of adjustments and appeals meetings shall be a public record and the secretary of the board shall keep all records and perform such additional duties as the board deems proper. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-47)  
Sec. 17-48. - Rules of procedure. 
The housing board of adjustments and appeals shall establish its own rules of procedure for accomplishment of its duties and functions, provided that such rules shall not be in conflict with the provisions of the Virginia Maintenance Code or of this article or laws of the state. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-48) 
Cross reference— General procedural rules for boards appointed by council, § 2-28(b).  
Sec. 17-49. - Grant of extension of time for performance of action required by code. 
When it is specified that the performance of any action shall be completed within a stated time after notice requiring such action, if the housing board of adjustments and appeals finds that compliance therewith would cause undue hardship on an owner, the board may grant a reasonable extension of such time. All such extensions shall be subject to review as deemed necessary by the board or upon application of the director of permits and inspections. When reviewing applications based on undue financial hardship, the board may consider the applicant's income from all sources, general financial worth, age, physical and mental condition, costs associated with reaching a condition of compliance, and any and all other evidence that may be properly related to the ability of the applicant to comply with the Virginia Maintenance Code. No such extension shall be granted if an inspection of the property reveals a condition that makes the property dangerous to the general public or the occupants thereof or a nuisance. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-49; Ord. No. 1991-21, § 1, 3-12-1991)  
Sec. 17-50. - Appeals to board generally. 
(a)  The housing board of adjustments and appeals shall consider and determine appeals whenever it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of the Virginia Maintenance Code or any of the regulations thereunder have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted. 
(b)  Any person receiving written notice from the director of permits and inspections, or his representative, of deficiencies in his property under the Virginia Maintenance Code, which do not affect the manner of construction or materials to be used in the erection, alteration, repair, maintenance or use of a building or structure, may, within 21 days following the date of such notice, enter an appeal in writing to the board. Such appeal shall state the name of the applicant and owner, the location of the property, the date of the notice of violations and the number of such notice. The appellant must state the variance or modification requested, the reason therefor and the hardship or conditions upon which the appeal is made. No appeal filed later than 21 days after the date of such notice shall be acted upon by the board, unless the director of permits and inspections consents thereto. 
(c)  No appeal shall be considered under this section where an appeal case has been previously decided involving the same premises. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-50; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 5(17-18(c)), 12-13-1988)  
Sec. 17-51. - Decisions of board. 
(a)  All decisions of the housing board of adjustments and appeals to vary the application of any provision of this Code and/or the Virginia Maintenance Code or to modify an order of the director shall specify in what manner such variance or modification is made, the conditions upon which it is made and the reasons therefor. 
(b)  Every decision of the board shall be in writing and shall indicate the vote upon the decision. A copy of all decisions shall be promptly filed in the office of the director and shall be open to public inspection. The secretary shall notify the appellant in writing of the final action of the board and provide notification of a right of appeal. 
(Code 1973, § 17-18; Code 1988, § 17-51)  
Secs. 17-52—17-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - RENTAL INSPECTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2005-50, § 2, adopted June 28, 2005, repealed former Div. 3, §§ 17-71—17-76, which pertained to certificate of compliance for rental dwellings. Section 1 of said ordinance enacted provisions designated as a new Div. 3, §§ 17-81—17-94. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
 
Sec. 17-81. - Legislative intent. 
(a)  This division is intended to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the occupants of residential rental dwelling property units throughout the city and to assure the maintenance of the city's rental housing stock. 
(b)  The creation and designation of rental inspection districts in this division results from a finding by the city council that the residential dwelling units within a designated rental inspection district are either: 
(1)  Blighted or in the process of deteriorating; or 
(2)  In need of inspection by the city to prevent deterioration, taking into account the number, age and condition of the residential dwelling units and that the inspection of residential rental dwelling units inside each proposed rental inspection district is necessary to maintain safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for tenants and other residents living in the rental inspection district. 
(Code 1988, § 17-81; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-82. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building maintenance official means an officer or other designated authority charged with the administration and enforcement of the provisions of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code dealing with existing structures or a duly authorized representative. 
Building official means an officer or other designated authority charged with the administration and enforcement of the Uniform Statewide Building Code for new construction and permit issuance or a duly authorized representative. 
Department means the department of permits and inspections for the city. 
Director means the director of permits and inspections for the City of Portsmouth or his designee. 
Dwelling unit means a building or structure or part thereof that is used for a home or residence by one or more persons who maintain a household. 
Owner means the person shown on the current real estate tax assessment books or current real estate tax assessment records. 
Rental inspection district means an area designated as such by city council in accordance with the requirements of Code of Virginia, § 36-105.1:1. 
Residential rental dwelling unit means a dwelling unit that is leased or rented to one or more tenants. However, a dwelling unit occupied in part by the owner thereof shall not be construed to be a residential dwelling unit unless a tenant occupies a part of the dwelling unit which has its own cooking and sleeping areas, and a bathroom, unless otherwise provided in the zoning ordinance by the local governing body. 
(Code 1988, § 17-82; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-83. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be a violation and a misdemeanor for any owner, agent, property manager or person in charge of a residential rental dwelling unit located within a rental inspection district as established by this division to rent or lease such dwelling unit prior to an inspection and issuance of a certificate of compliance as required by the provisions of this division, unless such occupancy is approved by a temporary waiver pending the issuance of a certificate of compliance. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this division, violations of this division shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 17-27. 
(Code 1988, § 17-83; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005; Ord. No. 2008-12, § 1, 2-12-2008)  
Sec. 17-84. - Notification of locality by owner of dwelling units. 
(a)  Every owner of a rental dwelling unit located within a rental inspection district shall notify the department, in writing, within 60 days after the creation or expansion of a rental inspection district if the owner's dwelling unit is used for residential rental purposes. 
(b)  Willful failure of an owner of a residential rental dwelling unit subject to a rental inspection to comply with the above written notification requirement will result in a civil penalty of up to $50.00. However, there shall be no penalty for the failure of an owner of a residential rental dwelling unit to comply with the written notification provision, unless and until the department provides personal or written notice to the property owner. 
(c)  For purposes of this subsection, notice sent by regular first class mail to the last known address of the owner as shown on the current real estate tax assessment books or current real estate tax assessment records shall be deemed to comply with this requirement. 
(Code 1988, § 17-84; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-85. - Initial inspection of dwelling units when rental inspection district is established. 
Upon the establishment of a rental inspection district, the department may, in conjunction with the written notifications as provided in section 17-84, proceed to inspect dwelling units in the designated rental inspection district to determine if a dwelling unit is being used as residential rental property and to determine compliance with the provisions of the building code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for the tenants of such property. 
(Code 1988, § 17-85; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-86. - Provisions for initial and periodic inspections of multifamily dwelling units. 
If a multifamily rental dwelling unit has more than ten rental dwelling units, in the initial and periodic inspections, the department shall inspect only a sampling of the dwelling units, of not less than two and not more than ten percent of the dwelling units, of a multifamily development. However, in no event, shall the department charge a fee authorized by this section for the inspection of more than ten dwelling units. If the department determines upon inspection of the sampling of dwelling units that there are violations of the building code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for the tenants of such multifamily development, the department may inspect as many dwelling units as necessary to enforce the building code. In the latter case, the fee shall be based upon a charge per dwelling unit inspected, as otherwise provided in section 7-143. 
(Code 1988, § 17-86; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-87. - Follow-up inspections. 
Upon the initial or periodic inspection of a residential rental dwelling unit subject to this division, the department may require the owner of the dwelling unit to submit to such follow-up inspections of the dwelling unit as the department deems necessary, until such time as the dwelling unit is brought into compliance with the provisions of the building code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for the tenants. 
(Code 1988, § 17-87; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-88. - Periodic inspections. 
Except as provided above in section 17-87, following the initial inspection of a residential rental dwelling unit subject to this division, the department may inspect any residential rental dwelling unit in a rental inspection district that is not otherwise exempted no more than once each calendar year. The term "periodic inspection" shall not be deemed to include a follow-up inspection as provided in section 17-87. 
(Code 1988, § 17-88; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-89. - Exemptions from rental inspection ordinance. 
(a)  Upon the initial or periodic inspection of a residential rental dwelling unit as described in sections 17-85 and 17-88, and provided that there are no violations of the building code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for the tenants of such residential rental dwelling unit, the department shall provide to the owner of such residential rental dwelling unit, an exemption from the rental inspection ordinance for a period of four years. In the event that a violation of the building code affecting the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions is found to exist, an exemption will not be granted. The owner shall be provided with a written notice listing all violations and the period of time required to bring the property into compliance. 
(b)  Upon being brought into compliance, a residential rental dwelling unit shall be subject to periodic inspections until such time as a periodic inspection reveals no violations of the building code. 
(c)  Upon the sale of a residential rental dwelling unit, the department may perform a periodic inspection subsequent to such sale. 
(d)  If a residential rental dwelling unit has been issued a certificate of occupancy prior to July 1, 2005, the department shall grant an exemption for a minimum period of four years from the date of the issuance of the certificate of occupancy. 
(Code 1988, § 17-89; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-90. - Revocation of rental inspection exemption. 
(a)  If the condition of the residential rental dwelling unit violates the building code during the exemption period, the department may revoke the exemption previously granted under this section. 
(b)  No exemption granted by this section shall be considered permanent. After the expiration of the exemption period, the owner shall submit a written request to the department for a periodic inspection and shall schedule such inspection within 45 days of the exemption's expiration. 
(Code 1988, § 17-90; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-91. - Inspection of a residential rental dwelling unit outside of a designated rental inspection district. 
The inspection of a residential rental dwelling unit outside of a designated rental inspection district shall be based upon a determination by the department that: 
(1)  There is a need to protect the public health, welfare and safety of the occupants of that individual dwelling; and 
(2)  The individual dwelling unit is either blighted, in the process of deteriorating or there is evidence of violations of the building code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for tenants living in the dwelling unit. 
(Code 1988, § 17-91; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-92. - Fees. 
Fees for all rental inspections shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1988, § 17-92; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-93. - Rental inspection districts established; maps. 
There are hereby established three rental inspection districts within the City of Portsmouth. The boundaries of each of the districts shall be as shown on a series of three maps entitled "Rental Inspection Districts Maps, Portsmouth, Virginia," dated July 1, 2005, and any amendments thereto. The rental inspection district maps shall be considered parts of this division as if set out herein and may be amended in accordance with section 17-94. 
(Code 1988, § 17-93; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Sec. 17-94. - Amendment of rental inspection ordinance or maps. 
This division and the rental inspection districts maps may be amended only after advertisement and public hearing in accordance with the Code of Virginia, § 36-105.1:1 and any amendment thereto. 
(Code 1988, § 17-94; Ord. No. 2005-50, § 1, 6-28-2005)  
Secs. 17-95—17-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - VACANT BUILDINGS 
 
Sec. 17-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Director means the director of permits and inspections. 
Vacant or unoccupied building means any building or structure which is not occupied, used or inhabited on a regular and continuing basis by some person with a valid claim of right to possession or a fee simple title. The intrusion of trespassers or squatters into such buildings on any basis shall not render such building occupied or nonvacant within the meaning of this article. 
(Code 1973, §§ 6-41, 6-43; Code 1988, § 17-131; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 1(6-43), 12-13-1988) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 17-132. - Violations of article. 
Except as otherwise provided herein, any person who violates or fails to comply with the provisions of this article or the Virginia Maintenance Code shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each violation of a separate and distinct provision shall be a separate offense and each such offense shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $2,500.00; additionally, if the violation concerns a residential unit and if the violation remains uncorrected at the time of the conviction, the court shall order the violator to abate or remedy the violation in order to comply with the Code. Except as otherwise provided by the court for good cause shown, any such violator shall abate or remedy the violation within six months of the date of conviction. 
(Code 1973, § 6-46; Code 1988, § 17-132; Ord. No. 1992-53, § 3, 6-23-1992; Ord. No. 1993-49, § 1, 6-22-1993)  
Sec. 17-133. - Closure required; care of structure and premises. 
(a)  The owner of any building shall, whenever the same is or becomes vacant or unoccupied, remove therefrom all paper or other combustible waste material accumulated therein, and shall securely close and lock and thereafter keep closed and locked all doors, windows and other openings into such building so long as it shall remain vacant or unoccupied. The owner shall also maintain the building and premises in a clean, sanitary and safe condition so as not to constitute a nuisance. 
(b)  Foundations, walls, chimneys, flues, roofs, awnings, marquees, accessory structures, porches, balconies, stairs, landings, fire escapes, and railings shall be kept by the owner of the premises structurally sound and free from defects and damage and maintained in accord with the construction and repair standards of the building code. 
(c)  The exterior of every structure or accessory structure shall be kept in good repair and kept painted where necessary for the purposes of preservation and appearance. All surfaces shall be maintained free of broken glass, loose shingles, crumbling stone or brick, excessively peeling paint or other condition reflective of deterioration or inadequate maintenance. Boards or other approved materials or methods used to cover windows, doors or other openings in the structure or accessory structures shall be custom cut in such a fashion as to fit snugly into the window frame or door frame or other opening. Such boards or material shall be painted to match the trim color of the structure. 
(d)  The exterior of the premises and the condition of accessory structures shall be maintained so that the appearance of the premises and all buildings thereon shall reflect a level of maintenance in keeping with the standards of the neighborhood. 
(e)  The premises shall be kept landscaped, and lawns, hedges, bushes and trees shall be kept trimmed. 
(f)  The above duties and responsibilities are hereby imposed upon every owner of any building covered by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 6-42; Code 1988, § 17-133)  
Sec. 17-134. - Registration and permits required. 
(a)  Whenever any building in the city is or hereafter becomes vacant or unoccupied and the building or any of its doors, windows or other openings cannot be securely closed by the conventional means used in the design of the building, as required by section 17-133, the owner of such building shall, within 15 days thereafter, secure such building against unauthorized entry by boarding up or by some other approved method; shall register such building with the director; and shall obtain therefor a permit. When such registration is accomplished and the fees as set forth in section 17-136 are paid, the director shall issue a permit allowing the building to be maintained in a boarded-up condition for a period of one month from that date. Any building that becomes vacant or unoccupied and cannot be secured by the conventional means used in the design of the building, shall be deemed a nuisance and a threat to public safety and welfare. If, after written notice to the building's owner, with reasonable opportunity to comply, the building is not secured by boarding up or other approved method, the city manager or his designee may cause the building to be so secured. The actual cost of securing the building, together with an administrative fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code, shall be charged to and collected from the building's owner. 
(b)  If the building is to remain vacant for more than the month for which the permit was issued, the owner shall renew such permit on or before its expiration date by certifying to the director or his designee that the building is secure against unauthorized entry and that the information provided in the initial registration remains unchanged. The permit must be obtained or renewed for each month or portion thereof during which the building is vacant or unoccupied and unable to be secured by conventional means. A permit shall be issued by the director or his designee upon receipt by the director or his designee of the required letter of certification. A new registration shall be required whenever the information provided in the initial registration changes. The new registration shall be filed with the director or his designee within ten days after such change. 
(c)  The owner of any building which has been vacant for a continuing period of 12 months or more shall register such building annually with the director or his designee by certifying to the director or his designee that the building is secure against unauthorized entry. The permit must be obtained or renewed annually while the building remains vacant or unoccupied. A permit shall be issued by the director or his designee upon receipt by the director or his designee of a letter of certification. A new registration shall be required whenever the information provided in the initial registration changes. The new registration shall be filed with the director or his designee within ten days after such change. Any person who fails to register a building as required by this subsection shall be subject to a civil penalty of $50.00. Notice shall be mailed to the owner, at the address to which property tax notices are sent, at least 30 days prior to the assessment of the civil penalty. 
(Code 1973, § 6-43; Code 1988, § 17-134; Ord. No. 1988-111, § 1(6-43), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1993-49, § 2, 6-22-1993; Ord. No. 2004-32, § 1, 6-15-2004) 
State Law reference— Registration of vacant buildings, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1127.  
Sec. 17-135. - Registration and permit forms; letters of certification; nonassignable. 
(a)  Registration shall be made on forms supplied by the director or his designee for such purpose and shall include the names and addresses of all persons having any interest in the premises, the name and address of the person who shall be responsible for compliance with this article, the facts and conditions of such vacancy, the date the building became vacant and the length of time the building is expected to remain vacant or unoccupied. 
(b)  Permits shall be on forms supplied by the director or his designee for such purpose and shall include the name of the person to whom issued, the full address of the building covered, a statement that the required fees have been paid, and the expiration date of the permit. No permit or registration shall be assignable. 
(c)  Letters of certification shall be on forms supplied by the director or his designee for such purpose and shall include a statement certifying that the building is secure against unauthorized entry and that the information provided on the initial registration forms remain unchanged. 
(Code 1973, § 6-44; Code 1988, § 17-135) 
State Law reference— Registration of vacant buildings, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1127.  
Sec. 17-136. - Fees. 
The fee schedule for the following, as set out in appendix A to this Code, shall apply to all those buildings required to be registered by section 17-134. The initial fee shall be due within the period of registration required under section 17-134. Thereafter, if subsequent inspections are required because the building does not conform to requirements of this article, the owner shall be assessed additional inspection fees for each and every required inspection. The additional fee shall be due within ten days of receipt of a notice of violation. 
(1)  Single-family or two-family dwellings. 
(2)  Multiple-family apartment dwellings. 
Plus for each additional apartment above five. 
(3)  All other classes of buildings whether institutional, commercial, industrial, for the first gross 1,000 square feet. 
Plus, an amount for each additional gross 1,000 square feet or fraction thereof. 
(4)  All classes of buildings whether residential, institutional, commercial or industrial which had been vacant for a period of 12 months or more: Annual registration fee. 
(Code 1973, § 6-45; Code 1988, § 17-136; Ord. No. 1993-49, § 3, 6-22-1993) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 17-137. - Inspections. 
Upon registration of any building under this article, or upon any such building coming to his attention, the director shall cause inspection to be made of the premises to determine the condition of such building and premises and to detect all fire, safety or health hazards. 
(Code 1973, § 6-47; Code 1988, § 17-137)  
Chapter 18 - JUNK, SECONDHAND GOODS AND PAWNBROKERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— License tax on junk and secondhand paper canvassers and dealers, §§ 20-21, 20-22. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate pawnshops and secondhand dealers, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1114; marking goods as secondhand, etc., required, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-218; dealers in junk and secondhand articles, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-825 et seq.; pawnbrokers, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4000 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  Pawnbroker. As used in this chapter, the word "pawnbroker" means any person who in any manner lends or advances money or other things for profit on the pledge and possession of tangible personal property, or other valuable things, other than securities or written or printed evidences of indebtedness or title, or who deals in the purchasing of personal property or other valuable things on condition of selling the same back to the seller at a stipulated price. 
(b)  Junk dealer. As used in this chapter, the term "junk dealer" is defined as any person who purchases, sells, barters or exchanges any kind of secondhand articles, including but not limited to junk, rags, rag cullings, bottles, scrap, metal drosses, steel, iron, old lead or lead pipe, old bathroom fixtures, old rubber or other like commodities, except paper, and except furniture, clothes, shoes and stoves or the like intended to be resold for use as such. 
(c)  Secondhand dealer. As used in this chapter, the term "secondhand dealer" means any person who buys, sells, barters or exchanges used or secondhand articles, including but not limited to such items as firearms, jewelry, clothing, office machines, household appliances, radios, television sets, electronic equipment, sporting equipment, photographic equipment, heating or plumbing fixtures or supplies, electrical fixtures or wiring, gas fixtures or appliances, water faucets, pipes, locks, bathtubs or any other secondhand merchandise intended to be resold for use as such. 
(Code 1988, § 18-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4000.  
Sec. 18-2. - Pawnbroker's records; report. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker shall keep at his place of business an accurate and legible record of each loan or transaction in the course of his business, including transactions in which secondhand goods, wares or merchandise are purchased for resale. The account shall be recorded at the time of the loan or transaction and shall include: 
(1)  A description, serial number, and a statement of ownership of the goods, article or thing pawned or pledged or received on account of money loaned thereon, or purchased for resale; 
(2)  The time, date and place of the transaction; 
(3)  The amount of money loaned thereon at the time of pledging the same or paid as the purchase price; 
(4)  The rate of interest to be paid on such loan; 
(5)  The fees charged by the pawnbroker, itemizing each fee charged; 
(6)  The full name, residence address, telephone number, and driver's license number or other form of identification of the person pawning or pledging or selling the goods, article or thing, together with a particular description, including the height, weight, date of birth, race, gender, hair and eye color, and any other identifying marks, of such person; 
(7)  Verification of the identification by the exhibition of a government-issued identification card such as a driver's license or military identification card. The record shall contain the type of identification exhibited, the issuing agency, and the number thereon; 
(8)  As to loans, the terms and conditions of the loan, including the period for which any such loan may be made; and 
(9)  All other facts and circumstances respecting such loan or purchase. 
(b)  A pawnbroker may maintain at his place of business an electronic record of each transaction involving goods, article or things pawned or pledged or purchased. If maintained electronically, a pawnbroker shall retain the electronic records for at least one year after the date of the transaction and make such electronic records available to any duly authorized law enforcement officer upon request. 
(c)  Every pawnbroker shall prepare a daily report of all goods, articles or things pawned or pledged with him or sold to him that day and shall file such report by noon of the following day with the chief of police. The report shall include the pledgor's or seller's name, residence, and driver's license number or other form of identification, and a description of the goods, articles or other things pledged or sold and, unless maintained in electronic format, shall be in writing and clearly legible to any person inspecting it. A pawnbroker may compile and maintain the daily report in an electronic format and, if so maintained, shall file the required daily reports electronically with the appropriate law enforcement officer through use of a disk, electronic transmission, or any other electronic means of reporting approved by the law enforcement officer. 
(d)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, §§ 8-1, 18-52; Code 1988, § 18-2) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Pawnbrokers' records and reports, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4009.  
Sec. 18-2.1. - Examination and search and seizure of property of pawnbrokers. 
Every pawnbroker and every employee of the pawnbroker shall admit to the pawnbroker's place of business during regular business hours the chief of police or his designee. The pawnbroker or employee shall permit the officer to examine all records required by this chapter and any article listed in a record which is believed by the officer to be missing or stolen and search for and take into possession any article known to him to be missing, or known or believed by him to have been stolen. However, the officer shall not take possession of any article without providing to the pawnbroker a receipt. 
(Code 1988, § 18-2.1; Ord. No. 1990-74, § 1, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4011.  
Sec. 18-3. - Junk dealer's records. 
(a)  Every merchant or foundryman who deals in junk, old metals and similar articles and every junk dealer shall keep at his place of business and shall carry and keep with him a book in which shall be fairly written in English, at the time of each transaction in the course of his business, an accurate account of such transaction, except as to the purchase of rags, bones, old iron and paper, setting forth a description of the goods, articles or other things purchased, the time of receiving same, the name and residence of the person selling or delivering the same together with a description of such person, including complexion, color of eyes and hair, height and general appearance, together with the license number and identification tag of any motor vehicle in which the goods or things were delivered or a description of the vehicle. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-2; Code 1988, § 18-3) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Dealers in secondhand building supplies, records, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-120.  
Sec. 18-4. - Junk dealer's reports. 
(a)  Every junk dealer and merchant or foundryman who deals in junk, old metals and similar articles shall prepare a report, at the end of each day, of all goods, articles or things bought or received during the day and file such report not later than 12:00 noon of the following day with the chief of police. Such report may be compiled and maintained in an electronic format. If so maintained the report may be filed electronically with the chief of police in a manner approved by the chief of police. Such report shall include the name, residence, race, sex and date of birth of the person selling or delivering the same together with the license number of any motor vehicle being used or driven by such person at the time of the transaction. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-3; Code 1988, § 18-4) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Dealers in secondhand building supplies, reports delivered to chief of police, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-121.  
Sec. 18-5. - Retention of articles purchased or received by junk dealers. 
(a)  No automobiles, automobile parts, batteries, tires, wheels, brass, copper, lead, pipe or tubing made of copper, lead or brass, copper wire, lead insulated wire, brass or copper fixtures, radios or television sets, in whole or in part, bought or received by any junk dealer or merchant or foundryman who deals in junk, old metals and similar articles shall be disfigured or its identity destroyed or affected in any manner whatsoever for a period of five days following the date received or purchased, nor shall such property be in any manner concealed so that it cannot be readily found and inspected by the police, nor shall such property be sold or disposed of in any manner during this period of five days without permission of the chief of police. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-4; Code 1988, § 18-5) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Secs. 18-6—18-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SECONDHAND GOODS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Precious metals dealers, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4100 et seq.; sales of secondhand heating or plumbing fixtures or supplies, electric fixtures or wiring, gas fixtures or appliances, water fixtures or supplies or other secondhand fixtures of whatever kind or description pertaining to a building, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-117 et seq.; purchase, exchange, etc., of certain metals, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-125 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-26. - Purchasing from minor prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker, junk dealer, secondhand dealer or any other person to purchase, barter or exchange or in any manner obtain from minors under the age of 18 years, any kind of secondhand articles, junk, rags, metal or other like commodities. 
(b)  No pawnbroker, junk dealer, secondhand dealer or any other person shall purchase, barter or exchange or in any manner obtain from any seller who the dealer believes or has reason to believe is not the owner of such items, unless the seller has written and duly authenticated authorization from the owner permitting and directing such sale. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-16; Code 1988, § 18-26) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Limitation on purchase of precious metals, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4103.  
Sec. 18-27. - Purchaser to obtain bill of sale; identification of seller. 
(a)  Any person, except a licensed merchant or dealer, buying any secondhand articles at a private or public sale within the city shall obtain from the seller a properly dated written receipt or bill of sale, signed by such seller who shall therein specifically state the seller's address or place of residence. If the seller is not personally known to the buyer, the seller shall produce at least one document of positive identification which includes a picture of the seller. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-17; Code 1988, § 18-27) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Secs. 18-28—18-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CLOTHING, FURNITURE, APPLIANCES AND SIMILAR ARTICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Used bedding, upholstered furniture, etc., Code of Virginia, § 32.1-212 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-51. - Dealer's record of purchases. 
(a)  All dealers in secondhand clothing, furniture, appliances and other similar secondhand articles shall keep daily records of every article bought by them, such records to contain a full description of such articles, and to show all distinguishing marks, numbers, brands, letters, or monograms of any kind on such articles, together with the names and addresses of the parties from whom such articles were received. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-24; Code 1988, § 18-51) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 18-52. - Dealer's report of purchases. 
(a)  All dealers in secondhand clothing, furniture, appliances and other similar secondhand articles shall furnish daily to the chief of police, upon blanks to be prescribed by the chief, full and complete lists of all articles taken in or bought by such dealers within the 24 hours next preceding the date of such report. Such lists shall contain a full description of all such articles, together with all marks, numbers, brands, letters or monograms on such articles, and the names and addresses of the parties from whom such articles were received. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-25; Code 1988, § 18-52) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 18-53. - Health director's consent required for sale of secondhand mattresses, pillows or bedclothing. 
It shall be unlawful and a class 2 misdemeanor for any person to sell, or to expose for sale, any secondhand mattresses, pillows, bolsters or bedclothing of any description, without first obtaining consent of the director of public health, which consent shall be exhibited on the article so offered for sale and evidenced by such device as the director of public health. 
(Code 1973, § 16-1; Code 1988, § 18-53) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 2 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Used bedding, upholstered furniture, etc., Code of Virginia, § 32.1-212 et seq.  
Secs. 18-54—18-75. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - BUILDING MATERIAL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Sales of secondhand heating or plumbing fixtures or supplies, electric fixtures or wiring, gas fixtures or appliances, water fixtures or supplies or other secondhand fixtures of whatever kind or description pertaining to a building, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-117 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-76. - Definition. 
As used in this division, the term "secondhand building material" includes lumber, bricks, doors, windowpanes, hardware, plumbing, heating, electric light and gas fixtures or any other material ordinarily used in the construction of buildings. 
(Code 1973, § 18-34; Code 1988, § 18-76) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definition of building fixtures, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-117.  
Sec. 18-77. - Record of purchases. 
(a)  All persons who buy secondhand building material other than from a licensed dealer shall keep a daily record of all material so purchased, which record shall contain the name and address of the person from whom the material was purchased, and a description of the property purchased with any distinguishing marks, numbers or trade names which may be thereon. Such records shall be kept for a period of 12 months after each purchase. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-35; Code 1988, § 18-77) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Books on sale or purchase of certain building materials, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-120.  
Sec. 18-78. - Information concerning purchases to be furnished police. 
(a)  Any person who buys any secondhand building material from a person who is not a licensed dealer, other than where he purchases a building as a whole and wrecks the same, within 24 hours after such purchase, furnish the chief of police a description of the materials purchased, and the name and address of the person from whom purchased. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-36; Code 1988, § 18-78) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Reports delivered to chief of police, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-121.  
Secs. 18-79—18-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - MOTOR VEHICLE PARTS AND ACCESSORIES 
 
Sec. 18-101. - Definition. 
As used in this division, the word "dealer" means a person engaged in the business of buying or otherwise acquiring secondhand tires or secondhand motor vehicle parts or accessories. 
(Code 1988, § 18-101)  
Sec. 18-102. - Inspection of records and certificates required by division. 
The records and certificates required by this division shall at all times be open and subject to inspection by the chief of police and any member of the police department of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 18-48; Code 1988, § 18-102)  
Sec. 18-103. - Dealer's record of purchases. 
(a)  Every dealer shall keep at his place of business a permanently bound book in which shall be legibly written in ink, in English, at the time of each transaction in the course of his business, an accurate account of each purchase or acquisition of any secondhand tire or secondhand motor vehicle part or accessory. 
(b)  The account required to be kept by this section shall set forth an accurate description of the secondhand tire, motor vehicle part or accessory, including any distinguishing marks and numbers thereon, purchased or acquired, the date thereof and the name, residence and description of the person selling or delivering the same. The description of such person shall consist of his color, sex, approximate height, age and any distinguishing feature. 
(c)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, §§ 18-44, 18-45; Code 1988, § 18-103) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 18-104. - Dealer to obtain certificate from seller. 
(a)  Before any dealer buys or acquires any secondhand tire or motor vehicle part or accessory, he shall require the person selling or delivering the same to certify, in writing signed by such person on a form prescribed by the chief of police, an accurate description of the tire, motor vehicle part or accessory and when, from whom and how the same were acquired by him. The certificate shall be preserved by the dealer at his place of business. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-47; Code 1988, § 18-104) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 18-105. - Purchases by dealer prohibited between 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
It shall be unlawful and a class 1 misdemeanor for a dealer to purchase or acquire any secondhand tire or secondhand motor vehicle part or accessory between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(Code 1973, § 18-46; Code 1988, § 18-105) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Secs. 18-106—18-125. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - RESIDENTIAL SALES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-126. - Definition. 
The term "residential sale," as used in this article, means the sale of personal property in, at or upon any residentially zoned property. The term "residential sale" shall include any sale which is held out to be or which is commonly known as a garage, yard, attic, basement, porch, patio or room sale, or any other type of general sale involving the offering for sale of multiple items of personal property conducted from or on any premises located in a zoning district which does not permit retail or commercial sales, where goods or articles of any type are held out for sale to the public. The term "residential sale" does not encompass the mere incidental sale of one or two items of personal property when such sale is not a part of a general sale of a number of items of personal property. 
(Code 1973, § 18-61; Code 1988, § 18-126) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 18-127. - Violations of article. 
Any person who violates or fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. Each violation of a separate and distinct provision of this article shall be a separate offense, and each day any violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1973, § 18-65; Code 1988, § 18-127) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 18-128. - Exemptions from article. 
Periodic sales held exclusively at churches or other places of worship, public or private schools, or other similar places of public assembly under the auspices of a nonprofit organization operated exclusively for religious, charitable, community or educational purposes are exempt from the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 18-64; Code 1988, § 18-128)  
Sec. 18-129. - General prohibition against sales in residential areas. 
The conduct of general retail sales or commercial sales or any sales of multiple items of personal property in residential areas of the city is, except as otherwise expressly authorized by law, prohibited. 
(Code 1973, § 18-62; Code 1988, § 18-129)  
Sec. 18-130. - Signs advertising sale. 
No signs shall be posted anywhere in the city advertising a residential sale, except that the property owner may install on the residential lot on which the sale is to be held one sign not larger than four square feet. Such sign shall be posted not more than 48 hours prior to the date of the sale and shall be removed at the end of the last day upon which the sale is held. 
(Code 1973, § 18-64; Code 1988, § 18-130)  
Sec. 18-131. - Hours and days of sale. 
Any sale conducted pursuant to a permit issued under this article shall be limited in time to the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. on three consecutive days. No such sale shall be conducted on Sunday. If the sale is not held because of inclement weather, and an amended application so stating is submitted to the commissioner of revenue, another permit may be issued for a sale date within 30 days of the original permitted date. 
(Code 1973, § 18-64; Code 1988, § 18-131)  
Sec. 18-132. - Sale items not to be placed in public right-of-way or so as to interfere with traffic. 
No personal property sold or offered for sale at a residential sale shall be placed, kept or displayed on or in any public right-of-way or in any manner as to interfere with or impede the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1973, § 18-64; Code 1988, § 18-132) 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 22.  
Sec. 18-133. - Parking of vehicles; temporary controls to alleviate hazards or congestion. 
All parking of vehicles by persons conducting or attending a residential sale shall be in compliance with all applicable laws and ordinances. Further, the police department may enforce temporary controls to alleviate any special hazards or congestion created by the residential sale. 
(Code 1973, § 18-64; Code 1988, § 18-133) 
Cross reference— Parking regulations, § 22-561 et seq.  
Sec. 18-134. - Sale of goods received on consignment prohibited. 
No goods received from any commercial business or enterprise on a consignment basis shall be sold or offered for sale at a residential sale. 
(Code 1973, § 18-64; Code 1988, § 18-134)  
Sec. 18-135. - Suspension or cancellation for public good. 
The chief of police may, when circumstances indicate the existence of or creation of a nuisance or danger to the health, safety or welfare of the public through the conduct of a residential sale, suspend or cancel the sale for a given period of time or for the duration of the time allocated in the permit issued under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 18-64; Code 1988, § 18-135)  
Secs. 18-136—18-155. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 18-156. - Required. 
No person shall conduct a residential sale without first obtaining a permit so to do from the commissioner of the revenue. 
(Code 1973, § 18-63; Code 1988, § 18-156)  
Sec. 18-157. - Application. 
Application for a permit required by this division shall be made to the commissioner of the revenue in such form as the commissioner shall require at least five days prior to the desired beginning date of the residential sale. 
(Code 1973, § 18-63; Code 1988, § 18-157)  
Sec. 18-158. - Fee. 
Every application for a permit required by the provisions of this division shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 18-63; Code 1988, § 18-158) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 18-159. - Investigation prior to issuance. 
Before issuing a permit under the provisions of this division, the commissioner of the revenue may conduct such investigation as may reasonably be necessary to determine if there is compliance with this Code and to determine the impact the proposed sale would have on the neighborhood in question relative to the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(Code 1973, § 18-63; Code 1988, § 18-159)  
Sec. 18-160. - Limitation on issuance to members of same family. 
No more than two permits per year shall be issued under this division to the same family or any member of a family who actually resides within the same residence. 
(Code 1973, § 18-64; Code 1988, § 18-160)  
Sec. 18-161. - Display. 
Each permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be displayed in a visible and conspicuous place during the time of the sale. 
(Code 1973, § 18-63; Code 1988, § 18-161)  
Chapter 19 - LIBRARIES AND MUSEUMS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Damaging library property, § 24-317. 
State Law reference— Authority to establish local and regional libraries, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-33 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 19-1. - Library card fee; non-resident library patrons. 
An annual fee, as set out in Appendix A and any subsequent amendments thereto, shall be charged prior to the issuance of a library card to any individual who is a resident of a locality imposing such a fee on the citizens of Portsmouth. The fee shall not be charged to non-resident employees of the City of Portsmouth, non-resident city property owners, non-resident city business owners, and non-resident Tidewater Community College students attending classes in the City of Portsmouth. The fee shall be payable on July 1st of each year or at such time thereafter as an individual subject to the fee shall seek to use a library card. 
( Ord. No. 2009-70 , § 1, 7-28-2009)  
Secs. 19-2—19-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC LIBRARY ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Local library boards generally, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-35 et seq. 
 
Sec. 19-21. - Established. 
There is hereby created a board to be known as the public library advisory board. 
(Code 1973, § 19-1; Code 1988, § 19-21)  
Sec. 19-22. - Composition; election and terms of members. 
The public library advisory board shall consist of nine members, who shall be citizens of the city and shall be appointed by the city council. Members of the public library advisory board shall be appointed for terms of three years. Members of the public library advisory board shall hold office until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1973, § 19-2; Code 1988, § 19-22) 
State Law reference— Membership and term of office of four years, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-35.  
Sec. 19-23. - Members' oath. 
Each member of the public library advisory board shall take the oath of office prescribed by law for city officials. 
(Code 1973, § 19-4; Code 1988, § 19-23)  
Sec. 19-24. - Filling of vacancies. 
All vacancies on the public library advisory board shall be filled by appointment by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1973, § 19-5; Code 1988, § 19-24)  
Sec. 19-25. - Compensation of members. 
The members of the public library advisory board shall serve as such without compensation. 
(Code 1973, § 19-3; Code 1988, § 19-25)  
Sec. 19-26. - Organizational meeting; election of officers. 
The members of the public library advisory board shall, immediately after their appointment and qualification, meet and organize. The members of the public library advisory board shall elect a chair, a vice-chair and such other officers thereof, if any, as they may deem necessary. 
(Code 1973, § 19-6; Code 1988, § 19-26)  
Sec. 19-27. - Ex officio secretary designated. 
The library director of the Portsmouth Public Library shall be ex officio secretary of the public library advisory board. 
(Code 1973, § 19-7; Code 1988, § 19-27)  
Sec. 19-28. - Quorum. 
A majority of the members of the public library advisory board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1973, § 19-8; Code 1988, § 19-28)  
Sec. 19-29. - Adoption of rules. 
The public library advisory board shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their guidance as may be deemed necessary and expedient. 
(Code 1973, § 19-9; Code 1988, § 19-29)  
Sec. 19-30. - Duties and responsibilities. 
The public library advisory board shall have the duties and responsibilities prescribed by the Library of Virginia. 
(Code 1973, § 19-10; Code 1988, § 19-30)  
Secs. 19-31—19-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PORTSMOUTH LAW LIBRARY[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Law libraries, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-60 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 19-51. - Definition. 
As used in this article, the term "law library" means the Portsmouth Law Library. 
(Code 1988, § 19-51) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 19-52. - Administrative supervision. 
Subject to the supervision and control of the city manager, the city attorney shall be charged with administration of the affairs of the law library. 
(Code 1973, § 19-24; Code 1988, § 19-52)  
Sec. 19-53. - Appointment of employees. 
The librarian, assistants and employees of the law library shall be appointed by the city manager after consultation with the law library board or the librarian in the manner prescribed by the city charter for the appointment of officers and employees of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 19-25; Code 1988, § 19-53) 
Cross reference— Appointment of city employees generally, § 2-101.  
Secs. 19-54—19-75. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LAW LIBRARY BOARD 
 
Sec. 19-76. - Established; composition. 
There is hereby created a board to be known as the law library board, which shall consist of five members. The city attorney shall be an ex officio member of such board, and the remaining four members shall be appointed by the city council. Two of the appointed members of such board shall be practicing attorneys, one shall be a judge of one of the courts located within the city, and one shall be a qualified person as provided for in section 2-28(a) who is not a licensed attorney and not an official or employee of any court located within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 19-26; Code 1988, § 19-76; Ord. No. 1990-129, § 8, 12-11-1990)  
Sec. 19-77. - Terms of members. 
The term of the ex officio member of the law library board shall begin on November 1, 1966, and shall correspond to his official tenure. The terms of the appointed members of such board shall begin on November 1, 1966. Of the original board, one of the appointed members shall be appointed for a term of one year, one for a term of two years, one for a term of three years, and one for a term of four years. At the expiration of the respective terms of such appointed members, their successors shall be appointed for terms of four years. The appointed members shall hold office during their respective terms and until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1973, § 19-27; Code 1988, § 19-77)  
Sec. 19-78. - Members' oath. 
Each member of the law library board shall take the oath of office prescribed by law for city officials. If any such member shall, for 30 days after receiving notice of such appointment, fail to take such oath, he shall be considered as having declined such office, and the same shall be deemed vacant. 
(Code 1973, § 19-29; Code 1988, § 19-78)  
Sec. 19-79. - Filling of vacancies. 
All vacancies on the law library board shall be filled by appointment by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1973, § 19-30; Code 1988, § 19-79)  
Sec. 19-80. - Compensation of members. 
All of the members of the law library board shall serve as such without compensation. 
(Code 1973, § 19-28; Code 1988, § 19-80)  
Sec. 19-81. - Organizational meeting; election, term of officers. 
The members of the law library board shall, immediately after their appointment and qualification, meet and organize. The members of the law library board shall elect a chairman, a vice-chairman and such other officers thereof, if any, as they may deem necessary. All of such officers shall hold office for a term of one year. 
(Code 1973, § 19-31; Code 1988, § 19-81)  
Sec. 19-82. - Board may appoint law librarian secretary. 
The law library board may appoint the librarian of the law library to the office of secretary of the board. 
(Code 1973, § 19-32; Code 1988, § 19-82)  
Sec. 19-83. - Quorum. 
A majority of the members of the law library board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1973, § 19-33; Code 1988, § 19-83)  
Sec. 19-84. - Board to control, manage law library; adoption of rules. 
The law library board shall have the control and management of the city law library and shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their guidance and for the control and management of the law library as may be deemed necessary and expedient. 
(Code 1973, § 19-34; Code 1988, § 19-84)  
Sec. 19-85. - Board's power to accept, expend gifts, funds; reduction of appropriations. 
The law library board shall have the power to accept, administer and expend for operating expenses funds received as gifts, including gifts in trust. If the law library board receives and expends for operating expenses any funds not included in its budget as approved by the city council, the council may direct that the amount appropriated from city funds be reduced by the amount so expended from outside such budget. 
(Code 1973, § 19-35; Code 1988, § 19-85)  
Sec. 19-86. - Board to furnish information to city manager. 
The law library board shall furnish the city manager, whenever requested by him, a detailed statement of the amount of money deemed necessary by the board for the operation of the law library for any specified time and also such other information as may be desired with respect to the operation and management of such library. 
(Code 1973, § 19-36; Code 1988, § 19-86)  
Secs. 19-87—19-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LAW LIBRARY ASSESSMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Assessment for law library authorized, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-70. 
 
Sec. 19-111. - Imposed; amount. 
There is hereby imposed for the law library fund an assessment as part of the costs incident to each civil action filed in the circuit court, located within the boundaries of the city, the sum as set forth in appendix A to this Code, and for each civil action filed in the districts courts, located within the boundaries of the city, the sum as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 19-44; Code 1988, § 19-111; Ord. No. 2000-14, § 1, 4-25-2000) 
State Law reference— Authority for assessment, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-70.  
Sec. 19-112. - Exemptions. 
The assessment of costs provided for in this division shall be in addition to all other costs prescribed by law, but shall not apply to any action in which the state or any political subdivision thereof or the federal government is a party and in which the costs are assessed against the state, political subdivision thereof or federal government. 
(Code 1973, § 19-48; Code 1988, § 19-112) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-70.  
Sec. 19-113. - Collection, remittance. 
The assessment imposed by this division shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed and remitted by him to the city treasurer within ten days after the end of each month. 
(Code 1973, § 19-45; Code 1988, § 19-113) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-70.  
Sec. 19-114. - Use of funds. 
The monies collected under this division shall be for the acquisition of law books, law periodicals and computer legal research services and equipment for the establishment, use and maintenance of a law library which shall be open for the use of the public. In addition to the acquisition of law books, law periodicals and computer legal research services and equipment, disbursements from the law library fund may include compensation to be paid the librarians and other necessary staff for the maintenance of such library and acquisition of suitable quarters for such library. 
(Code 1973, § 19-46; Code 1988, § 19-114) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-70.  
Sec. 19-115. - Accounting procedures. 
The chief financial officer shall set up a special account on his books for the law library fund and the funds so deposited shall be disbursed on vouchers signed by such persons as may be authorized by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 19-47; Code 1988, § 19-115; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Secs. 19-116—19-149. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MUSEUMS 
 
Sec. 19-150. - Museum admission fees. 
The daily fees as set out in appendix A to this Code shall be charged for admission to city museums for the following: 
(1)  Children's Museum of Virginia: 
a.  Regular admission. 
Children less than two years of age 
Children 2 to 17 years of age 
Adults 
Military with ID and seniors (62 years of age and older), AAA members 
b.  Group: Portsmouth Public Schools students. 
c.  Reserved. 
d.  Group: Per person, self-guided tour. 
e.  Additional fees: 
With either Focus Program or Planetarium Program. 
With both Focus Program and Planetarium Program. 
(2)  Other museums per person: 
a.  Courthouse Galleries. 
b.  Naval Shipyard Museum/Lightship Museum. 
Children less than two years of age 
Children 2 to 17 years of age 
Adults 
Military with ID, seniors (62 years of age and older), AAA members 
(3)  Keypass discount program. Upon payment of a fee as set out in Appendix A to this Code, a person shall be entitled to admittance to all city museums except for the Planetarium during normal working hours for 90 days from the date of issuance. 
Children less than two years of age 
Children 2 to 17 years of age 
Adults 
Military with ID, seniors (62 years of age and older), AAA members 
(4)  Members of the Portsmouth Museums and/or the Friends of the Naval Shipyard Museum shall, upon providing proof of active membership, be entitled to admission without charge to any city museum. An individual membership shall entitle the individual member to admission without charge. A family membership shall entitle members of the immediate family to admission without charge. 
(5)  The city manager or his designee is authorized to establish such waivers of admission fees as deemed appropriate, provided that the conditions or grounds for such waivers are specified in writing. 
(6)  The fees established by this section and set out in appendix A to this Code shall not be applicable to any exhibitions which, by contractual agreement preclude fees from being charged for admission. 
(7)  The director of museums is authorized to set promotional or discount rates for certain exhibits or events not to exceed the established admission fees. 
These rates may be offered in conjunction with promotions or even involving other organizations or entities. 
(Code 1988, § 19-150; Ord. No. 1998-51, § 3, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2002-40, § 1, 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 2011-23, § 1, 5-4-2011; Ord. No. 2013-29, § 1, 5-14-2013)  
Chapter 20 - LICENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of city as to licenses and license taxes, § 2.02. 
Cross reference— Permit for commercial recreation centers, § 3-101 et seq.; dog licenses, § 4-61 et seq.; permit for residential (yard) sales, § 18-156 et seq.; vehicle licenses, § 22-71 et seq.; permit for private detectives and private detective agencies, § 27-111 et seq.; permit for dealers in precious metals and gems, § 28-51 et seq.; permit for sidewalk vendors in downtown district, § 32-201 et seq.; permit for operation of public swimming pool, § 34-5; taxation, ch. 35; payment of personal property and machinery and tools taxes prerequisite to issuance of license, § 35-4; certificate of public convenience and necessity for taxicabs, § 37-61 et seq. 
State Law reference— Local license taxes, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3700 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 20-1. - Chapter overrides conflicting ordinances. 
Except as may be otherwise provided by the laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia or article II of this chapter, the following provisions shall be applicable to the levy, assessment, and collection of licenses required and taxes imposed on businesses, trades, professions and callings and upon the persons, firms and corporations engaged therein within this locality. 
(Code 1988, § 20-1; Ord. No. 1995-116, § 2, 12-12-1995)  
Sec. 20-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Affiliated group means: 
(1)  One or more chains of includable corporations connected through stock ownership with a common parent corporation which is an includable corporation if: 
a.  Stock possessing at least 80 percent of the voting power of all classes of stock and at least 80 percent of each class of the nonvoting stock of each of the includable corporations, except the common parent corporation, is owned directly by one or more of the other includable corporations; and 
b.  The common parent corporation directly owns stock possessing at least 80 percent of the voting power of all classes of stock and at least 80 percent of each class of the nonvoting stock of at least one of the other includable corporations. As used in this chapter, the term "stock" does not include nonvoting stock which is limited and preferred as to dividends. The term "includable corporation" means any corporation within the affiliated group irrespective of the state or country of its incorporation; and the term "receipts" includes gross receipts and gross income. 
(2)  Two or more corporations if five or fewer persons who are individuals, estates or trusts own stock possessing: 
a.  At least 80 percent of the total combined voting power of all classes of stock entitled to vote or at least 80 percent of the total value of shares of all classes of the stock of each corporation; and 
b.  More than 50 percent of the total combined voting power of all classes of stock entitled to vote or more than 50 percent of the total value of shares of all classes of stock of each corporation, taking into account the stock ownership of each such person only to the extent such stock ownership is identical with respect to each such corporation. 
When one or more of the includable corporations, including the common parent corporation is a nonstock corporation, the term "stock" as used in this article shall refer to the nonstock corporation membership or membership voting rights, as is appropriate to the context. 
(3)  Two or more entities if such entities satisfy the requirements in subsections (1) or (2) of this section as if they were corporations and the ownership interests therein were stock. 
Assessment means a determination as to the proper rate of tax, the measure to which the tax rate is applied, and ultimately the amount of tax, including additional or omitted tax, that is due. An assessment shall include a written assessment made pursuant to notice by the assessing official or a self-assessment made by a taxpayer upon the filing of a return or otherwise not pursuant to notice. Assessments shall be deemed made by an assessing official when a written notice of assessment is delivered to the taxpayer by the assessing official or an employee of the assessing official, or mailed to the taxpayer at his last known address. Self-assessments shall be deemed made when a return is filed, or if no return is required, when the tax is paid. A return filed or tax paid before the last day prescribed by ordinance for the filing or payment thereof shall be deemed to be filed or paid on the last day specified for the filing of a return or the payment of tax, as the case may be. 
Assessor or assessing official means the commissioner of revenue of this jurisdiction. 
Base year means the calendar year preceding the license year, except for contractors subject to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3715. 
Broker means an agent of a buyer or a seller who buys or sells stocks, bonds, commodities, or services, usually on a commission basis. 
Business means a course of dealing which requires the time, attention and labor of the person so engaged for the purpose of earning a livelihood or profit. It implies a continuous and regular course of dealing, rather than an irregular or isolated transaction. A person may be engaged in more than one business. The following acts shall create a rebuttable presumption that a person is engaged in a business: 
(1)  Advertising or otherwise holding oneself out to the public as being engaged in a particular business; or 
(2)  Filing tax returns, schedules and documents that are required only of persons engaged in a trade or business. 
Commodity means staples such as wool, cotton, etc., which are traded on a commodity exchange and on which there is trading in futures. 
Contractor shall have the meaning prescribed in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3714(B), whether such work is done or offered to be done by day labor, general contract or subcontract. 
Dealer means any person engaged in the business of buying and selling securities for his own account, but does not include a bank, or any person insofar as he buys or sells securities for his own account, either individually or in some fiduciary capacity, but not as part of a regular business. 
Definite place of business means an office or a location at which occurs a regular and continuous course of dealing for 30 consecutive days or more. A definite place of business for a person engaged in business may include a location leased or otherwise obtained from another person on a temporary or seasonal basis; and real property leased to another.
