Sound level meter. An instrument which includes a microphone, amplifier, RMS detector, integrator or time averager, output meter and any applicable weighting network used to measure sound pressure levels. 
Zone. Any reference to property being in a particular "zone" shall mean the zoning district category of the property, as per chapter 40.1 of this Code. 
(c)  Per se offenses. The following activities are deemed to comprise creating excessive sound in violation of this section, without any requirement of scientific measurement of sound levels: 
(1)  A person blowing a car horn when it is not reasonably necessary to do so for legitimate safety or emergency purposes. 
(2)  A person operating a sound system in a motor vehicle at a sound level that, when heard in another vehicle with the windows closed, interferes with normal conversation, interferes with normal use or enjoyment of a car radio, interferes with use of a communication system (such as a cell phone, car telephone, citizens band radio, or police radio), or creates physically perceptible vibrations. 
(3)  A person allowing an animal to make sound that unreasonably and repeatedly disturbs another person in his or her residence after being requested to stop. 
(4)  A person operating a motor vehicle that generates loud exhaust sound without having a muffler that meets all applicable motor code requirements. 
(5)  Sound that unreasonably interferes with the functioning of a court of law, religious activities at an established place of worship, a medical facility, or the conduct of government activities in a governmental building. 
(d)  Offenses requiring scientific measurement of sound levels. The following sound levels shall be deemed to be excessive sound in violation of this section, when measured outside the real property line of the sound source. The zone shall be determined by where the sound is measured, not where it is generated. 
(1)  Residential zones; night. In a residential zone between 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., sound meeting or exceeding 55 dBA. 
(2)  Residential zones; day. In a residential zone between 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., sound meeting or exceeding 65 dBA. 
(3)  Commercial zones. In a commercial zone, sound meeting or exceeding 75 dBA. 
(e)  Scientific measurement procedures. 
(1)  The decibel level of any noise regulated by the preceding subsection may be measured by the use of a sound level meter. Such measurements shall be accepted as prima facie evidence of the level of noise at issue in any court or legal proceeding to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(2)  The accuracy of the sound level meter may be tested by a calibrator. Any sworn report of the results of any test of the calibrator for the accuracy of a sound level meter shall be admissible in court in any criminal or civil proceeding, as evidence of the facts therein stated. 
(3)  An individual operating a sound level meter pursuant to the provisions of this section shall issue a certificate to indicate: 
(i)  That the sound level meter used to take the decibel level reading was operated in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications; 
(ii)  That the city has on file a sworn report which states that the sound level meter has been tested within the past 12 months and has been found to be accurate; 
(iii)  The name of the accused; 
(iv)  The location of the noise; 
(v)  The date and time that the reading was made: 
(vi)  The zone in which the reading was made; and 
(vii)  The decibel level reading. 
(4)  Such certificate, when attested by the operator taking the decibel level reading, shall be admissible in court in any criminal or civil proceeding as evidence of the facts therein stated and of the decibel level reading. A copy of the certificate shall be delivered to the accused upon request. 
(f)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  The operation of construction devices used in construction activities between 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(2)  The operation of lawn care maintenance equipment such as power mowers, chain saws, and string trimmers, and vehicles for the removal of debris, garbage or refuse with properly working mufflers between 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(3)  The repair, maintenance or construction of federal, state, regional, or local governmental facilities. 
(4)  Emergency work to repair equipment or facilities. 
(5)  The operation of railroad and railway equipment and vehicles. 
(6)  Sound generated by any emergency governmental function, including but not limited to emergency vehicles. 
(7)  Recreational activities or events on publicly owned property, where authorized by the city manager or his designee. 
(8)  Sound generated by boats or ships in navigable waterways, or by aircraft. 
(9)  Duly permitted or authorized demolition activities. 
(10)  Churches engaged in religious activities. 
(11)  Burglar alarms or vehicle alarms, except that this exemption shall not apply if the owner of the property or vehicle fails to terminate the sounding of the alarm within a reasonable period of time. 
(12)  Other activities specifically authorized in advance in writing by the chief of police or his designee. 
(g)  Penalties. Except as otherwise provided in this section, the penalty for a violation of this section shall be as set for a Class IV misdemeanor. For any person who is convicted of a second or subsequent offense of this section within 12 months of a prior conviction, the penalty shall be as set forth for a Class III misdemeanor. 
(h)  Other remedies. This section shall not be deemed to limit the ability of any person to bring a common law civil proceeding to abate any excessive sound that is alleged to comprise a public or private nuisance. In addition, the City of Portsmouth and any person shall be entitled to seek equitable relief to enjoin a violation of this section. The prohibitions and penalties set forth in this section shall be deemed cumulative to any other prohibitions penalties that may be set forth elsewhere. 
(Code 1973, §§ 21-96, 21-97; Code 1988, § 24-255; Ord. No. 1989-84, § 1, 9-26-1989; Ord. No. 1994-48, § 1, 6-14-1994; Ord. No. 2009-89, §§ 1, 2, 9-8-2009) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11; restrictions on blowing of locomotive whistles, § 29-3.  
Sec. 24-256. - Abusive and insulting language generally. 
If any person shall, in the presence or hearing of another, curse or abuse such other person concerning himself or any of his relations, or otherwise use such language, under circumstances reasonably calculated to provoke a breach of the peace, he shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-91; Code 1988, § 24-256) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11; use of offensive language by operator of vehicle for hire, § 37-1. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-416.  
Sec. 24-257. - Slander and libel. 
(a)  Any person who shall falsely utter and speak, or falsely write and publish, of and concerning any female of chaste character, any words derogatory of such female's character for virtue and chastity, or imputing to such female acts not virtuous and chaste, or who shall falsely utter and speak, or falsely write and publish, of and concerning another person, any words which, from their usual construction and common acceptation, are construed as insults and tend to violence and breach of the peace or shall use grossly insulting language to any female of good character or reputation, shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(b)  The defendant in a prosecution under this section shall be entitled to prove, in mitigation of the punishment, the provocation which induced the libelous or slanderous words or any other fact or circumstances tending to disprove malice or lessen the criminality of the offense. 
(Code 1973, 21-90; Code 1988, § 24-258) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-417.  
Sec. 24-258. - Public drunkenness. 
If any person is intoxicated in public, whether such intoxication results from alcohol, narcotic drug, or other intoxicant or drug of whatever nature, he shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. In any area in which there is located a court-approved detoxification center a law enforcement officer may authorize the transportation, by police or otherwise, of public inebriates to such detoxification center in lieu of arrest; however, no person shall be involuntarily detained in such center. 
(Code 1973, § 21-93; Code 1988, § 24-259; Ord. No. 1990-68, § 1, 6-26-1990; Ord. No. 1994-65, § 1, 6-28-1994) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-388.  
Sec. 24-259. - Prohibited conduct in public places. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to engage in any of the following types of conduct: 
(1)  To unreasonably or unnecessarily obstruct, impede, or restrict the free passage of others along any portion of a sidewalk or public plaza. 
(2)  To unreasonably or unnecessarily obstruct, impede, or restrict the free passage of others into or from private property. 
(3)  To lie or sit upon a mattress, or to lie or sleep, while on a public sidewalk or on the ground in a public plaza. 
(4)  While on a public sidewalk or public plaza, or while in a public parking area, to erect and/or to occupy a tent or other temporary protective structure. This paragraph shall not apply to any person acting with written city authorization or as part of a city-authorized festival or event. 
(5)  To fail to remove such tent or other protective structure described in the preceding paragraph, and also all debris or articles associated therewith. 
(6)  To lie upon a bench that is on a sidewalk or in a public plaza. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "public plaza" means only: 
(1)  The sidewalks, steps, and public areas surrounding or adjacent to High Street Landing and the North Landing. 
(2)  The public ways and parking areas along and adjacent to the seawall. 
(3)  The steps, portico, and plaza areas that are a part of or immediately adjacent to the Main Public Library. 
(4)  The plaza area of Middle Street between High Street and County Street, adjacent to the Children's Museum of Virginia. 
(c)  This section shall not be interpreted or applied to: 
(1)  Lawful picketing, demonstrations, or the exercise of the right of free speech. 
(2)  Any person experiencing a medical emergency 
(3)  Persons observing parades, festivals, or other public events 
(4)  Persons in an orderly line awaiting an opportunity to purchase tickets to a movie or other performance event. 
(d)  Before charging any person with an offense under this section, the enforcing officer shall first inform the person that the conduct in question is prohibited, direct the person to cease the conduct and move on, and give the person a reasonable opportunity to comply. Thereafter, if there is no compliance, the person may be charged. If a person has received such a warning and within 24 hours again engages in conduct which comprises a violation of this section, no further warning shall be required. 
(Code 1988, § 24-260; Ord. No. 1995-87, § 1, 7-25-1995; Ord. No. 2007-104, § 1, 11-27-2007) 
State Law reference— Authority to prohibit loitering, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-926.  
Sec. 24-260. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-104, § 2, adopted November 27, 2007, repealed § 24-260, which pertained to definition of loitering. See also the Code Comparative Table.  
Sec. 24-261. - Penalties. 
Any person convicted of a violation of section 24-259 shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Each day that a violation occurs shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1988, § 24-262; Ord. No. 1995-87, § 1, 7-25-1995) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 24-262. - Aggressive panhandling. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to engage in aggressive panhandling. The term "aggressive panhandling" requires threatening, intimidating, or harassing conduct and means: 
(1)  Harassment by following and continuing to insist on a gift of money from another person in a public place after the initial request for money from that person has been denied; 
(2)  Requesting the gift of money from another person in a public place, with the request accompanied by an unauthorized touching of that person; 
(3)  Requesting the gift of money from another person in a public place, with the request accompanied or followed by the intentional blocking or interfering by any means with the person's free passage along the public place; or 
(4)  Requesting the gift of money from another person in a public place, with the request accompanied by conduct which creates a reasonable apprehension of imminent physical harm or assault. 
(b)  The mere requesting of a gift of money in a public place without engaging in any of the forms of threat, intimidation, or harassment set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall not be unlawful. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 24-263; Ord. No. 1997-68, 12-9-1997)  
Secs. 24-263—24-275. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE 
 
Sec. 24-276. - Obstructing justice by threats or force. 
(a)  If any person without just cause knowingly obstructs a judge, magistrate, justice, juror, witness, attorney for the commonwealth or any law enforcement officer in the performance of his duties as such or fails or refuses without just cause to cease such obstruction when requested to do so by such judge, magistrate, justice, juror, witness, attorney for the commonwealth or law enforcement officer, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  If any person, by threats or force, knowingly attempts to intimidate or impede a judge, magistrate, justice, juror, attorney for the commonwealth, witness, or any law enforcement officer, lawfully engaged in his duties as such, or to obstruct or impede the administration of justice in any court, he shall be deemed to be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to such conduct as would constitute a violation of Code of Virginia, § 18.2-460(C). 
(Code 1973, § 21-98; Code 1988, § 24-276; Ord. No. 1989-62, § 1, 6-27-1989; Ord. No. 1990-88, § 2, 8-14-1990; Ord. No. 1993-51, § 1, 6-22-1993) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 24-277. - Officer refusing, delaying, etc., to execute process for criminal. 
If any officer willfully and corruptly refuses to execute any lawful process requiring him to apprehend or confine a person convicted of, or charged with, an offense, or willfully and corruptly omits or delays to execute such process, whereby such person shall escape and go at large, such officer shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-106; Code 1988, § 24-278) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-469.  
Sec. 24-278. - Officer corruptly or partially summoning juror. 
If any sheriff or other officer corruptly, or through favor or ill will, summons a juror, with intent that such juror shall find a verdict for or against either party, he shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor, and forfeit his office; and he shall be forever incapable of holding any office of honor, profit or trust under the Constitution of Virginia. 
(Code 1973, § 21-103; Code 1988, § 24-280) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-465.  
Sec. 24-279. - Corruptly procuring juror to be summoned. 
If any person procures or attempts to procure a juror to be summoned, with intent that such juror shall find a verdict for or against either party, he shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-104; Code 1988, § 24-281) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-466.  
Sec. 24-280. - Extortion by officer. 
If any officer, for performing an official duty for which a fee or compensation is allowed or provided by law, knowingly demands and receives a greater fee or compensation than is so allowed or provided, he shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-107; Code 1988, § 24-283) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-470.  
Sec. 24-281. - Fraudulent issuance of fee bills. 
If any person authorized by law to charge fees for services performed by him and issue bills therefor fraudulently issues a fee bill for a service not performed by him, or for more than he is entitled to, he shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor and shall forfeit his office and be forever incapable of holding office of honor, profit or trust under the Constitution of Virginia. 
(Code 1973, § 21-108; Code 1988, § 24-284) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-471.  
Sec. 24-282. - Mistreatment or interference with police animals. 
Any person who, without causing bodily injury, willfully torments, beats, kicks, strikes or otherwise mistreats an animal owned by the police department or who willfully interferes with the lawful performance of such animal in a police activity shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Any person who willfully touches such animal in any manner after being directed not to do so by a police officer shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-98.1; Code 1988, § 24-289; Ord. No. 1989-62, § 1, 6-27-1989) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 or 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11; cruelty to animals generally, § 4-7.  
Secs. 24-283—24-310. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 24-311. - Authorization of police department to arrest persons for trespassing on private property. 
The owner, lessee, custodian, or person lawfully in charge of any property may designate the police department as a "person lawfully in charge of the property" for the purpose of forbidding another to go or remain upon the lands, buildings or premises as specified in the designation. The designation shall be in writing on a form approved by the city attorney and on file with the police department. The designation shall be admissible in evidence in any applicable trespass prosecution, without requiring the presence or testimony of such actual owner, lessee, or custodian. 
(Code 1988, § 24-311; Ord. No. 2005-53, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt this section, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1717.1.  
Sec. 24-312. - Manufacture, sale, etc., of devices to shield against electronic detection of shoplifting. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, sell, offer for sale, distribute or possess any specially coated or laminated bag or other device primarily designed and intended to shield shoplifted merchandise from detection by an antitheft electronic alarm sensor, with the intention that the same be used to aid in the shoplifting of merchandise. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-149.2; Code 1988, § 24-313) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-105.2.  
Sec. 24-313. - Trespass at night upon church or school property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, without the consent of some person authorized to give such consent, to go or enter upon, in the nighttime, the premises or property of any church or upon any school property for any purpose other than to attend a meeting or service held or conducted in such church or school property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, whether or not a student, to enter upon or remain upon any school property in violation of: (i) any direction to vacate the property by a person authorized to give such direction, or (ii) any posted notice which contains such information, posted at a place where it reasonably may be seen. Each time such person enters upon or remains on the premises after such direction shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of: (i) subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor, and (ii) subsection (b) of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(d)  For purposes of this section: (i) "school property" includes a school bus as defined in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100, and (ii) "church" means any place of worship and includes any educational building or community center owned or leased by a church. 
(Code 1973, § 21-120; Code 1988, § 24-317; Ord. No. 1988-58, § 1, 6-14-1988; Ord. No. 1989-62, § 1, 6-27-1989; Ord. No. 1993-51, § 1, 6-22-1993; Ord. No. 1994-65, § 1, 6-28-1994) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-128.  
Sec. 24-314. - Entering Afton Square Mall during certain hours prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful and a class 2 misdemeanor for any person to go on or enter upon any portion of Afton Square Mall between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(Code 1973, § 21-176; Code 1988, § 24-318) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 2 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 24-315. - Destruction of posted signs; posting land of another. 
Any person who shall mutilate, destroy or take down any "posted," "no hunting" or similar sign or poster on the lands or waters of another, or who shall post such sign or poster on the lands or waters of another, without the consent of the landowner or his agent, shall be deemed guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor and his hunting license shall be revoked for a period not exceeding the expiration date of such license. 
(Code 1973, § 21-126; Code 1988, § 24-324) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-135.  
Sec. 24-316. - Removal or repair of defacement of buildings, walls, fences and other structures. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to willfully and maliciously damage or deface any public buildings, facilities and personal property or any private buildings, facilities and personal property. The penalty for violation is a class 1 misdemeanor. The punishment for any such violation in which the defacement is: (i) more than 20 feet off the ground, (ii) on a railroad or highway overpass, or (iii) committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with any criminal street gang, as that term is defined by Code of Virginia, § 18.2-46.1, shall include a mandatory minimum fine of $500.00. 
(b)  Upon a finding of guilt under this section in any case tried before the court without a jury, in the event the violation constitutes a first offense that results in property damage or loss, the court, without entering a judgment of guilt, upon motion of the defendant, may defer further proceedings and place the defendant on probation pending completion of a plan of community service work. If the defendant fails or refuses to complete the community service as ordered by the court, the court may make final disposition of the case and proceed as otherwise provided. If the community service work is completed as the court prescribes, the court may discharge the defendant and dismiss the proceedings against him. Discharge and dismissal under this section shall be without adjudication of guilt and is a conviction only for the purposes of applying the ordinance in subsequent proceedings. 
(c)  This section shall direct that the community service, to the extent feasible, include the repair, restoration or replacement of any damage or defacement to property within the city, and may include clean-up, beautification, landscaping or other appropriate community service within the city. A designee of the city manager shall supervise the performance of any community service work required and to report thereon to the court imposing such requirement. At or before the time of sentencing, the court shall receive and consider any plan for making restitution or performing community service submitted by the defendant. The court shall also receive and consider the recommendations of the supervisor of community service in the city concerning the plan. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no person convicted of a violation of this section shall be placed on probation or have his sentence suspended unless such person makes at least partial restitution for such property damage or is compelled to perform community services, or both, as is more particularly set forth in Code of Virginia, § 19.2-305.1. 
(e)  If the city seeks to clean or cover the defacement, it shall give notice to the owner and lessee, if any, of any private building or facility that has been defaced that, within 15 days of receipt of such notice, if the owner or lessee does not clean or cover the defacement or object to the removal of the defacement, the city may clean or cover the defacement at the city's expense. The director of permits and inspections may undertake or contract for such removal or repair of defacement of any public building, wall, fence or other structure or any public building, wall, fence or other structure where such defacement is visible from any public right-of-way. 
(Code 1988, § 24-325; Ord. No. 1995-74, § 1, 6-13-1995) 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt this section, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1812.2.  
Sec. 24-317. - Damaging, defacing, etc., public property generally. 
(a)  If any person willfully and maliciously breaks any window or door of any courthouse, house of public worship, college, schoolhouse or other public building or library; or willfully and maliciously injures or defaces any courthouse, house of public worship or any other public building; or willfully and maliciously destroys or carries away any property belonging to or in any of such buildings shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor if the damage is less than $1,000.00. 
(b)  Any person who willfully and unlawfully injures or defaces any book, newspaper, magazine, pamphlet, map, picture, manuscript or other property belonging to any library, reading room, museum or other property located in any library, reading room, museum or other educational institution, or unlawfully removes the same thereof, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor, provided the damage to the property or the value of the property carried away is less than $1,000.00. 
(Code 1973, § 21-128; Code 1988, § 24-326; Ord. No. 1990-68, § 1, 6-26-1990) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-138.  
Sec. 24-318. - Damaging or defacing city property. 
It shall be unlawful and a class 1 misdemeanor for any person to willfully and maliciously damage or deface any real or personal property owned or operated or maintained by the city. This includes, but is not limited to, parks, playgrounds, playfields, recreation facilities, public buildings and facilities and fixtures thereof, and any personal property therein or thereon. 
(Code 1973, § 21-127.1; Code 1988, § 24-327) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11; authority of city manager to offer reward in cases involving damage to city property, § 2-167; damaging parking meters, §§ 22-610, 22-641; damaging park property, § 25-99; damaging property of department of public utilities, § 38-4. 
State Law reference— Damaging public property, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-138.  
Sec. 24-319. - Possession or duplication of keys to building or other property owned by city. 
(a)  No person shall knowingly possess any key to the lock of any building or other property owned by the city, without receiving permission from a person duly authorized to give permission to possess such key. 
(b)  No person, without receiving permission from a person duly authorized to give such permission, shall knowingly duplicate, copy or make a facsimile of any key to a lock of a building or other property owned by the city. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-186; Code 1988, § 24-328) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-503.  
Sec. 24-320. - Unlawful use of, or injury to, telephone and telegraph lines; copying or obstructing messages. 
Any person who shall: 
(1)  Maliciously injure, molest, cut down or destroy any telephone or telegraph line, wire, cable, or pole or the material or property belonging thereto; 
(2)  Maliciously cut, break, tap or make any connection with any telephone or telegraph line, wire, cable or instrument of any telegraph or telephone company which has legally acquired the right-of-way by purchase, condemnation, or otherwise; 
(3)  Maliciously copy in any unauthorized manner any message, either social, business, or otherwise, passing over any telephone or telegraph line, wire or cable in this state; 
(4)  Willfully or maliciously prevent, obstruct or delay by any means or contrivance whatsoever the sending, conveyance or delivery of this state of any authorized communication by or through any telephone or telegraph line, wire or cable under the control of any telephone or telegraph company doing business in this state; or 
(5)  Maliciously aid, agree with, employ or conspire with any unauthorized person unlawfully to do or cause to be done any of the acts hereinbefore mentioned; shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 21-130; Code 1988, § 24-330) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-164.  
Sec. 24-321. - Damaging, tampering with, etc., vehicles, boats, etc. 
(a)  Any person who shall individually or in association with one or more others willfully break, injure, tamper with or remove any part of any vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel for the purpose of injuring, defacing or destroying such vehicle, aircraft boat or vessel, or temporarily or permanently preventing its useful operation, or for any purpose against the will or without the consent of the owner of such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel, or who shall in any other manner willfully or maliciously interfere with or prevent the running or operation of such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person who shall, without the consent of the owner or person in charge of a vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad, climb into or upon such vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad, with intent to commit any crime, malicious mischief, or injury thereto, or who, while a vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad is at rest and unattended, shall attempt to manipulate any of the levers and starting crank or other devices, brakes or mechanism thereof or to set into motion such vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad, with the intent to commit any crime, malicious mischief, or injury thereto, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. This subsection shall not apply when any such act is done in an emergency or in furtherance of public safety or by or under the direction of an officer in the regulation of traffic or performance of any other official duty. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to a bona fide repossession of a vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel by the holder of a lien on such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel, or by the agents or employees of such lienholder. 
(Code 1973, §§ 21-135—21-137; Code 1988, § 24-336) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11; boats, ch. 6; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 22; railroads, ch. 29. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-146—18.2-148.  
Secs. 24-322—24-429. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - REGULATION OF SMOKING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Food and food establishments, ch. 15. 
 
Sec. 24-430. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Bar or lounge means any area or room utilized primarily for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption by patrons on the premises and in which the sale of food is merely incidental to the sale of alcoholic beverages. Although a restaurant may contain a bar or lounge area, the terms "bar or lounge area" shall not encompass the entire restaurant or any dining area. 
Food store means any supermarket or grocery store which is designed and arranged to display food products and which has as its primary business purpose the sale of food products to consumers for consumption off the premises and not for resale, and which derives a substantial portion of its income therefrom. 
Health care facilities means any office or institution providing individual care and treatment of disease, whether physical, mental or emotional, or other medical, physiological or psychological conditions, including, but not limited to, hospitals, clinics, nursing homes, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, offices of any physician, dentist, psychologist, psychiatrist, physiologist, podiatrist, optometrist or optician. 
Public meeting means any meeting or assembly held in a public building or building leased for public purpose which is opened to the public for the conduct of the affairs of, and the transaction of business by, any legislative or administrative body or agency of the city, including boards, commissions, authorities, councils, committees, subcommittees and other subordinate groups thereof, receiving or expending and supported in whole or in part by public funds. 
Restaurant means any establishment designed and arranged to sell or offer for sale to customers any food or food products for consumption on the premises, regardless whether the food is prepared or cooked on or off the premises, and shall include restaurant facilities which are an integral part of a retail store, motel, hotel, catering establishment or other similar facility. 
Retail store means any establishment whose primary purpose is to sell or offer for sale to consumers, not for resale, any goods, wares, merchandise, articles or other things and all activities, operations and services connected therewith or incidental thereto. Retail stores shall not include food stores, hotels, motels, restaurants and those restaurant facilities which are an integral part of a retail store, motel, hotel, catering establishment or other similar facilities. 
Shared work area means any enclosed area on any premises owned or leased by the city or the Portsmouth Public Schools and in which two or more employees are assigned to work for most of their workday, where such employees share common work spaces, equipment or facilities and where each employee is aware of or readily available to observe the activities of others taking place in his work area. 
Smoking or to smoke means the act of smoking or carrying a lighted or smoldering cigar, cigarette or pipe of any kind or lighting a cigar, cigarette or pipe of any kind. 
(Code 1988, § 24-430; Ord. No. 1989-50, § 1, 6-13-1989)  
Sec. 24-431. - Smoking prohibited in certain public places. 
Except as otherwise provided in this article, smoking shall be prohibited in the following public places: 
(1)  Elevators in buildings generally used by and open to the public; 
(2)  Waiting rooms, lobbies, wards, hallways and other public areas of health care facilities; 
(3)  Any building owned or leased by the city or the Portsmouth School Board and used for public purposes except in areas where smoking is permitted pursuant to the provisions of this article; 
(4)  Any art gallery, library, museum or similar cultural facility, supported in whole or in part with public funds; 
(5)  Any elementary or secondary school building or child care facility, whether public or private, in common areas such as classrooms, hallways, auditoriums and public meeting rooms; 
(6)  Places of entertainment such as theatres, concert halls, gymnasiums, bowling alleys, auditoriums and enclosed arenas, except smoking in performances as part of the production. Provided, however, that smoking may be permitted in lawfully designated areas pursuant to the provisions of this article; 
(7)  Public restrooms, unless separate facilities are provided for smokers and nonsmokers; 
(8)  In a designated no smoking area of any restaurant that is subject to the provisions of section 24-432 of this article; 
(9)  Any retail store and any food store in which more than four persons are regularly employed at any one time; 
(10)  Any public meeting. 
(Code 1988, § 24-431; Ord. No. 1989-50, § 1, 6-13-1989)  
Sec. 24-432. - Designated no smoking area in restaurant. 
(a)  Any restaurant having a seating capacity of 50 or more persons shall have a designated no smoking area sufficient to meet customer demand. Restaurants may not determine that no such demand exists. Restaurants with a seating capacity of less than 50 persons are encouraged, but not required, to designate no smoking areas. Any restaurant required to have a designated no smoking area shall post signs conspicuous to ordinary public view at each entrance to the establishment indicating that a no smoking area is available. 
(b)  In determining whether a restaurant is subject to the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, the following shall not be included: 
(1)  Seats in the bar or lounge area of a restaurant; 
(2)  Seats in any separate room of a restaurant which is used exclusively for private functions; 
(3)  Seats in any room of a restaurant which is closed and not available for seating. 
(Code 1988, § 24-432; Ord. No. 1989-50, § 1, 6-13-1989)  
Sec. 24-433. - Where smoking not regulated. 
The prohibitions of this article shall not apply within the following areas: 
(1)  Lawfully designated smoking area which meets the conditions set forth in section 24-434; 
(2)  The area of a theatre, concert hall, gymnasium, auditorium or other place of entertainment commonly referred to as a lobby if physically separated from the spectator area; 
(3)  Office or work areas in buildings owned or leased by the city or the Portsmouth School Board which are not shared work areas; 
(4)  Shared work areas of buildings owned or leased by the city or the Portsmouth School Board where each and every employee regularly assigned to the shared work area consents in writing to smoking; 
(5)  Areas of enclosed shopping centers or malls that are external to the retail stores and are used by customers as a route of travel from one store to another, and that consist primarily of walkways and seating arrangements; 
(6)  Any tobacco shop or store primarily concerned with selling tobacco and smoking implements; 
(7)  Courthouses owned or leased by the city; 
(8)  Bars and lounge areas; 
(9)  Health care facilities or portions thereof which engage primarily in the treatment of patients suffering from alcohol and other chemical dependency or abuse, or psychiatric disorders or illnesses when implementation of smoking prohibitions would, in the written opinion of attending physicians, produce a significant risk of worsening a patient's mental health. 
(Code 1988, § 24-433; Ord. No. 1989-50, § 1, 6-13-1989)  
Sec. 24-434. - Designated smoking area. 
The owner or person in charge of any building, structure, space, place or area in which smoking is prohibited may designate separate rooms or areas in which smoking is permitted; provided that: 
(1)  Rooms or areas in which smoking is permitted and which are so designated shall be separate to the extent reasonably practicable from those rooms or areas entered by the public in the normal course of use of the particular business or institution; 
(2)  In designated smoking areas, ventilation systems and existing physical barriers shall be used when reasonably practicable to minimize the toxic effect of smoking adjacent to nonsmoking areas; and 
(3)  Such designated smoking areas shall not be so large in number or area in any one building that the fundamental purposes of this article are defeated. 
(Code 1988, § 24-434; Ord. No. 1989-50, § 1, 6-13-1989)  
Sec. 24-435. - Posting of signs. 
Any person who owns, manages or otherwise controls any building or area in which smoking is regulated by this article shall post in an appropriate place in a clear, conspicuous and sufficient manner "smoking permitted" signs or "no smoking permitted" signs (or the international "no smoking" symbol consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it). Printing on such signs shall be at least one inch in height and the international symbol shall have a circle of at least four inches in diameter. 
(Code 1988, § 24-435; Ord. No. 1989-50, § 1, 6-13-1989)  
Sec. 24-436. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who owns, manages, operates or otherwise controls the use of any premises subject to the prohibitions or restrictions of this article to fail to comply with its provisions. Any such person violating any such provision or failing to comply with the requirements of this article shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. Each day a violation of this article shall continue constitutes a separate violation. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in any area prohibited or restricted by the provisions of this article; provided, however, that no such person shall be deemed to have violated the provisions of this article unless such person shall have been requested to extinguish a lighted or smoldering cigar, cigarette or pipe of any kind and having been so requested failed to do so. Any such person violating any provision or failing to comply with any of the requirements of this article shall be fined up to $25.00. 
(Code 1988, § 24-436; Ord. No. 1989-50, § 1, 6-13-1989)  
Sec. 24-437. - Enforcement. 
The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the director of public health or his designee, or any other department or person designated by the city manager. 
(Code 1988, § 24-437; Ord. No. 1989-50, § 1, 6-13-1989)  
Sec. 24-438. - Other applicable laws or regulations. 
This article shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise prohibited or restricted by other applicable laws or regulations. 
(Code 1988, § 24-438; Ord. No. 1989-50, § 1, 6-13-1989)  
Chapter 25 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Amusements, ch. 3; boats, and waterways, ch. 6; trees and shrubs on city property, § 36-26 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to establish and maintain parks and playgrounds, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1801; authority to establish and conduct system of public recreation, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1806. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 25-1—25-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 25-46. - Established. 
The advisory board of recreation and parks heretofore established is hereby redesignated and shall henceforth be referred to and known as the parks and recreation commission. 
(Code 1973, § 24-17; Code 1988, § 25-46)  
Sec. 25-47. - Composition; appointment and term of members. 
The parks and recreation commission shall consist of nine members. The members of the commission shall be appointed by the city council for terms of three years. 
(Code 1973, § 24-18; Code 1988, § 25-47; Ord. No. 1990-129, § 10, 12-11-1990)  
Sec. 25-48. - Ex officio members. 
(a)  The city council may appoint three ex officio members to the parks and recreation commission who will take part in all activities of the commission, except that they shall not have the right to vote on any matter. 
(b)  One nonvoting member shall be an employee of the school board of the city; one nonvoting member shall be an employee of the Portsmouth Redevelopment and Housing Authority; and one nonvoting member shall be an employee of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 24-18.1; Code 1988, § 25-48)  
Sec. 25-49. - Compensation of members. 
The members of the parks and recreation commission shall serve as such without compensation. 
(Code 1973, § 24-19; Code 1988, § 25-49)  
Sec. 25-50. - Vacancies in membership. 
Any vacancy in the membership of the parks and recreation commission shall be filled by the city council for the expired portion of the term. 
(Code 1973, § 24-20; Code 1988, § 25-50)  
Sec. 25-51. - Removal of members. 
Any member of the parks and recreation commission may be removed by the city council for inefficiency, neglect of duty, misfeasance, or malfeasance in office. 
(Code 1973, § 24-21; Code 1988, § 25-51)  
Sec. 25-52. - Adoption of rules. 
The parks and recreation commission may adopt reasonable rules for the conduct of its business. 
(Code 1973, § 24-22; Code 1988, § 25-52) 
Cross reference— General procedural rules for commissions appointed by council, § 2-28(b).  
Sec. 25-53. - Quorum. 
A majority of the members of the parks and recreation commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1973, § 24-23; Code 1988, § 25-53)  
Sec. 25-54. - Selection, term of chairman; creation, filling of other offices. 
The parks and recreation commission shall choose annually one of its at-large members to be chair for a term of one year and until his successor is chosen and qualified. The parks and recreation commission may create and fill such other offices as it may determine is necessary. 
(Code 1973, § 24-24; Code 1988, § 25-54)  
Sec. 25-55. - Date of regular meetings. 
The parks and recreation commission shall hold regular monthly meetings on a date to be fixed by such commission. 
(Code 1973, § 24-25; Code 1988, § 25-55)  
Sec. 25-56. - Calling of special meetings. 
Special meetings of the parks and recreation commission may be called at any time on the call of the chair or any two members thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 24-26; Code 1988, § 25-56)  
Sec. 25-57. - Meetings to be public. 
All meetings of the parks and recreation commission shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1973, § 24-27; Code 1988, § 25-57)  
Sec. 25-58. - Records of proceedings. 
The parks and recreation commission shall keep a record of all its proceedings, which shall be a public record. 
(Code 1973, § 24-28; Code 1988, § 25-58)  
Sec. 25-59. - Planning ground areas on master plan. 
The parks and recreation commission shall plan in detail the ground areas designated for parks and recreation areas on the city's master park and recreation plan. When any such designated area includes school property, such plan shall be prepared jointly with the school board and due consideration shall be given to the present and future needs of the school program. The purpose of such planning shall be to effect the greatest possible utilization of school property in the community recreation program. 
(Code 1973, § 24-29; Code 1988, § 25-59)  
Sec. 25-60. - Development, maintenance of areas on master plan. 
The parks and recreation commission shall develop and maintain the areas shown on the city's master parks and recreation plan according to the officially approved detailed plans. Where any such area includes school property, its development and maintenance shall be accomplished by agreement between the commission and the school board. 
(Code 1973, § 24-30; Code 1988, § 25-60)  
Sec. 25-61. - Conducting, supervising programs. 
The parks and recreation commission shall conduct a citywide recreation program and may provide, conduct and supervise any form of recreation which will contribute to the welfare and happiness of the citizens of the city, utilizing suitable facilities and properties owned or controlled by the city, or otherwise with the consent of the owners or other persons in charge thereof; in no case, however, shall school property be used when needed by school authorities in the interest of the educational program. 
(Code 1973, § 24-31; Code 1988, § 25-61)  
Sec. 25-62. - Promoting public interest, understanding in program. 
The parks and recreation commission shall promote public interest in and understanding of the city's parks and recreation program. 
(Code 1973, § 24-32; Code 1988, § 25-62)  
Sec. 25-63. - Contracting with consultants. 
The parks and recreation commission shall have the authority to contract with consultants for such services as it may require within the limit of the funds appropriated therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-33; Code 1988, § 25-63)  
Sec. 25-64. - Acceptance, expenditure of gifts; reduction of appropriations. 
The parks and recreation commission shall have the power to accept, administer and expend for operating and capital expenses, funds received as gifts or from sources other than the city; provided, however, that funds received as gifts in trust shall be handled in accordance with the terms of such trust. Funds received from sources other than the city shall be accounted for and deposited to the credit of the city for the use of the parks and recreation commission, except that funds received as gifts in trust shall be accounted for in a special fund created and maintained for such purpose and designated as the parks and recreation commission fund. The parks and recreation commission shall have no authority to enter into any contract or incur obligations binding upon the city, the cost of which will exceed the unencumbered cash balance of the fund at the time when the obligation is incurred. If the parks and recreation commission receives and expends for operating or capital expenses any funds not included in its budget as approved by the city council, the city council may direct that the amount appropriated for city funds be reduced by the amount so expended from outside such budget. 
(Code 1973, § 24-34; Code 1988, § 25-64)  
Sec. 25-65. - Advising director of matters submitted for consideration. 
The parks and recreation commission shall advise the director of all matters submitted to such commission for its consideration. 
(Code 1973, § 24-35; Code 1988, § 25-65; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997)  
Sec. 25-66. - Listing of recommended capital improvements. 
The parks and recreation commission shall submit annually to the city manager, when requested by him, a list of recommended capital improvements for parks and recreation purposes, including the acquisition of land and buildings and the development, improvement and maintenance thereof. Such list shall set forth such projects as the commission deems necessary or desirable to be accomplished during the succeeding six-year period and shall be arranged in order of priority, with recommendations as to which projects shall be accomplished in which years with the estimated costs thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 24-36; Code 1988, § 25-66)  
Sec. 25-67. - Reports. 
The parks and recreation commission shall submit a report of its operations to the city council annually at the end of each fiscal year and such other reports as may be requested from time to time by the council or the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 24-37; Code 1988, § 25-67)  
Sec. 25-68. - Review of actions by council. 
All actions of the parks and recreation commission shall be subject to review by the city council, which may take such action thereon as it deems advisable. 
(Code 1973, § 24-38; Code 1988, § 25-68)  
Secs. 25-69—25-85. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL PARK REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 25-86. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Bathing area means any beach or water area designated by or under authority of the city manager as a bathing area. 
Director means the director of parks, recreation, and leisure services or designee. 
Footpath or trail means any path or trail maintained for pedestrians. 
Owner means any person owning, leasing, operating, or having the exclusive use of a vehicle, animal or any other property under a lease or otherwise. 
Park, unless specifically limited, means and includes all designated parks, golf courses and other recreational areas owned by the city. 
Permit, except as otherwise provided in this article, means any written license issued by or under authority of the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 24-49; Code 1988, § 25-86) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 25-87. - Rules of construction. 
In the interpretation of this article, its provisions shall be construed as follows: 
(1)  Any requirement or prohibition of any act shall, respectively, extend to and include the causing or procuring, directly or indirectly of such act; 
(2)  No provision hereof shall make unlawful any act necessarily performed by any officer or employee of the city in line of duty or work as such, or by any person, his agents or employees, in the proper and necessary execution of the terms of any agreement with the city; and 
(3)  Any act otherwise prohibited by this article, provided it is not otherwise prohibited by law or local ordinance, shall be lawful if performed under, by virtue of and strictly within the provisions of a permit so to do, and to the extent authorized thereby. 
(Code 1973, § 24-50; Code 1988, § 25-87)  
Sec. 25-88. - Violations of article. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-87; Code 1988, § 25-88) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 25-89. - Use permits generally. 
A permit to use a park or to do any act in a park shall authorize the same only insofar as it may be performed in strict accordance with the terms and conditions thereof. Any violation by its holder or his agents or employees of any term or condition thereof shall constitute grounds for its revocation by the director, whose action therein shall be final. In case of revocation of any permit, all moneys paid for or on account thereof shall, at the option of the director, be forfeited to and retained by the city. The holder of such permit, together with his agents or employees who violated such terms and conditions, shall be jointly and severally liable to the city for all damages and loss suffered by it in excess of money so forfeited and retained; but neither such forfeiture and retention by the city of the whole or any part of such moneys nor the recovery or collection thereby of such damages, or both, shall in any manner relieve such person from liability to punishment for any violation of any provision of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 24-51; Code 1988, § 25-89)  
Sec. 25-90. - Permit for use of designated portions of parks. 
The director is hereby authorized to issue a permit for the use of designated portions of parks upon the payment of fees to be established and upon the execution of a written agreement establishing the terms and conditions of the use. 
(Code 1973, § 24-176; Code 1988, § 25-90)  
Sec. 25-91. - Fee for reservation of picnic shelters at City Park. 
Picnic shelters may be reserved at City Park upon payment of a reservation fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1973, §§ 24-172, 24-175; Code 1988, § 25-93; Ord. No. 1989-41, § 3, 5-15-1989; Ord. No. 1990-40, § 1, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1994-37, § 1, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 1995-24, § 1, 3-28-1995; Ord. No. 1998-17, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 1999-12, § 1, 4-27-1999) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 25-91.1. - Fee to ride Pokey Smoky II at City Park. 
The fee to ride the Pokey Smoky II at City Park shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
( Ord. No. 2011-25, § 1, 5-4-2011) 
Editor's note— Sec. 3 of Ord. No. 2011-25 states that this ordinance will take effect July 1, 2011.  
Sec. 25-91.2. - Admission fee for the Splash Park at the Neighborhood Facility. 
There shall be no fee for admission to the Splash Park at the Neighborhood Facility. 
( Ord. No. 2011-25, § 1, 5-4-2011; Ord. No. 2013-40, § 1, 8-13-2013) 
Editor's note— Sec. 3 of Ord. No. 2011-25 states that this ordinance will take effect July 1, 2011.  
Sec. 25-91.3. - City Park boat ramp parking. 
The parking fee for the City Park boat ramp shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2020-34 , § 11, 5-12-2020)  
Sec. 25-92. - Fees for use of athletic, recreational and special activity facilities. 
(a)  Fees for the rental of athletic, recreational and special activity facilities shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code for the following categories: 
(1)  Gym, per hour. 
(2)  Social hall, per hour. 
(3)  Meeting hall/room, per hour. 
(4)  Gym, athletic practice sessions only, per hour. 
(5)  Damage deposit required for gym, except for athletic practice sessions per rental. 
(6)  Damage deposit required for meeting room per rental. 
(7)  Damage deposit required for social hall per rental. 
(b)  Fees for special activities coordinated by or collected by the department of parks, recreation and leisure services shall be set by the city manager. This special activity fee shall include a fee to be paid per team for softball, volleyball, basketball, and tennis, and for participation in Friendship Garden Weddings, other special activities and athletic programs not specified herein. 
(c)  For purposes of this subsection (c) and the related fees set out in Appendix A to this Code, the term youth means any person under 18 years of age, the term adult means any person between and including the ages of 18 and 54, and the term senior means any person 55 years or older. Fees for individual use of recreational facilities operated by the department of parks, recreation and leisure services and determined by the city manager to be subject to this subsection shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code for the following categories: 
(1)  Adult Membership Card (annual) 
(2)  Adult Replacement Card 
(3)  Youth Membership Card (annual) 
(4)  Youth Replacement Card 
(5)  Senior Membership Card (annual) 
(6)  Senior Replacement Card 
(7)  Visitor Pass (one week) 
(8)  Adult or Senior Day Pass 
(9)  Youth Day Pass 
(d)  For purposes of this subsection (d) and the related fees set out in Appendix A to this Code, the term adult class program means class programs primarily intended for participation by persons 18 years of age or older. Fees for multi-session adult class programs offered by the department of parks, recreation and leisure services shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(e)  For purposes of this subsection (e) and the related fees set out in Appendix A to this Code, the term fitness class program means an adult class program that is primarily related to physical fitness and the term senior means any person 55 years or older. Seniors who are residents of Portsmouth shall have the option of paying the annual rate or quarterly rate established in Appendix A for participation in fitness class programs. A senior paying the annual rate may participate in any fitness class program offered during the calendar year without paying the charge established pursuant to subsection (d) for the individual class program. A senior paying the quarterly rate may participate in any fitness class program offered during the applicable quarter without paying the charge established pursuant to subsection (d) for the individual class program. 
(Code 1973, § 24-6; Code 1988, § 25-94; Ord. No. 1990-80, § 1, 6-26-1990; Ord. No. 1994-37, § 2, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997; Ord. No. 1998-17, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 2015-80, § 1, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. 2016-16, § 1, 3-8-2016) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 25-93. - Meetings and exhibitions. 
No person shall in any park erect any structure, stand or platform, hold any meeting, or exhibition, perform any ceremony, make any speech, or address except by permit. 
(Code 1973, § 24-51; Code 1988, § 25-95)  
Sec. 25-94. - Commercial enterprises. 
No person shall, in any park, without a permit, sell or offer for sale, hire, lease or let out, any object or merchandise, property privilege, service or any other thing, or engage in any business or erect for such purposes, any building, booth, tent, stall or any other structure whatsoever. 
(Code 1973, § 24-53; Code 1988, § 25-96)  
Sec. 25-95. - Subletting park property. 
No person to whom property of any park has been entrusted for personal use shall hire, lease, let out, or sell the same to any other person. 
(Code 1973, § 24-54; Code 1988, § 25-97)  
Sec. 25-96. - Commercial vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall operate a bus, taxicab or other commercial vehicle designed or used for transportation of passengers or property within any park, recreational area, or playground without a permit specifically authorizing the operation of a commercial vehicle within such park, recreational area, or playground. 
(b)  Any violation of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-56; Code 1988, § 25-99) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11; vehicles for hire, ch. 37.  
Sec. 25-97. - Advertising. 
No sign, notice, or advertisement of any nature shall be erected or posted at any place within any park without permission in writing from the director; nor shall any musical instrument, radio, talking machine, or drum be operated or any noise be made for the purpose of attracting attention to any exhibition of any kind. 
(Code 1973, § 24-57; Code 1988, § 25-100)  
Sec. 25-98. - Soliciting alms or contributions. 
(a)  No person shall, within any park, recreational area, or playground, solicit alms or contributions for any purpose. 
(b)  Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be sentenced for the first offense to pay a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00 or undergo imprisonment for not more than six months, or both, and for the second and any subsequent offense to pay a line of not less than $500.00 and not more than $1,000.00 or to undergo imprisonment for not more than one year, or both. 
(Code 1973, § 24-58; Code 1988, § 25-101) 
Cross reference— Solicitation of contributions generally, § 26-46 et seq.  
Sec. 25-99. - Damaging; removing, etc., flowers, plants, etc. 
(a)  No person shall remove, destroy, cut down, scar, mutilate, injure, take or gather in any manner any tree, flower, fern, shrub, rock, or plant or mineral in any park, recreational area or playground. 
(b)  Any violation of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-59; Code 1988, § 25-102) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11; general prohibition against removing or damaging trees or shrubs on city property, § 36-28.  
Sec. 25-100. - Disposal of refuse, garbage, etc. 
No person shall deposit in any part of any park any garbage, sewage, refuse, waste, vegetables, foodstuffs, boxes, tin cans, paper, or other litter or other waste material or obnoxious material, except in containers designed for such purposes. 
(Code 1973, § 24-61; Code 1988, § 25-104) 
Cross reference— Garbage and refuse generally, ch. 16.  
Sec. 25-101. - Bathing, where permitted; clothing required. 
No person shall bathe, dive, jump, wade, or swim in the waters of any lake, river, stream, pond, pool, fountain or other waters in any park except at such times, and in such places, as the director may designate as bathing areas, and unless so covered with clothing as to prevent any indecent exposure of the person. 
(Code 1973, § 24-63; Code 1988, § 25-106)  
Sec. 25-102. - Dressing and undressing. 
Dressing and undressing, except in bathhouses, tents, or other enclosed camping vehicles is prohibited in any park. 
(Code 1973, § 24-64; Code 1988, § 25-107)  
Sec. 25-103. - Entering toilet set aside for opposite sex. 
No person in any park shall enter a toilet set aside for the opposite sex. 
(Code 1973, § 24-65; Code 1988, § 25-108)  
Sec. 25-104. - Picnicking. 
Picnicking is allowed only in the areas designed as picnic areas. 
(Code 1973, § 24-66; Code 1988, § 25-109)  
Sec. 25-105. - Sports and games, where permitted. 
No games or athletic contest shall be allowed except in such places as may be designated therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-68; Code 1988, § 25-111)  
Sec. 25-106. - Boating. 
Boating of any kind in a bathing area is prohibited except such boating as is necessary to keep such areas properly protected and policed. No person shall use privately owned boats or canoes on any park waters without a permit. 
(Code 1973, § 24-69; Code 1988, § 25-112) 
Cross reference— Boats and waterways, ch. 6.  
Sec. 25-107. - Riding or driving horses. 
No person shall use, ride, or drive a horse except in designated areas. 
(Code 1973, § 24-70; Code 1988, § 25-113) 
Cross reference— Animals and fowl, ch. 4.  
Sec. 25-108. - Animals at large. 
No person shall cause or permit any animal owned by him, in his custody, or under his control, to go at large within any park unless held in leash by a responsible person, and such leash shall not exceed seven feet in length. Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the restrictions established by this section shall not apply in the following circumstances: 
(1)  Unleashed dogs shall be permitted in designated fenced areas within a park which have been expressly established by the city manager or the city manager's designee as areas where leashes are not required; and 
(2)  The city manager or the city manager's designee may authorize the presence of unleashed specially trained dogs on the park property for property maintenance activities conducted by or at the direction of the city, provided that all such activities shall be performed in compliance with all applicable state and federal laws; and 
(3)  In addition to and not in limitation of subsections (1) and (2) of this section, guide dogs, service dogs or other dogs accorded special status under federal or state disability or accommodation laws or regulations may be unleashed, but only as and to the extent necessary to accommodate the disability of the individual they are accompanying. 
(Code 1973, § 24-71; Code 1988, § 25-114; Ord. No. 2016-87 , § 2, 10-25-2016) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 25-109. - Hunting, molesting wildlife. 
No person within the confines of any park, shall hunt, pursue, trap, shoot, injure, kill or molest in any way any bird or animal, nor shall any person have any wild bird or animal in his possession within the park. 
(Code 1973, § 24-72; Code 1988, § 25-115)  
Sec. 25-110. - Fires, lighted cigarettes, etc. 
No person shall kindle, build, maintain or use a fire other than in places provided or designated for such purposes except by special permit. Any fire shall be continuously under the care and direction of a competent person over 16 years of age from the time it is kindled until it is extinguished. No person within the confines of any park shall throw away or discard any lighted match, cigarette, cigar or other burning object. Any lighted match, cigarette, cigar, or other burning object must be entirely extinguished before being thrown away or discarded. 
(Code 1973, § 24-75; Code 1988, § 25-118) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 13.  
Sec. 25-111. - Smoking. 
No person shall smoke in any structure or place in any park where smoking is prohibited. Smoking may be forbidden by the director or his authorized agent in any part of any park when it is deemed the fire hazard makes such action advisable. 
(Code 1973, § 24-76; Code 1988, § 25-119)  
Sec. 25-112. - Vehicles, traffic, where prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle in any park or recreation area within or upon a safety zone, walk, golf cart path, fire truck trail, service road, or any part of any park or recreation area or playground not designated or customarily used for such purpose. 
(b)  No person shall drive any vehicle in any park, recreation area or playground area except upon the paved roads or parking areas, or on such other areas as may, on occasion, be specifically designated as temporary parking areas by the director. 
(c)  No person shall use or ride any motorized vehicle, moped, motorcycle or motorized push scooter off of the roadway or in any area not designated or customarily used for vehicle travel in any park, parkway, beach, or any grounds for recreational or playground use, unless on authorized business for the city or pursuant to an authorized permit issued by the director. 
(d)  A violation of this section shall constitute a traffic infraction punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1973, § 24-77; Code 1988, § 25-120; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997; Ord. No. 2005-104, § 1, 11-22-2005) 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 22.  
Sec. 25-113. - Standing and parking. 
(a)  No owner or driver shall cause or permit a vehicle to stand anywhere in any park or recreation area or playground outside of designated parking spaces. Motorists in such areas may stop for a reasonable time in a driveway area to receive or discharge passengers. 
(b)  No person shall park a vehicle in any park, recreational area or playground area except in an established or designated parking area, and such use shall be in accordance with the posted direction or with the instruction of any park ranger or police officer who may be present. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall constitute a traffic infraction punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1973, §§ 23-221, 24-78; Code 1988, § 25-121)  
Sec. 25-114. - Entering and leaving parks; vehicle operation. 
(a)  No person shall enter or leave any park, recreation area or playground area except by the roadways or streets designated and in the direction indicated for such purposes. 
(b)  No person shall operate a vehicle in any park in violation of the applicable provisions of the state and city traffic laws in regard to equipment and operation of vehicles, or in violation of such regulations as are contained in this article and other chapters of this Code. 
(c)  Persons operating a vehicle in any park, recreation area, or playground area, shall obey all police officers and such persons authorized and instructed to direct traffic whenever and wherever needed in parks, recreational areas, and playground areas, and on the streets or roads immediately adjacent thereto in accordance with the provisions of this article and such supplementary regulations as may be issued by the director. 
(d)  Any person operating a vehicle in any park, recreation area or playground area shall observe all traffic signs indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping or parking and all others posted for proper control and to safeguard life and property. 
(e)  A violation of this section shall constitute a traffic infraction punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1973, § 24-79; Code 1988, § 25-122; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997)  
Sec. 25-115. - Speed limits. 
(a)  The maximum speed limit within a park shall be 15 miles per hour, provided that the city manager may decrease or increase the speed limits after an engineering and traffic investigation, and such new speed limit shall become effective when indicated upon the roadway by signs. Rates of speed in excess of the posted speed limit are prohibited. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a traffic infraction punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1973, § 24-80; Code 1988, § 25-123)  
Sec. 25-116. - Gambling. 
(a)  Gambling in any park is prohibited and shall be punishable as a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person bringing into any park or having in his possession while there, any implement or device commonly used, or intended for gambling purposes, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-81; Code 1988, § 25-124) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11; gambling generally, § 24-131 et seq.  
Sec. 25-117. - Avoiding charges. 
No person shall make, use or gain admittance to, or attempt to use or gain admittance to, the facilities in any park for the use of which a charge is made unless he shall have paid the charge fixed for such use or admittance. 
(Code 1973, § 24-82; Code 1988, § 25-125)  
Sec. 25-118. - Indecent exposure. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to indecently expose himself in any park. 
(Code 1973, § 24-83; Code 1988, § 25-126)  
Sec. 25-119. - Disorderly conduct. 
No person shall disobey a lawful order of a park ranger or otherwise conduct himself in any riotous or disorderly manner whatsoever. 
(Code 1973, § 24-84; Code 1988, § 25-127)  
Sec. 25-120. - Closing hours generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, without a permit issued by the director to go onto or enter upon any portion of any city park or recreation area during hours when the park or recreation area is designated as closed. Hours of opening and closing shall be designated by the director or designee, and posted therein for public information. 
(b)  Upon the application of any person desiring to use the city park boat ramp for purposes of launching or retrieving a boat during hours prohibited above, the director shall issue a permit for such use and such permit shall specify the date of such intended use and shall list the name of the applicant and all persons in his party. The applicant shall display his copy of the permit to any police officer or parks, recreation and general services department employee upon demand. 
(c)  No person shall enter any park area posted as "Closed to the Public," nor shall any person use or encourage the use of any area in violation of posted notices. Any section or part of any park or recreation area may be declared closed to the public by the director at any time and for any interval of time either temporarily or at regular stated intervals (daily or otherwise), and either entirely or confined to certain uses as the director shall determine. 
(d)  Police officers may remove or ask anyone to leave any public park or recreation area when that person's conduct is such as to disrupt the general permit or when allowing such person to remain in any public park or recreation area could lead to a more serious breach of the peace. Police officers may close the entire park when conditions exist that, if allowed to continue, could seriously jeopardize the safety and well-being of any persons within the park. 
(e)  Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-85; Code 1988, § 25-128; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 2 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 25-121. - Possession, consumption, etc., of alcoholic beverages, drugs, etc. 
(a)  Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages, drugs, or controlled substances, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 54.1-3401, or any other intoxicating substance in any part of any city park, recreation area, or playground area is prohibited except as noted herein. No person shall enter or be in any park or recreation area or playground area while under the influence of alcoholic beverages, drugs, any controlled substance or any other intoxicating substance. Alcoholic beverages may be consumed or served in areas designated as "Closed to the Public" and by persons with permission from the city manager, and who are in possession of the appropriate state alcoholic beverage control board permits. 
(b)  Any violation of these prohibitions as to the possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages, the entering or being in any park, recreation area or playground area while under the influence of alcoholic beverages, drugs, any controlled substance, or any other intoxicating substances, or the consumption or serving of alcoholic beverages without permission of the city manager or without the appropriate state alcoholic beverage control board permit shall be punishable as a class 4 misdemeanor. All other violations of this section shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 24-86; Code 1988, § 25-129) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 or 4 misdemeanors, § 1-11.  
Secs. 25-122—25-145. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSES 
 
Sec. 25-146. - Maintenance and operation. 
The care and operation of municipal golf courses shall be under the city manager and such agents as he may appoint. 
(Code 1973, § 24-98; Code 1988, § 25-146)  
Sec. 25-147. - Professional for each course. 
The city manager is authorized to appoint a golf professional for each of the municipal golf courses, who shall have charge of the care and operation of the respective golf courses and the collection of fees. The golf professional shall be responsible for the collection of all fees at the golf course. 
(Code 1973, § 24-99; Code 1988, § 25-147)  
Sec. 25-148. - Fees. 
(a)  Fees generally. Any person desiring to play golf shall first apply to the golf professional of the golf course and pay the fees as set forth in appendix A to this Code and any subsequent amendments thereto before starting to play. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, and the fees set out in Appendix A to this Code, the following definitions shall apply: 
Adult means any person 18 years of age or older. 
Junior means any person under 18 years of age. 
Senior means any person 55 years of age or older. 
Super senior means any person over 75 years of age. 
Weekday means Monday through Thursday. 
Weekend means Friday through Sunday. 
(c)  Reduction or waiver of fees. The fees for play at Bide-A-Wee Golf Course and The Links at City Park may be reduced or waived by the city manager to set and establish rates for golf subscriptions and for temporary off season, non-peak day, promotional golf package, junior and senior, and individual birthday play. The purpose of any rate adjustment shall be to assure maximum use at rates competitive with other area golf courses during periods of decreased play and to encourage the use of the courses and golf carts. 
(Code 1973, § 24-100; Code 1988, § 25-148; Ord. No. 1988-47, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1989-1, § 1(24-100), 1-10-1989; Ord. No. 1989-39, § 1, 5-15-1989; Ord. No. 1990-40, § 2, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1990-80, § 2, 6-26-1990; Ord. No. 1991-22, § 1, 3-12-1991; Ord. No. 1991-43, § 1, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1992-36, § 1, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 1992-78, § 1, 9-22-1992; Ord. No. 1993-30, § 1, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 1994-37, § 3, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 1995-24, § 1, 3-28-1995; Ord. No. 1995-46, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 1997-72, § 1, 12-9-1997; Ord. No. 2003-24, § 1, 4-22-2003; Ord. No. 2004-28, § 1, 6-15-2004; Ord. No. 2007-45, § 1, 4-24-2007; Ord. No. 2009-62 , § 1, 6-23-2009, eff. 7-1-2009; Ord. No. 2013-27, § 1, 5-14-2013)
