Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 25-149. - Disposition of fees collected; report of such fees. 
Each golf professional shall pay all fees collected by him to the city treasurer daily, or whenever the city manager may direct, and file a copy of his report with the chief financial officer on the form provided for that purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 24-101; Code 1988, § 25-149; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 25-150. - Sale of soft drinks, etc. 
Each golf professional shall have the privilege of selling soft drinks, candy, tobacco, and golf supplies under regulations prescribed by the city manager. Such sales shall be conducted as to involve no expense or liability to the city. 
(Code 1973, § 24-102; Code 1988, § 25-150)  
Secs. 25-151—25-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - NATIONAL GUARD ARMORY 
 
Sec. 25-201. - Use permit generally. 
(a)  The city manager may issue a permit to any person, except as hereinafter provided, for the use of the National Guard Armory upon the payment of the fees hereinafter established and upon compliance with the other requirements hereinafter set forth. No meeting or other activity shall be held at the armory other than that stated in the application. 
(b)  No such permit shall be granted to any person who, for security reasons, is not approved by the commanding officer of the National Guard unit using the armory. 
(c)  No such permit shall be granted to any person reported by the attorney general of the United States as having significance in connection with the national security. 
(d)  No such permit shall be granted to any person when there is danger of any breach of the peace, tumult, riot, resistance of law, or danger to person or property. 
(e)  No such permit shall be granted to any person when such use of the armory would interfere in any manner with the use thereof by the National Guard or endanger the security of the equipment stored therein. 
(Code 1973, § 24-139; Code 1988, § 25-201)  
Sec. 25-202. - Fees—Established. 
The fees as set out in appendix A to this Code for the following categories shall be charged for the use of the armory: 
(1)  For use by a nonprofit organization or private individual, per day or any fraction thereof. 
(2)  For use by a commercial organization, per day or any fraction thereof. 
(3)  As used herein, a "day" shall be defined as a period of eight hours beginning at the time the permittee is granted access to the armory. Additional hours, or fraction thereof, shall be charged by multiplying the number of additional hours and the hourly rate as established by subsections (1) or (2) of this section and as set out in appendix A to this Code (divided by eight) plus a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 24-140; Code 1988, § 25-202; Ord. No. 1989-40, § 1, 5-15-1989; Ord. No. 1994-37, § 4, 5-10-1994) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 25-203. - Same—Payment. 
The fees provided for in section 25-202 shall be paid in full in advance. 
(Code 1973, § 24-141; Code 1988, § 25-203)  
Sec. 25-204. - Deposit against damages. 
(a)  Before any permit to use the armory may be issued, the applicant shall deposit with the city a cash deposit, bond or insurance policy in an amount not less than the amount set out in appendix A to this Code to cover the cost of damages sustained by the armory or any of the equipment, fixtures or facilities located therein by reason of the use or occupancy thereof by the applicant. 
(b)  Within 30 days following the use of the armory by the applicant, any such deposit or portion thereof, bond or insurance policy not necessary to cover the cost of any damages which may have been sustained as a result of the issuance of such permit shall be refunded or cancelled, as the case may be. 
(Code 1973, § 24-142; Code 1988, § 25-204)  
Sec. 25-205. - Police protection. 
The permittee shall provide such police protection as may be specified by the chief of police after considering the type of use, the hours of use and the probable attendance. 
(Code 1973, § 24-143; Code 1988, § 25-205)  
Sec. 25-206. - Cancellation or revocation of permit. 
The city may cancel or revoke any permit issued under the provisions of section 25-201 at any time for any reason without liability to the applicant or any other person. 
(Code 1973, § 24-144; Code 1988, § 25-206)  
Secs. 25-207—25-246. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - MUNICIPAL SWIMMING POOLS 
 
Sec. 25-247. - Admission fees. 
The director shall establish a fee schedule for admission fees to city swimming pools, such fee schedule to be submitted to the city manager for approval and not to exceed the charges as set out in appendix A to this Code for the following categories: 
(1)  Three years of age and younger. 
(2)  Four years of age and older. 
(3)  Annual membership—Unlimited use. 
(Code 1973, § 24-151; Code 1988, § 25-247; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997; Ord. No. 1998-17, § 1, 4-28-1998) 
Charter reference— Authority of council to establish and collect fees and charges, § 2.14.  
Sec. 25-248. - Safety rules and regulations. 
The director shall establish safety rules and regulations for city swimming pools and to post such rules at such swimming pools after asking the advice of the parks and recreation commission. 
(Code 1973, § 24-152; Code 1988, § 25-248; Ord. No. 1997-15, § 2, 3-11-1997) 

Chapter 26 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Prohibition against peddlers making noise, § 24-255(b)(9). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 26-1—26-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS OF PERISHABLE FAMILY SUPPLIES GROWN OR PRODUCED BY THEM[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Peddlers who sell or offer for sale in person or by their employees ice, wood, charcoal, meats, milk, butter, eggs, poultry, game, vegetables, fruits or other family supplies of a perishable nature or farm products grown or produced by them and not purchased by them for sale are not subject to the business, professional, occupational license tax, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3717. 
 
Sec. 26-26. - Application of article. 
This article shall apply to peddlers of ice, wood, meats, milk, butter, eggs, poultry, fish, oysters, game, vegetables, fruits, or other family supplies of a perishable nature grown or produced by them and not purchased by them for sale. 
(Code 1973, § 25-16; Code 1988, § 26-26)  
Sec. 26-27. - License exemption. 
(a)  Peddlers subject to the provisions of this article, including their bona fide employees, shall not be required to obtain a license under chapter 20 of this Code, if they comply with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any police officer or other officer charged with the enforcement of chapter 20 of this Code may at any time question any peddler claiming exemption from city license taxation pursuant to this section and may require of such peddler an affidavit in support of any claim made by him that the produce then in or on his vehicle was grown or produced by him. It shall be unlawful and a class 1 misdemeanor for a peddler to make any false statement in such affidavit. 
(Code 1973, §§ 25-16, 25-19, 25-20; Code 1988, § 26-27) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 26-28. - Annual certificate to be filed with commissioner of revenue. 
(a)  Every peddler subject to the provisions of this article shall, on or before May 1 of each year, file with the commissioner of the revenue a certificate under oath in which shall be given the name and post office address of the peddler, the location of the land on which the family supplies of a perishable nature are grown or produced, or are to be grown or produced, whether the peddler is the owner thereof or renter, and in the latter case, the name of the landlord or owner and the time from which and to which the lease is to run. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a class 1 misdemeanor for a peddler to make any false statement in a certificate filed under this section. 
(Code 1973, §§ 25-17, 25-20; Code 1988, § 26-28) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 26-29. - Issuance, contents and display of producer's vehicle tag. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a certificate as provided for in section 26-28 and such other evidence under oath as may be sufficient to establish the fact that the peddler is entitled to the exemption granted in section 26-27, the city treasurer shall furnish to the peddler a tag suitable to be displayed on his vehicle, on which tag shall be printed or stamped "City of Portsmouth _______ Producer No. _______," together with the year for which issued, which tag the peddler shall display upon his truck or other vehicle whenever he is engaged in peddling within the city. 
(b)  Any peddler failing to display the tag as required in subsection (a) of this section or permitting the tag obtained by him to be used in the sale of any family supplies of a perishable nature not grown or produced by him shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, §§ 25-18, 25-20; Code 1988, § 26-29) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Secs. 26-30—26-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SOLICITATION OF CONTRIBUTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Solicitation of contributions in parks, § 25-98. 
State Law reference— Solicitation of contributions, Code of Virginia, § 57-48 et seq.; ordinances regulating such solicitations, Code of Virginia, § 57-63. 
 
Sec. 26-46. - Definitions. 
Unless a different meaning is required by the context, the following terms as used in this chapter shall have the meanings hereinafter respectively ascribed to them: 
Charitable organization means any organization which is or holds itself out to be organized or operated for any charitable purpose or any organization which solicits contributions from the public. This definition shall not be deemed to include: 
(1)  Any church or convention or association of churches, primarily operated for nonsecular purposes and no part of the net income of which inures to the direct benefit of any individual; 
(2)  Any political party as defined in Code of Virginia, § 24.2-101 or any political campaign committee or political action committee or other political committee required by state or federal law to file a report or statement of contributions and expenditures; 
(3)  Any authorized individual who solicits, by authority of such organization, solely on behalf of a registered or exempt charitable organization or on behalf of an organization excluded from the definition of charitable organization. 
Charitable purpose means any charitable, benevolent, humane, philanthropic, or eleemosynary purpose and the purposes of influencing legislation or influencing the actions of any public official or instigating, prosecuting or intervening in litigation. 
Charitable sales promotion means advertised sales that feature the names of both the commercial co-venturer and the charitable or civic organization and which state that the purchase or use of the goods, services, entertainment, or any other thing of value that the commercial co-venturer normally sells, will benefit the charitable or civic organization or its purposes. To qualify as a charitable sales promotion, the consumer must pay the same price for the thing of value as the commercial co-venturer usually charges without the charitable sales promotion and the consumer retains the thing of value. 
Civic organization means any local service club, veterans post, fraternal society or association, volunteer fire or rescue groups, or local civic league or association of ten or more persons not organized for profit but operated exclusively for educational or charitable purposes, including the promotion of community welfare, and the net earnings of which are devoted exclusively to charitable, educational, recreational or social welfare purposes. 
Commercial co-venturer means any person who: 
(1)  Is organized for profit; 
(2)  Is regularly and primarily engaged in trade or commerce, other than in connection with soliciting for charitable or civic organizations or charitable purposes; and 
(3)  Conducts an advertised charitable sales promotion for a specified limited period of time. 
Contribution means any gift, bequest, devise or other grant or any money, credit, financial assistance or property of any kind or value, including the promise to contribute, except payments by the membership of an organization for membership fees, dues, fines or assessments, or for services rendered to individual members, and except money, credit, or financial assistance or property received from any governmental authority. The term "contribution" shall not include any donation of blood or any gift made pursuant to the Uniform Anatomical Gift Act (Code of Virginia, § 32.1-289 et seq.). 
Federated fundraising organization means any federation of independent charitable organizations which have voluntarily joined together, including but not limited to United Fund or Community Chest, for the purposes of raising and distributing money for and among themselves and where membership does not confer operating authority and control of the individual agencies upon the federated group organization. 
Fundraising expenses means the expenses of all activities that constitute or are an integral and inseparable part of a solicitation. 
Membership means those persons to whom, for payment of fees, dues, assessments, and the like, an organization provides services and confers a bona fide right, privilege, professional standing, honor or other direct benefit, in addition to the right to vote, elect officers or hold offices. The term "membership" shall not include those persons who are granted a membership upon making a contribution as the result of solicitation. 
Parent organization means that part of a charitable organization which coordinates, supervises or exercises control over policy, fundraising and expenditures, or assists or advises one or more chapters, branches or affiliates. 
Person means any individual, organization, trust, foundation, association, partnership, corporation, society, or other group or combination acting as a unit. 
Professional fundraising counsel means any person who, for a flat fixed fee under a written agreement, plans, conducts, manages, carries on, advises or acts as a consultant, whether directly or indirectly, in connection with soliciting contributions for, or on behalf of, any charitable or like organization, but who actually solicits no contributions as part of such services. A bona fide salaried officer or employee of a registered or exempt charitable organization or a registered parent organization shall not be deemed to be a professional fundraising counsel. 
Professional solicitor means any person who, for a financial or other consideration, solicits contributions for or on behalf of a charitable or civic organization, whether such solicitation is performed personally or through his agents, servants or employees or through agents, servants or employees specially employed by or for a charitable or civic organization, who are engaged in the solicitation of contributions under the direction of such person, or any person who, for a financial or other consideration, plans, conducts, manages, carries on, advises or acts as a consultant to a charitable or civic organization in connection with the solicitation of contributions but does not qualify as a professional fundraising counsel. A bona fide salaried officer or employee of a registered or exempt charitable organization or a registered parent organization shall not be deemed a professional solicitor. 
Sale, sell and sold mean the transfer of any property or the rendition of any service to any person in exchange for consideration, including any purported contribution without which such property would not have been transferred or such services would not have been rendered. 
Solicit and solicitation mean the request or appeal, directly or indirectly, for any contribution on the plea or representation that such contribution will be used for a charitable purpose, including without limitation, the following methods of requesting such contribution: 
(1)  Any oral or written request; 
(2)  Any announcement to the press, over the radio or television, or by telephone or telegraph concerning an appeal or campaign to which the public is requested to make a contribution for any charitable purpose connected therewith; 
(3)  The distribution, circulation, posting or publishing of any handbill, written advertisement or other publication which directly or by implication seeks to obtain public support; or 
(4)  The sale of, offer or attempt to sell any advertisement, advertising space, subscription, ticket or any service or tangible item in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable purpose or where the name of any charitable organization is used or referred to in any such appeal as an inducement or reason for making any such sale, or when or where, in connection with any such sale, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the proceeds from any such sale will be donated to any charitable purpose. 
"Solicitation," as defined herein, shall be deemed to occur when the request is made, at the place the request is received, whether or not the person making the same actually receives any contribution. 
(Code 1973, § 25-31; Code 1988, § 26-46; Ord. No. 1990-66, § 1, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-48.  
Sec. 26-47. - Exemptions from article generally. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall be construed as being applicable to the American Red Cross or any of its local chapters. 
(b)  No charitable organization shall be required to comply with the provisions of this article if such organization has registered with state commissioner of agriculture and consumer services or if such organization is a chapter, branch or affiliate included in the consolidated report of an organization or federated organization which is so registered. Such organization shall, however, register with the city manager its name, the names of its solicitors and the dates and times that they will be soliciting in the city. 
(Code 1988, § 26-47) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 57-60(d), 57-63(d).  
Sec. 26-48. - Exemptions from certain provisions of article. 
(a)  The following shall be exempt from the registration requirements of section 26-55 and the requirements of section 26-60, but shall otherwise be subject to the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Educational institutions that are accredited by the state board of education, by a regional accrediting association or by an organization affiliated with the National Commission on Accrediting, the Association Montessori International, the American Montessori Society, or the Virginia Association of Independent Schools, any foundation having an established identity with any of the aforementioned educational institutions and any other educational institution confining its solicitation of contributions to its student body, alumni, faculty and trustees and their families. 
(2)  Persons requesting contributions for the relief of any individual specified by name at the time of the solicitation when all of the contributions collected, without any deductions whatsoever, are turned over to the named beneficiary for his use. 
(3)  Charitable organizations which do not intend to solicit and receive, during a calendar year, and have not actually raised or received during any of the three next preceding calendar years, contributions from the public in excess of $5,000.00, if all their functions, including fundraising activities, are carried on by persons who are unpaid for their services and if no part of their assets or income inures to the benefit of or is paid to any officer or member. Nevertheless, if the contributions raised from the public, whether all of such is or is not received by any charitable organization during any calendar year, shall be in excess of $5,000.00, it shall, within 30 days after the date it shall have received total contributions in excess of $5,000.00, register with and report to the city manager as required by this article. 
(4)  Organizations which solicit only within the membership of the organization by the members thereof. 
(5)  Organizations which have no office within the city, which solicit in the city from without the commonwealth solely by means of telephone or telegraph, direct mail or advertising in the national media. 
(6)  The term "charitable sales promotion" means advertised sales that feature the names of both the commercial co-venturer and the charitable or civic organization and which state that the purchase or use of the goods, services, entertainment, or any other thing of value that the commercial co-venturer normally sells, will benefit the charitable or civic organization or its purposes. To qualify as a charitable sales promotion, the consumer must pay the same price for the thing of value as the commercial co-venturer usually charges without the charitable sales promotion and the consumer retains the thing of value. 
(7)  Health care institutions have been granted tax-exempt status under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and defined herein as any facilities that have been granted tax-exempt status under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, and that are: (i) licensed by the state Department of Health or the Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Substance Abuse Services; (ii) designated by the Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) as federally qualified health centers; (iii) certified by the HCFA as rural health clinics; or (iv) wholly organized for the delivery of health care services without charge; and any supporting organization that exists solely to support any such health care institutions. For the purposes of clause (iv), "delivery of health care services without charge" includes the delivery of dental, medical or other health services where a reasonable minimum fee is charged to cover administrative costs. 
(8)  Civic organizations as defined herein. 
(9)  Nonprofit debt counseling agencies licensed pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 6.1-363.2 et seq. Agencies designated by the Virginia Department for the Aging pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 2.2-703(A)(6) as area agencies on aging. 
(10)  Labor unions, labor associations and labor organizations that have been granted tax-exempt status under section 501(c)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(11)  Trade associations that have been granted tax-exempt status under section 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(12)  Organizations that have been granted tax-exempt status under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and that are organized wholly as regional emergency medical services councils in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.11. 
(13)  Nonprofit organizations that have been granted tax-exempt status under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and that solicit contributions only through: (i) grant proposals submitted to for-profit corporations, (ii) grant proposals submitted to other nonprofit organizations that have been granted tax-exempt status under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, or (iii) grant proposals submitted to organizations determined to be private foundations under section 509(a) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(14)  Museum that has registered with the state commissioner of agriculture and consumer affairs as required by Code of Virginia, § 57-49 and that has been granted tax-exempt status under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(b)  A charitable organization shall be subject to the provisions of Code of Virginia, §§ 57-57 and 57-59, but shall otherwise be exempt from the provisions of this chapter for any year in which it confines its solicitations in the commonwealth to five or fewer contiguous cities and counties, and in which it has registered under the charitable solicitations ordinance, if any, of each such city and county. No organization shall be exempt under this subsection if, during its next preceding fiscal year, more than ten percent of its gross receipts were paid to any person or combination of persons, located outside the boundaries of such cities and counties, other than for the purchase of real property, or tangible personal property or personal services to be used within such localities. An organization that is otherwise qualified for exemption under this subsection that solicits by means of a local publication, or radio or television station, shall not be disqualified solely because the circulation or range of such medium extends beyond the boundaries of such cities or counties. 
(c)  No charitable organization shall be exempt under this section unless it shall submit, before any solicitation in any calendar year, to the city manager on forms to be prescribed by him, the name, address and purpose of the organization and a statement setting forth the reason for the claim for exemption. Parent organizations may file consolidated applications for exemptions for any chapters, branches or affiliates which they believe to be exempt from the registration provisions of this article. If exempted, the city manager shall issue annually, a letter of exemption which may be exhibited to the public. No registration fees shall be required of any exempt organization. The letter of exemption shall remain in effect as long as the organization continues to solicit in accordance with its claim for exemption. 
(Code 1973, § 25-42; Code 1988, § 26-48) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-60.  
Sec. 26-49. - Reciprocal agreements with other municipalities. 
The city manager may enter into a reciprocal agreement with the appropriate authority of any municipality within the commonwealth for the purpose of exchanging information with respect to charitable organizations, professional fundraising counsel and professional solicitors. Pursuant to such agreements, the manager may accept information filed by charitable organizations, professional fundraising counsel and professional solicitors with the appropriate authority of another locality within this commonwealth in lieu of the information required to be filed by this article. 
(Code 1973, § 25-33; Code 1988, § 26-49)  
Sec. 26-50. - Article does not authorize unlawful acts or omissions or decrease liability imposed by law. 
Nothing contained in this article shall be construed as making lawful any act or omission which is now unlawful, or as decreasing the liability, civil or criminal, of any person, imposed by existing laws. 
(Code 1973, § 25-43; Code 1988, § 26-50) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-62.  
Sec. 26-51. - Judicial review of orders under article. 
Any person aggrieved by any final order to the city manager under this article is entitled to judicial review in accordance with the provisions of the Administrative Process Act (Code of Virginia, § 9-6.14:1 et seq.). Either party may appeal any final order of such court in the same manner as provided by law in cases of appeals of right. 
(Code 1973, § 25-44; Code 1988, § 26-51) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-67.  
Sec. 26-52. - Investigation to enforce article. 
(a)  Whenever the city manager has reasonable cause to believe that a violation of this article may have occurred, the manager, upon his own motion or upon complaint of any person, may investigate any charitable or civic organization, professional fundraising counsel or professional solicitor to determine whether such charitable or civic organization, professional fundraising counsel or professional solicitor has violated the provisions of this article. In the conduct of such investigation, the manager may: 
(1)  Require or permit any person to file a statement in writing, under oath or otherwise as the manager determines, as to all facts and circumstances concerning the matter to be investigated. 
(2)  Administer oaths or affirmations and, upon his motion or upon request of any party, subpoena witnesses, compel their attendance, take evidence, and require the production of any matter which is relevant to the investigation, including the existence, description, nature, custody, condition and location of any books, documents or other tangibles and the identity and location of persons having knowledge of relevant facts or any other matter reasonably calculated to lead to the discovery of material evidence. 
(b)  Any proceedings or hearings by the manager under this section, where witnesses are subpoenaed and their attendance is required for evidence to be taken or any matter is to be produced to ascertain material evidence, shall take place within the city. 
(c)  Upon failure to obey a subpoena and upon reasonable notice to all persons affected thereby, the city manager may apply to the circuit court of the city for an order imposing punishment for contempt of the subpoena or compelling compliance. 
(d)  No officer, agent, director or trustee of any charitable or civic organization, professional fundraising counsel or professional solicitor shall refuse or fail, after notice, to produce any books or any records of such organization. 
(Code 1973, §§ 25-39(m), 25-41; Code 1988, § 26-52) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 57-57(M), 57-59(b).  
Sec. 26-53. - Penalty for violations of article. 
Any person who willfully and knowingly violates or causes to be violated any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished for the first offense to pay a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $1,000.00 or by confinement in jail for not more than six months, or both, and for the second and any subsequent offense by fine of not less than $500.00 and not more than $2,500.00 or by confinement in jail for not more than one year, or both. 
(Code 1973, § 25-41; Code 1988, § 26-53; Ord. No. 1991-68, § 1, 6-25-1991) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-59(a).  
Sec. 26-54. - Actions to enjoin violations of article. 
(a)  Whenever the city attorney has reason to believe that any charitable or civic organization, professional fundraising counsel or professional solicitor is operating in violation of the provisions of this article, he may, in addition to all other actions authorized by law, bring an action in the name of the commonwealth against such charitable or civic organization, such professional fundraising counsel or professional solicitor, or their officers, directors or other agents, to enjoin the continuation of such violation, solicitation or collection, or the engaging therein, or the conducting of any acts in furtherance thereof and for such other relief as the court deems appropriate. 
(b)  In any action brought under subsection (a) of this section, the court may also award to the commonwealth a civil penalty of not more than $5,000.00 per violation, to be paid to the state literary fund, and reasonable expenses incurred by the city in investigating and preparing the case, not to exceed $250.00 per violation, and such expenses shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 25-41; Code 1988, § 26-54; Ord. No. 1990-66, § 2, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-59(c).  
Sec. 26-55. - Registration of organizations. 
(a)  Every charitable organization, except as otherwise provided in this article, which intends to solicit contributions within the city, or have funds solicited on its behalf, shall, prior to any solicitation, file an initial registration statement with the city manager upon forms acceptable to him. Each registration statement shall thereafter be refiled on or before the 15th day of the fifth calendar month of the next and each following fiscal year in which such charitable organization is engaged in solicitation activities within the city. It shall be the duty of the president, chairman or principal officer of such charitable organization to file the statements required herein. Such statements shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name of the organization and the purpose for which it was organized. 
(2)  The principal address of the organization, the address of any offices in the city and its designated agent for process within the commonwealth. If no such agent is designated, the organization shall be deemed to have designated the secretary of the commonwealth. If the organization does not maintain an office, the statement shall include the name and address of the person having custody of its financial records. 
(3)  The names and addresses of any chapters, branches or affiliates in the city. 
(4)  The place where and the date when the organization was legally established, the form of the organization, and a reference to any determination of its tax-exempt status under the Internal Revenue Code. 
(5)  The names and addresses of the officers, directors, trustees and the principal salaried executive staff officer. 
(6)  A copy of a balance sheet and income and expense statement, with the opinion of an independent public accountant for the organization's immediately preceding fiscal year, or a copy of a financial statement certified by an independent public accountant covering, in a consolidated report, complete information as to all the preceding year's fundraising activities of the charitable organization, showing kind and amount of funds raised, fundraising expenses and allocation or disbursement of funds raised; provided that, no charitable organization which has registered with the city manager for the current and next preceding three years, or is exempt from such registration for such years, shall be required to file any financial information. The report required by this subsection shall comply with the accounting standards prescribed in section 26-60. Any organization with gross revenue of less than $25,000.00 may submit a balance sheet and income and expense statement verified under oath or affirmation by the treasurer of the organization. 
(7)  A statement showing the computation of the percentages provided for in subsection (b) of this section. 
(8)  A statement indicating whether the organization intends to solicit contributions from the public directly or have such done on its behalf by others. 
(9)  A statement indicating whether the organization is authorized by any other governmental authority to solicit contributions and whether it, or any officer, professional fundraiser or professional solicitor thereof, is or has ever been enjoined by any court or otherwise prohibited from soliciting contributions in any jurisdiction. 
(10)  The general purpose for which the contributions to be solicited shall be used. 
(11)  The name under which it intends to solicit contributions. 
(12)  The names of the individuals or officers of the organization who will have final responsibility for the custody of the contributions. 
(13)  The names of the individuals or officers of the organization responsible for the final distribution of the contributions. 
(14)  A statement indicating whether the organization, or any officer, professional solicitor or professional fundraiser thereof, has ever been convicted of a felony and, if so, a description of the pertinent facts. 
(b)  Each charitable organization shall, as a part of its registration statement, compute the percentage which its fundraising expenses for its preceding fiscal year bore to its support received directly from the public during such year. 
(c)  Each chapter, branch or affiliate located within the city, except an independent member agency of a federated fundraising organization, shall separately report the information required by this section or report the information to its parent organization which shall then furnish such information as to itself and all local affiliates, chapters and branches in a consolidated form. All affiliated organizations included in a consolidated registration statement shall be considered as one charitable organization for all purposes of this article. If a consolidated registration statement is filed, all statements thereafter filed shall be upon the same basis unless permission to change is granted by the city manager. 
(d)  Each federated fundraising organization located within the city shall report the information required by this section in a consolidated form. Any federated fundraising organization may elect to exclude from its consolidated report information relating to the separate fundraising activities of all of its independent member agencies. No member agency of a federated fundraising organization shall be required to report separately any information contained in such a consolidated report. Any separate solicitation campaign conducted by, or on behalf of, any such member agency in the city shall nevertheless be subject to all other provisions of this article. 
(e)  The registration forms shall be verified under oath or affirmation by an authorized officer of the charitable organization. 
(f)  Every charitable organization which submits an independent registration to the manager shall pay an annual registration fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code. A parent organization filing on behalf of one or more chapters, branches or affiliates or a federated fundraising organization filing on behalf of its member agencies shall pay a single annual registration fee. All fees paid hereunder shall be credited to the office of the city manager, for reimbursement of administrative expenses. 
(Code 1973, §§ 25-32, 25-40; Code 1988, § 26-55) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 57-49, 57-58, 57-63(a)(3).  
Sec. 26-56. - Commercial co-ventures. 
(a)  No commercial co-venturer shall conduct any charitable sales promotion in the city on behalf of a charitable or civic organization unless the charitable or civic organization is duly registered or granted the appropriate exempt status as provided by this article. 
(b)  Prior to any charitable sales promotion in the city, the commercial co-venturer shall have a written agreement with the charitable or civic organization on whose behalf the charitable sales promotion is to be conducted. Such agreement shall be signed by an authorized representative of the commercial co-venturer and two officers of the charitable or civic organization. 
(c)  The commercial co-venturer shall maintain all records in connection with the charitable sales promotion for a period of three years after the end date of the charitable sales promotion. All such records shall be made available to the city manager upon request. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-61.2.  
Sec. 26-57. - Reports by organizations with no local office and which solicit solely by telephone, mail, etc. 
Any charitable organization having no office or place of business within the commonwealth and soliciting in the city from without the city solely by telephone or telegraph, direct mail or advertising in local or national media, and any professional fundraising counsel or professional solicitor engaged by such an organization, shall file with the city manager any report which would otherwise be required of it or require that a determination of exemption be made. 
(Code 1973, § 25-33; Code 1988, § 26-56) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-51(b).  
Sec. 26-58. - Publication of warnings as to unregistered organizations. 
If the city manager determines that any charitable or civic organization not registered with his office and not exempt from registration, irrespective of whether such organization is subject to the jurisdiction of this city, has solicited or may be soliciting in this city, directly or indirectly, by any means including without limitation, by telephone or telegraph, by direct mail or by advertising in national media, he may, after ten days' written notice mailed to the charitable or civic organization, cause to be printed in one or more newspapers published in this city a notice in substantially the following form: 
WARNING—UNREGISTERED 
CHARITABLE SOLICITATION 
The organization named below has solicited contributions from Portsmouth citizens for allegedly charitable purposes. It has not registered with or been granted the appropriate exempt status by the city manager as required by law. Contributors are cautioned that their contributions to such organization may be used for noncharitable purposes. 
(Code 1988, § 26-57) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-52.  
Sec. 26-59. - Publication of warning solicitations by unregistered professional solicitors. 
(a)  If the city manager determines that any charitable or civic organization has contracted with a professional solicitor to solicit on its behalf and that the professional solicitor may be soliciting or has solicited in this city, directly or indirectly, by any means including, without limitation, by telephone or telegraph, by direct mail or by advertising in national media, and the professional solicitor has not registered with the state commissioner of agriculture and consumer services as required by Code of Virginia, § 57-61, the city manager may, after five days' written notice mailed to the charitable or civic organization, cause to be printed in one or more newspapers published or distributed in the city a notice in substantially the following form: 
WARNING—UNREGISTERED 
CHARITABLE SOLICITATION 
BY PROFESSIONAL SOLICITOR 
(b)  The charitable or civic organization named below has contracted with a professional solicitor to solicit on its behalf. The professional solicitor has not registered with the Commonwealth of Virginia as required by law. Contributors are cautioned that their contributions may be used for noncharitable purposes. 
(Code 1973, § 25-34; Code 1988, § 26-58) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-52.1.  
Sec. 26-60. - Records to be kept by organizations. 
Every charitable organization shall keep true fiscal records for all fiscal years in accordance with the standards set out in Code of Virginia, § 57-53. Such records shall be retained for a period of at least three years after the end of the period to which they relate. 
(Code 1973, § 25-35; Code 1988, § 26-59) 
State Law reference— Records to be kept, Code of Virginia, § 57-53.  
Sec. 26-61. - Contracts between organizations and fundraising counsel or professional solicitors. 
(a)  Every contract or agreement between professional fundraising counsel and a charitable or civic organization must be in writing and shall be filed with the city manager within ten days after such contract or written agreement is entered into. 
(b)  Every contract, or a written statement of the nature of the arrangement to prevail in the absence of a contract, between a professional solicitor and a charitable or civic organization shall be filed with the city manager at least ten days prior to the commencement of the contract. 
(c)  All agreements and arrangements between professional fundraising counsel and charitable or civic organizations must be reduced to writing before executed or acted upon. 
(Code 1973, § 25-36; Code 1988, § 26-60) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-54.  
Sec. 26-62. - Documents and information filed under article constitute public records; charge for copies thereof. 
Registration statements, reports, professional fundraising counsel contracts or professional solicitor contracts and all other documents and information required to be filed under this article shall become public records in the office of the city manager and shall be open to the general public for inspection at such time and under such conditions as the manager may prescribe. A charge not exceeding the amount as set forth in appendix A to this Code per page may be made for any copy of such documents and information as may be furnished any person by the manager. 
(Code 1973, § 25-38; Code 1988, § 26-61) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-56.  
Sec. 26-63. - False or incorrect information in statements or reports required by article. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully and knowingly give false or incorrect information to the city manager in filing statements or reports required by this article, whether such report or statement is verified or not. 
(Code 1973, §§ 25-39(a), 25-41; Code 1988, § 26-62) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 57-57(O), 57-59(a).  
Sec. 26-64. - Allowing solicitations by unregistered professional solicitors. 
No charitable or civic organization shall allow a professional solicitor to solicit on its behalf if the professional solicitor has not registered pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 57-61. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(j); Code 1988, § 26-63) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(J).  
Sec. 26-65. - Disclosure required of professional solicitors. 
(a)  Every professional solicitor who solicits contributions from a prospective contributor in the city shall identify himself and his employer, shall disclose that he is a paid solicitor and shall further disclose, in writing, the fact that a financial statement for the last fiscal year is available from the state office of consumer affairs. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a professional solicitor to solicit contributions from a potential donor in the city without clearly and conspicuously disclosing to the potential donor, prior to orally requesting a contribution, or contemporaneously with a written request for a contribution, at the point of solicitation, the minimum percentage of any amount contributed which will be received by the charitable or civic organization for its own use. 
(Code 1973, § 25-34; Code 1988, § 26-64) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 57-55.1, 57-55.2.  
Sec. 26-66. - Receipts required for certain contributions. 
No charitable or civic organization shall accept any contribution exceeding $5.00 in cash or tangible property without providing, on request of the donor, a written receipt acknowledging such contribution on behalf of the organization. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(g); Code 1988, § 26-65) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(G).  
Sec. 26-67. - Unlawful solicitations generally. 
(a)  No charitable or civic organization, professional fundraising counsel or professional solicitor shall solicit in the city without being duly registered as required by law. 
(b)  No professional solicitor shall solicit on behalf of a charitable or civic organization unless the charitable or civic organization has registered or been granted the appropriate exempt status under this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(k); Code 1988, § 26-66; Ord. No. 1990-66, § 2, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(K).  
Sec. 26-68. - Soliciting without authority from organization. 
(a)  No person shall make any representation that he is soliciting contributions for or on behalf of a charitable or civic organization or shall use or display any emblem, device or printed matter belonging to or associated with a charitable or civic organization for the purpose of soliciting or inducing contributions from the public without first being authorized to do so by the charitable or civic organization. 
(b)  No professional solicitor shall solicit in the name of or on behalf of any charitable or civic organization unless such solicitor has written authorization of two officers of such organization, a copy of which shall be filed with the manager. Such written authorization shall bear the city signature of the solicitor and shall expressly state on its face the period for which it is valid, which shall not exceed one year from the date issued. Such authorization shall be carried by the solicitor when making solicitations and shall be exhibited, on request, to persons solicited, police officers or agents of the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(e), (f); Code 1988, § 26-67; Ord. No. 1990-66, § 2, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(E), (F).  
Sec. 26-69. - Soliciting by certain persons prohibited. 
No person, and no organization of which such person is an officer, professional fundraising counsel or professional solicitor, shall solicit within the city if: 
(1)  Such person has been convicted in any jurisdiction of embezzlement, larceny or other crime involving the obtaining of money or property by false pretenses or the misapplication of funds impressed with a trust, unless such person has received a pardon for such offense or the public is informed of such conviction in a manner approved in writing by the city manager before any solicitation occurs; or 
(2)  Such person has ever been enjoined by any court or otherwise prohibited from soliciting in any jurisdiction, unless the city manager shall first determine in writing that such person is entitled to solicit in such jurisdiction at the time of soliciting within the city or that the reason for such injunction or prohibition does not involve moral turpitude. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(h); Code 1988, § 26-68) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(H).  
Sec. 26-70. - Soliciting for benefit of nonresident who fails to supply information to city manager. 
No person shall solicit within the city for the benefit of any other person located without the city. If such other person refuses to supply any information which the city manager deems necessary to assure himself that the provisions of this article are complied with. A solicitation shall be deemed to be on behalf of every person who receives, directly or indirectly, more than ten percent of the gross amount collected. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(i); Code 1988, § 26-69) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(I).  
Sec. 26-71. - Misleading solicitations generally. 
(a)  No charitable organization shall use or exploit the fact of registration under this article so as to lead the public to believe that such registration in any manner constitutes an endorsement or approval by the city. The use of the following statement shall not be deemed a prohibited exploitation: "Registered with the City of Portsmouth as required by law. Registration does not imply endorsement of a public solicitation for contributions." 
(b)  No person shall, in connection with the solicitation of contributions or the sale of tangible personal property or services represent, or lead anyone by any manner, means, practice or device whatsoever to believe that the person on whose behalf such solicitation or sale is being conducted is a bona fide charitable organization or that the proceeds of such solicitation or sale will be used for charitable purposes, if he has reason to believe such not to be the fact. 
(c)  No person shall employ in any solicitation or collection of contributions for a charitable purpose any device, scheme or artifice to defraud or obtain money or property by any misrepresentation or misleading statement. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(a), (b), (l); Code 1988, § 26-70) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(A), (B), (L).  
Sec. 26-72. - Misrepresentations as to sponsors, endorsers, etc. 
(a)  No person shall, in connection with the solicitation of contributions or the sale of tangible personal property or services for charitable purposes, represent or lead anyone by any manner, means, practice or device whatsoever to believe that any other person sponsors or endorses such solicitation of contributions, sale of tangible personal property or services for charitable purposes or approves of such charitable purposes or a charitable organization connected therewith when such other person has not given written consent to the use of his name for these purposes. 
(b)  Any member of the board of directors or trustees of a charitable organization or any other person who has agreed to either serve or to participate in any voluntary capacity in the campaign shall be deemed thereby to have given his consent to the use of his name in such campaign. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the publication of names of contributors without their written consent in an annual or other periodic report issued by a charitable organization for the purpose of reporting on its operations and affairs to its membership or for the purpose of reporting contributions to contributors. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(c); Code 1988, § 26-71) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(C).  
Sec. 26-73. - Misrepresentations as to income tax deductions. 
(a)  No person shall denominate any membership fee or purchase price of goods or services sold as a contribution or as a donation or in any other manner represent or imply that the member or the purchaser of such goods or services will be entitled to an income tax deduction for his cost or any portion thereof unless: 
(1)  A signed opinion of counsel or an internal revenue service ruling or determination letter holding such cost to be deductible has been obtained; or 
(2)  The member or purchaser is informed in writing that such cost may not be deductible. 
(b)  No person shall represent or imply that a contributor will be entitled to any income tax deduction for his contribution unless a signed opinion of legal counsel or an Internal Revenue Service ruling or determination letter holding gifts to such organization to be deductible has been obtained. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(d); Code 1988, § 26-72; Ord. No. 1990-66, § 2, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(D).  
Sec. 26-74. - Unlawful use of funds raised by solicitation. 
No person shall use or permit the use of the funds raised by a charitable solicitation for any purpose other than the solicited purpose or, with respect to funds raised by general appeals, the general purposes of the charitable or civic organization on whose behalf the solicitation was made. 
(Code 1973, § 25-39(n); Code 1988, § 26-73; Ord. No. 1990-66, § 2, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(N).  
Sec. 26-75. - Donation of tickets to events. 
No person shall represent, in any solicitation, that tickets to events will be donated for use by another unless he complies with the following requirements: 
(1)  He shall have obtained commitments, in writing, from persons or charitable or civic organizations stating that they will accept donated tickets and specifying the number of persons for whom they are willing to accept tickets; 
(2)  He shall not collect or accept more contributions for donated tickets than the number of ticket commitments he has received from persons or charitable or civic organizations; 
(3)  He shall have printed in advance on each ticket the exact number of persons to be admitted by the ticket and the dollar price or value of each ticket; 
(4)  He shall distribute the tickets in a timely fashion to those having given commitments; and 
(5)  He shall maintain during the solicitation and for a period of three years thereafter records reflecting the name and address of each contributor and the amount of money and number of tickets donated by each such contributor; and the written commitments of each person or charitable or civic organization to accept tickets and specifying the number of persons on whose behalf tickets were to be accepted, as required in subsection (1) of this section. 
(Code 1988, § 26-74; Ord. No. 1990-66, § 3, 6-26-1990)  
Sec. 26-76. - Funding of terrorist activities or organizations. 
No person shall knowingly use or permit the use of funds raised by a solicitation or by contribution to benefit or provide support, directly or indirectly, in cash or in kind, to terrorists, terrorist organizations, terrorist activities or to family members of any terrorist. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(R).  
Sec. 26-77. - Professional solicitation on behalf of charitable or civic organization. 
No professional solicitor shall solicit on behalf of a charitable or civic organization unless the charitable or civic organization has registered or been granted the appropriate exempt status under this chapter. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-57(P).  
Chapter 27 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Resisting police officer, § 24-246; giving false information to police officer, § 24-247; mistreatment or interference with police animals, § 24-282; fire and police retirement system, § 30-151 et seq.; automatic security alarms programmed to dial police department, § 31-26 et seq. 
State Law reference— General powers and duties of local police force, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1704, 15.2-1710; criminal records exchange, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-387 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 27-1. - Composition of police department. 
The positions in the police department of the city shall consist of a chief and such officers and employees as may, from time to time, be deemed necessary by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 2-186; Code 1988, § 27-1) 
Cross reference— Chief of police or police department line officer designated by chief to act as sergeant-at-arms at council meetings, § 2-65; application of civil service system to employees of police department, § 2-136; representative from police department to attend meetings of emergency medical service advisory commission, § 2-691.  
Sec. 27-2. - Appointment of chief of police. 
The chief of police department shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 2-187; Code 1988, § 27-2)  
Sec. 27-3. - Bondsmen soliciting or loitering at police station. 
It shall be unlawful and a class 4 misdemeanor for any person to solicit for compensation bail bonds from any person detained at the police station or to loiter or remain in the police station after executing any bail bond requested of him. 
(Code 1973, § 8-29; Code 1988, § 27-3) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 27-4. - Impersonating officer. 
Any person who shall falsely assume or exercise the functions, powers, duties and privileges incident to the office of sheriff, police officer, marshal or other peace officer or who shall falsely assume or pretend to be any such officer shall be deemed guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 29-1; Code 1988, § 27-4) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11; impersonating fire, rescue and emergency services personnel, § 24-249. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-174.  
Sec. 27-5. - Unlawful use of police uniform and badge. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person not a member of the police department to wear the duly prescribed uniform of the police department or any distinctive part of such uniform, or a uniform, any part of which is similar in color to or is otherwise a distinctive part of the duly prescribed uniform of the police department to wear or otherwise exhibit a badge prescribed for members of the department or a badge similar thereto. 
(b)  Any violation of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 29-2; Code 1988, § 27-5) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Unlawful wearing of officer's uniform or insignia, etc., Code of Virginia, § 18.2-175.  
Sec. 27-6. - False alarms of criminal activities. 
(a)  The following terms when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection: 
(1)  Alarm means any device which, when actuated by the occurrence of a criminal act requiring police response, transmits a signal to a central alarm system, a third party or directly to the emergency operations center or produces an audible or visible signal designed to notify persons within audible or visual range of the signal. 
(2)  False alarm means a signal from an alarm resulting in a response by the police department when an emergency situation did not exist. 
(b)  Following police response to the actuation of a false alarm, the alarm user shall provide to the responding officer any and all information required for the filing of a false alarm report. 
(c)  No service charge shall be imposed upon the first occurrence of a false alarm. A service charge as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be imposed for a second false alarm occurrence, for the third and fourth occurrences, for the fifth through ninth occurrences, and for subsequent occurrences within a 12-month period; except that where it is demonstrated to the chief of police that a false alarm was generated by adverse weather conditions, electrical or telephonic power failures, and other causes, including equipment malfunctions, not resulting from the negligence of the alarm user, his agents and employees, a service charge shall not be assessed. The service charge shall be payable within five days of written notification to the alarm user of the assessment. 
(Code 1973, §§ 29-76—29-78; Code 1988, § 27-6; Ord. No. 2004-25, § 1, 6-15-2004) 
Cross reference— Security alarms, ch. 31.  
Sec. 27-7. - Fees; police services and documents. 
The fees as set forth in appendix A to this Code are established for the following police administrative services and documents: 
(1)  Criminal record check. 
(2)  Fingerprinting. 
(3)  Identification photos. 
(4)  Reports (offense, accident, police). 
(5)  Photographs. 
(6)  911 tape copy. 
(7)  Mugshot. 
(8)  Videotape copy. 
(9)  Copies (per page). 
(10)  Research and copying (per hour). 
(11)  Concealed handgun permit. 
(Code 1988, § 27-7; Ord. No. 2004-25, § 2, 6-15-2004; Ord. No. 2013-28, § 1, 5-14-2013)  
Secs. 27-8—27-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Auxiliary police officers, appointment, revocation, uniform, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1731 et seq. 
 
Sec. 27-26. - Appointment and limitation on number of members; revocation of appointment. 
The city manager shall appoint as auxiliary police officers as many persons of good character as he shall deem necessary, not to exceed 100, and their appointment shall be revocable at any time by the city manager. 
(Code 1973, § 29-14; Code 1988, § 27-26) 
State Law reference— Appointment, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1733.  
Sec. 27-27. - Members not compensated or subject to civil service system. 
The members of the auxiliary police force shall serve as such without compensation and shall not be subject to the provisions of any law providing a civil service system for the members of the regular police force. 
(Code 1973, § 29-19; Code 1988, § 27-27) 
Cross reference— Civil service, § 2-136 et seq. 
State Law reference— Auxiliary police forces in cities, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-17-31 et seq.  
Sec. 27-28. - Authority of city manager to prescribe uniform, organization and regulations. 
The city manager shall have the authority to prescribe the uniform, organization and such rules and regulations as he shall deem necessary for the operation of the auxiliary police force. 
(Code 1973, § 29-15; Code 1988, § 27-28) 
State Law reference— Uniforms, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1733.  
Sec. 27-29. - When members may be called into service. 
(a)  The city manager may call into service such auxiliary policemen as may be deemed necessary: 
(1)  In time of public emergency; 
(2)  At such times as there is an insufficient number of regular police officers to preserve the peace, safety and good order of the community; 
(3)  At any time for the purpose of training such auxiliary police officers. 
(b)  The chief of police may call into service members of the auxiliary police force who have been trained in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1731(B) in order to aid and assist regular police officers in the performance of their duties. 
(c)  The chief of police may call into service persons who were members of the auxiliary police force prior to July 1, 1987, and who had been trained in accordance with the requirements in effect prior to that date, in order to aid and assist regular police officers in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1973, § 29-16; Code 1988, § 27-29) 
State Law reference— Calling auxiliary policemen into service, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1734.  
Sec. 27-30. - Powers and immunities of members. 
(a)  The members of the auxiliary police force called into service by the city manager shall have all the powers and authority and all the immunities of constables at common law. 
(b)  The members of the auxiliary police force called into service by the chief of police shall have all the powers and authority and all the immunities of full-time law enforcement officers. 
(Code 1973, § 29-17; Code 1988, § 27-30) 
State Law reference— Members called into service by the chief of police, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1734.  
Sec. 27-31. - Jurisdictional limitations of members. 
The members of the auxiliary police force shall not be required to act beyond the limits of the jurisdiction of the city except when called upon to protect any public property belonging to the city which may be located beyond its boundaries. 
(Code 1973, § 29-18; Code 1988, § 27-31) 
State Law reference— Jurisdictional limits, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1735.  
Sec. 27-32. - Members to wear uniforms. 
The members of the auxiliary police force shall wear the uniform prescribed by the city manager at all times while serving as auxiliary policemen. 
(Code 1973, § 29-20; Code 1988, § 27-32) 
State Law reference— Uniforms, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1734.  
Secs. 27-33—27-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - UNCLAIMED PROPERTY IN CUSTODY OF POLICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Unclaimed property, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1734. 
 
Sec. 27-51. - Definition. 
As used in this article, the term "unclaimed personal property" shall mean any personal property belonging to another which has been acquired by a law enforcement officer pursuant to his duties, which is not needed in any criminal prosecution, which has not been claimed by its rightful owner and which the state treasurer has indicated will be declined if remitted under the Virginia Uniform Disposition of Unclaimed Property Act, Code of Virginia, § 55-210.1 et seq. Such term shall not apply to bicycles, motor vehicles and their contents, contraband items, lost and found items or currency. Unclaimed bicycles and mopeds may be disposed of in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1720. Unclaimed firearms may be disposed of in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1721. 
(Code 1973, § 29-31; Code 1988, § 27-51; Ord. No. 1990-81, § 1, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1719.  
Sec. 27-52. - Sale. 
(a)  Any unclaimed property which has been in the possession of the police department and unclaimed for a period of more than 60 days shall be subject to public sale or retention for use by the police department. Prior to the sale or retention for use of any unclaimed item by the police department, the chief of police shall make reasonable attempts to notify the rightful owner of the property, obtain from the commonwealth's attorney in writing a statement advising that the item is not needed in any criminal prosecution, and cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city once a week for two consecutive weeks, notice that there will be a public display and sale of unclaimed personal property. Such property, including property selected for retention by the police department, shall be described generally in the notice together with the date, time and place of the sale and shall be made available for public viewing at the sale. 
(b)  If any goods, wares, merchandise or chattels which are of perishable nature, or which shall be expensive to keep, shall at any time remain unclaimed in the custody of the police department, the chief of police may sell the same at public auction, at such time and after such notice as to him shall seem proper. 
(Code 1973, §§ 29-32, 29-33; Code 1988, § 27-52; Ord. No. 1995-44, § 1, 4-25-1995) 
Cross reference— Sale of unclaimed bicycles impounded by police department, § 5-38(d). 
State Law reference— Provisions similar to subsection (a) above, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1719.  
Sec. 27-53. - Disposition of property or proceeds. 
(a)  The chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall pay from the proceeds of a sale under this article the costs of advertisement, removal, storage, investigation as to ownership and liens and notice of sale. The balance of the proceeds shall be held by the chief of police for the owner and paid to the owner upon satisfactory proof of ownership. Any unclaimed item retained for use by the police department shall become the property of the city and shall be retained only if, in the opinion of the police chief, there is a legitimate use for the property by the police department and retention of the item is a more economical alternative than purchase of a similar or equivalent item. 
(b)  If no claim is made by the owner for the property or proceeds within 60 days of the sale, the remaining funds shall be deposited in the general fund of the city, and the retained property may be placed into use by the police department. 
(c)  The owner of the property shall be entitled to apply to the city within three years from the date of sale and, if timely application is made therefor, and satisfactory proof of ownership of the proceeds or property is made, the city treasurer or the chief of police, as applicable, shall pay the remaining proceeds of the sale to the owner of the property, or return the property to the owner, without interest or other charges or compensation. No claim shall be made nor any suit, action or proceeding instituted for the recovery of such proceeds or property after three years from the date of sale. 
(Code 1973, § 29-34; Code 1988, § 27-53; Ord. No. 1995-44, § 1, 4-25-1995) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1719.  
Secs. 27-54—27-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - REGISTRATION OF FELONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Sex Offender and Crimes Against Minors Registry Act, Code of Virginia, § 9.1-900 et seq. 
 
Sec. 27-71. - Violations of article. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 29-51; Code 1988, § 27-71) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 27-72. - Exemptions from article as to persons pardoned or on probation. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall apply to any person who has received or who shall receive a full and unconditional pardon for each or any crime whereof he has been convicted, or to any person who is or shall be on probation under the laws of the state, or whose probation period under the laws of the state has expired without any revocation of such probation having been made. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to a person whose conviction occurred more than ten years prior to his arrival in the city. 
(Code 1973, §§ 29-46, 29-50; Code 1988, § 27-72)  
Sec. 27-73. - When required. 
(a)  Any person who has been convicted of any offense punishable as a felony in this state or elsewhere, who comes into the city from any point outside of the city, and remains in the city for a period exceeding 24 hours shall report to and register with the chief of police, within 24 hours after his arrival within the boundaries of the city. 
(b)  Every person residing in the city who is convicted outside the city of any offense punishable as a felony in this state or elsewhere shall, within 24 hours after his return to the city, report to and register with the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, §§ 29-44, 29-45; Code 1988, § 27-73)  
Sec. 27-74. - Statement of registrant. 
Persons required to report and register by section 27-73 shall furnish to the chief of police a statement, in writing, signed by such person and giving the following information: 
(1)  His true name and all aliases which he has used or under which he may have been known. 
(2)  A full and complete description of his person. 
(3)  The kind, character and nature of each crime of which he has been convicted. 
(4)  The place where any of such crimes were committed and the place of conviction of the same. 
(5)  The name under which he was convicted in each instance and the date thereof. 
(6)  The name, if any, and the location of each prison, reformatory, jail and other penal institution in which he was confined, or to which he was sentenced. 
(7)  The location and address of his residence, stopping place, living quarters or place of abode in the city, and each one thereof if more than one; or, the address or location of his intended residence, stopping place, living quarters or place of abode therein, and each one thereof, with a description of the character of each such place, whether a hotel, apartment house, dwelling house or otherwise, giving the street number thereof, if any, or such description of the address or location thereof as will so identify the same as to make it possible of location, and the length of time for which he expects or intends to reside within the territorial boundaries of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 29-44; Code 1988, § 27-74)  
Sec. 27-75. - Photographing and fingerprinting of registrant. 
At the time of reporting and registering pursuant to section 27-73, the person so reporting shall be photographed and fingerprinted by the chief of police, and such photograph and fingerprints shall be made a part of the permanent record provided for in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 29-44; Code 1988, § 27-75)  
Sec. 27-76. - Report of change of address. 
In the event that any person required to be registered under this article changes any place of residence, stopping place or living quarters to any new or different place within the city, other than any place last shown in the statement furnished to the chief of police, he shall, within 24 hours after the making of such change, notify the chief of police, in a written and signed statement, of such change of address and shall furnish in such written statement his new address. 
(Code 1973, § 29-47; Code 1988, § 27-76)  
Sec. 27-77. - Furnishing false or misleading information. 
It shall be unlawful for any person required by any provision of this article to furnish any statement or report, to furnish therein any false or fictitious address, or any address other than a true address or intended address, or to furnish, in making any such report or statement any false, untrue or misleading information or statement relating to any information required by any provisions of this article to be furnished. 
(Code 1973, § 29-47; Code 1988, § 27-77)  
Sec. 27-78. - Disposition and use of statements, photographs, etc. 
(a)  The statements, photographs and fingerprints provided for in this article shall at all times be kept by the chief of police in a file separate and apart from other files and records maintained and kept by the police department and shall not be open to inspection by the public or by any person other than a regular member of the police department; provided, however, that any such photograph or duplicates thereof may be exhibited to persons other than police officers of the city for the purpose of assisting in identifying perpetrators of any crime. 
(b)  Copies of the statements, photographs and fingerprints referred to in this article may be transmitted to any law enforcement officer when request is made in writing by such law enforcement officer asking for the record of a certain person named therein, or for the record of a person whose photograph or fingerprints reasonably correspond with photographs or fingerprints submitted with such request; provided, that such written request states that such record is deemed necessary for the use of such law enforcement officer in or concerning the investigation of any crime, or any person who is accused of committing a crime, or any crime which is reported to have been committed; and provided further, that such request in writing shall state that the record will be used only for such purpose. 
(Code 1973, §§ 29-48, 29-49; Code 1988, § 27-78) 
State Law reference— Dissemination of criminal history record information, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-389.  
Secs. 27-79—27-95. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PRIVATE DETECTIVES AND PRIVATE DETECTIVE AGENCIES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Private security services, Code of Virginia, § 9.1-138 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 27-96—27-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 27-111. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a private detective or to operate a private detective agency in the city unless he has a current permit from the chief of police. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any employee of any person engaged in the business of private detective or operating a private detective agency in the city to perform investigative or detective work in the city unless he has a current permit from the chief of police to do so. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, §§ 29-62, 29-69; Code 1988, § 27-111) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 27-112. - Exceptions. 
(a)  The provisions of this division shall not be applicable to any officer of the police force of the state or of any city, town or county thereof nor to any employee of the United States or any of its agencies when such officer or employee is acting within the scope of and in the course of his employment. 
(b)  The provisions of this division shall not be applicable to any private detective who has been issued a permit by any other city, county or town in the state to engage in the business of a private detective where such permit was issued under an ordinance establishing standards substantially similar to those contained in this division. 
(Code 1973, § 29-68; Code 1988, § 27-112)  
Sec. 27-113. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring a permit under this division shall make application therefor to the chief of police on a form prescribed by him, which application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and office address of the applicant and whether the applicant is an individual, an association, a firm, partnership or corporation. 
(2)  If the applicant is an individual, his residence address; if the applicant is an association, a firm or partnership, the names and residence addresses of the members thereof, if the applicant is a corporation, the names and residence addresses of the officers thereof. 
(3)  The place and period of residence and employment of each individual member or officer for five years immediately preceding the date of application.
