(4)  The nature and length of experience in investigative and detective work which such individual, members or officers have had. 
(b)  The application shall be dated and shall be signed by the individual applicant or the members of the association, firm or partnership applying or, for and on behalf of the corporation applying, by the president and secretary thereof, and the signers shall make oath that the information set forth in the application is true and correct. 
(Code 1973, § 29-63; Code 1988, § 27-113)  
Sec. 27-114. - Investigation of application; issuance or denial of permit. 
The chief of police shall investigate promptly each application for a permit under this division, and if he finds: 
(1)  That the individual or the members of the association, firm or partnership or the officers of the corporation applying for the permit are of good moral character; 
(2)  That the individual, the members of the association, firm or partnership or the officers of the corporation, as the case may be, have never been convicted of a felony or of a misdemeanor directly related to the occupation or have never violated any regulations directly related to the occupation; and 
(3)  That the applicant is registered and licensed by the commonwealth to do private investigative or detective work; he shall grant the permit; otherwise, he shall refuse the permit. 
(Code 1973, § 29-64; Code 1988, § 27-114)  
Sec. 27-115. - Not transferable. 
No permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1973, § 29-65; Code 1988, § 27-115)  
Sec. 27-116. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The chief of police at any time, after giving at least five days' written notice and opportunity to be heard to the permittee, may suspend for such length of time as he may deem proper or revoke any permit which he has granted under the provisions of this division for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud or misrepresentation by the permittee in the procurement of the permit. 
(2)  A false report knowingly made by the permittee with regard to any matter about which the permittee was employed. 
(3)  Divulgence by the permittee to any person other than his client of any information which he obtained from or for his client except when authorized by his client to make such divulgence or when required by law to do so. 
(4)  False swearing in any judicial proceeding or suborning perjury by the permittee. 
(5)  Conviction of the permittee of a felony. 
(6)  If the permittee is an association, a firm, partnership or corporation, commission by any member or officer thereof or by any employee thereof who performs investigative or detective work therefor of any of the aforesaid acts. 
(7)  Revocation or suspension of the permittee's registration or license by the commonwealth. 
(b)  The notice to be given to the permittee may be sent to him by certified mail to the address given by him in his application for a permit, which mailing shall constitute sufficient service of the notice. 
(Code 1973, § 29-66; Code 1988, § 27-116)  
Sec. 27-117. - Appeals from decisions of chief of police. 
From any decision of the chief of police refusing to grant, suspending or revoking any permit pursuant to this division, the applicant or permittee, as the case may be, shall have a right of appeal to the circuit court. 
(Code 1973, § 29-67; Code 1988, § 27-117)  
Chapter 28 - PRECIOUS METALS AND GEMS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 28-1—28-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DEALERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to adopt ordinance similar to this article, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4111. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 28-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Coin means any piece of gold, silver or other metal fashioned into a prescribed shape, weight and degree of fineness, stamped by authority of government with certain marks and devices, and having a certain fixed value as money. 
Dealer means any person engaged in the business of purchasing secondhand precious metals or gems, removing in any manner precious metals or gems from manufactured articles not then owned by such person or buying, acquiring or selling precious metals or gems removed from such manufactured articles. "Dealer" shall include any employer or principal on whose behalf a purchase is made and any employee or agent who makes any such purchase for or on behalf of his employer or principal. The definition shall not be construed so as to include any person engaged in the following: 
(1)  Purchases of precious metals or gems directly from other dealers, manufacturers or wholesalers for retail or wholesale inventories, provided the selling dealer has complied with the provisions of this division. 
(2)  Purchases of precious metals or gems from a duly qualified fiduciary who is disposing of the assets of the estate being administered by such fiduciary in the administration of an estate. 
(3)  Acceptance by a retail merchant of trade-in merchandise previously sold by such retail merchant to the person presenting that merchandise for trade-in. 
(4)  Repairing, restoring or designing jewelry by a retail merchant, if such activities are within his normal course of business. 
(5)  Purchases of precious metals or gems by industrial refiners and manufacturers, insofar as such purchases are made directly from retail merchants, wholesalers, dealers or by mail originating outside the commonwealth. 
(6)  Purchasing and processing nonprecious scrap metals which incidentally may contain traces of precious metals recoverable as a byproduct. 
Gem means any item containing precious or semiprecious stones customarily used in jewelry. 
Precious metal means any item except coins composed in whole or in part of gold, silver, platinum or platinum alloys. 
(Code 1973, § 18-50; Code 1988, § 28-26) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4100.  
Sec. 28-27. - Article not applicable to sale or purchase of coins. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to the sale or purchase of coins. 
(Code 1988, § 28-27) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4109(B).  
Sec. 28-28. - Article not applicable to financial institutions dealing in gold and silver bullion. 
The provisions of this article shall not apply to any bank, branch thereof, trust company or bank holding company, or any wholly owned subsidiary thereof, engaged in buying and selling gold and silver bullion. 
(Code 1973, § 18-50; Code 1988, § 28-28) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4109(C).  
Sec. 28-29. - Waiver of article provisions for certain exhibitions and shows. 
The chief of police may waive by written notice any provision of this article, except section 28-36, for particular numismatic, gem or antique exhibitions or craft shows sponsored by nonprofit organizations, provided that the purpose of the exhibitions or shows is nonprofit in nature, notwithstanding the fact that there may be casual purchases and trades made at such exhibitions or shows. 
(Code 1973, § 18-58; Code 1988, § 28-29) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4109(A).  
Sec. 28-30. - Violations of article. 
Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor for the first offense. Upon conviction of any subsequent offense he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 18-59; Code 1988, § 28-30) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 or 2 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4110(A).  
Sec. 28-31. - Inspection of records required by article listed in such records. 
Every dealer shall admit to his premises during regular business hours the chief of police or his designee or any law enforcement official of the state or federal governments, and shall permit such officer to examine all records required by this article, and to examine any article listed in a record which is believed by the officer to be missing or stolen and search for and take into possession any article known to him to be missing, or known or believed by him to have been stolen. 
(Code 1973, § 18-51; Code 1988, § 28-31; Ord. No. 1991-69, § 1, 6-25-1991) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4101.1.  
Sec. 28-32. - Bond or letter of credit. 
(a)  Every dealer, at the time of obtaining a permit under division 2 of this article, shall enter into a recognizance to the city secured by a corporate surety authorized to do business in the commonwealth, in the penal sum of $10,000.00, conditioned upon due observance of the terms of this article. In lieu of a bond, a dealer may cause to be issued by a bank authorized to do business in the commonwealth a letter of credit in favor of the city in the sum of $10,000.00. 
(b)  A single bond upon an employer or principal may be written or a single letter of credit issued to cover all employees and all transactions occurring at a single location. 
(c)  If any person shall be aggrieved by the conduct of any dealer who has violated the provisions of this article, he may maintain an action for recovery in any court of proper jurisdiction against such dealer and his surety, provided that recovery against the surety shall be only for that amount of the judgment, if any, which is unsatisfied by the dealer. 
(Code 1973, § 18-56; Code 1988, § 28-32) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 54.1-4106, 54.1-4107.  
Sec. 28-33. - Notice of closing and reopening of business; location of business. 
If the business of a dealer is not operated without interruption, Saturdays, Sundays and recognized holidays excepted, the dealer shall notify the chief of police of all closings and reopenings of the business. The business of a dealer shall be conducted only from the fixed and permanent location specified in his application for a permit under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 18-57; Code 1988, § 28-33) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108(E).  
Sec. 28-34. - Credentials and statement of ownership required from seller. 
No dealer shall purchase precious metals or gems without first ascertaining the identity of the seller by requiring an identification issued by a governmental agency with a photograph of the seller thereon, and at least one other corroborating means of identification, and obtaining a statement of ownership from the seller. 
(Code 1973, § 18-52; Code 1988, § 28-34) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4102.  
Sec. 28-35. - Record of purchases. 
(a)  Every dealer shall keep at his place of business an accurate and legible record of each purchase of precious metals or gems. The record of each such purchase shall be retained by the dealer for not less than 24 months. These records shall set forth the following: 
(1)  A complete description of all precious metals or gems purchased from each seller. The description shall include all names, initials, serial numbers or other identifying marks or monograms on each item purchased, the true weight or carat of any gem, and the price paid for each item; 
(2)  The date and time of receiving the items purchased; 
(3)  The full name, residence address, workplace, home and work telephone numbers, date of birth, sex, race, height, weight, hair and eye color and other identifying marks; 
(4)  Verification of the identification by the exhibition of a government-issued identification card, such as a driver's license or military identification card. The record shall contain the type of identification exhibited, the issuing agency, and the number thereon; and 
(5)  A statement of ownership from the seller. 
(b)  The information required by subsections (a)(1) through (a)(3) of this section shall appear on each bill of sale for all precious metals and gems purchased by a dealer, and a copy shall be mailed or delivered within 24 hours of the time of purchase to the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, § 18-51; Code 1988, § 28-35; Ord. No. 1990-76, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4101(A), (B).  
Sec. 28-36. - Prohibited purchases. 
(a)  No dealer shall purchase precious metals or gems from any seller who is under the age of 18 years. 
(b)  No dealer shall purchase precious metals or gems from any seller who the dealer believes, or has reason to believe, is not the owner of such items, unless the seller has written and duly authenticated authorization from the owner permitting and directing such sale. 
(Code 1973, § 18-53; Code 1988, § 28-36) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4103.  
Sec. 28-37. - Retention of purchases. 
(a)  A dealer shall retain all precious metals or gems purchased for a minimum of ten calendar days from the date on which a copy of the bill of sale is received by the chief of police pursuant to section 28-35. Until the expiration of this period, the dealer shall not sell, alter or dispose of a purchased item in whole or in part, or remove it from the city. 
(b)  If a dealer performs the service of removing precious metals or gems, he shall retain the metals or gems removed and the article from which the removal was made for a period of ten calendar days after receiving such article and precious metals or gems. 
(Code 1973, § 18-54; Code 1988, § 28-37) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4104.  
Sec. 28-38. - Record of sales. 
Each dealer shall keep and maintain for at least 24 months an accurate and legible record of the name and address of each person to whom he sells any precious metal or gem in its original form after the waiting period required by section 28-37. This record shall also show the name and address of the seller from whom the dealer purchased such item. 
(Code 1973, § 18-55; Code 1988, § 28-38) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4105.  
Secs. 28-39—28-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 28-51. - Required. 
No person shall engage in the activities of a dealer within the city, unless he has a current permit so to do issued pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1973, § 18-57; Code 1988, § 28-51) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108(A).  
Sec. 28-52. - Application; fee. 
Any person desiring a permit required by this division shall file with the chief of police an application form which shall include the applicant's full name and any aliases and his address, age, date of birth, sex and fingerprints; the name, address and telephone number of the applicant's employer, if any; and the location of the applicant's place of business. Such application shall be accompanied by an application fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 18-57; Code 1988, § 28-52) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108(B).  
Sec. 28-53. - Inspection and approval of applicant's weighing device. 
Before a permit required by this division may be issued, the applicant must have all weighing devices used in his business inspected and approved by the local or state weights and measures officials and present written evidence of such approval to the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, § 18-57; Code 1988, § 28-53) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108(C).  
Sec. 28-54. - Issuance or denial. 
Upon the filing of a proper application for a permit under this division and compliance with the provisions of this division, the applicant shall be issued a permit by the chief of police, provided the applicant has not been convicted of a felony or crime of moral turpitude within seven years prior to the date of the application. The permit shall be denied, if the applicant has previously been denied a permit or has had a permit revoked under this division or any ordinance of another jurisdiction similar in substance to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 18-57; Code 1988, § 28-54) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108(B).  
Sec. 28-55. - Not transferable. 
No permit issued under this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1973, § 18-57; Code 1988, § 28-55) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108(D).  
Sec. 28-56. - Term; renewal. 
A permit issued under this division shall be valid for one year from the date issued, unless sooner revoked, and may be renewed in the same manner as the permit was initially obtained, with an annual permit fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 18-57; Code 1988, § 28-56) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4108(D).  
Sec. 28-57. - Revocation. 
Upon the first conviction by any court of a dealer for violation of any provision of this article, the chief of police may revoke his permit to engage in business as a dealer under this article for a period of one full year from the date the conviction becomes final. Such revocation shall be mandatory upon a second conviction. 
(Code 1973, § 18-59; Code 1988, § 28-57) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4110(B).  
Chapter 29 - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 22; tampering with locomotive or other railroad rolling stock, § 24-321. 
State Law reference— Railroad corporations, Code of Virginia, § 56-345.1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 29-1. - Violations of chapter. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 29-1) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 29-2. - When locomotive bell to be rung. 
While any locomotive is passing along or across any street, the bell of such locomotive shall be kept constantly ringing. Any person who shall violate this section or cause such violation, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $10.00. In case such fine is not paid by the person incurring the same, the company by which he is employed shall be liable for such fine. 
(Code 1973, § 30-2; Code 1988, § 29-7) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 56-414; similar penalty for failure to ring bell as required by state law, Code of Virginia, § 56-415.  
Sec. 29-3. - Restrictions on blowing of locomotive whistles. 
Locomotive steam whistles shall be used to give signals within the city limits only where other means of signaling are impracticable. In such case, no locomotive steam whistle shall be blown for a longer period than five seconds at a time, except to give an alarm of fire. 
(Code 1973, § 30-3; Code 1988, § 29-8)  
Sec. 29-4. - Railroad cars obstructing street; standing vehicle on track. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any railroad company, or any receiver or trustee operating a railroad, to obstruct for a longer period than five minutes, the free passage on any street or road, by standing cars or trains across the same, except a passenger train while receiving or discharging passengers, but a passway shall be kept open to allow normal flow of traffic; nor shall it be lawful to stand any wagon or other vehicle on the track of any railroad which will hinder or endanger a moving train; provided, that when a train has been uncoupled, so as to make a passway, the time necessary required, not exceeding three minutes, to pump up the air after the train has been recoupled shall not be included in considering the time such cars or trains were standing across such street or road. 
(b)  Any such railroad company, receiver or trustee violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00; provided that the fine may be $100.00 for each minute beyond the permitted time but the total fine shall not exceed $500.00. 
(c)  This section shall not apply when a train is stopped due to breakdown, mechanical failure or emergency. 
(Code 1973, § 30-4; Code 1988, § 29-9) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 56-412.1.  
Sec. 29-5. - Trespassing on track. 
(a)  Any person who goes upon the track of a railroad other than to pass over such track at a public or private crossing or who willfully rides, drives or leads any animal, or contrives for any animal to go on such track except to cross as aforesaid, without the consent of the railroad company or other person operating such road, shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(b)  A second violation of the provisions of this section occurring within two years of the first violation shall be punishable as a class 3 misdemeanor. A third or subsequent violation of the provisions of this section occurring within two years of a second or subsequent violation shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to any section of track which has been legally abandoned pursuant to an order of a federal or state agency having jurisdiction over the track and is not being used for railroad service. For purposes of this section, "track" shall mean the rail, ties and ballast of the railroad. 
(Code 1973, § 30-10; Code 1988, § 29-10; Ord. No. 1993-52, § 1, 6-22-1993) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1, 3 and 4 misdemeanors, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-159.  
Chapter 30 - RETIREMENT SYSTEMS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Pensions and retirement for city officers and employees generally, Code of Virginia, § 51.1-800 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 30-1—30-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PORTSMOUTH SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT SYSTEM[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Virginia Retirement Act, Code of Virginia, § 51.1-124.2 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 30-26. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, unless otherwise required by the context, the following words and terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
Accumulated contributions means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member as contributions to the system, together with interest thereon at the rate of two percent per annum from the end of the fiscal year in which each such contribution was made. 
Actuarial equivalent means a benefit of equal value when computed upon the basis of such actuarial tables as are adopted by the board. Such benefits shall not be subject to employer discretion. The actuarial tables adopted by the board for this purpose are incorporated into this article as part of the system's plan document. 
Average final compensation means the average annual creditable compensation of a member during his 36 highest consecutive months of creditable service or during the entire period of his creditable service if less than 36 months. 
Beneficiary means any person entitled to receive benefits of any kind under this article because of the death of a member. 
Board means the board of trustees of the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System established by section 30-51. 
Creditable compensation means the full compensation payable to an employee working the full working time for his position; provided, however, that if an employee receives increases in compensation in the last four years of creditable service, not related to promotion, which exceed the average compensation increase in the same period received by other employees holding comparable positions, or which, in case there are not comparable positions, exceed the average percentage compensation increase in the same period received by all other employees, such excess shall be deducted in computing creditable compensation if the board finds after consideration of all circumstances that the primary purpose of such compensation increase was to increase the retirement benefit of such employee. 
Creditable service means for any member, the most recent period of continuous service as an employee rendered by the member plus membership service for which credit is allowed under this chapter; provided, however, that periods before and after periods of unpaid authorized leave shall be included as creditable service but the period of leave itself shall not be credited as creditable service. In addition, under regular service retirement and excluding deferred or vested retirement, one-half of unused sick leave as of the effective date of retirement shall be added to creditable service. 
Employee means any person regularly employed in the service of the city on a full-time basis and whose compensation is wholly paid by the city, and persons holding offices in the city required by the constitution of this state and their deputies, assistants and employees employed on a full-time basis and whose compensation is paid partly by the city and partly by the state, and members of the city council; but shall not include any person who is eligible for membership in the Virginia Retirement System, the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System or who enters into an agreement with the city for inclusion in a deferred compensation retirement plan which agreement specifically prohibits inclusion in other retirement systems established by the city. An employee shall also be taken to mean any person employed under a grant program who has been regularly employed in the service of the city on a full-time basis for a period such that the person will have become vested under the conditions as stated in section 30-116, and whereby such grant program has participated in making the necessary contributions to the system for the full period of the employee's service to be credited. Effective July 1, 2011, a person shall be deemed to be regularly employed on a full-time basis if classified as such in the employer's payroll system. In case of doubt, the board shall decide who is an employee within the meaning of this definition. 
Employer means the city or the authority of the city having the power to appoint an employee to office or employment. 
Examiner means the medical examiners provided for in section 30-61. 
Member means any employee who has been included in the membership of the system as provided in section 30-76, and whose membership has not terminated under the provisions of section 30-77. 
Normal retirement date means the first of the month next following or coinciding with the 65th birthday of a member. 
Retirement allowance means the retirement payments to which a member is entitled as provided in this article. 
Service means service as an employee for which compensation is paid by the employer. 
System means the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System provided for in this article. The provisions of this article are intended to meet the requirements of Section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code (as such section may be amended or renumbered, or any successor provision thereto) and the regulations thereunder applicable to governmental plans. 
(Code 1973, § 31-201; Code 1988, § 30-26; Ord. No. 1988-21, § 3, 2-23-1988; Ord. No. 1991-46, § 1, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 1, 11-22-2016; Ord. No. 2017-23 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-25-2017) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 30-27. - Short title of article. 
The short title of this article is "Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System." 
(Code 1973, § 31-202; Code 1988, § 30-27)  
Sec. 30-28. - Established; name. 
There is hereby established a retirement system for city employees to be known as the "Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System" by which and in which name it shall, pursuant to the provisions of this article, transact all of its business. 
(Code 1973, § 31-203; Code 1988, § 30-28)  
Sec. 30-29. - Duties of appointing authorities. 
The authority having the power to hire the services of a member shall keep such records from time to time shall furnish such information as the board may require in the discharge of its duties. Upon employment of a member, the authority shall inform the member of his duties and obligations in connection with the system as a condition of employment. 
(Code 1973, § 31-204; Code 1988, § 30-29)  
Sec. 30-30. - Acceptance of employment as consent to provisions of article. 
Every member shall be deemed to consent and agree to all the provisions of this article and any amendments thereto, and payment of salary or compensation shall be a full and complete discharge of all claims for services rendered by such person during the period covered by such payment, except as to any benefits provided by this article. 
(Code 1973, § 31-205; Code 1988, § 30-30)  
Sec. 30-31. - Contributions—By members. 
No contributions shall be made by or required of members of the system. Contributions by a member made prior to July 1, 1967, shall be retained in the assets of the system until the member ceases to be an employee. 
(Code 1973, § 31-248; Code 1988, § 30-31)  
Sec. 30-32. - Same—By employer. 
(a)  The employer shall contribute annually an amount equal to the sum of the normal contribution and the accrued liability contribution if any. The normal contribution for any year shall be determined as percentage of the creditable compensation of the members for such year, such percentage being referred to as the normal contribution rate. The accrued liability contribution shall be the dollar amount determined in subsection (c) of this section. 
(b)  The normal contribution rate shall be defined as the percentage of the total annual creditable compensation of the members that is represented by the annual normal cost required to provide the benefits of the system, other than any future adjustments as provided for in section 30-122, computed in accordance with the recognized actuarial principles on the basis of methods and assumptions approved by the board. 
(c)  The accrued liability contribution shall be defined as the level annual contribution necessary to amortize the then remaining unfunded accrued liability over an amortization period as follows: 
Actuarial Valuation Date 	Amortization Period 
July 1, 2004 	35 years 
July 1, 2005 	34 years 
July 1, 2006 	30 years 
July 1, 2007 	30 years 
July 1, 2008 and later 	to June 30, 2037 
 
The unfunded accrued liability at any particular time shall be determined, in accordance with recognized actuarial principles on the basis of methods and assumptions approved by the board, as the excess, if any, of the then present value of benefits, including any adjustments as provided for in section 30-122, expected to be paid in the future to retired and not-yet-retired members or their beneficiaries over the sum of the value of the assets then held in the retirement account plus the then present value of the normal contributions expected to be made in the future by the employer. 
(d)  The normal contribution rate and the accrued liability contribution shall be determined from the results of each valuation of the system using the actuarial basis adopted by the board and shall continue in force until a new valuation is made. The accrued liability contribution shall be adjusted each year based on the amount of the adjustment approved by the city council for that year using the actuarial basis adopted by the board. 
(e)  The board shall certify to the city manager the normal contribution rate and the accrued liability contribution and every change made therein from time to time. 
(f)  The aggregate employer contribution for any year shall be at least sufficient, when combined with the amount then held in the retirement account, to provide the benefits payable from the account during the current year. 
(Code 1973, § 31-249; Code 1988, § 30-32; Ord. No. 1990-56, § 1, 6-12-1990; Ord. No. 2000-15, § 1, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 2004-16, § 1, 3-9-2004)  
Sec. 30-33. - Retirement account. 
All of the funds and assets of the system shall be held in a single retirement account, in which shall be accumulated all contributions by the members and by the employer, and to which all income from the invested funds and assets of the system shall be credited. From this account shall be paid the investment management fees, and the death benefits and retirement allowances provided for in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 31-255; Code 1988, § 30-33; Ord. No. 1990-47, § 1, 5-22-1990)  
Sec. 30-34. - Cash deposits to meet disbursements. 
For the purpose of meeting disbursements for retirement allowances and other payments, there may be kept available cash, on deposit in one or more banks or trust companies that are designated by the council as depositories for funds of the city. The board shall not be liable for any loss sustained as to such funds that are on deposit in such banks or trust companies. 
(Code 1973, § 31-256; Code 1988, § 30-34; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 2, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-35. - Protection against fraud. 
Any person who shall knowingly make any false statement or shall falsify or permit to be falsified any records of the system in any attempt to defraud the system shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 31-206; Code 1988, § 30-35) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 30-36. - Alteration, amendment or repeal of provisions of article. 
(a)  The council reserves the right to alter, amend or repeal any provision of this article, or any application thereof to any person; provided, however, that the amount of benefit which at the time of any such alteration, amendment or repeal shall have accrued to the extent provided under subsection (c) of this section for the members or beneficiaries shall not be affected thereby. 
(b)  If the council repeals the provisions of this article, the board shall continue to administer the system in accordance with the provisions of this article for the sole benefit of the then members, any beneficiaries then entitled to receive benefits hereunder, and any future beneficiaries who become entitled to receive benefits under the joint and last survivor option provided for in this article. 
(c)  In the event of repeal as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the assets of the system shall be allocated by the board in an equitable manner to provide benefits for the persons designated in subsection (b) of this section in accordance with the provisions of this article, in the following order: 
(1)  For the benefit of the then members not yet retired to the extent of their accumulated contributions, if any. If any funds remain, then 
(2)  For the benefit of the retired members and the then beneficiaries entitled to receive benefits hereunder and beneficiaries already designated under the joint and last surviving option provided for in this article by the then retired members to the extent of the then actuarial value of their retirement allowances. If any funds remain, then 
(3)  For the benefit of members not then retired and beneficiaries, if any, designated by the members under the joint and last survivor option provided for in this article, to the extent, not provided under subsection (c)(1) of this section, of the then actuarial value of accrued retirement allowances, based on years of creditable service and average final compensation as of the date of repeal. The allocation under this subsection shall be on the basis of the oldest-ages-first method. In the event the assets at such date of repeal are insufficient to provide all of the benefits of subsection (c)(1) or (c)(2) of this section or both, then the employer will contribute to the assets from time to time, as and when required, the amount necessary to make up such insufficiency. 
(d)  The allocation of assets of the system provided for in subsection (c) of this section shall be carried out through the payment by the board of the benefits provided for in this section as they become due, or by the transfer of such assets to any retirement system replacing this system; provided that such vesting of benefits as provided by this section shall be fully maintained under such new retirement system. Any funds remaining in the assets of this system after all of the vested benefits provided by this section have been paid shall revert to the general fund. 
(e)  Any allocation of assets made in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be final and binding on all persons entitled to benefits under such provisions. 
(f)  Upon the termination or partial termination of the system, each member shall become fully vested, as of the termination date or partial termination date, in his service retirement allowance to the extent funded, regardless of length of service or amount of creditable service. 
(Code 1973, § 31-207; Code 1988, § 30-36; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 3, 11-22-2016  
Secs. 30-37—30-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— General procedural rules for boards appointed by council, § 2-28. 
 
Sec. 30-51. - Established; name; administration of system. 
The system shall be administered by a board of trustees to be known as the "Board of Trustees of the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System," which board is hereby established. 
(Code 1973, § 31-213; Code 1988, § 30-51)  
Sec. 30-52. - Composition; appointment, term, suspension or removal and compensation of members; vacancies. 
The board shall consist of seven voting members to be appointed by the city council and two non-voting ex officio members. One ex officio member shall be the chief financial officer or designee and the other ex officio member shall be the director of human resource management or designee. Of the voting members, appointed by city council, one shall be a retired employee and six shall be other than employees or otherwise in the employ of the city. Each appointment shall be made for a term of four years, except an appointment to fill a vacancy which shall be for the unexpired term. Board members appointed by city council shall serve for no longer than a maximum of two terms. Members who are employees of a department from which an appointment shall be made may propose names of employees for consideration by city council. To be considered for appointment to the board by city council, an applicant must demonstrate an understanding of investments and financial markets. Board members shall attend annual training programs and shall comply with all applicable city policies. The council may suspend or remove any member of the board at its pleasure. A member of the board who is not an employee or otherwise in the employ of the city shall receive as his compensation $10.00 per day for each day or part thereof actually spent in the discharge of his duties. A member who is in the employ of the city shall receive as his compensation $10.00 for each day or part thereof actually spent in the discharge of his duties if such day or part thereof is not otherwise a part of the regular working hours of the employee. No member shall receive as compensation in the aggregate more than $120.00 in any one year. Members shall be reimbursed for the expenses incurred by them in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1973, § 31-214; Code 1988, § 30-52; Ord. No. 1994-95, § 1, 9-27-1994; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 4, 11-22-2016  
Sec. 30-53. - Quorum. 
A majority of the members of the board shall constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1973, § 31-215; Code 1988, § 30-53)  
Sec. 30-54. - Chairman; vice-chairman; secretary. 
The board shall elect a chairman and a vice-chairman from among its members. It shall also appoint a secretary who may or may not be a member of the board. 
(Code 1973, § 31-216; Code 1988, § 30-54; Ord. No. 1994-103, § 1, 11-8-1994)  
Sec. 30-55. - Employment of actuary; necessary expenditures. 
The board may employ an actuary as its technical advisor and incur such expenditures as it deems necessary for the efficient administration of the system, as specified by this article, within the limitations of funds provided by the city council for this purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 31-217; Code 1988, § 30-55; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 5, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-56. - Actuarial investigations and valuations. 
(a)  At least once in each five-year period, the board shall cause an actuarial investigation to be made of all of the experience under the retirement system. Pursuant to such investigations, the board shall, from time to time, revise the actuarial bases of the rates of employer contributions prescribed under this article. 
(b)  The board shall cause an annual valuation to be made of the assets and liabilities of the system and shall prepare an annual statement of the amounts to be contributed by the employer under this article. 
(c)  The board shall publish annually such valuation of the assets and liabilities and a statement of receipts and disbursements of the system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-218; Code 1988, § 30-56)  
Sec. 30-57. - Record of proceedings. 
The board shall keep a record of all its proceedings and such record shall be open to inspection by the members. 
(Code 1973, § 31-219; Code 1988, § 30-57)  
Sec. 30-58. - Trustee of funds and investments. 
The board shall be the trustee of the funds created by this article and shall have the full power to invest and reinvest such funds, subject to the limitation that an investment shall be authorized and made, except upon the exercise of bona fide discretion, in securities which, at the time of making the investment, are, by law, permitted for the investment of funds by fiduciaries in this state. Subject to such limitation, the board shall have full power to hold, purchase, sell, assign, transfer or dispose of, any of the securities or other investments in which any of the funds created herein have been invested, as well as the proceeds of all such investments and any monies or deposits belonging to such funds of the system. 
Pursuant to the standards set forth in Section 803 of Title 51.1 of the Virginia Code, the board shall discharge its duties with respect to the system solely in the interest of the members and beneficiaries thereof and shall invest the assets of the system with the care, skill, prudence, and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing that a prudent person acting in a like capacity and familiar with such matters would use in the conduct of an enterprise of like character and like aims. The board shall also diversify such investments so as to minimize large losses unless under the circumstances it is clearly prudent not to do so. 
Upon no circumstances at any time prior to the satisfaction of all liabilities with respect to members and their beneficiaries under the trust shall any part of the trust corpus or income of the system be used for or diverted to any purpose other than for the exclusive benefits of the members and their beneficiaries and for the reasonable administrative expenses of the system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-220; Code 1988, § 30-58; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 6, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-59. - Conflicts of interest and prohibited interests of board members. 
The State and Local Government Conflict of Interests Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3100, et seq., as the same may be amended, restated or moved from time to time, governs defining and prohibiting inappropriate conflicts and required disclosures of economic interests as they relate to the system and the board. In addition, to the extent not less stringent than the State and Local Government Conflict of Interests Act, the restrictions in this section apply. No member of the board shall have any direct or indirect interest in the gains or profits of any investment authorized and made by the board, except insofar as any such member may be a member or beneficiary of the system. No member of the board shall, directly or indirectly, for himself or as an agent, in any manner use the funds, monies or deposits of the system, except to make such current and necessary payments therefrom as are authorized by the board; nor shall any member of the board become an endorser or surety or in any manner an obligor for monies loaned by or borrowed from the system. Without limitation, all board members and contractors of the board shall avoid actual or potential conflicts of interest and the appearance of actual or potential conflicts of interest. 
(Code 1973, § 31-221; Code 1988, § 30-59; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 7, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-60. - Fiscal officer; funds generally; combination of funds with funds of fire and police retirement system. 
The chief financial officer or such other institutional custodian as may be appointed by the board shall be the custodian of all of the funds created by this article. For investment purposes only, the funds created by this article may be combined with the funds of the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System; all registered securities in such combined funds shall be registered in the name "City of Portsmouth, Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System" and every change in registration, by reason of sale, assignment, transfer or disposal of such securities shall be accomplished by the signature of the chief financial officer and securities shall be delivered by him when directed so to do by resolution of the board. The custodian of the combined funds shall keep such records as may be necessary accurately to determine at any time the proportions of the total funds representing the funds of the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System and the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System respectively. Allocation of investment income, capital gains and losses, and expenses of administration of the combined funds among the two systems shall be made by the custodian in the ratio of the amounts of the funds in each of the respective systems to the combined total amount of funds in both systems. All payments from such funds shall be made by checks issued upon orders signed by such person as is designated for the purpose of the board. No order shall be signed unless it has previously been authorized by the board, which authorization shall be recorded on the records of the board. 
(Code 1973, § 31-222; Code 1988, § 30-60; Ord. No. 1995-81, §§ 1, 2, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 8, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-61. - Medical examiners. 
The board shall, from time to time, employ one or more physicians, practicing in the city, upon such terms and conditions as it may prescribe, who shall be known as the "medical examiner" and whose duty it shall be to pass upon all medical examinations required under this article or by the board, and to investigate all health or medical statements and certificates made by or in behalf of any person in connection with the payment of money to such person under this article, and shall report in writing to the board his or their conclusions and recommendations upon all matters referred to him or them. 
(Code 1973, § 31-223; Code 1988, § 30-61)  
Secs. 30-62—30-75. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - MEMBERSHIP 
 
Sec. 30-76. - Composition. 
Membership in this system as of any date after June 30, 1967, shall consist of all the employees except those who had attained their normal retirement date at the date of employment, and all former employees who were at any time members of the system and whose membership in the system had not been terminated under the provisions of this article. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, no employee shall be a member of the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System except by making a valid election for transfer from the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System prior to December 1, 1984; nor shall any employee hired or (rehired) on or after December 1, 1984 be included as a member. In addition, any retiree of the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System who as of November 30, 1984, is employed by an employer who participates in the Virginia Retirement System (VRS) shall be transferred to that retirement system for the purpose of payments of pensions. No city council member whose first term of office commences after December 1, 2016 shall qualify for membership in the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System by virtue of his or her service on city council. 
(Code 1973, § 31-229; Code 1988, § 30-76; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 9, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-77. - Period of membership; cessation of membership. 
(a)  Each employee who becomes a member of the system shall continue to be a member so long as he remains an employee and so long thereafter as he is entitled to future benefits under any provision of the system. Not in limitation but in amplification of the foregoing, the membership of any person in the system shall cease: 
(1)  Upon his termination of service as an employee, other than by retirement, before he has become vested under the conditions as stated in section 30-116; provided however, that for the purposes of this section the entrance of a member into authorized leave of absence shall not constitute termination of service as an employee; provided the member reenters service as an employee at the expiration of the period of authorized leave, and the entrance of a member into the armed forces of the United States shall not constitute termination of service as an employee; provided the member's service in such armed forces qualifies as creditable service under section 30-99; 
(2)  Upon the cessation of his retirement allowance, unless in such event he immediately again becomes an employee; or 
(3)  Upon his death. 
(b)  Should any person terminate service as an employee other than by retirement under the provisions of this article, after he has completed the number of years of creditable service required for entitlement to benefits under section 30-116; and should such person at any time again become an employee, any benefits becoming payable under the provisions of this article shall be determined on the basis of the total creditable years of service combined for all such periods of employment. 
(c)  Anything to the contrary herein notwithstanding, the membership of any person shall not cease by virtue of the fact that he became eligible for membership in the state supplemental retirement system upon employment by or transfer to the offices of the commissioner of the revenue or the city treasurer upon or within 60 days of July 1, 1959. The membership of any such person shall cease if his employment in the offices of the commissioner of the revenue or the city treasurer thereafter terminates for any reason other than death. 
(d)  Anything to the contrary herein notwithstanding, the membership of any person shall not cease by virtue of the fact that he became eligible for membership in the state supplemental retirement system upon transfer of the department of public health of the city to the state health department effective July 1, 1960. The membership of any such person shall cease if his employment in the state health department thereafter terminates for any reason other than death, retirement or resignation to accept immediate employment with the city in a position covered by the provisions of this article. Service with the state health department by any such person shall be considered as creditable service under this article when determining eligibility for ordinary disability retirement, service connected disability retirement, and additional death benefits under sections 30-124 and 30-125, but such service shall not be considered as creditable service when computing allowances under this article. 
(e)  The retirement allowance payable to any member who retires pursuant to the provisions of subsection 30-116(a) and who returns to employment with the city shall not terminate upon re-employment. At the time of re-employment, the member shall become a member of the Virginia Retirement System, subject to the vesting and other requirements of that System. 
(Code 1973, § 31-230; Code 1988, § 30-77; Ord. No. 2015-09, § 1, 3-3-2015 )  
Sec. 30-78. - Statement of facts as to status as member. 
Under such rules and regulations as are adopted by the board, each member, or someone in his behalf, shall file with the board, in such form as the board may prescribe, a statement of facts pertaining to his status as a member, which shall include a detailed description of all service rendered as an employee, and such other information as the board may require. Until such statement is filed, no member or his beneficiary shall be eligible to receive any benefits under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 31-236; Code 1988, § 30-78)  
Secs. 30-79—30-95. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CREDITABLE SERVICE 
 
Sec. 30-96. - Determination. 
The board shall determine by appropriate rules and regulations how much service in any year is the equivalent of a year of service, but in no case shall it allow credit for more than one year of service for all service rendered in any period of 12 consecutive months. 
(Code 1973, § 31-237; Code 1988, § 30-96)  
Sec. 30-97. - Effective of cessation of membership. 
When membership ceases, an employee shall thereafter lose all right to any retirement allowance or benefits under this article arising from service prior to the date of cessation of membership; except as hereinafter provided. Forfeitures shall not be applied to increase the benefits of any member. Funds freed through forfeitures that arise for any reason shall only be used to reduce employer contribution and to pay reasonable administrative expenses of the system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-238; Code 1988, § 30-97; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 10, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-98. - Inclusion of former service. 
(a)  Any person who was formerly a member of the system and who ceased to be a member upon becoming a member of the Virginia Retirement System may, upon again becoming an employee, be restored to membership in the system and have his previous time as a member counted as creditable service provided: 
(1)  He has remained in continuous service with the city and combined city-state office, and 
(2)  Verification of previous time as a member can be shown subject to the approval of the board. 
(b)  Creditable service for a period of membership in the Virginia Retirement System is subject to the provisions of section 30-100. 
(Code 1973, § 31-239; Code 1988, § 30-98)  
Sec. 30-99. - Inclusion of service in armed forces. 
Any service of a member of the armed forces of the United States commencing in a period of war or national emergency, or as a result of or to anticipate conscription in other periods, shall be included as creditable service; provided, that the member was in service as an employee, immediately prior to entry into such armed forces; and further provided, that he resumed service as an employee within 90 days of the date on which he had the right of release from such armed forces, or within such longer period, if any as provided by the laws of the United States applicable thereto. 
(Code 1973, § 31-240; Code 1988, § 30-99)  
Sec. 30-100. - Inclusion of service under the Virginia Retirement System. 
With respect to any member who is employed full-time by the city at the time of making application hereunder for service credits and who was a member of the former Virginia Retirement System, currently the Virginia Retirement System, immediately prior to becoming a member of this system, and whose membership in the Virginia Retirement System has ceased through withdrawal of the individual's contributions thereunder, the period of time during which the individual was a member of the Virginia Retirement System shall be included as creditable service hereunder, provided the individual terminates membership in said system and pays into the retirement system an actuarially determined amount deemed to be correct and neutral by the retirement board with regard to funding the projected additional retirement allowance to be received by the member through the purchase of such additional service credit. Such amount paid into the retirement system by the member under the provisions of this section shall remain as assets of the retirement system and shall not be considered as employee contributions, any other provisions of this article to the contrary notwithstanding. Effective July 1, 2011, a member shall be deemed to be employed on a full-time basis if classified as such according to the employer's payroll system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-241; Code 1988, § 30-100; Ord. No. 2005-93, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 2017-23 , § 1(Exh. A), 4-25-2017)  
Sec. 30-101. - Inclusion of service under the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System. 
Any person who was formerly a member of the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System shall be granted creditable service for the period he was a member of such system provided he has remained in continuous service with the city and does not withdraw his contributions, if any, to such system or if he has made such a withdrawal pays into this system the amount of contributions he previously withdrew from such system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-242; Code 1988, § 30-101)  
Secs. 30-102—30-115. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - BENEFITS 
 
Sec. 30-116. - Service retirement. 
(a)  Any member in service who has attained the age of 50 and who has attained the number of years of creditable service required for entitlement to benefits under the vesting provisions of this section may retire at any time then or thereafter upon written notification to the board, made by the member or his employer, setting forth at what time the retirement is to become effective; provided that such effective date shall be after his last day of service, but shall not be more than 90 days prior to or subsequent to the filing of such notice. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) of this section to the contrary notwithstanding, any member who, for the two-year period immediately before retirement, was employed in a bona fide executive or a high policy-making position, as that term is defined in the Age Discrimination Employment Act (29 USCS 621 et seq.), attaining age 70 shall be retired forthwith. 
(c)  Any member who terminates service as an employee prior to retirement and who complies with one of the requirements set forth in subsections (c)(1), (2), (3), (4) or (5) of this section, and who has attained the age of 60, may retire at any time then or thereafter under the provision of subsection (a) of this section. If such member shall have terminated service prior to July 1, 1994, he shall receive a retirement allowance calculated on the basis of the benefits in effect on the date of his termination of service. 
(1)  The member terminated prior to July 1, 1973, but after the attainment of age 50 and the completion of 20 years of creditable service; 
(2)  The member terminated after June 30, 1973, and after the completion of ten years of creditable service; 
(3)  Membership began before July 1, 1977 and the member terminated after June 30, 1974 and after the completion of five years of creditable service; 
(4)  Membership began after June 30, 1977, and termination occurred after the completion of ten years creditable service; 
(5)  Membership began after June 30, 1991, and termination occurred after the completion of five years of creditable service. 
Provided, however, that no such member shall be entitled to the benefits of this subsection if his supervisor certifies that his service was terminated because of dishonesty, malfeasance, or misfeasance in office. Such certification may be appealed to the board, and its decision shall be final. 
(d)  Any member in service who has attained the age of 50, and who has attained not less than 30 years of creditable service, may retire at any time then or thereafter upon written notification to the board, made by the member or his employer, setting forth the time the retirement is to become effective; provided that such effective date shall be after his last day of service, but shall not be more than 90 days prior to or subsequent to the filing of such notice. 
(e)  Any member in service who has attained the age of 50, and who has at least ten years of creditable service, may retire with a reduction in benefits at any time upon written notification to the board, made by the member or his employer, setting forth the time the retirement is to become effective; provided that such effective date shall be after his last day of service, but shall not be more than 90 days prior to or subsequent to the filing of such notice. 
(f)  Upon a showing of good cause, the board may waive the 90-day notification requirement of subsections (a), (d) and (e) of this section relating to the period after termination of service. For purposes of this subsection, good cause shall be deemed to exist if a member who is otherwise eligible to apply for service retirement has first applied for disability retirement, and the application has been denied. 
(Code 1973, § 31-262; Code 1988, § 30-116; Ord. No. 1988-20, § 1, 2-23-1988; Ord. No. 1988-21, § 4, 2-23-1988; Ord. No. 1991-46, § 2, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1994-97, § 1, 10-11-1994; Ord. No. 1995-60, § 1, 5-9-1995; Ord. No. 1998-42, § 1, 9-8-1998; Ord. No. 2000-2, § 1, 1-11-2000)  
Sec. 30-117. - Service retirement allowance. 
(a)  Upon the retirement, as provided in subsections 30-116(a) and (b), on or after July 1, 1977, of a member who either has attained his normal retirement date or has attained age 50 and who has completed the number of years of creditable service required for entitlement to benefits under the vesting provisions of subsection 30-116(c), the member shall receive an annual retirement allowance, payable at least monthly to him during his lifetime, the amount of which shall be two percent of his average final compensation multiplied by the number of years of creditable service. 
(b)  Upon his retirement as provided in section 30-116(c) on or after July 1, 1973, a member shall receive an annual retirement allowance payable at least monthly to him during his lifetime the amount of which, before and after his normal retirement date, shall be determined in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, except that if the member terminated service as an employee prior to July 1, 1974, and has completed less than 20 years of creditable service, the allowance as computed shall be reduced to a percentage of itself in accordance with the following table: 
Completed Years of 
Creditable Service 	Applicable 
Percentage 
Ten but less than 11 	50 
Eleven but less than 12 	55 
Twelve but less than 13 	60 
Thirteen but less than 14 	65 
Fourteen but less than 15 	70 
Fifteen but less than 16 	75 
Sixteen but less than 17 	80 
Seventeen but less than 18 	85 
Eighteen but less than 19 	90 
Nineteen but less than 20 	95 
 
(c)  If after termination of service and prior to retirement, as provided in section 30-116(c), subsection (a) of this section is amended, the member's allowance calculation shall be based on the amended subsections in effect as of the date of retirement. 
(d)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, if a member's retirement allowance is payable under one of the options of section 30-128 the amount and duration thereof shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of the applicable option. 
(e)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, any person whose membership began on or after his 50th birthday and after July 1, 1977, shall not be eligible for or receive a retirement allowance as provided for herein unless the member be in service at his normal retirement date. 
(f)  Upon retirement as provided in section 30-116(d), the member shall receive an annual retirement allowance, payable at least monthly during his lifetime, the amount of which shall be determined in the same manner as for retirement at his normal retirement date with the years of creditable service and average final compensation being determined as of the date of his actual retirement. 
(g)  In addition to the allowance payable under subsections (a) through (d) of this section, a member retiring on or after July 1, 1992, but before July 1, 1993, shall receive an additional allowance equal to monthly payments of $100.00 from date of retirement until his 62nd birthday. A member retiring on or after July 1, 1993, shall receive an allowance equal to monthly payments of $200.00 from the date of retirement until his 62nd birthday. A member retiring on or after July 1, 1994, shall receive an allowance equal to monthly payments of $200.00 from the date of retirement until his 65th birthday. This subsection shall not apply to sections 30-119, 30-121, 30-122, 30-124, 30-125 and 30-127 of this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 31-263; Code 1988, § 30-117; Ord. No. 1988-20, § 2, 2-23-1988; Ord. No. 1992-34, § 1, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 1993-40, § 1, 5-25-1993; Ord. No. 1994-39, § 1, 5-24-1994; Ord. No. 1994-40(1), § 1, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 2000-2, § 2, 1-11-2000 ; Ord. No. 2013-31, § 1, 5-28-2013)  
Sec. 30-118. - Ordinary disability retirement. 
(a)  Any member, in service or within 90 days after termination of service, who has five or more years of creditable service may, at any time on or after July 1, 1973, and before his normal retirement date, retire on account of disability not compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act upon written notification to the board made by the member or his employer, setting forth at which time the retirement is to become effective; provided, that such effective date shall be after the last day of service but shall not be more than 90 days prior to the date of such notification; and provided further, the examiner, after a medical examination of such member, shall certify: 
(1)  That such member is, and has been continuously since such effective date, if prior to the filing of such notice, mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty. 
(2)  That such incapacity is likely to be permanent. 
(3)  That such member should be retired. 
(4)  That such member, at the time of his employment by the city, was not eligible for or receiving retirement allowance or pension by reason of disability from any other employer. 
(b)  For good cause shown, the board may waive the 90-day period set forth in subsection (a) of this section relating to the period following the termination of service. For purposes of this section, good cause shall exist and the board shall waive such notification period if: (i) the member would otherwise qualify for disability retirement but for failing to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, and (ii) the medical examiner, acting solely in his own discretion after reviewing objective medical evidence of the disability and its cause, certifies that: (a) the disability and its cause existed on the date the member's employment was terminated, (b) the member had no knowledge of the existence of the disability and its cause at any time within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated, and (c) the member could not, with reasonable inquiry, have ascertained the existence of the disability within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated. 
(Code 1973, § 31-264; Code 1988, § 30-118; Ord. No. 1998-42, § 2, 9-8-1998)  
Sec. 30-119. - Ordinary disability retirement allowance. 
(a)  Upon retirement, as provided in section 30-118, on or after July 1, 1977, a member shall receive an annual retirement allowance, payable at least monthly to him during his lifetime and continued disability in an amount equal to two percent of his average final compensation multiplied by the number of years of his "disability credited service" as herein defined. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the term "disability credited service" for any member shall be taken to mean the smallest of: 
(1)  Twice the member's actual period of creditable service; 
(2)  The member's period of creditable service plus ten years; 
(3)  The number of years of creditable service the member would have completed at age 50 if he had remained in service as an employee until then; if the member is over age 50 "disability credited service" shall be equal to the member's actual creditable service; 
(4)  Twenty-five years; if the member's actual creditable service is greater than 25 years, "disability credited service" shall be equal to the member's actual creditable service. 
(c)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, if a member's retirement allowance is payable under one of the options of section 30-128, the amount and duration thereof shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of the applicable option. 
(d)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, any person whose membership began on or after his 60th birthday, shall not be eligible for or receive a disability retirement allowance as provided for herein. 
(Code 1973, § 31-265; Code 1988, § 30-119; Ord. No. 2000-2, § 3, 1-11-2000; Ord. No. 2013-31, § 1, 5-28-2013)  
Sec. 30-120. - Service-connected disability retirement. 
(a)  Any member, in service or within 90 days after termination of service, may, at any time before his normal retirement date, retire on account of disability compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act upon written notification to the board, made by the member or his employer, setting forth at what time the retirement is to become effective; provided, that such effective date shall be after the last day of service and after the date the award of compensation under that act becomes final, but shall not be more than 90 days prior to the date of such notification; and provided further, the examiner, after a medical examination of such member, shall certify: 
(1)  That such member is, and has been continuously since such effective date, if prior to the filing of such notice, mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty. 
(2)  That such incapacity is likely to be permanent. 
(3)  That such member should be retired. 
(4)  That such member, at the time of his employment by the city, was not eligible for or receiving retirement allowance or pension by reason of disability from any other employer. 
(b)  For good cause shown, the board may waive the 90-day period set forth in subsection (a) of this section relating to the period following the termination of service. For purposes of this section, good cause shall exist and the board shall waive such notification period if: (i) the member would otherwise qualify for disability retirement but for failing to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, and (ii) the medical examiner, acting solely in his own discretion after reviewing objective medical evidence of the disability and its cause, certifies that: (a) the disability and its cause existed on the date the member's employment was terminated, (b) the member had no knowledge of the existence of the disability and its cause at any time within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated, and (c) the member could not, with reasonable inquiry, have ascertained the existence of the disability within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated. 
(Code 1973, § 31-266; Code 1988, § 30-120; Ord. No. 1998-42, § 2, 9-8-1998) 
State Law reference— Virginia Workers' Compensation Act, Code of Virginia, § 65.2-100 et seq.  
Sec. 30-121. - Service-connected disability retirement allowance. 
(a)  Upon his retirement as provided in section 30-120 on or after July 1, 1977, a member shall receive an annual retirement allowance, payable at least monthly to him during his lifetime and continued disability, in an amount determined as follows: 
(1)  With respect to any allowance falling due in a month before the member's normal retirement date, or in a month before the member's normal retirement date and before any social security allowance payment falling due that is based on the member's primary social security benefit, or before entitlement to total and permanent disability benefits under the social security act, two-thirds of the member's average final compensation; provided that the benefit payable under this subsection shall not be less than the amount that would have been payable under the provisions of section 30-119, as determined at the time of disability retirement. 
(2)  With respect to any allowance payment falling due after the member's normal retirement date, or in a month before the member's normal retirement date and after any social security allowance payment falling due is based on the member's primary social security benefit or after entitlement to total and permanent disability benefits under the social security act, an amount which when added to one-half of the initial annual amount of the primary social security benefit at his normal retirement date, or to one-half of the initial amount of any social security payment that is based on the member's primary social security benefit and falling due before the member's normal retirement, or to one-half of the amount of the primary total and permanent disability benefit under the social security act to which the member first became entitled, would equal two-thirds of the member's average final compensation; provided that the benefit payable under this subsection should not be less than the amount that would have been payable under the provisions of section 30-119. 
(b)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, if a member's retirement allowance is payable under one of the options of section 30-128 the amount and duration thereof shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of the applicable option. 
(c)  The compensation finally awarded to the member under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act or which is adjusted pursuant to that act shall be deducted from any allowance becoming payable under the provisions of this section, and the excess of the allowance, if any, shall be paid to the member. When the time for payment of compensation under such act has elapsed, the member shall thereafter receive the full amount of such allowance payable at least monthly during his lifetime and continued disability. 
(d)  Beginning July 1, 2006, and thereafter, in order to receive a service-connected disability retirement allowance, a member retiring on account of disability compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act shall participate in vocational rehabilitation following his or her release for light-duty occupations. This requirement shall not apply or will cease to apply if the member has attained or subsequently attains full service retirement eligibility as defined in sections 30-116, et seq. 
(Code 1973, § 31-267; Code 1988, § 30-121; Ord. No. 1992-34, § 2, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 2006-38, § 1, 5-9-2006)  
Sec. 30-121.1. - Reduction of health insurance rates for certain members after service-connected disability retirement. 
The annual health insurance rates of any member receiving a service-connected disability retirement allowance may be reduced to the rate paid by active employees, provided that: 
(1)  The member's service-connected disability retirement allowance is less than $20,000.00; and 
(2)  The member is enrolled in a city-provided health insurance plan. 
(Code 1988, § 30-121.1; Ord. No. 2005-97, § 1, 11-22-2005)  
Sec. 30-122. - Adjustments of retirement allowance. 
Any person receiving a retirement allowance under sections 30-117, 30-119, 30-121, 30-124(b), or section 30-128, shall, upon the annual prior approval of city council, receive an adjustment of retirement allowance as of July 1, each year, in an amount to be approved by the city council. The amount of the adjustment shall be determined as a percentage of the retirement allowance being received, including in percentage of the retirement allowance being received, including in percentage adjustments approved in prior years. Such adjustments shall be subject to the same conditions of payment as are applicable to the retirement allowance. In no case shall the operation of this section result in a reduction in the amount of any person's total amount below the amount of the retirement allowance that would have been payable in the absence of this section. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in no event shall city council approve or authorize adjustments to retirement allowances unless the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System is funded at no less than 80 percent of the actuarial accrued liability. 
(Code 1973, § 31-268; Code 1988, § 30-122; Ord. No. 1988-21, § 5, 2-23-1988; Ord. No. 2019-74 , § 1(Exh. A), 10-22-2019)  
Sec. 30-123. - Refund of accumulated contributions. 
(a)  Upon the retirement of a member or upon his termination of service as an employee, other than by death, he shall be paid, on demand, but not later than 90 days thereafter, the amount of his accumulated contributions, if any, in a lump sum; provided that if the amount of such accumulated contributions is less than $10.00, no such payment shall be made. 
(b)  Should a member die at any time while in service, the amount of his accumulated contributions shall be paid in a lump sum in accordance with section 30-129, provided that if the amount of such accumulated contributions is less than $10.00, no such payment shall be made. 
(c)  Notwithstanding provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the board may elect to refund all such accumulated contributions at any time if it finds that such action is in the best interests of the retirement system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-269; Code 1988, § 30-123)  
Sec. 30-124. - Ordinary death benefits. 
(a)  Should a member, who had one or more years of creditable service, die in service at any time before retirement from a cause not compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act, an additional benefit equal to $5,000.00 shall then be payable in a lump sum in accordance with section 30-129. 
(b)  Should a member die in service on or after July 1, 1977, who at any time has obtained a number of years of creditable service required for entitlement to benefits under the vesting provisions of section 30-116, from a cause not compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act, there shall be paid a retirement allowance to the first of the following listed persons who shall survive the member and in the priority listed herein: 
(1)  Widow or widower, pension payable during widowhood. 
(2)  Child or children under the age of 18 years, pension payable to age 18 for each child. 
(3)  Dependent mother or father. 
(4)  Dependent sister or brother. 
If there is more than one child, or more than one dependent parent or more than one dependent sister or brother, the pension shall be divided in a manner as the board may determine. Parents, brothers or sisters must receive more than 50-percent support from the member in order to be considered dependent for the purposes of this pension. Payments to a child or children under the age of 18 years shall be made only to a court-appointed guardian or administrator of the estate of the member.
