Such retirement allowance shall be payable to the first eligible person as stipulated and shall be an allowance, unless subsection (c) of this section is applicable, equal to one-half of the retirement allowance that would have been payable to the member had the member retired under the provisions of section 30-119 on the date of his death after having elected to have his allowance payable under the joint and last survivor option described in section 30-128(a)(1). If the member is under the age of 55 at the date of death, it shall be assumed for the purpose of the one-half joint and last survivor option calculation that the member be age 55 at the date of his death. Such allowance shall be in addition to any benefits provided for in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Should a member become eligible for service retirement in accordance with section 30-116 but continue as an employee, the member may, on a form prescribed by the board, and in advance of retirement, make an election of a joint and last survivor option as described in section 30-128(a)(1). The designated fraction of the option shall be any amount greater than one-half or 50 percent and equal to or less than 100 percent. If a member having made such a designation shall die in service before retirement from a cause not compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act there shall be paid a retirement allowance to the widow or widower equal to the designated option percent of the allowance that would have been payable to the member had the member retired under the provisions of section 30-116 on the date of his death with the option so designated; or the amount as accorded in subsection (b) of this section, whichever is greater. Upon retirement of the member, the member's retirement allowance shall be calculated to include the election previously designated, unless such retirement is for disability. The retirement allowance to be continued after the member's death to the widow or widower shall be limited to a maximum of one-half of the deceased allowance received by the member during the member's lifetime. In making an election of an option as provided under this subsection, a member may also elect a modification of the joint and last survivor option whereby a provision is made for no decrease in allowance should the member's spouse die before the retirement of the member, or a return to an undecreased allowance should the member's spouse die before the member died during retirement. Such modification shall be determined by an actuarial report as of the retirement of the member. 
(Code 1973, § 31-270; Code 1988, § 30-124)  
Sec. 30-125. - Additional benefits before retirement for service-connected cause. 
(a)  Should a member die in service at any time before retirement from a cause compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act, there shall be paid, in addition to any other benefits under this article, an annual allowance payable monthly to the widow of such member during her widowhood, if he leaves a widow, equal to one-half of the member's average final compensation. If he leaves no widow or the widow dies or remarries before the youngest child, if any, of the deceased member, has attained the age of 18 years, then such child or children, if any, under the age of 18 years, shall be paid such allowance until such child or children die or attain the age of 18 years, whichever shall first occur. If more than one child survives the deceased member, the allowance shall be divided among them in such manner as the board may determine. If the deceased member leaves neither widow nor child or children under the age of 18 years, then such allowance shall be paid to his parent wholly dependent upon him for support, divided in such manner as the board may determine, during the life of such parents; provided, however, that the amount of any allowance payable under his subsection shall be reduced by the amount of any social security benefits arising from coverage of the member under the Federal Social Security Act to which any such widow, child or parent may become entitled under the Federal Social Security Act, in effect at the member's death; and provided further, that if the total of the allowances payable under this subsection is less than the amount provided by section 30-124, the difference between such amount and such total shall be paid together with the last payment due under this subsection to the person entitled to receive the last payment. 
(b)  If neither widow, child or children nor wholly dependent parents survive such member, the benefits payable under this section shall be in the same amount and payable in the same manner as the benefits payable under section 30-124. 
(c)  The compensation awarded under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act for the death of such member shall be deducted from the benefit provided for in subsection (a) of this section, and the excess of the benefit, if any, shall be paid to the person specified in that subsection when the time for which payments of the compensation finally awarded under that act has elapsed, such person shall thereafter receive the full amount of the benefit payable as provided in that subsection. 
(Code 1973, § 31-271; Code 1988, § 30-125)  
Sec. 30-126. - Additional retirement benefits for judges of district courts. 
Every judge of the general district court or of the juvenile and domestic relations district court of this city who has attained the age of 70 years and has served for not less than ten years as a judge of any one or more of such courts and who retires or is retired from active service pursuant to the provisions of this article, upon such retirement, shall be paid in addition to any other benefits payable under this article a supplemental retirement allowance of $1,200.00 per year. The supplemental retirement allowance provided for in this section shall be paid in equal monthly installments. The payments provided herein shall be paid out of the general fund of the city and not out of the fund established by this article. The monies paid to such retired judges hereunder shall be deemed to be a gratuity and such payments shall cease at such time as the state shall provide a retirement system of such judges. 
(Code 1973, § 31-272; Code 1988, § 30-126)  
Sec. 30-127. - Death benefits after retirement or disability. 
(a)  Should a member who retired prior to July 1, 1967, die at any time after retirement but before receiving total retirement allowances provided in this article at least equal to his accumulated contributions as of his date of retirement, the difference between such accumulated contributions and such total allowances shall then be payable in a lump sum in accordance with section 30-129, unless the retirement allowance is then being paid in accordance with any of the option contained in section 30-128, as in effect at his date of retirement. 
(b)  Should a member who had at least one year of creditable service die after termination of service and before his normal retirement date, after having been continuously disabled from date of termination of service to date of death to such an extent that he would have qualified for disability retirement in accordance with section 30-118 or section 30-120 without regard to any creditable service requirements or actual retirement thereunder, provided that written notification of such disability is given to the board by the member, his employer or his beneficiary designated as provided in section 30-129 within one year after the member's termination of service, an additional benefit equal to $1,000.00 shall be payable in a lump sum in accordance with section 30-129. 
(Code 1973, § 31-273; Code 1988, § 30-127)  
Sec. 30-128. - Optional benefits. 
(a)  Each member who retires under any of the provisions of this article shall have the right at any time, not subsequent to the later of the effective date of the member's retirement or the date of the written notification to the board of the retirement of the member, to elect to have his retirement allowance payable under any one of the applicable options set forth in this section in lieu of the retirement allowance that would otherwise be payable to him. The member shall make any such election by written request to the board and such election shall be subject to the approval of the board. 
(1)  Joint and last survivor option. The member shall be provided a 50 percent spousal option at no cost to the member calculated on a spousal age difference of no younger than five years of the member. If the spouse is more than five years younger than the member, the member may elect to receive a decreased retirement allowance during his lifetime which represents the additional cost for a member's spouse who is younger than five years of the member. The member may also elect to receive a decreased allowance during his lifetime based on the additional cost of 75 percent or 100 percent spousal option. If the member's retirement is for disability, the retirement allowance to be continued after the member's death shall be limited to a maximum of one-half of the retirement allowance received by the member during his lifetime. 
A member retired prior to July 1, 1992, who at date of retirement elected a spousal option, shall receive an increase in pension equal to the cost of a 50 percent spousal option calculated on a spousal age difference of no younger than five years of the member. 
An unmarried member shall upon marriage, be provided a 50 percent spousal option, calculated on a spousal age difference of no younger than five years of the member provided that the member submit written notification to the board within 90 days after the marriage, and provided that evidence satisfactory to the board of the good health of the retired member is submitted with the notification. 
(2)  Social security option. If a member retires prior to his normal retirement date, he may elect to receive an increased retirement allowance up to his normal retirement date and a decreased retirement allowance thereafter, thereby providing a more nearly level retirement income when such decreased retirement allowance is added to his anticipated primary benefits under the social security act. 
(3)  Other options. The member may elect some other combination of benefits to the member and/or to such other beneficiary as the member shall designate, provided, however, that if the member's retirement is for disability, the election of the requirement allowance to be continued after the member's death should be limited to a maximum of one-half of the decreased retirement allowance received by the member during his lifetime. 
(b)  The election of a member of any one of the options stated in this section shall be null and void if the member dies prior to retirement, and the election by a member of the joint and last survivor option shall be null and void if the designated beneficiary dies before the member has retired. 
(c)  A member who has elected any one of the options stated in this section may, at any time prior to the later of the effective date of the member's retirement or the date of written notification to the board of retirement of the member, revoke such an election by written notification to the board. 
(d)  A retired member who has elected or has been provided a joint and last survivor option, may by written notification to the board, elect a different spousal recipient if the following occurs: (1) the original spousal recipient has died; or (2) a final decree of divorce of the retired member from the original spousal recipient has been entered permitting the revocation of the joint and last survivor option; (3) evidence satisfactory to the board of the good health of the retired member is submitted with the notification; and (4) the notification to the board of the change in election occurs within 90 days of the occurrence of one or two or within 90 days after remarriage. Except as provided above, if the provisions of this subsection are invoked by a retired member on the basis of the member having been divorced from his former spousal recipient and the marriage had been of a duration of 20 years or more, the provisions of this subsection shall not be applicable until the death or remarriage of the former spouse unless such spouse consents in writing to the revocation. If such an election is made as a result of the death or divorce of the spousal recipient, the benefit payable to the retired member may be adjusted retroactively for a period of not more than 30 days from the date the board first receives notification of the member's election to make such a change. 
(Code 1973, § 31-274; Code 1988, § 30-128; Ord. No. 1992-34, § 3, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 1999-20, § 1, 7-27-1999)  
Sec. 30-129. - Payment of death benefits. 
All lump sum payments falling due under this article upon the death of a member or former member shall be paid to such person, if any, as the member shall have designated to be the beneficiary thereof, otherwise to the executors or administrators of the member. Any such beneficiary designation shall be made in writing and filed with the board in such manner as may be required by the board. Any such designation may be changed from time to time by the member by his filing with the board a new written designation. 
(Code 1973, § 31-275; Code 1988, § 30-129)  
Sec. 30-130. - Medical examinations of beneficiary of disability retirement allowance. 
Once each year during the first five years following the retirement of a member on a disability retirement allowance and at least once in every three-year period thereafter, the board may require any such member prior to his normal retirement date to undergo a medical examination by the examiner. Should such a member refuse to submit to undergo a medical examination by the examiner, his retirement allowance shall be discontinued until his withdrawal of such refusal, and should such refusal continue for one year, all his rights to any further disability allowance shall cease. 
(Code 1973, § 31-276; Code 1988, § 30-130)  
Sec. 30-131. - Reduction of disability retirement allowance. 
(a)  Whenever a member receiving a disability retirement allowance subsequently becomes engaged in gainful occupation, the disability allowance shall be reduced by the amount of income received which exceeds the difference between the disability retirement allowance and the amount of wages or salary the member would have been entitled to had his employment progressed in the same range and grade with credit for the level of seniority he would have attained had he not been disabled. Such reduction in disability retirement allowance shall continue until his retirement date. 
(b)  Should the examiner report and certify to the board at any time that any member receiving a disability retirement allowance is able to engage in gainful occupation paying an amount equal to or more than his average final compensation as described in subsection (a) of this section and should the board find that such member shall have refused any employment considered by the board suitable to his capacity, he shall not be entitled to any such allowance during the continuance of such refusal, unless in the option of the board, such refusal was justified. 
(c)  At least once each year during the first five years following retirement of a member on a disability retirement allowance, and at least once in every two-year period thereafter, the board shall require any such member, prior to his normal retirement date, to submit to the secretary of the board such information as the board may deem appropriate concerning any gainful employment, and the compensation therefor, in which the member may be participating or in which the member may have participated subsequent to his retirement from service. In addition to the foregoing requirement, any member on a disability retirement allowance shall, within 30 days of obtaining employment report to the secretary of the board the date and place of such employment and the amount of earnings. Should such member 
refuse to submit the information as directed by this section, his retirement allowance shall be discontinued until his withdrawal of such refusal, and should such refusal continue for a period of one year, all his rights to any further disability allowance shall cease. Should the board determine that an overpayment of a disability allowance has been made, such overpayment shall be corrected by a suspension of all or a part of the disability allowance for such period of time as may be necessary to complete such repayment. 
(Code 1973, § 31-277; Code 1988, § 30-131; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 11, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-132. - Cessation of disability retirement allowance. 
Should any member receiving a disability retirement allowance be at any time prior to his normal retirement date in service, his disability retirement allowance shall cease and he shall thereafter resume his active membership in the system. Any service on the basis of which his disability retirement allowance was computed shall thereafter be counted as creditable service and in addition, the period of disability retirement shall be counted as creditable service. 
(Code 1973, § 31-278; Code 1988, § 30-132)  
Sec. 30-133. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-31, § 2, adopted May 28, 2013, repealed § 30-133, which pertained to Social Security benefits and derived from Code 1973, § 31-379; Code 1988, § 30-133.  
Sec. 30-134. - Changes or errors in records resulting in erroneous payments. 
Should any change or error in records result in any member or beneficiary receiving from the system more or less than he would have been entitled to receive had the records been correct, then on discovery of any such error the board shall correct the same, and as far as practicable shall adjust the payments in such a manner that the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which such member or beneficiary was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(Code 1973, § 31-280; Code 1988, § 30-134)  
DIVISION 6. - MAXIMUM BENEFITS AND OTHER LIMITATIONS AND SPECIAL RULES 
 
Sec. 30-135. - Limitation on creditable compensation taken into account. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, except in the case of an employee who first became a member before July 1, 1996, creditable compensation taken into account for purposes of determining benefits under the system shall be limited by the compensation limit pursuant to Section 401(a)(17) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. For purposes of applying the limitation applicable to each year, the limit for a plan year shall be the limitation in effect for the calendar year in which the plan year begins determined without increases in the limitation for subsequent years. An employee who first became a member before July 1, 1996 shall be considered a grandfathered employee for purposes of Section 401(a)(17) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 12, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-136. - Limitation on annual benefit and special vesting rules. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the annual benefit under the system of any member and any related death or other benefit shall, if necessary, be reduced to the extent required by Section 415(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, as adjusted by the Secretary of the Treasury pursuant to Section 415(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, all as applicable to governmental plans. Notwithstanding the foregoing, adjustments in the dollar limitation under Section 415(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall only be applicable to benefits provided by this system with respect to a member who is an eligible employee at the time the adjustment is effective. In comparing the system benefit to the dollar limitation, system benefits must be converted to an annual benefit (as defined in Section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986) by, except as provided below, converting a benefit payable in a form other than a straight life annuity to an actuarially equivalent straight life annuity before applying the limitations of this section. The annual benefit does not include any benefits attributable to employee contributions or the assets transferred from a qualified plan that was not maintained by a participating employer. No actuarial adjustment to the benefit is required for (i) the value of a joint and survivor annuity, (ii) the value of benefits that are not directly related to retirement benefits (such as the qualified disability benefit, pre-retirement death benefits, and post-retirement medical benefits), and (iii) the value of post-retirement cost-of-living increases made in accordance with Section 415(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and Inc. Tax Regs. Section 1.415-3(c)(2)(iii). Section 415(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the regulations thereunder are hereby incorporated by reference. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, for purposes of adjusting any benefit or limitation under Section 415(b)(2)(B), (C), or (D) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, the applicable actuarial adjustment factors shall be based on the following assumptions: 
(1)  Mortality according to the table prescribed in Rev. Rul. 2001-62, the 1994 Group Annuity Reserving Table (94 GAR). Notwithstanding the foregoing, the mortality table used for this purpose shall automatically be the table specified in any future revenue rulings or federal regulations that amend or supersede Revenue Ruling 2001-62 by specifying a new mortality table for this purpose; and 
(2)  Interest at the rate prescribed in Section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and the regulations and other guidance published thereunder. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a member shall be fully vested in his retirement allowance upon the attainment of his normal retirement date. 
(Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 12, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-137. - Required minimum distributions. 
On and after January 1, 1989, the retirement allowance of a member who has terminated employment shall begin no later than the later of (i) April 1 of the calendar year following the calendar year that the member attains seventy and one-half years of age or (ii) April 1 of the calendar year following the calendar year in which the member terminates employment. If the member fails, following reasonable notification, to elect a form of payment by such required beginning date, the retirement allowance shall be paid as a single life annuity. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, Section 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code, including as such section is amended or renumbered, or any successor provision thereto, and the regulations thereunder applicable to governmental plans are incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 12, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-138. - Rollover rules. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter to the contrary that would otherwise limit a distributee's election, a distributee may elect, at the time and in the manner prescribed by the board, to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee in a direct rollover. The terms "eligible rollover distribution", "eligible retirement plan" and "distributee" have the meanings prescribed by Section 401(a)(31) of the Internal Revenue Code (including as such section is amended or renumbered, or any successor provision thereto) and the regulations thereunder, as may be amended. Such terms shall include non-spouse designated beneficiaries and inherited individual retirement accounts in accordance with Section 402(c)(11) of the Internal Revenue Code (as such section may be amended or renumbered, or any successor provision thereto) and the regulations thereunder applicable to governmental plans. In the event of a mandatory cash-out, as that term is defined under the Internal Revenue Code and the regulations thereunder applicable to governmental plans, greater than $1,000, if the member does not elect to have such distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the member in a direct rollover or to receive the distribution directly in accordance with this section, then the board shall pay the distribution in a direct rollover to an individual retirement plan designated by the board that satisfies the safe harbor provision of Code of Virginia, § 51.1-124.30.F, and such provisions shall be interpreted and administered in accordance therewith. 
(Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 12, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-139. - Military service. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any provision of this article to the contrary, benefits and service credit with respect to qualified military service will be provided in accordance with Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, and the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 (USERRA). 
(b)  To the extent not inconsistent with the foregoing, the following special rules shall apply in case of reemployed veterans notwithstanding the provisions of the system: 
(1)  A reemployed veteran shall not be considered to have incurred a break in service by reason of his qualified military service. 
(2)  Qualified military service of a reemployed veteran shall be counted as service for vesting under the plan. 
(c)  To the extent required by USERRA or Section 401(a)(37) of the Internal Revenue Code for purposes of determining vesting in accrued benefits and entitlement to death benefits under the system, in the event a member ceases to be an employee in order to perform qualified military service and dies on or after January 1, 2007 while performing qualified military service, the member's death shall be considered to have occurred while he was an employee and, if he ceased to be an eligible employee in order to perform qualified military service, while he was an eligible employee so that his beneficiaries are entitled to any additional benefits provided under the system (other than benefit accruals relating to the period of qualified military service unless otherwise expressly provided), including without limitation any additional or enhanced vesting or death benefits, had the member resumed employment with the participating employer and then terminated employment on account of death. 
(d)  For purposes of this paragraph, the following terms have the following meanings: 
(1)  Qualified military service means any service in the uniformed services (as defined in Chapter 43 of Title 38 of the United States Code) by any individual if such individual is entitled to reemployment rights under such chapter with respect to such service and to the employer. 
(2)  Reemployed veteran means a person who is or, but for his qualified military service, would have been a member at some time during his qualified military service and who is entitled to the restoration benefits and protections of the USERRA with respect to his qualified military service and the system. 
(Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 12, 11-22-2016)  
Secs. 30-140—30-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PORTSMOUTH FIRE AND POLICE RETIREMENT SYSTEM  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 30-151. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, unless otherwise required by the context, the following words and terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
Accumulated contributions means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member as contributions to the system, together with interest thereon at the rate of two percent per annum from the end of the fiscal year in which each such contribution was made. 
Actuarial equivalent means a benefit of equal value when computed upon the basis of such actuarial tables as are adopted by the board. Such benefits shall not be subject to employer discretion. The actuarial tables adopted by the board for this purpose are incorporated into this article as part of the system's plan document. 
Average final compensation means the average annual creditable compensation of a member during his 36 highest consecutive months of creditable service or during his entire period of his creditable service if less than 36 months. 
Beneficiary means any person entitled to receive benefits of any kind under this article because of the death of a member. 
Board means the board of trustees of the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System as provided for in sections 30-176 to 30-184. 
Creditable compensation means the full compensation payable to an employee working the full working time for his position; provided, however, that if an employee receives increases in compensation in the last four years of creditable service, not related to promotion, which exceed the average compensation increase in the same period received by other employees holding comparable positions, or which, in case there are not comparable positions, exceed the average percentage compensation increase in the same period received by all other employees, such excess shall be deducted in computing creditable compensation if the board finds after consideration of all circumstances that the primary purpose of such compensation increase was to increase the retirement benefit of such employee. 
Creditable service means for any member the most recent period of continuous service as an employee rendered by the member plus membership service for which credit is allowed under this article; provided, however, that periods before and after periods of unpaid authorized leave shall be included as creditable service but the period of leave itself shall not be credited as creditable service. In addition, under regular service retirement and excluding deferred or vested retirement, one-half unused sick leave as of the effective date of retirement shall be added to creditable service. 
Employee means every firefighter or police officer regularly employed in the police and fire departments of the city on a full-time basis. The city manager, having the authority to appoint, discipline and remove firefighters and police officers pursuant to the city charter, and who was appointed prior to July 26, 1994, shall be deemed to be an employee as defined herein. A member of a local retirement system who, through election to a position as a constitutional officer, is no longer eligible for membership in the local system, and who, prior to such election has accumulated within that system more than half the total service credits necessary to become eligible for full normal retirement benefits, with the concurrence of the city council, may also be deemed an employee as defined herein, in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 51.1-132. The word "employee" shall not include any person who is eligible for membership in the Virginia Retirement System, except as permitted by Code of Virginia, § 51.1-132, or the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System or who enters into an agreement with the city for inclusion in a deferred compensation retirement plan, which agreement specifically prohibits inclusion in other retirement systems established by the city. Effective July 1, 2011, a firefighter or police officer shall be deemed to be regularly employed on a full-time basis if classified as such according to the employer's payroll system. 
Employer means the city or the authority of the city having the power to appoint an employee to office or employment. 
Examiner means the medical examiners provided for in sections 30-176 to 30-184. 
Member means any employee who has been included in the membership of the system as provided in section 30-201, and whose membership has not terminated under the provisions of section 30-202. 
Normal retirement date means the first of the month next following or coinciding with the 55th birthday of a member. 
Retirement allowance means the retirement payments to which a member is entitled as provided in this article. 
Service means service as an employee for which compensation is paid by the employer. 
System means the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System provided for in this article. The provisions of this article are intended to meet the requirements of Section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code (as such section may be amended or renumbered, or any successor provision thereto) and the regulations thererunder applicable to governmental plans. 
(Code 1973, § 31-91; Code 1988, § 30-151; Ord. No. 1990-58, § 1, 6-12-1990; Ord. No. 1991-46, § 3, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1994-40(1), § 1, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 1994-76, § 1, 7-26-1994; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 13, 11-22-2016; Ord. No. 2017-23 , § 2(Exh. A), 4-25-2017) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 30-152. - Short title of article. 
The short title of this article is "Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System." 
(Code 1973, § 31-92; Code 1988, § 30-152)  
Sec. 30-153. - Established; name. 
There is hereby established a retirement system for employees to be known as the "Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System" by and in which name it shall, pursuant to the provisions of this article, transact all of its business. 
(Code 1973, § 31-93; Code 1988, § 30-153)  
Sec. 30-154. - Duties of appointing authorities. 
The authority having the power to hire the services of a member shall keep such records and from time to time shall furnish such information as the board may require in the discharge of its duties. Upon employment of a member, the authority shall inform the member of his duties and obligations in connection with the system as a condition of employment. 
(Code 1973, § 31-94; Code 1988, § 30-154)  
Sec. 30-155. - Acceptance of employment as consent to provisions of article. 
Every member shall be deemed to consent and agree to all the provisions of this article and any amendments thereto, and payment of salary or compensation shall be a full and complete discharge of all claims for services rendered by such person during the period covered by such payment, except as to any benefits provided by this article. 
(Code 1973, § 31-95; Code 1988, § 30-155)  
Sec. 30-156. - Contributions—By members. 
No contributions shall be made by or required of members of the system. Contributions by a member made prior to July 1, 1967, shall be retained in the assets of the system until the member ceases to be an employee. 
(Code 1973, § 31-134; Code 1988, § 30-156)  
Sec. 30-157. - Same—By employer. 
(a)  The employer shall contribute annually an amount equal to the sum of the normal contribution and the accrued liability contribution if any. The normal contribution for any year shall be determined as percentage of the creditable compensation of the members for such year, such percentage being referred to as the normal contribution rate. The accrued liability contribution shall be the dollar amount determined in subsection (c) of this section. 
(b)  The normal contribution rate shall be defined as the percentage of the total annual creditable compensation of the members that is represented by the annual normal cost required to provide the benefits of the system, other than any future adjustments as provided for in section 30-122, computed in accordance with the recognized actuarial principles on the basis of methods and assumptions approved by the board. 
(c)  The accrued liability contribution shall be defined as the level annual contribution necessary to amortize the then remaining unfunded accrued liability over a period as follows: 
Actuarial Valuation Date 	Amortization Period 
July 1, 2004 	35 years 
July 1, 2005 	34 years 
July 1, 2006 	30 years 
July 1, 2007 	30 years 
July 1, 2008 and later 	to June 30, 2037 
 
The unfunded accrued liability at any particular time shall be determined, in accordance with recognized actuarial principles on the basis of methods and assumptions approved by the board, as the excess, if any, of the then present value of benefits, including any adjustments as provided for in section 30-122, expected to be paid in the future to retired and not-yet-retired members or their beneficiaries over the sum of the value of the assets then held in the retirement account plus the then present value of the normal contributions expected to be made in the future by the employer. 
(d)  The normal contribution rate and the accrued liability contribution shall be determined from the results of each valuation of the system using the actuarial basis adopted by the board and shall continue in force until a new valuation is made. The accrued liability contribution shall be adjusted each year based on the amount of the adjustment approved by the city council for that year using the actuarial basis adopted by the board. 
(e)  The board shall certify to the city manager the normal contribution rate and the accrued liability contribution and every change made therein from time to time. 
(f)  The aggregate employer contribution for any year shall be at least sufficient, when combined with the amount then held in the retirement account, to provide the benefits payable from the account during the current year. 
(Code 1973, § 31-135; Code 1988, § 30-157; Ord. No. 1990-56, § 1, 6-12-1990; Ord. No. 2000-15, § 1, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 2004-16, § 2, 3-9-2004)  
Sec. 30-158. - Retirement account. 
All of the funds and assets of the system shall be held in single retirement account, in which shall be accumulated all contributions by the members and by the employer, and to which all income from the invested funds and assets of the system shall be credited. From this account shall be paid the investment management fees, and the death benefits and retirement allowances provided for in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 31-141; Code 1988, § 30-158; Ord. No. 1990-47, § 1, 5-22-1990)  
Sec. 30-159. - Cash deposits to meet disbursements. 
For the purpose of meeting disbursements for retirement allowances and other payments, there may be kept available cash on deposit in one or more banks or trust companies that are designated by the council as depositories for funds of the city. The board shall not be liable for any loss sustained as to such funds that are on deposit in such banks or trust companies. 
(Code 1973, § 31-142; Code 1988, § 30-159; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 14, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-160. - Protection against fraud. 
Any person who shall knowingly make any false statement or shall falsify or permit to be falsified any record of the system in any attempt to defraud the system shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 31-96; Code 1988, § 30-160) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 30-161. - Alteration, amendment or repeal of provisions of article. 
(a)  The council reserves the right to alter, amend or repeal any provision of this article or any application thereof to any person; provided, however, that the amount of benefits which at the time of any such alteration, amendment or repeal shall have accrued to the extent provided under subsection (c) of this section for the members or beneficiaries shall not be affected thereby. 
(b)  If the council repeals the provisions of this article, the board shall continue to administer the system in accordance with provisions of this article for the sole benefit of the then members, any beneficiaries then entitled to receive benefits hereunder, and any future beneficiaries who become entitled to receive benefits under the joint and last survivor option provided for in this article. 
(c)  In the event of repeal as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the assets of the system shall be allocated by the board in an equitable manner to provide benefits for the persons designated in subsection (b) of this section in accordance with the provisions of this article but based on years of creditable service and average final compensation as of the date of repeal and in the following order: 
(1)  For the benefit of the then members not yet retired to the extent of their accumulated contributions, if any. If any funds remain, then 
(2)  For the benefit of the retired members and the then beneficiaries entitled to receive benefits hereunder and beneficiaries already designated under the joint and last survivor option provided for in this article by the then retired members, to the extent of the then actuarial value of their allowances. If any funds remain, then 
(3)  For the benefit of members not then retired and beneficiaries, if any, designated by the members under the joint and last survivor option provided for in this article, to the extent, not provided under subsection (c)(1) of this section, of the then actuarial value of their accrued retirement allowances, based on years of creditable service and average final compensation as of the date of repeal. The allocation under this subsection shall be on the basis of the oldest-ages-first method. 
In the event the assets at such date of repeal are insufficient to provide all of the benefits of subsection (c)(1) or (c)(2) of this section or both, then the employer will contribute to the assets from time to time, as and when required, the amount necessary to make up such insufficiency. 
(d)  The allocation of assets of the system provided for in subsection (c) of this section shall be carried out through the payment by the board of the benefits provided for in this section as they become due, or by the transfer of such assets to any retirement system replacing this system; provided, that such vesting of benefits as provided by this section shall be fully maintained under such new retirement system. Any funds remaining in the assets of this system after all of the vested benefits provided by this section have been paid shall revert to the general fund. 
(e)  Any allocation of assets made in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be final and binding on all persons entitled to benefits under such provisions. 
(f)  Upon the termination or partial termination of the system, each member shall become fully vested, as of the termination date or partial termination date, in his service retirement allowance to the extent funded, regardless of length of service or amount of creditable service. 
(Code 1973, § 31-97; Code 1988, § 30-161; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 15, 11-22-2016)  
Secs. 30-162—30-175. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 
 
Sec. 30-176. - To administer system. 
The system shall be administered by the board of trustees of the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System, as established by section 30-51. 
(Code 1973, § 31-103; Code 1988, § 30-176)  
Sec. 30-177. - Compensation of members. 
Each member of the board shall receive the same compensation as provided in section 30-52. 
(Code 1973, § 31-104; Code 1988, § 30-177)  
Sec. 30-178. - Employment of actuary; necessary expenditures. 
The board may employ an actuary as its technical advisor and incur such expenditures as it deems necessary for the efficient administration of the system, as specified by this article, within the limitations of funds provided by the council for this purpose. 
(Code 1973, § 31-105; Code 1988, § 30-178; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 16, 11-22-2016  
Sec. 30-179. - Actuarial investigations and valuations. 
(a)  At least once in each five-year period, the board shall cause an actuarial investigation to be made of all of the experience under the retirement system. Pursuant to such investigations, the board shall, from time to time, revise the actuarial bases of the rates of employer contributions prescribed under this article. 
(b)  The board shall cause an annual valuation to be made of the assets and liabilities of the system and shall prepare an annual statement of the amounts to be contributed by the employer under this article. 
(c)  The board shall publish annually such valuation of the assets and liabilities and a statement of receipts and disbursements of the system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-106; Code 1988, § 30-179)  
Sec. 30-180. - Record of proceedings. 
The board shall keep a record of all its proceedings and such record shall be open to inspection by the members. 
(Code 1973, § 31-107; Code 1988, § 30-180)  
Sec. 30-181. - Trustee of funds and investments. 
The board shall be the trustee of the several funds created by this article and shall have full power to invest and reinvest such funds, subject to the limitation that no investment shall be authorized and made, except upon the exercise of bona fide discretion, in securities which, at the time of making the investment, are, by law, permitted for the investment of funds by fiduciaries in this state. Subject to such limitation, the board shall have full power to hold, purchase, sell, assign, transfer or dispose of, any of the securities or other investments in which any of the funds created herein have been invested, as well as the proceeds of all such investments and any monies or deposits belonging to such funds of the system. 
Pursuant to the standards set forth in Section 803 of Title 51.1 of the Virginia Code, the board shall discharge its duties with respect to the system solely in the interest of the members and beneficiaries thereof and shall invest the assets of the system with the care, skill, prudence, and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing that a prudent person acting in a like capacity and familiar with such matters would use in the conduct of an enterprise of like character and like aims. The board shall also diversify such investments so as to minimize large losses unless under the circumstances it is clearly prudent not to do so. 
Upon no circumstances at any time prior to the satisfaction of all liabilities with respect to members and their beneficiaries under the trust shall any part of the trust corpus or income of the system be used for or diverted to any purpose other than for the exclusive benefits of the members and their beneficiaries and for the reasonable administrative expenses of the system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-108; Code 1988, § 30-181; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 17, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-182. - Conflicts of interest and prohibited interests of board members. 
The State and Local Government Conflict of Interests Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3100, et seq., as the same may be amended, restated or moved from time to time, governs defining and prohibiting inappropriate conflicts and required disclosures of economic interests as they relate to the system and the board. In addition, to the extent not less stringent than the State and Local Government Conflict of Interests Act, the restrictions in this section apply. No member of the board shall have any direct or indirect interest in the gains or profits of any investment authorized and made by the board, except insofar as any such member may be a member or beneficiary of the system. No member of the board shall, directly or indirectly, for himself or as an agent, in any manner use the funds, monies or deposits of the system, except to make such current and necessary payments therefrom as are authorized by the board; nor shall any member of the board become an endorser or surety or in any manner an obligor for monies loaned by or borrowed from the system. Without limitation, all board members and contractors of the board shall avoid actual or potential conflicts of interest and the appearance of actual or potential conflicts of interest. 
(Code 1973, § 31-109; Code 1988, § 30-182; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 18, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-183. - Fiscal officer; funds generally, combination of funds with funds of Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System; how payments made. 
The chief financial officer or such other institutional custodian as may be appointed by the board shall be the custodian of all of the funds created by this article. For investment purposes only, the funds created by this article may be combined with the funds of the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System. All registered securities in such combined funds shall be registered in the name "City of Portsmouth, Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System" and every change in registration by reason of sale, assignment, transfer or disposal of such securities, shall be accomplished by the signature of the chief financial officer and securities shall be delivered by him when directed so to do by resolution of the board. The custodian of the combined funds shall keep such records as may be necessary to accurately determine at any time the proportions of the total funds representing the funds of the Portsmouth Fire and Police Department System and the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System, respectively. Allocation of investment income, capital gains and losses, and expenses of administration of the combined funds between the two systems shall be made by the custodian in the ratio of the amounts of the funds in each of the respective systems to the combined total amount of funds in both systems. All payments from such funds shall be made by checks issued upon orders signed by such person as is designated for the purpose by the board. No order shall be signed unless it has previously been authorized by the board, which authorization shall be recorded on the records of the board. 
(Code 1973, § 31-110; Code 1988, § 30-183; Ord. No. 1995-81, §§ 1, 2, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 19, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-184. - Medical examiners. 
The board shall, from time to time, employ one or more physicians, practicing in the city, upon such terms and conditions as it may prescribe, who shall be known as the "medical examiner" and whose duty it shall be to pass upon all medical examinations required under this article or by the board, and to investigate all health or medical statements and certificates made by or in behalf of any person in connection with the payment of money to such person under this article, and shall report in writing to the board his or their conclusions and recommendations upon all matters referred to him or them. 
(Code 1973, § 31-111; Code 1988, § 30-184)  
Secs. 30-185—30-200. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - MEMBERSHIP 
 
Sec. 30-201. - Composition. 
Membership in the system as of the date after June 30, 1967, shall consist of all the employees except those who had attained their normal retirement date at date of employment, and all former employees who were at any time members of the system and whose membership in the system had not been terminated under the provisions hereof. Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary, no employee who is hired or re-hired on or after July 1, 1995, shall become a member of the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System. 
(Code 1973, § 31-117; Code 1988, § 30-201; Ord. No. 1995-58, § 1, 4-25-1995)  
Sec. 30-202. - Period of membership; cessation of membership. 
(a)  Each employee who becomes a member of the system shall continue to be a member so long as he remains an employee and so long thereafter as he is entitled to future benefits under any provision of the system. Not in limitation but in amplification of the foregoing, the membership of any person in the system shall cease: 
(1)  Upon his termination of service as an employee, other than by retirement, before he has become vested under the conditions as stated in section 30-236; provided, however, that for the purposes of this section, the entrance of a member into authorized leave of absence shall not constitute termination of service as an employee; provided the member reenters service as an employee at the expiration of the period of authorized leave, and the entrance of a member into the armed forces of the United States shall not constitute termination of service as an employee; provided the member's service in such armed forces qualifies as creditable service under section 30-218; 
(2)  Upon the cessation of his retirement allowance, unless in such event he immediately again becomes an employee; or 
(3)  Upon his death. 
(b)  Should any person terminate service as an employee other than by retirement under the provisions of this article, after he has completed the number of years of creditable service required for entitlement to benefits under section 30-236; and should such person at any time again become an employee, any benefits becoming payable under the provisions of this article shall be determined on the basis of the total creditable years of service combined for all such periods of employment. 
(c)  The retirement allowance payable to any member who retires pursuant to the provisions of subsection 30-236(a) and who returns to police or fire employment after approval of the Civil Service Commission shall not terminate upon re-employment. At the time of re-employment, the member shall become a member of the Virginia Retirement System, subject to the vesting and other requirements of that system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-118; Code 1988, § 30-202; Ord. No. 2014-66, § 1, 8-12-2014 )  
Sec. 30-203. - Statement of facts as to status as member. 
Under such rules and regulations as are adopted by the board, each member, or someone on his behalf, shall file with the board, in such form as the board may prescribe, a statement of the facts pertaining to his status as a member, which shall include a detailed description of all service rendered as an employee and such other information as the board may require. Until such statement is filed, no member or his beneficiary shall be eligible to receive any benefits under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 31-123; Code 1988, § 30-203)  
Secs. 30-204—30-215. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CREDITABLE SERVICE 
 
Sec. 30-216. - Determination. 
The board shall determine by appropriate rules and regulations how much service in any year is the equivalent of a year of service, but in no case shall it allow credit for more than one year of service for all service rendered in any period of 12 consecutive months. 
(Code 1973, § 31-124; Code 1988, § 30-216)  
Sec. 30-217. - Effect of cessation of membership. 
When membership ceases, an employee shall thereafter lose all right to any retirement allowance or benefits under this article arising from service prior to the date of such cessation of membership. Forfeitures shall not be applied to increase the benefits of any member. Funds freed through forfeitures that arise for any reason shall only be used to reduce employer contribution and to pay reasonable administrative expenses of the system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-125; Code 1988, § 30-217; Ord. No. 2016-89 , § 20, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 30-218. - Inclusion of service in armed forces. 
Any service in the armed forces of the United States commencing in a period of war or national emergency or as a result of or to anticipate conscription in other periods, shall be included as creditable service; provided, that the employee was in service as an employee, immediately prior to entry into such armed forces; and further provided, that he resumed service as an employee within 90 days of the date on which he had the right of release from such armed forces, or within such longer period, if any, as provided by the laws of the United States applicable thereto. 
(Code 1973, § 31-126; Code 1988, § 30-218)  
Sec. 30-219. - Inclusion of service in the police or fire department of an annexed area. 
Any continuous period of service with the police or fire department of a county or city from which the city-annexed territory shall be included as creditable service; provided such employee was: 
(1)  A paid full-time employee of such county or city police or fire department, 
(2)  A resident of the annexed territory, and 
(3)  Transferred directly from such county or city department between the time the final annexation decree was entered and 60 days after the date the annexation became effective; and, provided, further, that such employee contributes to the retirement allowance account a sum equal to the amount the individual would have contributed had the individual been a member of the system during the period for which coverage is desired, anything in section 30-156 to the contrary notwithstanding. Such contributions shall be refundable in accordance with section 30-242. 
Effective July 1, 2011, an employee is deemed to be a paid full-time employee of a county or city-annexed territory if classified as such according to the payroll system of such county or city police or fire department. 
(Code 1973, § 31-127; Code 1988, § 30-219; Ord. No. 2017-23 , § 2(Exh. A), 4-25-2017)  
Sec. 30-220. - Inclusion of service under the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System. 
Any person who was formerly a member of the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System shall be granted creditable service for the period he was a member of such system provided he has remained in continuous service with the city and does not withdraw his contributions, if any, to such system or if he has made such a withdrawal pays into this system the amount of contributions he previously withdrew from such system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-128; Code 1988, § 30-220)  
Sec. 30-221. - Inclusion of service under the Virginia Retirement System. 
With respect to any member who is employed full-time by the city at the time of making application hereunder for service credits and who was a member of the former Virginia Retirement System, currently the Virginia Retirement System, immediately prior to becoming a member of this system, and whose membership in the Virginia Retirement System has ceased through withdrawal of the individual's contributions thereunder, the period of time during which the individual was a member of the Virginia Retirement System shall be included as creditable service hereunder, provided the individual terminates membership in said system and pays into the retirement system an actuarially determined amount deemed to be correct and neutral by the retirement board with regard to funding the projected additional retirement allowance to be received by the member through the purchase of such additional service credit. Such amount paid into the retirement system by the member under the provisions of this section shall remain as assets of the retirement system and shall not be considered as employee contributions, any other provisions of this article to the contrary notwithstanding. Effective July 1, 2011, a member shall be deemed to be employed on a full-time basis if classified as such according to the employer's payroll system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-129; Code 1988, § 30-221; Ord. No. 2005-93, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 2017-23 , § 2(Exh. A), 4-25-2017)  
Secs. 30-222—30-235. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - BENEFITS 
 
Sec. 30-236. - Service retirement. 
(a)  Any member, in service or within 90 days after termination of service, who has attained the age of 50 and who has attained the number of years of creditable service required for entitlement to benefits under the vesting provisions of this section or has completed 20 years of creditable service may retire at any time then or thereafter, upon written notification to the board, made by the member or his employer, setting forth at what time the retirement is to become effective; provided, that such effective date shall be after his last day of service, but shall not be more than 90 days prior to or subsequent to the filing of such notice. 
(b)  The provisions of paragraph (a) of this section to the contrary notwithstanding, any member remaining in service after his normal retirement date who attains 70 years of age shall be retired forthwith by the Portsmouth Retirement Board. The secretary to the board shall, at least six months prior to the date of any member's seventieth birthday, provide notice to the board and to the member of this mandatory retirement requirement. Retirement or other appropriate employment action may be mandated for any member, regardless of age, who does not meet applicable medical standards. 
(c)  Any member who terminates service as an employee prior to retirement and who complies with one of the requirements set forth in subsections (c)(1), (2), (3), (4) or (5) of this section, and who has attained the age of 60, may retire at any time then or thereafter under the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. If such member shall have terminated service prior to July 1, 1994, he shall receive a retirement allowance calculated on the basis of the benefits in effect on the date of his termination of service. 
(1)  The member terminated prior to July 1, 1973, but after the attainment of age 50 and the completion of 20 years of creditable service; 
(2)  The member terminated after June 30, 1973, and after the completion of ten years of creditable service; 
(3)  Membership began before July 1, 1977, and the member terminated after June 30, 1975, and after the completion of five years of creditable service; 
(4)  Membership began after June 30, 1977, and termination occurred after the completion of ten years of creditable service; or 
(5)  Membership began after June 30, 1991, and termination occurred after the completion of five years of creditable service. 
Provided, however, that no such member shall be entitled to the benefits of this subsection (c) of this section if his supervisor certifies that his service was terminated because of dishonesty, malfeasance or misfeasance in office. Such certification may be appealed to the board, and its decision shall be final. 
(d)  For good cause shown, the board may waive the 90-day period set forth in subsection (a) of this section relating to the period following the termination of service. For purposes of this section, good cause shall exist and the board shall waive such notification period if: (i) the member would otherwise qualify for disability retirement but for failing to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, and (ii) the medical examiner, acting solely in his own discretion after reviewing objective medical evidence of the disability and its cause, certifies that: (a) the disability and its cause existed on the date the member's employment was terminated, (b) the member had no knowledge of the existence of the disability and its cause at any time within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated, and (c) the member could not, with reasonable inquiry, have ascertained the existence of the disability within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated. 
(Code 1973, § 31-148; Code 1988, § 30-236; Ord. No. 1988-21, § 1, 2-23-1988; Ord. No. 1991-46, § 4, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1994-97, § 1, 10-11-1994; Ord. No. 1998-42, § 2, 9-8-1998; Ord. No. 2006-63, § 1, 7-25-2006)  
Sec. 30-237. - Service retirement allowance. 
(a)  Upon retirement as provided in section 30-236(a) or 30-236(b), a member shall receive an annual retirement allowance, payable at least monthly to him during his lifetime, in an amount equal to three percent of his average final compensation multiplied by the first 20 years of his creditable service, two percent of his average final compensation multiplied by the next five years of creditable service and one percent of his average final compensation multiplied by each additional year of creditable service thereafter. 
(b)  In addition to the allowance payable under subsections (a) through (d) of this section, a member retiring on or after July 1, 1992, but before July 1, 1993, shall receive an additional allowance equal to monthly payments of $100.00 from date of retirement until his 62nd birthday. A member retiring on or after July 1, 1993, shall receive an allowance equal to monthly payments of $200.00 from the date of retirement until his 62nd birthday. A member retiring on or after July 1, 1994, shall receive an allowance equal to monthly payments of $200.00 from the date of retirement until his 65th birthday. This subsection shall not apply to sections 30-239, 30-241, 30-243, 30-244, 30-245, and 30-246 of this Code and shall apply only to members receiving service retirement under section 30-236 of this Code. 
(c)  Upon retirement as provided in section 30-236(c), a member shall receive an annual retirement allowance, payable at least monthly to him during his lifetime, in an amount computed as provided for in subsection (a) of this section, except that if the member terminated service as an employee prior to July 1, 1975, and has completed less than 20 years of creditable service, the allowance as computed shall be reduced to a percentage of itself in accordance with the following table: 
Completed Years of 
Creditable Service 	Applicable 
Percentage 
Ten but less than 11 	50 
Eleven but less than 12 	55 
Twelve but less than 13 	60 
Thirteen but less than 14 	65 
Fourteen but less than 15 	70 
Fifteen but less than 16 	75 
Sixteen but less than 17 	80 
Seventeen but less than 18 	85 
Eighteen but less than 19 	90 
Nineteen but less than 20 	95 
 
(d)  If after termination of service and prior to retirement as provided in section 30-236(c), subsection (a) of this section is amended, the member's allowance calculation shall be based on the amended subsection in effect as of the date of retirement. 
(e)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, if a member's retirement allowance is payable under one of the options of section 30-247, the amounts and duration thereof shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of the applicable option. 
(f)  Any member retiring under the provisions of this section on or after July 1, 1992, and whose creditable service exceeds 40 years as of July 1, 1992, shall receive a benefit calculated on two percent for each year of creditable service multiplied by the member's average final compensation. 
(Code 1973, § 31-149; Code 1988, § 30-237; Ord. No. 1991-46, § 5, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1992-34, § 4, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 1993-40, § 2, 5-25-1993; Ord. No. 1994-39, § 2, 5-24-1994; Ord. No. 1994-106, § 1, 11-22-1994; Ord. No. 1994-40(1), § 2, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 2008-42, § 1, 5-27-2008) 
Editor's note— It should be noted that §§ 2, 3 of Ord. No. 2008-42 provide, 
"2. That the purpose of this ordinance is to correct a clerical error in Ordinance 1994-40, adopted on May 10, 1994, amending Section 30-237. That ordinance incorrectly referred to Code sections 30-119, 30-121, 30-122, 30-124, 30-125 and 30-127 that govern the Portsmouth Supplemental Retirement System when it authorized a service retirement allowance for members of the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System. The purpose of this ordinance is also to confirm that, for the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System, a service retirement allowance was always intended to be paid only to service retirees, and not to any other class of retirees. City Council hereby finds that the uniform practice of the Board of Trustees administering the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System both before and after enactment of said ordinance has been to pay a service retirement allowance only to service retirees in the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System and not to any other retirees in said system. Said practice is hereby affirmed and ratified as being consistent with the correct legislative intent of Ordinance 1994-40, and any possible contrary interpretation of said ordinance is specifically found to be inconsistent with the legislative intent of Portsmouth City Council. The purpose of this ordinance is conform the text of Section 20-237 to what has always been the legislative intent, and to conform it to what has been the uniform practice of the Board of Trustees in interpreting and applying said code section." 
"3. That, because this ordinance is adopted to correct a clerical error, the provisions adopted herein are deemed to have taken effect on May 10, 1994, the date of adoption of Ordinance 1994-40."  
Sec. 30-238. - Ordinary disability retirement. 
(a)  Any member, in service or within 90 days after termination of service, who has five or more years of creditable service may, at any time before his normal retirement date, retire on account of disability not compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act upon written notification to the board made by the member or his appointing authority, setting forth at which time the retirement is to become effective; provided, that such effective date shall be after the last day of service but shall not be more than 90 days prior to the date of such notification; and provided further, the examiner, after a medical examination of such member, shall certify: 
(1)  That such member is or has been continuously since such effective date, if prior to the filing of such notice, mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty. 
(2)  That such incapacity is likely to be permanent. 
(3)  That such member should be retired. 
(b)  For good cause shown, the board may waive the 90-day period set forth in subsection (a) of this section relating to the period following the termination of service. For purposes of this section, good cause shall exist and the board shall waive such notification period if: (i) the member would otherwise qualify for disability retirement but for failing to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, and (ii) the medical examiner, acting solely in his own discretion after reviewing objective medical evidence of the disability and its cause, certifies that: (a) the disability and its cause existed on the date the member's employment was terminated, (b) the member had no knowledge of the existence of the disability and its cause at any time within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated, and (c) the member could not, with reasonable inquiry, have ascertained the existence of the disability within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated. 
(Code 1973, § 31-150; Code 1988, § 30-238; Ord. No. 1998-42, § 2, 9-8-1998)  
Sec. 30-239. - Ordinary disability retirement allowance. 
(a)  Upon retirement as provided in section 30-238, a member shall receive an annual retirement allowance, payable at least monthly to him during his lifetime and continued disability, in an amount equal to three percent of his average final compensation multiplied by the number of years of his "disability credited service," as hereinafter defined. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the term "disability credited service" for any member shall be taken to mean the smallest of: 
(1)  Twice the member's actual period of creditable service; 
(2)  The member's period of creditable service plus ten years; 
(3)  The number of years of creditable service the member would have completed at his normal retirement date if he had remained in service as an employee until then; if the member is past his normal retirement date disability credited service shall be equal to the member's actual creditable service; 
(4)  Twenty years; if the member's actual creditable service is greater than 20 years, "disability credited service" shall be equal to the member's actual creditable service. An allowance shall be payable to the member according to subsection (a) of this section and an additional two percent for each year of creditable service for the next five years and an additional one percent for each year thereafter. 
(c)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, if a member's retirement allowance is payable under one of the options of section 30-247, the amount and duration thereof shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of the applicable option. 
(Code 1973, § 31-151; Code 1988, § 30-239; Ord. No. 1992-34, § 5, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 1994-39, § 3, 5-24-1994; Ord. No. 1994-40(1), § 3, 5-10-1994)  
Sec. 30-240. - Service-connected disability retirement. 
(a)  Any member, in service or within 90 days after termination of service, may retire on account of disability compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act upon written notification to the board, made by the member or his employer, setting forth at what time the retirement is to become effective; provided, that such effective date shall be after the last day of service and after the date the award of compensation under that act becomes final, but shall not be more than 90 days prior to the date of such notification; and provided further, the examiner, after a medical examination of such member, shall certify: 
(1)  That such member is, and has been continuously since such effective date, if prior to the filing of such notice, mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty. 
(2)  That such incapacity is likely to be permanent. 
(3)  That such member should be retired. 
(b)  For good cause shown, the board may waive the 90-day period set forth in subsection (a) of this section relating to the period following the termination of service. For purposes of this section, good cause shall exist and the board shall waive such notification period if: (i) the member would otherwise qualify for disability retirement but for failing to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, and (ii) the medical examiner, acting solely in his own discretion after reviewing objective medical evidence of the disability and its cause, certifies that: (a) the disability and its cause existed on the date the member's employment was terminated, (b) the member had no knowledge of the existence of the disability and its cause at any time within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated, and (c) the member could not, with reasonable inquiry, have ascertained the existence of the disability within 90 days after the date the member's employment was terminated. 
(Code 1973, § 31-152; Code 1988, § 30-240; Ord. No. 1998-42, § 2, 9-8-1998)  
Sec. 30-241. - Service-connected disability retirement allowance. 
(a)  Upon retirement as provided in section 30-240, a member shall receive an annual retirement allowance, payable at least monthly to him during his lifetime and continued disability, in an amount equal to the larger of: 
(1)  Two-thirds of the member's average final compensation; or 
(2)  The allowance to which the member would be entitled under the provisions of section 30-239 if his disability were not compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act. 
(b)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, if a member's retirement allowance is payable under one of the options of section 30-247, the amount and duration thereof shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of the applicable option. 
(c)  The compensation finally awarded to the member under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act or adjusted pursuant to that act shall be deducted from any allowance becoming payable under the provisions of this section, and the excess of the allowance, if any, shall be paid to the member. When the time for payments of compensation under such act has elapsed, the member shall thereafter receive the full amount of such allowance payable at least monthly during his lifetime and continued disability. 
(d)  Beginning July 1, 2006, and thereafter, in order to receive a service-connected disability retirement allowance, a member retiring on account of disability compensable under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act shall participate in vocational rehabilitation following his or her release for light-duty occupations. This requirement shall not apply or will cease to apply if the member has attained or subsequently attains full service retirement eligibility as defined in sections 30-236, et seq. 
(Code 1973, § 31-153; Code 1988, § 30-241; Ord. No. 1992-34, § 6, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 2006-38, § 1, 5-9-2006)  
Sec. 30-241.1. - Reduction of health insurance rates for certain members after service-connected disability retirement. 
The annual health insurance rates of any member receiving a service-connected disability retirement allowance may be reduced to the rate paid by active employees, provided that: 
(1)  The member's service-connected disability retirement allowance is less than $20,000.00; and 
(2)  The member is enrolled in a city-provided health insurance plan. 
(Code 1988, § 30-241.1; Ord. No. 2005-97, § 1, 11-22-2005)  
Sec. 30-242. - Refund of accumulated contributions. 
(a)  Upon the retirement of a member or upon his termination of service as an employee, other than by death, he shall be paid, on demand, but not later than 90 days thereafter, the amount of his accumulated contributions, if any, in a lump sum; provided that if the amount of such accumulated contributions is less than $10.00, no such payment shall be made. 
(b)  Should a member die at any time while in service, the amount of his accumulated conditions shall be paid in a lump sum in accordance with section 30-248; provided that if the amount of such accumulated contributions is less than $10.00, no such payment shall be made. 
(c)  Notwithstanding provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the retirement board may elect to refund all such accumulated contributions at any time if it finds that such action is in the best interests of the retirement system. 
(Code 1973, § 31-154; Code 1988, § 30-242)  
Sec. 30-243. - Adjustments of retirement allowance. 
Any person receiving a retirement allowance under sections 30-237, 30-239, 30-241, 30-244(c), or section 30-247 shall, upon the annual prior approval of city council, receive an adjustment of retirement allowance as of July 1, each year, in an amount to be approved by the city council. The amount of the adjustment shall be determined as a percentage of the retirement allowance being received, including any percentage adjustments approved in prior years. Such adjustments shall be subject to the same conditions of payment as are applicable to the retirement allowance. In no case, shall the operation of this section result in a reduction in the amount of any person's total benefit below the amount of the retirement allowance that would have been payable in the absence of this section. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in no event shall city council approve or authorize adjustments to retirement allowances unless the Portsmouth Fire and Police Retirement System is funded at no less than 80 percent of the actuarial accrued liability. 
(Code 1973, § 31-155; Code 1988, § 30-243; Ord. No. 1988-21, § 2, 2-23-1988; Ord. No. 2019-74 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-22-2019)  
Sec. 30-244. - Ordinary death benefits. 
(a)  Should a member, who had one or more years of creditable service, die in service at any time before retirement from a cause not comprehensible under the Virginia Workers' Compensation Act, an additional benefit equal to $5,000.00 shall then be payable in a lump sum in accordance with section 30-248. 
(b)  If the member at the date of death had more than five years of creditable service, there shall be paid a retirement allowance to the first of the following-listed persons who shall survive the member and in the priority listed herein: 
(1)  Widow or widower, pension payable during widowhood. 
(2)  Child or children under the age of 18 years, pension payable to age 18 for each child. 
(3)  Dependent mother or father. 
(4)  Dependent sister or brother. 
If there is more than one child, or more than one dependent parent, or more than one dependent sister or brother, the pension shall be divided in a manner as the board may determine. Parents, brothers or sisters must receive more than 50-percent support from the member in order to be considered dependent for the purposes of this pension.
