(Code 1988, § 34-36; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-37. - Safety and rescue equipment; other safety features. 
Every public swimming pool shall be equipped with the following aids to safety and rescue which shall be readily accessible at all times: 
(1)  One or more safety tubes or lightweight but strong poles with blunted ends, not less than 12 feet (four meters) in length. 
(2)  One or more throwing ring buoys of less than 15 inches (38 centimeters) in diameter having a 150 pound (68.4 kilogram) test line attached of sufficient length to reach twice the width of the pool, placed on racks at strategic points adjacent to the pool. 
(3)  A lifeline shall be provided at the break in grade between the shallow and deep portions of the swimming pool, or six inches (15.2 centimeters) of either shallow side of the break with its position marked with visible floats at not greater than seven-foot (2.10 meter) intervals. The lifeline shall be securely fastened to wall anchors or corrosion-resistant materials and of a type which shall be recessed or have no projection which shall constitute a hazard when the line is removed. The line shall be of sufficient size and strength to offer a good handhold and support loads normally imposed by bathers. 
(4)  A readily-accessible room or area designated and equipped for emergency care of casualties. Minimum equipment shall be an approved first aid kit and a backboard meeting Red Cross standards. 
(5)  A direct-dial telephone with numbers for police, fire and rescue shall be readily accessible at all times. 
(6)  Approved signs shall be maintained in a legible manner as follows: 
a.  Occupant load signs. A sign with clearly legible letters, not less than four inches (10.2 centimeters) high shall be posted in a conspicuous place near the main entrance to a pool which shall indicate the number of occupants permitted for each pool. 
b.  Spa/hot tub pool. The occupant capacity of a spa/hot tub pool shall be based on one bather for every ten square feet (1.9 meters 2 ) of pool water surface area. 
c.  The occupant capacity of all other pools shall be based on one bather for every 27 square feet (2.50 meters 2 ) of pool water surface area. Exception: Occupant capacity requirements do not apply to wading pools. 
d.  Permanent and conspicuous signs shall be posted indicating the most direct route to the pool. 
(7)  In areas so indicated, signs with clearly legible letters not less than four inches (10.2 centimeters) high shall be posted in a conspicuous place and shall state "NO DIVING ALLOWED." 
(8)  Warning signs for pools using gas chlorine. Pools at which gas chlorine is used for disinfection shall have a conspicuously posted sign on the exterior side of the entry door to the chlorine room, or on the adjacent wall area. In addition to displaying the appropriate hazard identification symbol for gas chlorine, the sign shall state with clearly legible letters not less than four inches (10.16 centimeters) high, "DANGER: GASEOUS OXIDIZER-CHLORINE." 
(9)  Spa/hot tub warning signs. A precautionary sign with clearly legible letters shall be posted in a prominent place near the entrance to a spa pool which shall contain the following language: 
"CAUTION" 
a.  Elderly persons, pregnant women, infants and those with health conditions requiring medical care should consult a physician before entering the spa. 
b.  Unsupervised use by children under the age of 14 is prohibited. 
c.  Hot water immersion while under the influence of alcohol, narcotics, drugs or medicines may lead to serious consequences and is not recommended. 
d.  Do not use alone. 
e.  Long exposure may result in nausea, dizziness or fainting. 
(10)  The depth of water in pools shall be marked at one-foot increments (30.48 centimeters) and at least every 20 feet (6.1 meters) on both the horizontal deck surface and vertical surfaces of the pool wall. Numerals and letters shall be at least four inches (10.16 centimeters) in height and have a good contrast with the pool walls and deck. 
(11)  Fixed and floating platforms in public swimming pools shall be constructed with an air space of at least one foot (0.3 meters) between the water surface and the underside of the platform. 
(12)  There shall be one elevated lifeguard chair provided for every public pool with a depth of over five feet (1.52 meters) or 2,000 square feet (202.99 meters 2 ) of water surface. An additional chair will be required for each additional 1,000 square feet (92.8 meters 2 ) of water surface. 
(Code 1988, § 34-37; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-38. - Disinfection equipment. 
(a)  Chemical feeding equipment. Means shall be provided for regulating the feeding of chemicals to the water in the recirculation system. The installation and use of mechanical, automatically operated, positive displacement chemical feeders or dye type chemical feeders is required. 
(b)  Chlorinating equipment. All public pools shall be provided with approved chlorinating equipment which shall be capable of applying a dose of not less than ten ppm of chlorine within the turnover time. 
(c)  Use of chlorine gas. The use of chlorine gas as a disinfectant shall require the approval of the administrative authority. Such approval will be granted only after it has been demonstrated that the gas chlorinator room or area will be located in a manner which will not adversely affect the safety and health of patrons, pool personnel or the public. Chlorine gas feeding equipment and chlorine gas cylinders and other hazardous chemicals shall be installed in an enclosed space or room, separate from the filter room and electrical panels and shall be equipped with a door capable of being locked. The operating gas cylinder shall be placed on an accurate scale and fastened in place during storage and use. Gas chlorinator rooms shall be equipped with a forced draft fan exhausting to the outside room from the floor level. The exhaust fan shall be capable of providing 60 air changes per hour against the resistance offered by duct work or any other local factors. A fresh air inlet shall be provided near the ceiling. The gas chlorinator shall be protected from direct sunlight. 
(d)  Gas masks. An approved, self-contained gas mask for chlorine or a gas mask with a supply of oxygen under positive pressure or compressed air, either of which have been approved by the Bureau of Mines, in addition to local approval by the fire department, shall be provided where chlorine gas is being utilized. The mask shall be located accessible to, but outside of, the gas chlorinator room. 
(Code 1988, § 34-38; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-39. - Water heating. 
Indoor public pools shall be provided with water heating equipment thermostatically controlled and capable of maintaining the entire pool contents between 70 and 85 degrees Fahrenheit (21 degrees Celsius and 29.48 degrees Celsius). All heated pools, spas and hot tubs shall maintain a minimum halogen residual of 2.0 ppm or mg/l at all times. Spas and hot tubs shall have, on display, a clock and thermometer visible to occupants. Spas and pool water temperature shall not exceed 104 degrees Fahrenheit at any time that is occupied. 
(Code 1988, § 34-39; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-40. - Showers, water closets, lavatories, etc. 
(a)  Generally. Showers, water closets and lavatories shall be provided for each sex, in accordance with the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. The part of the structure containing the showers, water closets, urinals and lavatories shall be designed so that these facilities shall be in the line of travel used by the patrons prior to entering the pool area and shall be provided with an entrance and a separate exit opening directly to the pool deck; however, such exit shall not be near the deep portion of the pool. 
(b)  Requirements. Floor for all dressing rooms, showers, toilets and lavatories shall be smooth but must have nonslip finish and the room shall be ventilated so that the floors do not remain damp or wet. Walls and floors for all dressing rooms, toilet rooms and lavatories shall be of waterproof, easily cleanable materials. 
(1)  Dressing rooms. Separate dressing rooms may be provided for both sexes. When provided, metal lockers, wire baskets, hooks or other sanitary means of storage of clothing and personal accessories shall be provided. All storage containers for clothing shall be kept clean and sanitary. 
(2)  Showers. Showers shall be provided in the proportion of one for each 40 persons at the time of maximum load. Each shower shall supply an adequate quantity of tempered water. Water from each shower shall be provided with suitable facilities for making soap available. 
(3)  Toilets. Toilet facilities shall be provided as set forth in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(4)  Lavatories. Lavatories shall be provided as set forth in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(5)  Exceptions. Subsections (b)(1) through (b)(4) of this section shall not apply when bathers have access to these facilities either in living quarters located to more than 500 feet (152.4 meters) in travel distance from the pool, or in an adjacent building such as a recreational facility, clubhouse or cabana. 
(6)  Mirrors. Mirrors, if provided, shall be constructed in accordance with the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1988, § 34-40; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-41. - Spectators/spectator areas. 
Spectator areas shall be so separated from the pool area that spectators do not have access to the pool area. Spectator balconies shall not overhang any portion of the pool surface. 
(Code 1988, § 34-41; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-42. - Wading pools. 
(a)  The slope of the bottom of any wading pool shall be no greater than 1:15 nor less than 1:40. 
(b)  Wading pools shall be so designed that no obstructions are within an area bounded by a line five feet (1.5 meters) outside of the pool perimeter. 
(c)  Wading pools shall be separated from the main pool by a suitable barrier with a self-closing and self-latching device. 
(d)  Wading pools shall be provided with their own water return line to provide an adequate flow of chlorinated water, or shall have a filter system completely separate from the main pool with a turnover of two hours or less. 
(e)  Wading pools shall be required to have a vacuum line. 
(Code 1988, § 34-42)  
Secs. 34-43—34-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OPERATION 
 
Sec. 34-56. - Conditions and equipment. 
All equipment shall be maintained in satisfactory operating condition during operation of a public pool. 
(Code 1988, § 34-56; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-57. - Water supply. 
All public pools using well water shall have a satisfactory bacteriological sample taken prior to opening each year. 
(Code 1988, § 34-57; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-58. - Clarity of water. 
When a public pool is open and in use, the water shall be sufficiently clear to permit a disc six inches (15.24 centimeters) in diameter, divided into alternate black and white segments, and placed on the bottom of the pool at the deepest point, to be clearly visible from the pool deck at all distances up to ten yards (9.14 meters) in a horizontal direction from the projection of the disc on the pool surface. The disc shall be available on premises at all times or may be permanently affixed to the bottom of the pool in the deepest area. 
(Code 1988, § 34-58; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-59. - Water treatment. 
(a)  Chemicals other than chlorine, bromine, hypobromous acid, sodium hypochlorite, calcium hypochlorite, muriatic acid, lime soda ash, sodium bicarbonate, aluminum sulfate (alum), cyanuric acid and sodium bisulfate shall not be used to treat swimming pool water without written permission from the administrative authority. 
(b)  The impounded water shall at all times be treated in a manner which will prevent the growth of algae and the breeding of mosquitoes or other vermin. 
(c)  When the unheated swimming pool is open for use, a minimum of one ppm (parts per million) free chlorine residual shall be maintained in all parts of the pool. 
(d)  When the swimming pool is open for use, the pH of the pool water shall be kept between 7.2 and 7.8 with a minimum total alkalinity of 80 ppm, calcium hardness of 150 ppm. 
(e)  Approved test kits for all tests required in this article shall be available and in good working condition at all times. 
(f)  The operator or manager of each public swimming pool shall maintain and operate all mechanical equipment in a safe and proper manner. 
(g)  Where cyanuric acid is used as a stabilizing agent for residual chlorine, or if the source of residual chlorine is from a chlorinated cyanurate, a chlorine residual of at least 1.5 ppm shall be maintained with cyanuric acid residuals of at least 40 ppm. 
(h)  The operator or manager of each swimming pool shall cause an adequate supply of chemicals for the proper treatment of pool water to be on hand and available for use at all times. 
(i)  Protective clothing, i.e., respirators, face masks, rubber gloves and aprons or coveralls shall be provided for personnel handling chlorine chemical compounds and other caustic chemicals. 
(Code 1988, § 34-59; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-60. - Records. 
(a)  Record forms supplied by the administrative authority shall be maintained up-to-date and shall be available for inspection while the pool is in use and shall be retained for a period of at least four months, or for at least one year in the case of pools that operate year around. 
(b)  Unless otherwise modified by the administrative authority, disinfection tests, i.e., free chlorine residual and pH tests, shall be made and recorded at least once every two hours while the pool is in operation. Alkalinity and calcium hardness tests shall be made and recorded at least weekly. 
(Code 1988, § 34-60; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-61. - Placards. 
Placards approved by the administrative authority and covering personal health and safety regulations shall be posted within the swimming facility. Areas restricted to operating personnel shall be prominently identified. Signs warning employees of emergency procedures to be followed in case of exposure or contact with hazardous materials shall be posted in the room or area where such hazardous materials are stored and/or used. 
(Code 1988, § 34-61; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-62. - Food and drink area. 
Any person in the process of eating or drinking shall be restricted to the area designated for the preparation and serving of food and drink. This area shall be at least ten feet (3.05 meters) from the pool edge. 
(Code 1988, § 34-62; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-63. - Cleaning and maintenance. 
(a)  Generally. All parts of the pool and related pool facilities and equipment shall be kept clean and maintained in good repair. Floors shall be kept free from cracks and other defects. Walls, ceilings, partitions, doors, lockers and similar surfaces and equipment shall be refinished in a manner acceptable to the administrative authority as often as necessary to be kept in good repair. 
(b)  Hoses; sanitation. Hoses shall be provided for regular flushing and cleaning. The whole pool area shall be kept clean, sanitary, and free of litter and vermin. 
(c)  Plumbing fixtures. Toilets, urinals, showers, wash basins and other plumbing fixture shall be maintained in a clean condition and in good repair. 
(d)  General housekeeping and health spa facilities. All floors, walls, ceilings, showers, bathtubs, saunas, steam and vapor rooms, cabinets, toilets, stalls and other physical facilities of the health spa must be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. All equipment and fixtures shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively disinfected as often as needed to prevent the development of algae, fungi, mildew, mold or bacteria which may endanger the public safety or health. 
(Code 1988, § 34-63; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-64. - Precautions relative to communicable diseases. 
Any person having an obvious skin disease, nasal or ear discharge, inflamed eyes, or any communicable disease shall be excluded from the public swimming pool. 
(Code 1988, § 34-64; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-65. - Public safety; security. 
Public swimming pools shall be maintained in a manner which will not create a nuisance or hazard to the public safety and well-being when not in use, and the pool shall be adequately secured against entry by the public in general. 
(Code 1988, § 34-65; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-66. - Lifeguards. 
(a)  There shall be at least one lifeguard on duty at all times when the public pool is of 2,000 square feet (185.79 meters 2 ) of water surface or more and when open for use. 
(b)  Public pools which are less than 2,000 square feet (185.79 meters 2 ) may be used by adults, or children supervised by adults, without a designated lifeguard, provided it is posted as follows: "WARNING: No lifeguard on duty. Children under the age of 14 shall not be allowed to use a pool without an adult in attendance." 
(c)  Any individual retained as a lifeguard for public pools of 2,000 square feet (185.79 meters 2 ) or more shall possess a current certification for meeting the standard of a lifesaver as recommended by the American Red Cross, YMCA or other accredited agency for lifesaving personnel. 
(d)  The ratio of lifeguards to bathers shall be one lifeguard on duty for the first 75 bathers and an additional lifeguard for every additional 50 bathers, or fraction thereof. Lifeguards shall wear distinguishing emblems or clothing while on duty. 
(Code 1988, § 34-66; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-67. - Laundering. 
Bathing suits, towels and other reusable cloth materials furnished by a public pool shall be properly laundered so as to be sanitary before being issued to bathers. 
(Code 1988, § 34-67; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996)  
Sec. 34-68. - Animals. 
Animals, fowl and/or pets shall not be permitted within the public swimming pool. This section shall not apply to working dogs, such as seeing-eye dogs. 
(Code 1988, § 34-68; Ord. No. 1996-40, 6-25-1996) 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 4.  
Chapter 35 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— General authority of city as to taxation, § 2.02; duty of city treasurer to collect taxes, § 6.03. 
Cross reference— Dog license taxes, § 4-63 et seq.; finance, ch. 12; license taxes generally, ch. 20; vehicle license taxes, § 22-72 et seq.; special assessments for local improvements, § 32-251 et seq. 
State Law reference— General authority of city relative to taxes and assessments, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1104; taxation, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1 et seq.; local taxes, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3000 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 35-1. - Adoption of annual tax ordinance. 
The city council shall, at the first regular meeting in May of each year or as soon thereafter as practicable, adopt a tax ordinance, which shall specify the amount of per annum tax which is to be levied upon the real and personal property and upon persons within the city for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(Code 1973, § 35-1; Code 1988, § 35-1) 
Cross reference— Procedure for adoption of ordinance or resolution imposing taxes, § 2-29(b).  
Sec. 35-2. - Due date; penalty and administrative costs for delinquencies—Real estate taxes. 
(a)  City taxes for each fiscal year shall be due and payable during the year for which the same are assessed in four equal installments, as follows: One-fourth thereof on September 30, one-fourth thereof on December 31, one-fourth thereof on March 31 and one-fourth thereof on June 30 of such year. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, city taxes on real estate payable by persons qualifying as elderly or disabled people for the exemption of real estate taxes provided in division 2 and division 3 of article IV of this chapter, shall be due and payable for each fiscal year hereafter during the year for which the same are assessed in four equal installments, as follows: One-fourth thereof on October 5, one-fourth thereof on January 5, one-fourth thereof on April 5 and one-fourth thereof on July 5. In addition, any person who is 65 years old or older or who is disabled shall, upon verification of same by the city treasurer, qualify for payment on said dates. 
(c)  In the event any installment of taxes on real estate is not paid on or before the time the same is due and payable, as provided in subsection (a) of this section, there shall be added thereto a penalty of ten percent of the amount of the unpaid installment or $10.00, whichever is greater, but the penalty is not to exceed the amount of the unpaid installment. 
(d)  There is hereby imposed a fee to cover the administrative costs associated with the collection of delinquent taxes. Such fee shall be in addition to all penalties and interest, and shall be imposed in accordance with the provisions of section 35-3. 
(Code 1973, § 35-2; Code 1988, § 35-2; Ord. No. 1991-76, § 1, 7-9-1991; Ord. No. 1994-86, § 1, 8-23-1994; Ord. No. 1995-103, § 1, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 1997-19, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 2003-44, § 1, 7-22-2003) 
Charter reference— Penalties on delinquent taxes, § 2.13. 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3916.  
Sec. 35-3. - Delinquent taxes and charges; administrative costs, etc. 
(a)  Any provision of this Code notwithstanding, there is hereby imposed upon each person chargeable with delinquent taxes or other delinquent charges, fees to cover the administrative costs and reasonable attorney's or collection agency's fees actually contracted for. The attorney's or collection fees shall not exceed 20 percent of the taxes or other charges so collected. The administrative costs shall be in addition to all other penalties and interest, and shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code for taxes or other charges collected subsequent to 30 or more days after notice of delinquent taxes or charges pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3919 but prior to the taking of any judgment with respect to such delinquent taxes or charges, and as set forth in appendix A to this Code for taxes or other charges collected subsequent to judgment. If the collection activity is to collect on a nuisance abatement lien, the fee for administrative costs shall be as set forth in appendix A to this Code or 25 percent of the costs, whichever is less; however, in no event shall the fee be less than set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(b)  No tax assessment or tax bill shall be deemed delinquent and subject to the collection procedures prescribed in the Code of Virginia during the pendency of any administrative appeal under Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3980, so long as the appeal is filed within 90 days of the date of the assessment, and 30 days after the date of the final determination of the appeal, provided that nothing herein shall be construed to preclude the assessment or refund, following the final determination of such appeal, of such interest as otherwise may be provided by general law as to that portion of a tax bill that has remained unpaid or was overpaid during the pendency of such appeal and is determined in such appeal to be properly due and owing. 
(Code 1988, § 1-14; Ord. No. 2003-44, § 2, 7-22-2003) 
State Law reference— Penalty for collection of delinquent taxes, charges, etc., Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3940 et seq.; payment of administrative costs, etc., Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3958.  
Sec. 35-4. - Same—Taxes on personal property and machinery and tools. 
(a)  City taxes on personal property, except as provided under section 35-11 of this Code, and machinery and tools shall be paid on or before June 5 of the year in which such taxes are assessed. 
(b)  City taxes on personal property and machinery and tools of public service companies which are assessed by the state corporation commission shall be paid on or before December 5 of the year in which such taxes are assessed. 
(c)  Any person who shall fail to file such return when due shall pay a penalty of ten percent of the tax assessable on such return or $10.00, whichever is greater; provided, however, that the penalty shall in no case exceed the amount of the tax assessable. If the assessing official determines that the taxpayer has a history of noncompliance then both such penalties may be assessed. Such penalty shall be assessed on the day after such return is due. Any such penalty when so assessed shall become a part of the tax. 
(d)  In the event any taxes on personal property and machinery and tools are not paid on or before the time the same are due and payable, there shall be added thereto a penalty of ten percent of such unpaid taxes or $10.00, whichever is greater, but the penalty is not to exceed the amount of the unpaid tax. 
(e)  There is hereby imposed a fee to cover the administrative costs associated with the collection of delinquent taxes. Such fee shall be in addition to all penalties and interest, and shall be imposed in accordance with the provisions of section 35-3. 
(f)  In the instance that the city treasurer collects any tax owed to the city as a consequence of an action by an agency of the commonwealth pursuant to any program authorized by the Code of Virginia, any fee that such agency is allowed to charge the city or the taxpayer, pursuant to the Code of Virginia for the agency's participation in such program may be billed and collected from the taxpayer by the city treasurer. 
(g)  Every fiduciary shall file the returns mentioned in this section with the commissioner of the revenue. Every taxpayer owning machinery and tools or business personal property, if requested by the commissioner, shall include on his annual return of such property information as to the total of original capitalized cost by year of purchase. Every such taxpayer shall file with his annual return a copy of the most recent depreciation schedule submitted to federal and state tax authorities. 
(Code 1973, § 35-3; Code 1988, § 35-3; Ord. No. 1991-76, § 2, 7-9-1991; Ord. No. 1994-9, § 1, 2-22-1994; Ord. No. 1995-103, § 1, 11-14-1995; Ord. No. 1998-29, § 1, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 2003-44, § 1, 7-22-2003) 
Charter reference— Penalties on delinquent taxes, § 2.13. 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3916.  
Sec. 35-5. - Interest on delinquencies. 
(a)  Any person failing to pay any taxes on real estate, tangible personal property, except as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, machinery and tools or other taxes due to the city shall incur, in addition to a penalty thereon, interest on that amount of taxes which is due plus interest on any penalty assessed. Interest at the rate of ten percent per annum from the first day following the day such taxes are due and said penalty is assessed shall be collected upon the principal and penalties of all taxes and levies then remaining unpaid, and shall continue to accrue and be due until such time such taxes and penalty are paid in full. 
(b)  Any person failing to pay tangible personal property taxes on any vehicle from which the treasurer has deducted any amount to be paid by the commonwealth, as shown on the tax bill, shall incur interest on the principal amount of the tax, and any penalty assessed on the principal amount of the tax as a result of failure to pay, less the amount of the tax to be paid by the commonwealth. Interest shall be at the rate prescribed in subsection (a) of this section, and shall accrue in the manner prescribed herein. 
(Code 1973, § 35-8; Code 1988, § 35-4; Ord. No. 1989-60, 6-27-1989; Ord. No. 1990-37, § 1, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1999-8, § 1, 4-27-1999)  
Sec. 35-6. - Payment of delinquent real estate taxes first; disposition of monies tendered as current tax payments. 
(a)  Whenever taxes on a parcel or real property are delinquent or past due, such taxes shall be paid and applied to the first or oldest tax recorded. A taxpayer offering to pay taxes on the parcel of real estate shall be directed by the city treasurer to pay first all delinquent taxes and then such current taxes as are due or past due. Where a taxpayer submits monies designated for payment of current taxes on a specific parcel of land which is subject to delinquent taxes, the treasurer shall, notwithstanding the taxpayer's instructions to the contrary, cause the payment to be applied to the first or oldest delinquent taxes. This application of funds shall be made in all cases, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, regardless of whether the taxpayer tendered the payment with or without the knowledge of the provisions of this section. Where funds are diverted and applied to delinquent taxes, the treasurer shall promptly give notice to the taxpayer of such application; provided, however, that the failure to give such notice shall not invalidate such application or relieve the taxpayer of the obligation to pay those taxes from which the original payment was diverted. 
(b)  The foregoing provisions to the contrary notwithstanding, no payments shall be applied to any delinquent taxes where such taxes have not been assessed in the name of the taxpayer remitting payment. Where a payment is tendered for taxes owed in respect of one parcel of land, such payment shall not be applied to any taxes which are attributable to a parcel of land separately assessed by the city assessor. 
(c)  The city treasurer may institute proceedings to sell in accordance with law any real estate when any taxes on such real estate are delinquent on December 31 following the first anniversary of the date on which such taxes have become due provided proper notice is given in accordance with subsection A of Section 58.1-3965 of the Code of Virginia. 
(Code 1973, § 11-73.1; Code 1988, § 35-5; Ord. No. 1998-29, § 1, 5-26-1998; Ord. No. 2011-43, § 1, 6-28-2011)  
Sec. 35-7. - Notice to taxpayers as to due date and penalty. 
The city treasurer shall, except as provided under section 35-11, at least ten days prior to the time any city taxes or installments thereon are due, give public notice by advertisement in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city of the due date for such taxes and the penalties for failure to pay same when due. 
(Code 1973, § 35-4; Code 1988, § 35-6; Ord. No. 1995-103, § 1, 11-14-1995) 
State Law reference— Treasurer to publicize tax due dates, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3911.  
Sec. 35-8. - Assessment of personal property. 
The commissioner of the revenue shall proceed annually, on the first day of January, except as provided in section 35-9, to make assessments of all personal property, other than personal property of public service companies which is assessed by the state corporation commission, subject to the taxation by the provisions of this Code or other ordinance of the city in the same manner and form as is required by the revenue laws of the state. He shall record such assessments, upon separate rolls or books of assessments for the city, making the necessary complete copies thereof. He shall deliver to the city treasurer a copy of the record of assessments of personal property on or before the fifteenth day of April of each year and at such times as is necessary for the levying of personal property taxes. He shall deliver to the city treasurer copies of the records of assessments of personal property of public service companies which are assessed by the state corporation commission within 30 days after he receives the same. 
(Code 1973, § 35-16; Code 1988, § 35-7; Ord. No. 2006-24, § 1, 3-21-2006)  
Sec. 35-9. - Tax relief for qualifying motor vehicles. 
(a)  Basis of tax relief. The tax relief provided under this section relates to the Personal Property Tax Relief Act of 1998, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3523 et seq. ("PPTRA"), which was modified by the enactment of Chapter 1 of the Acts of Assembly, 2004 Special Session I, and the provisions of Item 503 of Chapter 951 of the 2005 Acts of Assembly (the 2005 revisions to the 2004-06 Appropriations Act, hereinafter cited as the "2005 Appropriations Act"). Terms used in this section that have defined meanings set forth in PPTRA shall have the same meanings as set forth in the Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3523. 
(b)  Method of computing and reflecting tax relief. For tax years commencing in 2006, the provisions of Item 503.E of the 2005 Appropriations Act, providing for the computation of tax relief as a specific dollar amount to be offset against the total taxes that would otherwise be due but for PPTRA and the reporting of such specific dollar relief on the tax bill, shall apply. The city council, shall, by resolution or ordinance, set the percentage of tax relief at a level that is anticipated to exhaust PPTRA relief funds provided to the city by the commonwealth. Personal property tax bills shall set forth on their face the specific dollar amount of relief credited with respect to each qualifying vehicle. 
(c)  Allocation of relief among taxpayers. Relief with respect to qualifying vehicles shall be provided at a percentage, annually fixed and applied to the first $20,000.00 in value of each such qualifying vehicle that is estimated to exhaust all available PPTRA relief from the Commonwealth. 
(d)  Transitional provisions. Pursuant to authority conferred in Item 503.D of the 2005 Appropriations Act, the city treasurer shall collect personal property taxes, in the amount of 100 percent of tax due without regard to any formal entitlement to state PPTRA relief, plus applicable penalties and interest, to any taxpayer whose taxes with respect to a qualifying vehicle for tax year 2005 or any prior tax year remain unpaid on September 1, 2006, or such date as commonwealth funds for reimbursement of the commonwealth's share of such bill have become unavailable, whichever occurs first. 
(e)  Penalty and interest. Penalty and interest with respect to bills issued pursuant to this section shall be computed on the entire amount of tax owed. Penalties and interest shall be computed at the rate provided in sections 35-4(c) and 35-5(b) from the original due date of the tax. 
(Code 1988, § 35-7.1; Ord. No. 2005-115, § 1, 12-13-2005; Ord. No. 2006-42, § 1, 5-23-2006)  
Sec. 35-9.1. - Exemption from personal property taxation for one motor vehicle owned and regularly used by an eligible disabled veteran. 
(a)  For the calendar year beginning January 1, 2016, and ending December 31, 2016, and for each and every calendar year thereafter, unless changed, not more than one motor vehicle owned and regularly used for personal use by an eligible disabled veteran shall be exempted from the personal property tax levied by the City of Portsmouth on motor vehicles. 
(b)  When used in this section, the phrase "disabled veteran" shall mean any veteran who has either lost, or lost the use of, one or both legs, or an arm or a hand, or who is blind, or who is permanently and totally disabled, and who therefore meets the requirements established in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3506(19), including that the disability is service connected, as certified by the department of veterans services. For purposes of this section, a veteran is blind if he or she meets the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100. 
(c)  To qualify for the exemption established herein, a disabled veteran must submit to the commissioner of the revenue: 
(1)  A written statement from the department of veterans services confirming that he or she meets the requirements of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3506(19); and 
(2)  A written statement from the department of veteran services confirming that the disability is service connected; and 
(3)  An application in the form required by the commissioner of the revenue and specifically identifying the motor vehicle for which an exemption is sought. 
(d)  An eligible disabled veteran may have no more than one motor vehicle exempted from taxation pursuant to this section. All other motor vehicles owned or regularly used by said eligible disabled veteran shall be taxed or levied pursuant to the general tax rate established by city council on motor vehicles. 
(e)  If an eligible disabled veteran seeks to change the motor vehicle subject to the exemption, the veteran must first submit an application to the commissioner of the revenue identifying the new vehicle. The exemption established by this section shall not automatically transfer or retroactively apply to a new motor vehicle acquired by an eligible disabled veteran. If an eligible disabled veteran transfers the exemption from one motor vehicle to another but maintains ownership of the first motor vehicle, the exemption shall continue to apply to the original motor vehicle for the tax year of the transfer and shall not apply to the new vehicle until the next tax year. 
(f)  The exemption established by this section shall not continue with a motor vehicle upon transfer, sale or other disposition of the vehicle by an eligible disabled veteran. 
(g)  The exemption established by this section shall first take effect for the calendar year in which an eligible disabled veteran submits an application meeting the requirements of subsection (c) for a qualified motor vehicle. The exemption shall not be applied retroactively to previous years' tax filings. 
( Ord. No. 2015-41, §§ 1, 2, 6-23-2015 ) 
Editor's note— At the city's instruction, section 35-9.1, adopted by Ord. No. 2015-41 , adopted June 23, 2015, has been codified herein as set out. These provisions shall take effect on January 1, 2016.  
Sec. 35-10. - Charging off and correction of delinquent personal property taxes. 
The commissioner of the revenue is hereby authorized to charge off or correct, from time to time, such unpaid and outstanding delinquent taxes for personal property as may be found to have been erroneously or incorrectly assessed. Prior to any such action, the commissioner of the revenue shall file with the city council, the chief financial officer and the city attorney a statement of the matter, and no such action shall become final until the expiration of ten days from the date that such statement shall have been received by the council in regular session. All such actions occurring in any one calendar month shall be consolidated into and filed as one report. 
(Code 1973, § 35-17; Code 1988, § 35-8; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-11. - Proration of tax on motor vehicles, trailers and boats. 
(a)  There shall be a personal property tax assessed and levied at the rate established each year by the city council on motor vehicles, trailers and boats ("hereafter referred to in this section as taxable property") which are titled or acquire a situs within the city on or after January 2 of any year. When taxable property acquires a situs within the city on or after January 2, the personal property tax for that year shall be assessed to the owner prorated on a monthly basis for the portion of the tax year during which the taxable property is titled or has situs within the city. When taxable property with a situs in the city is transferred to a new owner within the city, the personal property tax shall be assessed to the new owner prorated on a monthly basis for the portion of the tax year during which the new owner owns the taxable property. For the purpose of proration, a period of more than one-half of a month shall be counted as a full month, and a period of less than one-half of a month shall not be counted. All taxable property which acquires situs or has its title transferred after January 1 shall be assessed as of the first day of the month in which the taxable property acquires situs within the city or has its title transferred. The owner of taxable property acquiring situs within the city or to whom taxable property is transferred or who shall transfer title or acquire a new tax situs for the taxable property shall file a declaration with the commissioner of the revenue within 30 days of the date on which such property acquires a change of situs or title is transferred, on a form provided by the commissioner. 
(b)  When any taxable property loses its situs within the city or its title is transferred to a new owner, the taxpayer shall from that time be relieved from personal property tax on such taxable property on a prorated basis. The taxpayer is entitled to receive a credit for taxes already paid towards taxable property newly transferred to the taxpayer, or a credit against any property taxes outstanding against the taxpayer on a prorated basis. If there be no tax liability against which the credit can apply, the commissioner of the revenue shall apply to the city treasurer for a refund which can be made without further city council action. No refunds will be paid while the owner of the taxable property has any delinquent tax account with, or liability to, the city. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any taxable property which acquires a situs within the commonwealth in a nonprorating locality. 
(c)  Taxes on all taxable property titled or with a situs within the city acquired on or before April 15 of any year shall be paid on or before June 5 of that year. Any person failing to pay the tax by the due date shown on the bill shall incur interest and penalties as set forth in sections 35-4 and 35-5. 
(d)  Taxes on all taxable property which acquires situs within the city or has its title transferred after April first and through December thirty-first of any year shall be paid by the date shown on the bill which is mailed to the owner of the taxable property; provided, however, such due date shall be not less than 30 days after the date of the issuance of the tax bill. Any person failing to pay the tax by the date shown on the bill shall incur interest and penalties as set forth in sections 35-3 and 35-4. 
(e)  Any person who fails to file with the commissioner of the revenue as required in subsection (a) of this section, but is subsequently assessed with personal property tax, shall be taxed from the date that the title or situs was acquired and incur penalty and interest as provided herein. 
(f)  An exemption from the tax provided for in this section shall be granted for any tax year or portion thereof during which the property was legally assessed by another jurisdiction in the commonwealth, and such tax on the assessed property was paid and not refunded in whole or in part. 
(g)  Any person who moves to the city from a nonprorating locality in a single tax year shall be entitled to a property tax credit from the city if the person was liable for personal property taxes on a motor vehicle and has paid those taxes to a nonprorating locality and the owner replaces for any reason the original vehicle upon which taxes are due to the nonprorating locality for the same tax year. The city shall provide a credit against the total tax due on the replacement vehicle in an amount equal to the tax paid to the nonprorating locality for the period of time commencing with the disposition of the original vehicle and continuing through the close of the tax year in which the owner incurred tax liability to the nonprorating locality for the original vehicle. 
(Code 1988, § 35-9; Ord. No. 1991-76, §§ 3, 5, 7-9-1991; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001; Ord. No. 2006-24, § 1, 3-21-2006) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3516; mailing certain bills to taxpayers; penalties; electronic transmission, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3912.  
Sec. 35-12. - Submitting false information; refusing to answer. 
If any person shall give to the commissioner of the revenue a false list of persons or property subject to taxation, or shall refuse to give a list on oath or affirmation, when required by the commissioner of the revenue, the person so answering falsely or refusing to answer shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor, and the commissioner of the revenue shall proceed to list such person and his property according to the best information he can procure. 
(Code 1973, § 35-19; Code 1988, § 35-10) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 35-13. - Inaccessible persons to furnish list. 
Any person chargeable with taxes, who may be inaccessible to the commissioner of the revenue after due diligence on his part, shall, before June 1, furnish the commissioner of the revenue with such a list as it would have been his duty to furnish him in the usual way, and shall be subject to all the provisions of section 35-12 and chapter 20 of this Code. Any person failing to comply with this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 35-20; Code 1988, § 35-11) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 3 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 35-14. - Relief from erroneous assessments and erroneous payments generally. 
(a)  Any person who feels that he has been erroneously assessed for real estate tax or local levies on tangible personal property, machinery and tools, or a local license fee, or any other local levy, may, within three years from the last day of, the tax year for which such assessment was made, or within one year from the date of the assessment, whichever is later, make in writing application to the commissioner of the revenue regarding the assessment of local levies on tangible personal property, machinery and tools, or a local license fee, or any other local levy, or to the city assessor regarding the assessment of real estate, seeking by such application exoneration or abatement of such tax if same is unpaid or refund if such tax has been paid. An application that is not timely made will not be considered. 
(b)  If the commissioner of revenue when the application is for relief from the assessment of local levies on tangible personal property, machinery and tools, or a local license fee or any other local levy, or if the city assessor when the application is for relief from the assessment of real estate, is satisfied that he has erroneously assessed any applicant for the assessment in question, and assessment exceeds the proper amount, the commissioner of revenue or city assessor shall certify to the city treasurer and the city manager, or his designee, the amount erroneously assessed. If the taxes or fees have not been paid, the applicant shall be exonerated from payment of so much thereof as is erroneous, and if such taxes or fees have been paid, the city treasurer or his successor in office and the city manager, or his designee, shall refund to the applicant the amount erroneously paid, together with any penalties and interest paid thereon. When the commissioner of revenue or city assessor who made the erroneous assessment has been succeeded by another person, such person shall have the same authority as the commissioner or assessor making the original erroneous assessment, provided he makes diligent investigation to determine that the original assessment was erroneously made and certifies thereto to the city treasurer, the city manager, or his designee, and the city attorney. Additionally, the same refund procedure shall apply to the refunds of erroneous overpayment of taxes or fees by any applicant. 
(c)  If the assessment is less than the proper amount, the commissioner of the revenue or the city assessor shall assess such applicant with the proper amount. 
(d)  When an unpaid erroneous assessment of real estate is corrected under this section, and such real estate has been sold at a delinquent land sale, the city assessor shall certify a copy of such correction to the clerk of the circuit court of the city and the clerk shall note the correction in the delinquent land book opposite the entry of the tract or lot for the year or years for which the correction is made. 
(e)  Where the assessment which is subsequently considered erroneous was made as a result of miscalculation or ministerial error on the part of the commissioner of revenue, the city assessor, or any officer or employee of the city, interest on the amount erroneously assessed will be paid along with the refund at a rate of ten percent per annum from the date that the tax was paid or from the date the tax was required to be paid, whichever date is later. No interest will be paid where the assessment in question was based on a good faith assessment, was made as a result of a statutory assessment, or where the error was made on the part of the applicant. 
(f)  Whenever the city treasurer determines that there is a valid and legal claim against the city due by reason of the erroneous payment of any local tax, levy, license or fee, he is hereby fully empowered, authorized and directed, with the concurrence and approval of the city manager, and with the consent of the city attorney, to forthwith pay the amount of such claim to the respective claimant from the general fund or such special fund into which such tax, levy, license or fee may have been deposited. 
(Code 1973, § 35-7; Code 1988, § 35-12; Ord. No. 1990-91, § 1, 8-28-1990; Ord. No. 1992-32, § 1, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 1998-12, § 1, 4-14-1998; Ord. No. 2006-24, § 1, 3-21-2006; Ord. No. 2018-114 , § 1(Exh. A), 11-27-2018) 
State Law reference— Mailing certain bills to taxpayers; penalties; electronic transmission, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3912; correction of tax assessment, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3981; refunds of local taxes erroneously paid, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3990.  
Sec. 35-15. - Payment of locally assessed business tax prerequisite to issuance of license. 
The commissioner of the revenue shall not issue a business license for any business unless and until he receives a tax receipt and certificate signed by the city treasurer setting forth that all delinquent business license, real estate, personal property, meals, transient occupancy, severance and admissions taxes and machinery and tools taxes assessed by the city against such business have been paid in full. The requirements of this section shall be in addition to the requirements of the existing law but shall not be applicable to any person who, under the laws of the state, was not legally assessable with a personal property tax or a machinery and tools tax. 
(Code 1973, §§ 20-10, 35-5; Code 1988, § 35-13; Ord. No. 1989-101, 10-24-1989; Ord. No. 1995-85, § 1, 7-25-1995; Ord. No. 2013-02, § 1, 1-8-2013) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Requirement of evidence of payment of business license, business personal property, meals and admissions taxes, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3700.  
Sec. 35-16. - Giving bad check for payment of taxes. 
Any person uttering, publishing or passing any check or draft for the payment of taxes due the city which is subsequently returned because of insufficient funds, because there is no account or because the account has been closed, shall pay, in addition to the sum due, the fee prescribed in section 12-69 of this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 35-6; Code 1988, § 35-15) 
State Law reference— Authority for bad check charge, Code of Virginia, § 2.2-614.1; authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-106.  
Secs. 35-17—35-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - REAL ESTATE ASSESSMENTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Real estate assessments, § 2.12. 
State Law reference— Real estate assessments and reassessments generally, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3250 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 35-61. - Annual assessment required; office of assessor created. 
All real estate in the city not exempted from taxation by the Constitution of Virginia and not assessable for taxation by the state corporation commission as provided by law shall be assessed annually for taxation by the city, and for that purpose the office of city assessor is hereby created. 
(Code 1973, § 35-50; Code 1988, § 35-61) 
Charter reference— Council to provide for annual assessment, § 2.12(b)(1).  
Sec. 35-62. - Appointment, term and general powers and duties of assessor. 
The annual assessment of real estate in the city shall be made by a single assessor appointed by the city council for such purpose, who shall give his entire time to the duties of his office. The city assessor shall hold office during the pleasure of the council. The city assessor shall be known as the city assessor, and he shall have all the powers and duties prescribed by the laws of the state for assessors of real estate, and all the duties now devolved upon the commissioner of the revenue with respect to the assessment of real estate for taxation shall be transferred to and devolve upon the city assessor upon his taking the oath of office. The city assessor shall, on July 1 in each year, or as soon thereafter as possible, prepare the land book, reflecting all changes or assessments for that tax year, and perform all other duties required by law to be performed by the commissioner of the revenue with respect to assessment of real estate for taxation. 
(Code 1973, § 35-51; Code 1988, § 35-62) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 2.12(b)(1), (3).  
Sec. 35-63. - Authority of assessor to summons witnesses and require production of books, records, etc. 
The city assessor, in performing his duties, shall have authority to summon taxpayers, their agents and other persons who may have information on the subject to appear and testify under oath concerning the ownership and value of real estate assessable by the city assessor and to require the production of books of account and other papers and records containing such information for inspection by the city assessor. Such summons may be served by an officer authorized by law to serve process or by registered mail. Any person refusing to answer the summons of the city assessor or failing or refusing to furnish information or to produce books of account, papers or other records required by the city assessor, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Each day's failure to answer such summons or to furnish such information or to produce such book of account or other papers, or records, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1973, § 35-60; Code 1988, § 35-63) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 35-64. - Departments and bureaus to furnish assessor with information. 
The departments and bureaus of the city having in their possession or under their control data or information which will aid the city assessor in carrying out his work shall furnish the same to the city assessor upon written application therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 35-62; Code 1988, § 35-64)  
Sec. 35-65. - General procedure. 
The city assessor shall assess annually for taxation at its fair market value all real estate within the city subject to assessment by him, which shall include all lands, buildings, structures and improvements thereon, and manufactured homes installed according to the Uniform Statewide Building Code, and all rights thereto and interest therein, and he shall have the right and power to do all things necessary to assess such property. Except with respect to new construction and other cases where the same is not practicable, such assessments shall be completed not later than January 31 of the year preceding the tax year for which the same shall be effective, and taxes for each year on such real estate shall be made on the basis of the last assessment made prior to such year, subject to such changes as may have been lawfully made. 
(Code 1973, § 35-52; Code 1988, § 35-65; Ord. No. 1994-55, § 1, 6-14-1994) 
Charter reference— Similar provisions, § 2.12(b)(1), (2).  
Sec. 35-66. - Effective date. 
Every annual assessment of real estate shall be effective for tax purposes on July 1 of the fiscal year for which the assessment is made and the taxes and other charges shall be extended on the basis of every such assessment. The beginning of the tax and assessment year for the assessment of taxes on all real estate assessable by the city for taxation shall be July 1, and the owner of such real estate on that day shall be assessed with taxes for the fiscal year beginning on that day. 
(Code 1973, § 35-56; Code 1988, § 35-66)  
Sec. 35-67. - Notice of increase. 
Whenever the assessment of any real estate is increased by the city assessor, he shall give written notice thereof to the owner in whose name such property is listed by mailing the notice to the last known post office address of such owner or person having an interest in the property, but the validity of such assessment shall not be affected by any failure to give or receive such notice. Every such notice shall contain the assessed value of such real estate immediately preceding such increase. 
(Code 1973, § 35-53; Code 1988, § 35-67) 
State Law reference— Notice of change in assessment, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3330.  
Sec. 35-68. - Preparation, form and disposition of land book. 
When preparing the land book, the city assessor shall extend the taxes, prepare the tax bills and deliver the same to the city treasurer for proof and mailing. The form of the land book shall be prescribed by the city assessor and each and every parcel of real estate shall be entered separately thereon in the name of the owner thereof or in the name of the owner of any interest therein. The land book shall be so arranged that all real estate owned by the city, religious and fraternal societies and others exempt from taxation shall be listed separately from all other property assessed. No assessment of any real estate shall be held to be invalid because of any error, omission or irregularity in charging such real estate upon the land book unless it is shown by the person contesting such assessment that such error, omission or irregularity has operated to the prejudice of his or their rights. The original of the land book shall be filed in the office of the city assessor, and copies thereof shall be filed in the offices of the city treasurer and the clerk of the circuit court of the city. No change, alteration or addition to any entry appearing therein shall be made unless authorized by law. The city assessor shall, upon the completion of each annual assessment, certify on the land book, on oath, that all real estate subject to taxation by the city has been assessed by him at the fair market value thereof and that there are no errors on the face of the land book. The city assessor shall furnish to the state department of taxation one copy of the land book and such other information regarding the assessment as it may require. 
(Code 1973, § 35-54; Code 1988, § 35-68)  
Sec. 35-69. - Land book entry when street, alley, etc., closed to public use. 
Whenever any ordinance is passed closing any street, alley or other public place to public use or travel, the city clerk shall send a certified copy of such ordinance to the city assessor and the city assessor shall enter on the land book for the next ensuing year in the name of the abutting owners or persons who may be entitled to such property the parcels of land formerly occupied by such street, alley or other public place. 
(Code 1973, § 35-61; Code 1988, § 35-69)  
Sec. 35-70. - Assessment of nontaxable property; review of assessments by state corporation commission. 
The city assessor shall assess at its fair market value all real estate belonging to the city, religious and fraternal societies and others exempt from taxation. The city assessor shall review all assessments made by the state corporation commission and compare the same with the assessments of comparable property in the city and inform the state corporation commission of any discrepancies and inequities in the assessments. 
(Code 1973, § 35-55; Code 1988, § 35-70)  
Sec. 35-71. - Application for exemption. 
Every entity, except the commonwealth, any political subdivision of the commonwealth, or the United States, which owns real property exempt from taxation pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3600 et seq., after receiving 60 days' written notice, shall file biennially an application on forms supplied by the city assessor as a requirement for retention of the exempt status of the property. Such application shall show the ownership and usage of the property, and shall be filed within the next 60 days preceding the year for which the exemption, or the retention thereof, is sought. 
(Code 1973, § 35-57.1; Code 1988, § 35-71) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3605.  
Sec. 35-72. - Assessment of new buildings and improvements; substantially completed. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, all new buildings substantially completed or fit for use or occupancy prior to May 1 of the fiscal year of completion shall be assessed when so completed or fit for use and occupancy, and the city assessor shall enter in the land books the fair market value thereof as of the first day of the next succeeding quarter year after the building has been substantially completed or fit for use and occupancy. Further, the assessor shall assess or reassess, as required, any lot, tract, piece or parcel of land upon or to which improvements have been made. No partial assessment as provided herein shall become effective until information as to the date and amount of such assessment is recorded in the office of the official authorized to collect taxes on real property and made available for public inspection. The total tax on any such new building or improvement for that fiscal year shall be the sum of: 
(a)  The tax upon the assessment of such new building or improvement, computed according to the ratio which the portion of the fiscal year such building or improvement is substantially completed or fit for use and occupancy bears to the entire fiscal year; and 
(b)  The tax upon the assessment of such new building or improvement as it existed on July 1 of that fiscal year, computed according to the ratio which the portion of the fiscal year such building or improvement was not substantially complete or fit for use and occupancy bears to the entire fiscal year. 
(Code 1973, § 35-57; Code 1988, § 35-72; Ord. No. 2019-39 , § 1, 6-11-2019) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3992.  
Sec. 35-73. - Reduction of value when building damaged or destroyed. 
When from natural decay or other causes any previously assessed building or enclosure is either wholly destroyed or reduced in value below $100.00, the city assessor shall deduct from the charge against the owner the value at which such building and enclosure may have been assessed, and if the value of the building has been impaired by fortuitous happening beyond the control of the owner to the extent of $100.00 or more, the city assessor shall assess the building on its present condition and reduce the charge for the same to the amount so assessed. No such reduction shall be allowed in the case of damage to any building if the damage is repaired during the same calendar year in which it occurred. Application for such abatement shall be made by or on behalf of the owner of the building within the calendar year in which the building was damaged or destroyed or in which the damage was sustained and shall be effective from the first day of the quarter year after the application is made. 
(Code 1973, § 35-57; Code 1988, § 35-73) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3293. See also, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3222.  
Sec. 35-74. - Release of tax lien on portion of real estate. 
In the event that a purchaser acquires a portion of a tract of real estate, the purchaser may request the city assessor to determine the amount of any delinquent tax or assessment that is properly chargeable against such portion of the real estate. The city assessor shall determine the amount of tax or assessment due on such real estate. The city treasurer shall release such portion of real estate from any lien for delinquent taxes or assessments upon receipt of payment of the total amount of taxes, including penalty and interest, and assessments which may be determined to be due on such portion of the real estate; provided, however, the city hereby expressly retains its lien for delinquent taxes, including penalty and interest, and current assessments on that portion of the property which remains unsold, until such time as the taxes, penalty and interest and current assessments are paid in full. 
(Code 1973, § 35-64; Code 1988, § 35-74; Ord. No. 1998-22, § 1, 4-28-1998)  
Sec. 35-75. - Equalization of assessments generally. 
(a)  In order to equalize assessments of real estate annually, the city assessor shall hold hearings as often as may be necessary between February 1 and March 31 in each year for the purpose of receiving such evidence as may be presented to him by any taxpayer with respect to the inequality of the assessment made of the real estate owned by such taxpayer during the 12-month period ending on January 31 last ensuing. Any taxpayer feeling aggrieved by any such assessment of his property may apply to the city assessor for the equalization thereof on forms provided by the city assessor for that purpose. 
(b)  At least ten days before the hearings provided for in subsection (a) of this section, notice thereof shall be given by publication one time in one of the newspapers having general circulation in the city. Notwithstanding such notice, such hearings may be granted by the city assessor upon appointments. 
(c)  After hearing the evidence referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the city assessor may take such action as he may deem necessary to equalize assessments and shall record the action taken in the land book. Each taxpayer having made application for such hearing and any other taxpayer affected by the action of the city assessor shall be advised of the decision of the city assessor with respect to such assessment. 
(d)  The city assessor may authorize persons employed in his office who are competent so to do to hold any hearing referred to in this section provided that the evidence presented or a summary thereof is transmitted to the city assessor for action with respect thereto. 
(Code 1973, § 35-59; Code 1988, § 35-75)  
Sec. 35-76. - Board of equalization. 
(a)  There shall be a board of equalization as provided in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3370. 
(b)  The members of the board of equalization shall receive per diem compensation for the time they are actually engaged in the duties of their office at the rate of $50.00 per day. Such per diem compensation may be limited to such number of days as in the judgment of the council is sufficient for the work of the board in any calendar year. 
(c)  The board of equalization shall proceed to hold its hearings during the months of April and May in each year and shall consider all assessments originally made by the city assessor during the 12-month period and on January 31 last ensuing, giving precedence in order of hearing to those assessments effective for the current tax year. 
(Code 1973, § 35-58; Code 1988, § 35-76; Ord. No. 2012-04 , § 1, 1-24-2012)  
Sec. 35-77. - Relief from assessments. 
Any person, or the city, aggrieved by any assessment made by the city assessor or by the board of equalization may apply for relief in the manner provided by Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3984. 
(Code 1973, § 35-63; Code 1988, § 35-77)  
Secs. 35-78—35-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - USE VALUE ASSESSMENT OF CERTAIN REAL ESTATE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to adopt ordinance similar to this division, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3231. 
 
Sec. 35-101. - Findings of fact. 
The city finds that the preservation of real estate devoted to open space uses within its boundaries is in the public interest and, having heretofore adopted a land use plan, hereby ordains that such real estate shall be taxed in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3229 et seq. and this division. 
(Code 1973, § 35-64.1; Code 1988, § 35-101)  
Sec. 35-102. - Owner's application generally. 
(a)  The owners of any real estate meeting the criteria set forth in Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3230 and 58.1-3233 must submit an application for taxation on the basis of a use assessment to the city assessor by November 1 preceding the tax year for which such taxation is sought. 
(b)  Application under this section shall be on forms provided by the state tax commissioner and supplied by the city assessor and shall include such schedules, photographs, drawings and additional information as may be required by the city assessor. 
(c)  An application shall be submitted under this section whenever the use or acreage of land previously approved changes, except when a change in acreage occurs solely as a result of a conveyance necessitated by governmental action or condemnation of a portion of any land previously approved for taxation on the basis of use assessment. 
(d)  A separate application shall be filed under this section for each use for which qualification is sought. 
(e)  A property owner must revalidate annually, with the city assessor, any application previously approved under this division on forms prepared by the city assessor and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1973, § 35-64.2; Code 1988, § 35-102) 
State Law reference— Application by property owners for assessment, etc., continuation of assessment, etc., Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3234.  
Sec. 35-103. - Misstatements in application. 
(a)  In the event of a material misstatement of facts in the application or a material change in such facts prior to the date of assessment, such application for taxation based on use assessment granted thereunder shall be void and the tax for such year extended on the basis of value determined under Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3236(D). No application for assessment based on use shall be accepted or approved if, at the time the application is filed, the tax on the land affected is delinquent. Upon the payment of all delinquent taxes, including penalties and interest, the application shall be treated in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Any person failing to report properly any change in use of property for which an application for use value taxation had been filed shall be liable for all such taxes, in such amounts and at such times as if he had complied herewith and assessments had been properly made, and he shall be liable for such penalties and interest thereon as may be provided by ordinance. Any person making a material misstatement of fact in any such application shall be liable for all such taxes, in such amounts and at such times as if such property had been assessed on the basis of fair market value as applied to other real estate in the taxing jurisdiction, together with interest and penalties thereon. If such material misstatement was made with the intent to defraud the locality, he shall be further assessed with an additional penalty of 100 percent of such unpaid taxes. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, incorrect information on the following subjects will be considered material misstatements of fact: 
(1)  The number and identities of the known owners of the property at the time of application; 
(2)  The actual use of the property. 
The intentional misrepresentation of the number of acres in the parcel or the number of acres to be taxed according to use shall also be considered a material misstatement of fact for the purposes of this section. 
(Code 1973, § 35-64.6; Code 1988, §§ 35-103, 35-107) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3234, 58.1-3238.  
Sec. 35-104. - Determinations by city assessor. 
(a)  Prior to the assessment of any parcel of real estate, the city assessor shall: 
(1)  Determine that the real estate meets the criteria set forth in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3230 and the standards prescribed thereunder to qualify for one of the classifications set forth therein, and he may request an opinion from the director of the state department of conservation and recreation, the state forester or the state commissioner of agriculture and consumer services; 
(2)  Determine further that real estate devoted solely to: (i) agricultural or horticultural use consists of a minimum of five acres; except that for real estate used for purposes of engaging in aquaculture as defined in Code of Virginia, § 3.1-73.6 or for the purposes of raising specialty crops, the city council may by ordinance prescribe that these uses consist of a minimum acreage of less than five acres, (ii) forest use consists of a minimum of 20 acres, and (iii) open-space use consists of a minimum of five acres or such greater minimum acreage as may be prescribed by ordinance; except that for real estate adjacent to a scenic river, a scenic highway, a Virginia Byway or public property in the Virginia Outdoors Plan or for any real estate in any city, county or town having a density of population greater than 5,000 per square mile, the city council may by ordinance prescribe that land devoted to open-space uses consist of a minimum of one quarter of an acre. The minimum acreage requirements for special classifications of real estate shall be determined by adding together the total area of contiguous real estate excluding recorded subdivision lots recorded after July 1, 1983, titled in the same ownership. For purposes of this section, properties separated only by a public right-of-way are considered contiguous; and 
(3)  Determine further that real estate devoted to open-space use is: (i) within an agricultural, a forestal, or an agricultural and forestal district entered into pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 15.2-4300 et seq., or (ii) subject to a recorded perpetual easement that is held by a public body, and promotes the open-space use classification, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3230, or (iii) subject to a recorded commitment entered into by the landowners with the city council, or its authorized designee, not to change the use to a nonqualifying use for a time period stated in the commitment of not less than four years nor more than ten years. Such commitment shall be subject to uniform standards prescribed by the director of the state department of conservation and recreation pursuant to the authority set out in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3240. Such commitment shall run with the land for the applicable period, and may be terminated in the manner provided in Code of Virginia, § 15.2-4314 for withdrawal of land from an agricultural, a forestal or an agricultural and forestal district. 
(b)  Upon the refusal of the state commissioner of agriculture and consumer services, the state forester or the director of the state department of conservation and recreation to issue an opinion or in the event of an unfavorable opinion which does not comport with standards set forth in the statements filed pursuant to this section, the party aggrieved may seek relief in the circuit court and in the event that the court finds in his favor, it may issue an order which shall serve in lieu of an opinion for the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 35-64.3; Code 1988, § 35-104) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3233, 58.1-3240.  
Sec. 35-105. - Land book entries; tax to be extended from use value. 
The use value and fair market value of any property qualifying under this division shall be placed on the land book before delivery to the city treasurer and the tax for the next succeeding tax year shall be extended from the use value. 
(Code 1973, § 35-64.4; Code 1988, § 35-105) 
State Law reference— Real estate valuation, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3236.  
Sec. 35-106. - Roll-back tax when use changes to nonqualifying use. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed a roll-back tax, in such amount as may be determined under Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3237, upon any property or portion thereof as to which the use changes to a nonqualifying use under this division, plus simple interest on such roll-back taxes at the rate of ten percent per annum. 
(b)  The city assessor shall determine and assess the roll-back tax of the owner of any real estate liable for such tax, which shall be paid to the city treasurer within 30 days of assessment. Failure to make such payment shall cause the owner to be liable for an additional penalty of ten percent of the amount of the roll-back tax, which penalty shall be collected as part of the tax. In addition to such penalty, there is hereby imposed interest at the rate of ten percent per annum on the amount of roll-back tax duly assessed, and the penalty thereon, to the extent the same remains unpaid. 
(Code 1973, §§ 35-64.5, 35-64.6; Code 1988, § 35-106; Ord. No. 1990-70, § 1, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Change in use or zoning of real estate assessed; roll-back taxes, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3237; penalties, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3915, 58.1-3916.  
Sec. 35-107. - Applicability of general tax law. 
The provisions of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1 et seq. applicable to local levies and real estate assessment and taxation shall be applicable to assessments and taxation under this division mutatis mutandis including, without limitation, provisions relating to tax liens and the correction or erroneous assessments, and for such purposes the roll-back taxes shall be considered to be deferred real estate taxes. 
(Code 1973, § 35-64.7; Code 1988, § 35-108) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3243.  
Secs. 35-108—35-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EXEMPTIONS FROM REAL ESTATE TAXES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 35-121—35-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PAYMENTS IN LIEU OF REAL ESTATE TAXES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Payments in lieu of real estate taxes, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3400 et seq. 
 
Sec. 35-131. - Service charge on certain real property exempt from taxation, imposed. 
There is hereby imposed, pursuant to the authority of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3400 et seq., a fee or service charge which shall be collected from the owners of all real estate within the city which is exempt from taxation under Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3606(A)(1), which is property owned directly or indirectly by the commonwealth or any political subdivision thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 35-231; Code 1988, § 35-131)  
Sec. 35-132. - Computation. 
(a)  The fee or service charge imposed in section 35-131 shall be based on the assessed value of the real estate and the amount which the city expended in the fiscal year preceding the fiscal year such charge is assessed for the purpose of furnishing police and fire protection and for the collection and disposal of refuse. The cost of public school education shall be included in such amount in determining the service charge imposed or faculty and staff housing of an educational institution. Any amount received from federal or state grants specifically designated for such purposes and assistance provided to the city pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 14.1-84.1 et seq. shall not be considered in determining the cost of providing such services for the real estate.
