The expenditures for services not provided for certain real estate shall not be applicable to the calculations of the service charge for such real estate, nor shall such expenditures be applicable when a service is currently funded by another service charge. The service charge shall not be applicable to public roadways or property held for future construction of such roadways. This service charge shall not exceed the real estate tax which would have been payable had such property been fully taxable. The service charge shall be fixed by dividing such expenditures by the assessed fair market value of all the real estate within the city, except real estate owned by the United States government or any of its instrumentalities, expressed in $100.00, including nontaxable property, provided there first be listed and published by the city assessor in the land book of the city in the same manner as taxable real estate, all the exempt real estate. 
(b)  In the valuation of exempt real estate for purposes of this section, artistic and historical significance shall not be taken into account. 
(c)  Any person aggrieved by the assessment or the valuation of real estate for the purposes of this section may apply to the city assessor for correction thereof. If the city assessor advises that the assessment or valuation is erroneous, he shall correct the same. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city assessor may appeal to the circuit court of the city, as provided in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3984. 
(Code 1973, § 25-232; Code 1988, § 35-132) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3401.  
Sec. 35-133. - Billing; time of payment. 
The service charge imposed in section 35-131 shall be calculated and billed by the chief financial officer with payment made to the city treasurer. The payment shall be due on June 1 of the fiscal year in which billing is made. 
(Code 1973, § 35-233; Code 1988, § 35-133; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-134. - Tax exemption of real and personal property by classification and designation. 
The real and personal property of certain entities and organizations may be determined exempt from taxation by classification and designation as provided by article XVI of this chapter. 
(Code 1988, § 35-134; Ord. No. 2005-28, § 1, 4-26-2005)  
Sec. 35-135. - Environmental restoration sites. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority granted by § 58.1-3664 of the Code of Virginia, environmental restoration sites are hereby determined to be a separate class of property which is exempt from real estate taxation up to limit set herein, as set forth in this section. 
(b)  An environmental restoration site means real estate which contains or did contain environmental contamination from the release of hazardous substances, hazardous wastes, solid waste or petroleum, the restoration of which would abate or prevent pollution to the atmosphere or waters of the Commonwealth of Virginia and which (i) is subject to voluntary remediation pursuant to § 10.1-1232 of the Code of Virginia and (ii) receives a certificate of continued eligibility from the Virginia Waste Management Board during each year for which it qualifies for the applicable tax exemption. 
(c)  An environmental restoration site shall be classified as such for a single five-year period. That period shall commence on the date that the department of environmental quality issues a certification of voluntary completion for the property. A classification issued at any time during a calendar year shall be effective for the entire calendar year, without pro rating. The classification shall be for the current year and subsequent years only, no property shall be eligible for the classification for any year prior to 2006, and requests for reclassification for years prior to 2006 are both unauthorized and prohibited. No property shall be eligible for more than one five-year classification period. 
(d)  If an environmental restoration site is located in an enterprise zone designated by the Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia to take effect as of but not prior to January 1, 2014, then the classification granted by this section shall be for the full assessed value of land and improvements for any qualified tax parcel, up to a maximum assessed value of $5,000,000.00. Any assessed value in excess of $5,000,000.00 for any qualified tax parcel shall be fully taxable. For all other environmental restoration sites, the classification granted by this section shall be for the full assessed value of land and improvements for any qualified tax parcel, up to a maximum assessed value of $3,000,000.00. Any assessed value in excess of $3,000,000.00 for any qualified tax parcel shall be fully taxable. 
(e)  The burden shall be on the property owner to provide to the city assessor, within 90 days of the property owner's receipt: (i) a certification of voluntary completion from the department of environmental quality showing that the property qualifies initially as an environmental restoration site; and (ii) a certificate of continued eligibility from the Virginia Waste Management Board for each subsequent year of the five-year tax exemption period for which an exemption is sought. The city assessor shall have no responsibility to issue or to maintain the classification authorized under this section unless the property owner timely provides full and proper documentation of eligibility during each applicable tax year. 
(f)  If the owner of any property classified hereunder as an environmental restoration site fails to timely pay to the City of Portsmouth any other taxes which are legally owed to the city, he shall be deemed to have waived his claim to have the property classified under this section. This waiver shall apply for the tax year in question and for all subsequent tax years for which the property otherwise qualifies for an exemption. Once the classification of a property is deemed waived under this section, the waiver shall attach to the property and shall be irrevocable, regardless of possible change of ownership of the property. 
(Ord. No. 2006-45, § 1, 6-13-2006; Ord. No. 2015-05, § 1, 1-27-2015 )  
Secs. 35-136—35-155. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ELDERLY AND DISABLED PERSONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to grant exemption provided for in this division, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3210. 
 
Sec. 35-156. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Affidavit means the real estate tax exemption affidavit. 
Applicant means a person who applies for a real estate tax exemption under this division. 
Director means the director of social services or his designee. 
Dwelling means the full-time residence of the person claiming exemption from real estate taxes under this division. 
Exemption means exemption from city real estate taxes under the provisions of this division. 
Owner means any person owning title or partial title to real property. 
Permanently and totally disabled means unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity by reason of medically determinable physical or mental impairment or deformity which can be expected to result in death or can be expected to last for the duration of the person's life. [6] 
Property means real property. 
Taxable year means the year for which an annual assessment is made and for which exemption is claimed under this division. 
(Code 1973, § 35-221; Code 1988, § 35-156) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3217. 
 
Sec. 35-157. - Authorized. 
Subject to the annual appropriation by city council of funds at least equal to the total cost of such exemptions, real estate tax exemption is hereby authorized for qualified property owners who are not less than 65 years of age or who are permanently and totally disabled, and who are eligible according to the terms of this division. Persons qualifying for exemption are deemed to be bearing an extraordinary real estate tax burden in relation to their income and financial worth. Should any annual appropriation be less than the total cost of such exemptions, the tax exemption for the subject year shall be applied as a pro rata percentage of the applicable exemption. The pro rata exemption shall be calculated by dividing the appropriated funds by the total cost of the qualified exemptions. 
(Code 1973, § 35-222; Code 1988, § 35-157; Ord. No. 2009-45 , § 1, 5-12-2009, eff. 7-1-2009) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3218.  
Sec. 35-158. - Administration. 
(a)  Eligibility. Eligibility for exemption shall be determined by the director of social services according to the provisions of this division. The director is hereby authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce such rules and regulations in conformance with the provisions of this division and the laws of the commonwealth enabling this division as may be reasonably necessary to determine qualifications for exemption. 
(b)  Inquiries. The director shall make such inquiry of persons seeking exemption, requiring answers under oath, as may be reasonably necessary to determine the qualifications and eligibility for exemption. The director may, in addition, require the production of certified tax returns and appraisal reports to establish the income or financial worth of any applicant for exemption. All inquiries made by the director and all information supplied by an applicant shall be deemed confidential and shall not be released to any person other than an employee or officer of the city having need for such information, unless otherwise ordered by a court of law. 
(Code 1973, §§ 35-223, 35-225; Code 1988, § 35-158) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3213.  
Sec. 35-159. - General prerequisites to grant. 
An exemption shall be granted to persons eligible subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The person making application must own or partially own title to the property for which exemption is claimed. 
(2)  The person making application must be permanently and totally disabled or must be 65 years old or older as of June 30th of the immediately preceding taxable year. In the case of joint ownership between spouses occupying such property, eligibility of either spouse shall establish eligibility of both. 
(3)  The person making application shall not have disposed of assets to future heirs within the preceding five years if such assets would have made the applicant ineligible under the requirements of this section. 
(4)  The total combined income from all sources for the immediately preceding calendar year of the owner or owners claiming tax exemption and of the owners' relatives or other household member living in the subject dwelling shall not exceed $30,000.00; provided, that the first $4,000.00 of income of each relative other than spouse or other household member of the owner or owners who is living in the dwelling shall not be included in such total. In addition thereto, up to $7,500.00 of income of an owner who is permanently disabled shall not be included in such total. 
(5)  The net combined financial worth, including equitable interests, as of December 31st of the immediately preceding calendar year, of the owner or owners and of the spouse of any owner, excluding the value of the dwelling and the land, not exceeding one acre, upon which it is situated, and excluding furniture, household appliances and other items typically used in a home, shall not exceed $75,000.00. 
(Code 1973, § 35-224; Code 1988, § 35-159; Ord. No. 1988-42, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1988-109, §§ 1(35-224(e)), 2(35-224(f)), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1989-58, § 1, 6-27-1989; Ord. No. 1990-39, § 1, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1992-32, § 1, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 2005-95, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 2006-102, § 1, 12-12-2006) 
Editor's note— It should be noted that section 2 of Ord. No. 2006-102, provides, "That this ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2007 and shall apply to tax liens effective July 1, 2007." 
State Law reference— Similar provisions and authority of city as to income, net worth, etc., requirements, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3210—58.1-3212.  
Sec. 35-160. - Applicant's affidavit and certificate of disability—Generally. 
(a)  Not later than April 30 immediately preceding the taxable year in question, the person claiming exemption shall file a real estate tax exemption affidavit with the director of social services. Subject to the provisions of section 35-165, a person granted a real estate tax exemption shall refile said affidavit not later than April 30 of the third succeeding tax year following approval of an application; provided, however, each such person shall, prior to April 30 of each tax year, certify to the director that no information contained in the last preceding affidavit has changed to violate the limitations and conditions of the exemption. 
(b)  If the applicant is under 65 years of age, the affidavit required by this section shall have attached thereto a certification by the department of veteran's affairs or the railroad retirement board, or if such person is not eligible for certification by any of these agencies, a sworn affidavit by two medical doctors who are either licensed to practice medicine in the commonwealth or are military officers on active duty who practice medicine with the United States Armed Forces to the effect that such person is permanently and totally disabled, as defined in section 35-156. The affidavit of at least one of the doctors shall be based upon a physical examination of the person by such doctor. The affidavit of one of the doctors may be based upon medical information contained in the records of the civil service commission which is relevant to the standards for determining such permanent and total disability. 
(Code 1973, § 35-225; Code 1988, § 35-160; Ord. No. 1988-109, § 3(35-225(a)), 12-13-1988; Ord. No. 1990-71, § 1, 6-26-1990) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3213.  
Sec. 35-161. - Same—Extension of time for filing. 
(a)  The city manager, upon determining good cause, may extend the time specification in section 35-160(a) for applying for the exemption, if the applicant qualified for exemption in the immediate past tax year. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of section 35-160, any person who qualifies for exemption as a result of amendment by the city council of the combined income or net combined financial worth requirements of section 35-159 shall be permitted to make application for exemption not later than the thirtieth day of June immediately preceding the taxable year in question. 
(Code 1973, § 35-225; Code 1988, § 35-161; Ord. No. 1992-39, § 2, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 2006-102, § 1, 12-12-2006) 
Editor's note— It should be noted that section 2 of Ord. No. 2006-102, provides, "That this ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2007 and shall apply to tax liens effective July 1, 2007."  
Sec. 35-162. - Certification of assessor; adjustment of tax records, etc. 
If after audit and investigation, the director determines that a person is qualified for exemption, he shall so certify to the treasurer of the city, who shall deduct the amount of the exemption from the claimant's real estate tax liability and shall adjust the tax records accordingly. Any remaining tax due shall be billed in equal installments in accordance with section 35-2. 
(Code 1973, § 35-225; Code 1988, § 35-162)  
Sec. 35-163. - Amount of exemption. 
The person or persons qualifying for and claiming exemption shall have exempted that percentage of the real estate tax levied on the qualifying dwelling set forth in the following schedule: 
Total Income All Sources 	Tax Exemption 
(Percent) 
$0.00—21,000 	100 
21,001—22,000 	90 
22,001—23,000 	80 
23,001—24,000 	70 
24,001—25,000 	60 
25,001—26,000 	50 
26,001—27,000 	40 
27,001—28,000 	30 
28,001—29,000 	20 
29,001—30,000 	10 
Over $30,000 	0 
 
(Code 1973, § 15-226; Code 1988, § 35-163; Ord. No. 1988-42, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1990-39, § 2, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1992-39, § 3, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 2005-95, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 2006-102, § 1, 12-12-2006) 
Editor's note— It should be noted that section 2 of Ord. No. 2006-102, provides, "That this ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2007 and shall apply to tax liens effective July 1, 2007."  
Sec. 35-164. - Transfer. 
(a)  A taxpayer who is otherwise eligible for a tax exemption under this division shall not be deprived of such exemption if compelled by eminent domain proceedings, the threat of such proceedings or act of God to abandon the residence to which the tax exemption appertains. The tax exemption applicable to the residence that the taxpayer is forced to abandon shall be transferable to any residence purchased within 12 months after title to the first residence is conveyed or condemned. A taxpayer who is otherwise eligible for a tax exemption under this division shall not lose such eligibility and may transfer the same if he changes residences within the city. 
(b)  Any taxpayer seeking a transfer of an exemption shall make application therefor on forms provided by the director. Such forms shall include an affidavit reciting the facts that demonstrate eligibility for such exemption. If the director finds that the applicant is eligible for such exemption, he shall so certify to the city treasurer. The city treasurer shall thereupon deduct the exempted amount from the applicant's real estate tax liability. The exemption transfer, if granted, shall take effect from the date of the filing of the transfer application. 
(Code 1973, § 35-224.1; Code 1988, § 35-164; Ord. No. 2006-102, § 1, 12-12-2006) 
Editor's note— It should be noted that section 2 of Ord. No. 2006-102, provides, "That this ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2007 and shall apply to tax liens effective July 1, 2007."  
Sec. 35-165. - Notice and effect of changes in status. 
(a)  It is the responsibility of any property owner to whom an exemption has been granted to notify the director immediately of any changes in respect to income, financial worth, ownership of property or other factors occurring during the taxable year for which the affidavit is filed under this division and having the effect of exceeding or violating the limitations and conditions provided in this division. Such changes shall nullify any exemptions of real estate tax liability for the remainder of the then-current taxable year and the taxable year immediately following; provided, however, when change in property ownership resulted solely from the death of the qualifying individual, or sale of the property, the change shall result in a prorated exemption for the then-current taxable year, which prorated portion shall be determined by multiplying the amount of the exemption by a fraction wherein the number of complete months of the year such property was properly eligible for such exemption is the numerator and the number 12 is the denominator. The proceeds of the sale which would result in the prorated exemption shall not be included in the computation of net worth or income as provided in this section. 
(b)  Upon nullification or proration as provided in this section, the director shall so certify to the city treasurer who shall proceed to collect such taxes as may be due and to adjust his records accordingly. 
(Code 1973, § 35-227; Code 1988, § 35-165; Ord. No. 1989-58, § 2, 6-27-1989) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions as to nullification and authority to city to provide for proration, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3215.  
Sec. 35-166. - False claims. 
Any person falsely claiming an exemption shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1973, § 35-228; Code 1988, § 35-166) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 35-167. - Notice by city treasurer. 
The city treasurer shall enclose written notice, in each real estate tax bill for each taxable year of the terms and conditions of the real estate tax exemptions for elderly and disabled persons in the city. The treasurer shall employ any other reasonable means necessary to notify residents of the city about the terms and conditions of the real estate tax exemptions for elderly and handicapped persons. 
(Code 1988, §§ 35-167, 35-181; Ord. No. 1989-58, § 3, 6-27-1989; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993) 
State Law reference— Exemption or deferral of taxes on property of certain elderly and handicapped persons, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3210; notice of local real estate tax exemption or deferral program for the elderly and handicapped included in tax bill, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3213.1.  
Secs. 35-168, 35-169. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - ELDERLY AND DISABLED PERSONS; PARTIAL EXEMPTION FROM REAL ESTATE TAXES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Exemption or deferral of taxes on property of certain elderly and handicapped persons, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3210; notice of local real estate tax exemption or deferral program for the elderly and handicapped included in tax bill, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3213.1. 
 
Sec. 35-170. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Affidavit means the real estate tax exemption affidavit. 
Applicant means a person who applies for a real estate tax exemption under this division, who is not participating in the program as provided for in division 3 of this article. 
Director means the director of social services or his designee. 
Dwelling means a full-time residence of the person claiming exemption from real estate taxes under this division. 
Exemption means partial exemption from city real estate taxes for the amount by which the tax for any tax year exceeds the amount of tax on the subject dwelling for the tax year during which the owner claiming an exemption under this division was assessed in the 1993-1994 tax year or for the tax year thereafter if that was when the owner claiming an exemption first qualified for such exemption. Exemption for additions or substantial improvements to the subject dwelling, the value of which is determined by the city assessor, will be taxed at the rate currently in effect and added to the fixed annual amount together becoming the new annual fixed tax payable. 
Owner means any person owning title or partial title to real property. 
Permanently and total disabled means unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity by reason of medically determinable physical or mental impairment or deformity which can be expected to result in death or can be expected to last for the duration of the person's life. 
Property means real property. 
Taxable year means the year for which an annual assessment is made and for which exemption is claimed under this division. 
(Code 1988, ch. 35, art. IV, div. 2.1(intro.); Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993) 
State Law reference— Definition of taxable year and taxes, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-1, 58.1-3600; definition of permanently and totally disabled, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3217.  
Sec. 35-171. - Authorized. 
Subject to the annual appropriation by city council of funds at least equal to the total cost of such exemptions, real estate tax exemption is hereby authorized for qualified property owners who are not less than 65 years of age or who are permanently and totally disabled, and who are eligible according to the terms of this division. Persons qualifying for exemption are deemed to be bearing an extraordinary real estate tax burden in relation to their income and financial worth. Should any annual appropriation be less than the total cost of such exemptions, the tax exemption for the subject year shall be applied as a pro rata percentage of the applicable exemption. The pro rata exemption shall be calculated by dividing the appropriated funds by the total cost of the qualified exemptions. 
(Code 1988, § 35-171; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 2009-45 , § 1, 5-12-2009, eff. 7-1-2009)  
Sec. 35-172. - Administration. 
(a)  Eligibility. Eligibility for exemption shall be determined by the director of social services according to the provisions of this division. The director is hereby authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce such rules and regulations in conformance with the provisions of this division and the laws of the commonwealth enabling this division as may be reasonably necessary to determine qualifications for exemption. 
(b)  Inquiries. The director shall make such inquiry of persons seeking exemption, requiring answers under oath, as may be reasonably necessary to determine the qualifications and eligibility for exemption. The director may, in addition, require the production of certified tax returns and appraisal reports to establish the income or financial worth of any applicant for exemption. All inquiries made by the director and all information supplied by an applicant shall be deemed confidential and shall not be released to any person other than an employee or officer of the city having need for such information, unless otherwise ordered by a court of law. 
(Code 1988, § 35-172; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993)  
Sec. 35-173. - General prerequisites to grant. 
An exemption shall be granted to persons eligible, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The person making application must own or partially own title to the property for which exemption is claimed. 
(2)  The person making application must be permanently and totally disabled or must be 65 years old or older as of June 30th of the immediately preceding taxable year. In the case of joint ownership between spouses occupying such property, eligibility of either spouse shall establish eligibility of both. 
(3)  The person making application shall not have disposed of assets to future heirs within the preceding five years if such assets would have made the applicant ineligible under the requirements of this section. 
(4)  The total combined income from all sources for the immediately preceding calendar year of the owner or owners claiming tax exemption and of the owner's/owners' relatives or other household member living in the subject dwelling shall not exceed $50,000.00. 
The net combined financial worth, including equitable interests, as of December 31st of the immediately preceding calendar year, of the owner or owners and of the spouse of any owner, excluding the value of the dwelling and the land, not exceeding one acre, upon which it is situated, and excluding furniture, household appliances and other items typically used in a home, shall not exceed $175,000.00. 
(Code 1988, § 35-173; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 2005-95, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 2006-102, § 1, 12-12-2006) 
Editor's note— It should be noted that section 2 of Ord. No. 2006-102, provides, "That this ordinance shall take effect on January 1, 2007 and shall apply to tax liens effective July 1, 2007."  
Sec. 35-174. - Applicant's affidavit and certificate of disability—Generally. 
(a)  Not later than April 30 immediately preceding the taxable year in question, the person claiming exemption shall file a real estate tax exemption affidavit with the director of social services. Subject to the provisions of section 35-179, a person granted a real estate tax exemption shall refile such affidavit not later than April 30 of the third succeeding tax year following approval of an application; provided, however, each such person shall, prior to April 30 of each tax year, certify to the director that no information contained in the last preceding affidavit has changed to violate the limitations and conditions of the exemption. 
(b)  If the applicant is under 65 years of age, the affidavit required by this section shall have attached thereto a certification by the department of veteran's affairs or the railroad retirement board, or if such person is not eligible for certification by any of these agencies, a sworn affidavit by two medical doctors who are either licensed to practice medicine in the commonwealth or are military officers on active duty who practice medicine with the United States Armed Forces to the effect that such person is permanently and totally disabled, as defined in section 35-170. The affidavit of at least one of the doctors shall be based upon a physical examination of the person by such doctor. The affidavit of one of the doctors may be based upon medical information contained in the records of the civil service commission which is relevant to the standards for determining such permanent and total disability. 
(Code 1988, § 35-174; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993)  
Sec. 35-175. - Same—Extension of time for filing. 
(a)  The city manager, upon determining good cause, may extend the time specification in section 35-174(a) for applying for the exemption, if the applicant qualified for exemption in the immediate past tax year. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of section 35-174(a), any person who qualifies for exemption as a result of amendment by the city council of the combined income or net combined financial worth requirements of section 35-173 shall be permitted to make application for exemption not later than the June 30 immediately preceding the taxable year in question. 
(Code 1988, § 35-175; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993)  
Sec. 35-176. - Certification of city treasurer; adjustment of tax records, etc. 
If after audit and investigation, the director determines that a person is qualified for exemption, he shall so certify to the treasurer of the city, who shall deduct the amount of the exemption from the claimant's real estate tax liability and shall adjust the tax records accordingly. Any remaining tax due shall be billed in equal installments in accordance with section 35-2. 
(Code 1988, § 35-176; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993)  
Sec. 35-177. - Amount of partial exemption. 
(a)  The person qualifying for and claiming exemption shall have exempted that percentage of the real estate tax levied on the qualifying dwelling set forth herein. 
(b)  Beginning with the tax year that commences on July 1, 1994, and for all tax years hereafter, with respect to persons 65 years of age or older, and permanently and totally disabled persons, the amount of tax exempted under this division on the subject dwelling for any year shall be a sum equal to the amount by which the tax for any tax year exceeds the amount of tax on the subject dwelling for the tax year during which the owner claiming an exemption under this division was assessed in the 1993-1994 tax year or for the tax year thereafter if that was when the owner claiming an exemption first qualified for such exemption. Exemption for additions or substantial improvements to the subject dwelling, the value of which is determined by the city assessor, will be taxed at the rate currently in effect and added to the fixed annual amount together becoming the new annual fixed tax payable. 
(Code 1988, § 35-177; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993)  
Sec. 35-178. - Transfer. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the provisions of section 35-173: 
(1)  A taxpayer who is otherwise eligible for a tax exemption under this division shall not be deprived of such exemption if compelled by eminent domain proceedings, the threat of such proceedings or act of God to abandon the residence to which the tax exemption appertains. The tax exemption applicable to the residence which the taxpayer is forced to abandon shall be transferable to any residence purchased within 12 months after title to the first residence is conveyed or condemned. 
(2)  A taxpayer who is otherwise eligible for a tax exemption under this division shall not lose such eligibility and may transfer the same if he changes residences within the city. 
(b)  Any taxpayer seeking a transfer of an exemption shall make application therefor on forms provided by the director. Such forms shall include an affidavit reciting the facts which demonstrate eligibility for such exemption. If the director finds that the applicant is eligible for such exemption, he shall so certify to the city treasurer. The city treasurer shall thereupon deduct the exempted amount from the applicant's real estate tax liability. The exemption transfer, if granted, shall take effect from the filing of the transfer application. 
(Code 1988, § 35-178; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993)  
Sec. 35-179. - Notice and effect of changes in status. 
(a)  It is the responsibility of any property owner to whom an exemption has been granted to notify the director immediately of any changes in respect to income, financial worth, ownership of property or other factors occurring during the taxable year for which the affidavit is filed under this division and having the effect of exceeding or violating the limitations and conditions provided in this division. Such changes shall nullify any exemptions of real estate tax liability for the remainder of the then-current taxable year and the taxable year immediate following; provided, however, when change in property ownership resulted solely from the death of the qualifying individual, or sale of the property, the change shall result in a prorated exemption for the then-current taxable year, which prorated portion shall be determined by multiplying the amount of the exemption by a fraction wherein the number of complete months of the year such property was properly eligible for such exemption is the numerator and the number 12 is the denominator. The proceeds of the sale which would result in the prorated exemption shall not be included in the computation of net worth or income as provided in this section. 
(b)  Upon nullification or proration as provided in this section, the director shall so certify to the city treasurer who shall proceed to collect such taxes as may be due and to adjust his records accordingly. 
(Code 1988, § 35-179; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993)  
Sec. 35-180. - False claims. 
Any person falsely claiming an exemption shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 35-180; Ord. No. 1993-35, § 1, 5-11-1993) 
Cross reference— Penalty for a class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Secs. 35-181—35-185. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - REHABILITATED REAL ESTATE[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to provide exemption, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(A), 58.1-3221(A); amount and duration of exemption and authority of city relating thereto, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(B), 58.1-3221(B). 
 
Sec. 35-186. - Authorized; amount; duration. 
A real estate tax exemption is hereby authorized for residential, commercial and industrial real estate which has undergone substantial rehabilitation, renovation or replacement in an amount equal to the increase in the assessed value resulting from the rehabilitation of the real estate, as determined by the city assessor, and this amount only shall be applicable to any subsequent assessment or reassessment for a period of ten years commencing on July 1 of the year following completion of the rehabilitation. 
(Code 1973, §§ 35-229, 35-230; Code 1988, § 35-186; Ord. No. 1994-71, § 1, 6-28-1994; Ord. No. 2008-78, § 1, 11-25-2008) 
State Law reference— Authority to provide above exemption, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(A), 58.1-3221(A); amount and duration of exemption and authority of city relating thereto, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(B), 58.1-3221(B).  
Sec. 35-187. - What constitutes substantial rehabilitation—Residential real estate. 
For the purpose of this division, residential real estate shall be deemed to have undergone substantial rehabilitation, renovation or replacement when a structure which is not less than 25 years of age has been so improved as to increase the assessed value of the structure by no less than 40 percent without increasing the total square footage of this structure by more than 15 percent. If the total square footage of such rehabilitated, renovated, or replacement structure exceeds that of the original structure by more than 15 percent, the excess square footage above said additional 15 percent shall not be entitled to the real estate tax exemption authorized by this division. 
(Code 1973, § 35-229; Code 1988, § 35-187; Ord. No. 1994-55, § 2, 6-14-1994; Ord. No. 2008-78, § 1, 11-25-2008; Ord. No. 2009-105 , § 1, 10-27-2009) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3220(A).  
Sec. 35-188. - Same—Commercial or industrial real estate. 
For the purposes of this division commercial or industrial real estate shall be deemed to have undergone substantial rehabilitation, renovation or replacement when a structure which is no less than 25 years of age has been so improved as to increase the assessed value of the structure by no less than 60 percent without increasing the total square footage of the structure by more than 15 percent. In the event of complete replacement of such structure, the increase in the total square footage shall be no more than 100 percent. If the total square footage of such rehabilitated, renovated, or replacement structure exceeds that of the original structure by more than 100 percent, the excess square footage above said additional 100 percent shall not be entitled to the real estate tax exemption authorized by this division. 
(Code 1973, § 35-230; Code 1988, § 35-188; Ord. No. 1994-55, § 3, 6-14-1994; Ord. No. 2008-78, § 1, 11-25-2008; Ord. No. 2009-105 , § 1, 10-27-2009) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3221(A).  
Sec. 35-189. - Owner's application. 
The owner of property which has undergone substantial rehabilitation, renovation or replacement shall be required to file an application requesting the exemption provided for in this division with the city assessor not later than ten days after obtaining the building permit for the rehabilitation. The owner shall also be required to pay a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code to the city for processing the application. 
(Code 1973, §§ 35-229, 35-230; Code 1988, § 35-189; Ord. No. 1994-55, § 4, 6-14-1994) 
State Law reference— Authority for above fee, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(D), 58.1-3221(D).  
Sec. 35-190. - Does not apply when historic structure demolished. 
Where rehabilitation is achieved through demolition or replacement of an existing structure, the exemption provided for in this division shall not apply when any structure demolished is a local, state, and/or federally designated historic structure as defined in section 40-51. 
(Code 1973, §§ 35-229, 35-230; Code 1988, § 35-190; Ord. No. 2007-85, § 1, 9-11-2007, eff. 1-1-2008) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3220(E).  
Sec. 35-191. - Removal or repair of derelict buildings. 
Any building declared to be a "derelict building" pursuant to section 17-2 of the Code of the City of Portsmouth and which has been demolished or renovated shall be exempt from taxation for a period of ten years commencing on July 1 of the year following completion of the demolition or renovation in an amount equal to the fair market value of the demolition costs or the fair market value of the renovation improvements as determined by the real estate assessor for the city, and as reflected in the real estate tax assessment records. The abatement of taxes for demolition shall not apply if the structure demolished is a registered Virginia landmark or is determined by the department of historic resources to contribute to the significance of a registered historic district. This exemption shall be transferable with the property. 
( Ord. No. 2009-78, § 1, 8-11-2009)  
Sec. 35-192. - Division does not authorize listing reduced value in land book. 
Nothing in this division shall be construed as to permit the city assessor to list in the land book any reduced value due to the exemption provided in this division. 
(Code 1973, §§ 35-229, 35-230; Code 1988, § 35-192) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(C), 58.1-3221(C).  
Secs. 35-193—35-215. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - REHABILITATED REAL ESTATE IN URBAN ENTERPRISE ZONE[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference— Further authority to provide above exemption, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(A), 58.1-3221(A); similar provisions as to amount and duration of exemption, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(B), 58.1-3221(B). 
 
Sec. 35-216. - Authorized; amount; duration. 
(a)  Pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 59.1-283, and the designation as an enterprise zone of such area(s) as approved by the Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia and described in those official Portsmouth, Virginia Enterprise Zone real estate parcel maps, which shall be retained by the local enterprise zone administrator, and as may be amended from time to time, a real estate tax exemption is hereby authorized for commercial, industrial, and mixed use real estate which is located within such zone and which has undergone substantial rehabilitation or renovation. For purposes of this division, the term "mixed use" shall mean any building developed as a mixed use development, as defined in chapter 40.1 of this code. The exemption shall be in an amount equal to the increase in the assessed value resulting from the rehabilitation of the real estate, as determined by the city assessor, and this amount only shall be applicable to any subsequent assessment or reassessment for a period of ten years commencing on July 1 of the year following the completion of the rehabilitation or renovation. 
If a commercial, industrial, or mixed use structure located within such zone has been improved through substantial rehabilitation or renovation so as to increase the assessed value of the structure by at least 100 percent without increasing the square footage of the structure by more than 15 percent, the exemption shall continue but shall be reduced by 15 percent annually for a period of five additional years so that the exemption in the 11th year will be 85 percent of the full exemption, 70 percent in the 12th year, 55 percent in the 13th year, 40 percent in the 14th year, and 25 percent in the 15th year. The exemption shall expire on June 30 of the 15th year. 
(b)  Property shall be eligible for the exemption referred to in subsection (a) of this section if the appropriate building permits were acquired by the property owner or the rehabilitation indicated on the application was completed subsequent to the inclusion of the property in the zone as verified by the city assessor. 
(Code 1973, § 35-234; Code 1988, § 35-216; Ord. No. 1994-55, § 5, 6-14-1994; Ord. No. 2002-09, § 2, 3-12-2002; Ord. No. 2011-69, § 1, 9-13-2011)  
Sec. 35-217. - What constitutes substantial rehabilitation—Residential real estate. 
For the purposes of this division, residential real estate shall be deemed to have undergone substantial rehabilitation, renovation or replacement when a structure which is no less than 25 years of age has been so improved as to increase the assessed value of the structure by no less than 40 percent without increasing the total square footage of such structure by more than 15 percent. If the total square footage of such rehabilitated, renovated, or replacement structure exceeds that of the original structure by more than 15 percent, the excess square footage above said additional 15 percent shall not be entitled to the real estate tax exemption authorized by this division. 
(Code 1973, § 35-234; Code 1988, § 35-217; Ord. No. 1994-55, § 6, 6-14-1994; Ord. No. 2009-105 , § 1, 10-27-2009) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3220(A).  
Sec. 35-218. - Same—Commercial, industrial, or mixed use real estate. 
For the purposes of this division, commercial, industrial, or mixed use real estate shall be deemed to have undergone substantial rehabilitation, renovation or replacement when a structure which is no less than 15 years of age has been so improved as to increase the assessed value of the structure by no less than 60 percent without increasing the total square footage of such structure by more than 15 percent. In the event of complete replacement of such structure, the portion of the replacement structure that shall be eligible for the real estate tax exemption shall not exceed 110 percent of the square footage of the original structure. 
(Code 1973, § 35-234; Code 1988, § 35-218; Ord. No. 1994-55, § 7, 6-14-1994; Ord. No. 2009-105 , § 1, 10-27-2009; Ord. No. 2011-69, § 1, 9-13-2011) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3221(A).  
Sec. 35-219. - Same—Owner's application. 
The owner of rehabilitated real estate shall be required to file an application requesting the exemption provided for in this division with the city assessor not later than ten days after obtaining a building permit for the rehabilitation. The owner shall not be required to pay a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code to the city for processing the application. 
(Code 1973, § 35-234; Code 1988, § 35-219; Ord. No. 1994-55, § 8, 6-14-1994; Ord. No. 2011-69, § 1, 9-13-2011) 
State Law reference— Authority for above fee, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(D), 58.1-3221(D).  
Sec. 35-220. - Does not apply when historic structure demolished. 
Where rehabilitation is achieved through demolition or replacement of an existing structure, the exemption provided for in this division shall not apply when any structure demolished is a registered Virginia landmark or is determined by the state department of conservation and historic resources to contribute to the significance of a registered historic district. 
(Code 1973, § 35-234; Code 1988, § 35-220) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3220(E).  
Sec. 35-221. - Termination upon conveyance of property. 
The exemption provided for in this division shall terminate immediately upon conveyance of fee simple ownership of the subject property. 
(Code 1973, § 35-234; Code 1988, § 35-221)  
Sec. 35-222. - Division does not authorize listing reduced value in land book. 
Nothing in this division shall be so construed as to permit the city assessor to list upon the land book any reduced value due to the exemption provided for in this division. 
(Code 1973, § 35-234; Code 1988, § 35-222) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3220(C), 58.1-3221(C).  
Secs. 35-223—35-229. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - EXEMPTION FOR DISABLED VETERANS AND THEIR SURVIVING SPOUSES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Sec. 2 of Ord. No. 2011-20 states that this ordinance will take effect July 1, 2011. 
 
Sec. 35-230. - Grant of exemption for one hundred percent disabled veterans. 
For real estate tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2011, an exemption shall be granted to persons eligible on January l, 2011, and thereafter, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The person applying for the real estate tax exemption must be a veteran who has been rated by the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs or its successor agency to have a 100 percent service-connected, permanent and total disability. 
(2)  The veteran and his or her spouse must occupy the real property as their principal place of residence. 
(3)  A surviving spouse of a veteran eligible for this exemption shall also qualify for the exemption as long as (a) the death of the veteran occurs on or after January l, 2011, (b) the surviving spouse does not remarry, and (c) the surviving spouse continues to occupy the real property as his or her principal place of residence. 
(4)  The qualifying dwelling which is the principal place of residence shall not exceed one acre upon which it is situated. 
( Ord. No. 2011-20, § 1, 5-10-2011)  
Sec. 35-231. - Application for exemption, affidavit and official documentation. 
(a)  The veteran or surviving spouse claiming an exemption under this article shall file with the commissioner of the revenue on the application provided by the city an affidavit setting forth the following: 
(1)  The name of the disabled veteran and the name of the spouse also occupying the principal residence, if any. 
(2)  The address of the property for which the exemption is requested. 
(3)  Whether the real property is jointly owned by a husband and wife. 
(4)  A statement that the real property is occupied as the veteran's and/or a surviving spouse's principal place of residence. 
(b)  The veteran shall also provide documentation from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs or its successor agency certifying that the veteran has a 100 percent service-connected, permanent and total disability. 
(c)  In the event that a surviving spouse of a veteran is claiming the exemption, the surviving spouse shall also provide documentation that the veteran's death occurred on or after January l, 2011. 
(d)  A veteran shall be required to refile for exemption from real estate taxes only if the veteran's principal place of residence changes. 
( Ord. No. 2011-20, § 1, 5-10-2011)  
Secs. 35-232—35-234. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - EXEMPTION FOR SURVIVING SPOUSES OF CERTAIN PERSONS KILLED IN THE LINE OF DUTY 
 
Sec. 35-235. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this division, "covered person" means any person set forth in the definition of "deceased person" in Code of Virginia, § 9.1-400 whose beneficiary, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 9.1-400, is entitled to receive benefits under Code of Virginia, § 9.1-402, as determined by the Virginia State Comptroller prior to July 1, 2017, or as determined by the Virginia Retirement System on and after July 1, 2017. All references to provisions of the Code of Virginia in this division 8 refer to the provisions as the same may be amended, restated, or moved. 
(Ord. No. 2017-88 , § 1(exh. A), 9-26-17)  
Sec. 35-236. - Exemption. 
(a)  Pursuant to article X, section 6-B of the Constitution of Virginia, for tax years beginning on or after July 1, 2017, the city exempts from taxation the real property described in subsection (b) of the surviving spouse of any covered person who occupies the real property as his or her principal place of residence. If the covered person's death occurred on or prior to July 1, 2017, and the surviving spouse has a principal residence on July 1, 2017, eligible for the exemption under this section, then the exemption for the surviving spouse shall begin on July 1, 2017. If the covered person's death occurs after July 1, 2017, and the surviving spouse has a principal residence eligible for the exemption under this section on the date that such covered person dies, then the exemption for the surviving spouse shall begin on the date that such covered person dies. If the surviving spouse acquires the property after July 1, 2017, then the exemption shall begin on the date of acquisition. The city shall not be liable for any interest on any refund due to the surviving spouse for taxes paid prior to the surviving spouse's filing of the affidavit or written statement required by section 35-237. 
(b)  Those dwellings qualifying for an exemption hereunder with assessed values in the most recently ended tax year that are not in excess of the average assessed value for such year of single-family residential dwellings in the city shall qualify for a total exemption from real property taxes under this article. If the value of a qualifying dwelling is in excess of the average assessed value as described in this subsection, then only that portion of the assessed value in excess of the average assessed value shall be subject to real property taxes, and the portion of the assessed value that is not in excess of the average assessed value shall be exempt from real property taxes. Single-family homes, condominiums, town homes, manufactured homes as defined in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100 whether or not the wheels and other equipment previously used for mobility have been removed, and other types of dwellings of surviving spouses, whether or not the land on which the single-family home, condominium, town home, manufactured home, or other type of dwelling of a surviving spouse is located is owned by someone other than the surviving spouse, that (i) meet this requirement and (ii) are occupied by such persons as their principal place of residence shall qualify for the real property tax exemption. If the land on which the single-family home, condominium, town home, manufactured home, or other type of dwelling is located is not owned by the surviving spouse, then the land is not exempt. 
(c)  The surviving spouse shall qualify for the exemption so long as the surviving spouse does not remarry and continues to occupy the real property as his or her principal place of residence. The exemption applies without any restriction on the spouse's moving to a different principal place of residence. 
(d)  The exemption from real property taxes shall apply to (i) the qualifying dwelling, or that portion of the value of such dwelling and land that qualifies for the exemption pursuant to subsection (b), and (ii) with the exception of land not owned by the surviving spouse, the land, not exceeding one acre, upon which it is situated. A real property improvement other than a dwelling, including the land upon which such improvement is situated, shall also be exempt from taxation so long as the principal use of the improvement is (a) to house or cover motor vehicles or household goods and personal effects as classified in subdivision A 14 of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3503 and as listed in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3504 and (b) for other than a business purpose. 
(e)  For purposes of this exemption, real property of any surviving spouse of a covered person includes real property (i) held by a surviving spouse as a tenant for life, (ii) held in a revocable inter vivos trust over which the surviving spouse holds the power of revocation, or (iii) held in an irrevocable trust under which the surviving spouse possesses a life estate or enjoys a continuing right of use or support. Such real property does not include any interest held under a leasehold or term of years. 
(f)  In the event that (i) a surviving spouse is entitled to an exemption under this section by virtue of holding the property in any of the three ways set forth in subsection (e) and (ii) one or more other persons have an ownership interest in the property that permits them to occupy the property, then the tax exemption for the property that otherwise would have been provided shall be prorated by multiplying the amount of the exemption by a fraction the numerator of which is 1 and the denominator of which equals the total number of people having an ownership interest that permits them to occupy the property. In the event that the principal residence is jointly owned by two or more individuals including the surviving spouse, and no person is entitled to the exemption under this section by virtue of holding the property in any of the three ways set forth in subsection (e), then the exemption shall be prorated by multiplying the amount of the exemption by a fraction the numerator of which is the percentage of ownership interest in the dwelling held by the surviving spouse and the denominator of which is 100. 
(Ord. No. 2017-88 , § 1(exh. A), 9-26-17)  
Sec. 35-237. - Application for exemption. 
(a)  The surviving spouse claiming the exemption under this division shall file with the commissioner of the revenue of the city, on forms to be supplied by the city, an affidavit or written statement (i) setting forth the surviving spouse's name, (ii) indicating any other joint owners of the real property, (iii) certifying that the real property is occupied as the surviving spouse's principal place of residence, and (iv) including evidence of the determination of the Virginia State Comptroller or the Virginia Retirement System, as applicable, as referenced in section 35-235. The surviving spouse shall also provide documentation that he or she is the surviving spouse of a covered person and of the date that the covered person died. The surviving spouse shall be required to refile the information required by this section only if the surviving spouse's principal place of residence changes. 
(b)  The surviving spouse shall promptly notify the commissioner of the revenue of any remarriage. 
(Ord. No. 2017-88 , § 1(exh. A), 9-26-17)  
Sec. 35-238. - Absence from residence. 
The fact that surviving spouses who are otherwise qualified for tax exemption pursuant to this article are residing in hospitals, nursing homes, convalescent homes, or other facilities for physical or mental care for extended periods of time shall not be construed to mean that the real estate for which tax exemption is sought does not continue to be the sole dwelling of such persons during such extended periods of other residence, so long as such real estate is not used by or leased to others for consideration. 
(Ord. No. 2017-88 , § 1(exh. A), 9-26-17)  
Secs. 35-239—35-245. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - RETAIL SALES TAX 
 
Sec. 35-246. - Levied; to be added to rate of state sales tax, etc. 
There is hereby levied and imposed, in addition to all other taxes and fees of every kind now imposed, a general retail sales tax at the rate of one percent to provide revenue for the general fund of the city. The rate of such tax shall be added to the rate of the state retail sales tax imposed by the "Virginia Retail Sales and Use Tax Act" (Code of Virginia, § 58.1-600 et seq.) and shall be subject to all the provisions of such act, all amendments thereof and all rules and regulations published with respect thereto, except that the applicable brackets of prices shall be as prescribed in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-628 for the combined tax and except that no discount under Code of Virginia, § 58.1-622 shall be allowed on the tax levied by this section. 
(Code 1973, § 35-74; Code 1988, § 35-246) 
State Law reference— Authority for above tax, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-605.  
Sec. 35-247. - Exemption of certain energy sources. 
There is excluded from the tax imposed by section 35-246 the sale or use of artificial or propane gas, firewood, coal or home heating oil used for domestic consumption. The term "domestic consumption" means the use of artificial or propane gas, firewood, coal or home heating oil by an individual purchaser for other than business, commercial or industrial purposes. 
(Code 1973, § 35-75; Code 1988, § 35-247) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-609; exemptions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-609.10.  
Secs. 35-248—35-270. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CIGARETTE TAX[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to levy cigarette tax and permitted provisions of ordinance providing for the administration and enforcement of such tax, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3830, 58.1-3832. 
 
Sec. 35-271. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms when used in this article shall, for the purposes of this article, have the following respective meanings, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Agent means every dealer and other person who is authorized by the commissioner of the revenue to purchase and affix stamps to packages of cigarettes under the provisions of this article. 
Dealer means every manufacturer, jobber, wholesale dealer or other person who supplies a seller with cigarettes. 
Package means every package, box, can or other container of any cigarettes, irrespective of the material from which such container is made, in or from which retail sales of cigarettes are normally made or intended to be made. 
Purchaser means every person to whom the title to any cigarettes is transferred by a seller within the corporate limits of the city. 
Sale means every act or transaction, irrespective of the method or means employed, including the use of vending machines or other mechanical devices, whereby title to any cigarettes shall be transferred from the seller to any other person within the corporate limits of the city, but shall not include any such act or transaction the taxation whereof by the city is precluded or prohibited under the constitution or the general laws of the state. 
Seller means every person engaged in the business of selling cigarettes who transfers title or in whose place of business title to any cigarettes is transferred within the corporate limits of the city for any purpose other than resale. 
Stamp means any type of stamp which will effectuate the purpose of paying the taxes authorized under this article including, but not limited to, heat-applied stamps or decalcomania to be sold by the city treasurer and to be affixed by an agent to every package of cigarettes, but it shall also denote any insignia or symbol printed by a meter machine upon any such package under the authorization of the commissioner of the revenue. 
(Code 1973, § 35-90; Code 1988, § 35-271; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 35-272. - Levied; amount. 
There is hereby levied and imposed by the city upon each and every sale of cigarettes a tax, to be paid by the seller, if not previously paid, in the manner prescribed in this article, which shall be 47.5 mills for each cigarette. 
(Code 1973, § 35-91; Code 1988, § 35-272; Ord. No. 1988-39, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1993-26, § 1, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 1995-55, § 1, 4-25-1995; Ord. No. 2001-19, § 1, 5-22-2001; Ord. No. 2003-06, § 1, 1-28-2003; Ord. No. 2009-38 , § 1, 5-12-2009, eff. 7-1-2009; Ord. No. 2014-44, § 1, 5-27-2014 ; Ord. No. 2014-59, § 1, 7-8-2014 ; Ord. No. 2019-26 , § 1, 5-14-2019)  
Sec. 35-273. - Method of payment. 
The tax imposed by this article shall be paid by affixing or causing to be affixed a stamp, of the proper denominational or face value, to each and every package of cigarettes sold within the city, in the manner and at the time provided for in this article. Every dealer and every seller in the city shall have the right to buy such stamps from the city treasurer and to affix the same to packages of cigarettes as provided in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 35-92; Code 1988, § 35-273; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-274. - Agents generally. 
Every dealer in the city shall have the right to buy and affix stamps as an agent, and the commissioner of the revenue may appoint, in addition to dealers, such other persons as agents for the purpose of buying and affixing stamps as he may deem necessary; provided, however, that a seller shall not be entitled to be appointed as an agent. Every agent shall at all times have the right to appoint a person in his employ to affix the stamps to any cigarettes under the agent's control. 
(Code 1973, § 35-92(a); Code 1988, § 35-274; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-275. - Preparation and sale of stamps generally; meter machines. 
(a)  For the purpose of making stamps available for use by dealers and other agents, the commissioner of the revenue shall prescribe, prepare, furnish and sell through the office of the city treasurer stamps of such design as may be necessary to evidence the payment of the tax imposed by this article. In the sale of such stamps to a dealer or other agent, the city treasurer shall allow a discount of eight percent of the value thereof to cover the cost which will be incurred by such dealer or agent in affixing the stamps to packages of cigarettes. The commissioner of the revenue may, from time to time, and as often as he deems advisable provide for the issuance and exclusive use of stamps of a new design and forbid the use of stamps of any other design. The commissioner of the revenue is hereby empowered to make and carry into effect all such reasonable rules and regulations relating to the preparation, furnishing and sale of stamps as he may deem necessary, including the granting of refunds when deemed appropriate. 
(b)  The commissioner of the revenue is further authorized and empowered to prescribe the method to be employed and the conditions to be observed in the use of meter machines for printing upon packages of cigarettes insignia to represent the payment of such tax; and in case such machines are employed the discount allowed by the city treasurer shall be ten percent of the value of the tax so indicated. 
(Code 1973, § 35-92(a); Code 1988, § 35-275; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-276. - General duties of dealers and sellers with respect to stamps, imprints. 
(a)  Every dealer in cigarettes shall purchase the stamps required by section 35-273 at the office of the city treasurer and shall be necessary to pay the tax imposed by this article and shall affix a stamp evidencing payment of such tax, or cause such stamp to be affixed, to each package of cigarettes prior to delivering or furnishing such cigarettes to any seller. Nothing herein contained shall preclude any dealer from authorizing and employing any other agent to purchase and affix such stamps in his behalf or to have a stamp meter machine used in lieu of gummed stamps to effectuate the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Every seller shall examine every package of cigarettes prior to exposing it for sale for the purpose of ascertaining whether such package has the proper stamp affixed thereto in compliance with the provisions of this article. If, upon such examination, unstamped or improperly stamped packages of cigarettes are discovered, the seller shall immediately notify the dealer from whom such packages were obtained, and upon such notification, the dealer shall forthwith either affix to such unstamped or improperly stamped packages the proper amount of stamps or shall replace such packages with others to which stamps have been properly affixed or imprinted thereon. 
(c)  Should a seller obtain or acquire possession of unstamped or improperly stamped cigarettes from any person other than a dealer, the seller shall forthwith notify the commissioner of the revenue of such fact and the commissioner of the revenue shall thereupon designate an agent to affix the proper stamps to such cigarettes, the funds required to purchase such stamps to be advanced to such agent by such seller. 
(d)  In the event that any packages of cigarettes are found in the possession of a seller without the proper stamps being affixed thereto, or without authorized printed markings of a meter machine thereon, and the seller shall be unable to submit evidence establishing that he received such packages within the immediately preceding 48 hours, the presumption shall be that such packages are being kept by the seller in violation of the provisions of this section and shall subject him to all the penalties provided for the violation of this article. 
(e)  In the event that the commissioner of the revenue shall promulgate rules and regulations so requiring, every dealer, agent or seller shall cancel all stamps upon packages of cigarettes in accordance with such rules and regulations. 
(Code 1973, § 35-92(b); Code 1988, § 35-276; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-277. - Visibility of stamps or meter markings. 
Stamps or the printed markings of a meter machine shall be placed upon each package of cigarettes in such manner as to be readily visible to purchaser. 
(Code 1973, § 35-92(b); Code 1988, § 35-277)  
Sec. 35-278. - Seizure and sale of unstamped cigarettes. 
Whenever the commissioner of the revenue or designee shall discover any cigarettes which are subject to the tax imposed under the provisions of this article, but upon which such tax has not been paid, or upon which stamps have not been affixed or evidence of payment shown thereon by the printed markings of a meter machine in compliance with the provisions of this article, the commissioner of the revenue is hereby authorized and empowered to seize and take possession forthwith of any such cigarettes, which shall thereupon be deemed to be forfeited to the city. Thereafter, the commissioner of the revenue, after providing notice of such seizure in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3832 to the known holders of property interests in such property, may sell such forfeited cigarettes. No credit from such sale shall be allowed toward any tax or penalties and interest owed. Such seizure and sale shall not be deemed to relieve any person from any of the penalties provided for the violation of this article. All monies collected under the provisions of this section shall be paid to the treasurer and treated as other taxes collected under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 35-97; Code 1988, § 35-278; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3832; administer and enforce local taxes on sale or use of cigarettes, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3832.  
Sec. 35-279. - Dealers' and sellers' records generally. 
It shall be the duty of every dealer and seller to maintain and to keep, for a period of two years, such records of cigarettes received and sold by him as may be required by the commissioner of the revenue, to make all of such records available for examination by the commissioner of the revenue upon demand, and to make available to the commissioner of the revenue the means, facilities and opportunity for making any such examination at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1973, § 35-93; Code 1988, § 35-279; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-280. - Disposition of revenue. 
All moneys derived by the city from the tax on the sale of cigarettes imposed by this article shall be deposited by the city treasurer to the credit of the general fund of the city for utilization for such legal purposes as the council may from time to time determine. 
(Code 1973, § 35-94; Code 1988, § 35-280)  
Sec. 35-281. - Administration of oaths; subpoena power. 
The commissioner of the revenue is authorized and empowered to administer oaths and to take affidavits in relation to any matter or proceedings in the exercise of his powers and duties relating to tax imposed by this article, and he shall have the power to subpoena and to require the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers or documents, and to examine such witnesses, books, papers and documents for the purpose of securing information pertinent to the performance of such duties. 
(Code 1973, § 35-96; Code 1988, § 35-281; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-282. - Rules and regulations for enforcement and administration of article; examination of books, records, etc. 
In addition to the powers granted to him elsewhere in this Code, the commissioner of the revenue is hereby authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce rules and regulations relating to: 
(1)  The method and means to be used in the cancellation of stamps. 
(2)  The delegation of any of his powers to his representative. 
(3)  The examination of books, records, invoices, papers and any and all cigarettes in and upon any premises where the same are placed, stored, sold, offered for sale or displayed for sale by seller. 
(4)  Any other matter pertaining to the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, §§ 35-95, 35-97; Code 1988, § 35-282; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-283. - Prohibited acts enumerated. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person: 
(1)  To perform any act or to fail to perform any act for the purpose of evading the payment of the tax imposed by this article, or of any part thereof. 
(2)  To falsely or fraudulently make, forge, alter or counterfeit any stamp or the printed markings of a meter machine, or to procure or cause to be made, forged, altered or counterfeited any such stamp or printed markings of a meter machine, or knowingly and willfully to alter, publish, pass or tender as true any false, altered, forged or counterfeited stamps or printed markings of a meter machine, or to use any stamp or marking more than once. 
(3)  To sell and dispense through a vending machine or other mechanical device any cigarettes upon which such tax has not been paid and upon which evidence of the payment thereof is not shown on each package of such cigarettes. 
(4)  To fail or refuse to perform any of the duties imposed upon him under the provisions of this article, or to fail or refuse to obey any lawful order which the commissioner of the revenue may issue under the provisions hereof. 
(Code 1973, §§ 35-98—35-101; Code 1988, § 35-283; Ord. No. 1995-81, § 1, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 2-13-2001)  
Sec. 35-284. - Violations of article. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Conviction of such violation and payment of a fine shall not relieve any person from the payment of any tax imposed under this article. 
(b)  In addition, any person who shall perform any fraudulent act or evade any tax imposed by this article shall be required to pay a penalty in the amount of 50 percent, and interest not to exceed three quarters of one percent per month, upon any tax found to be overdue and unpaid. 
(c)  Each violation of this article or noncompliance therewith shall be and constitute a separate offense and shall subject every person convicted thereof to the penalties prescribed herein. 
(Code 1973, § 35-102; Code 1988, § 35-284) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11. 
State Law reference— Authority to establish penalty, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3832.  
Secs. 35-285—35-295. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - UTILITY SERVICES TAX[12] 
Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2000-36, § 1, adopted Oct. 10, 2000, amended Art. VI, in its entirety, to read as herein set out. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Art. VI pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Charter reference— Authority to levy tax provided for in this article, § 2.02. 
Cross reference— License tax on heat, light and power companies, § 20-19; license tax on telephone companies, § 20-31. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 35-296—35-305. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASERS OF LOCAL EXCHANGE TELEPHONE SERVICE, MOBILE LOCAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICE, AND WATER SERVICE[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference— Tax on telegraph and telephone companies authorized, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3812; tax on water or heat, light and power companies authorized, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3814. 
 
Sec. 35-306. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms, when used in this division, shall have the following respective meanings, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Purchaser means every person who purchases a utility service. 
Residential use means use by the owner or tenant of private residential property or the tenant of an apartment who is billed for and pays directly the charge for utility service in or for such property. 
Seller means every person, whether a public service corporation of the city or not, who sells or furnishes any utility service. 
Utility service means local exchange telephone service, mobile local telecommunications service, as defined in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3812, and water service furnished in the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1988, § 35-306; Ord. No. 2000-36, § 1, 10-10-2000) 
State Law reference— Definitions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3812(M).  
Sec. 35-307. - Levied; amount. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed and levied by the city upon each purchaser of any utility service a tax upon the charge made by the seller against the purchaser with respect to each purchase of utility service, exclusive of any federal tax thereon, in the amount of 20 percent of the first $2,000.00 of such charge made or incurred during any monthly period. 
(b)  There is hereby imposed and levied by the city upon each consumer of mobile local telecommunication service a tax at a rate equal to ten percent of the monthly gross charge, in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3812. However, the tax shall not be applicable to any amount charged in excess of $30.00 per month for each mobile service consumer. This tax shall not apply to any public safety answering point as defined in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3813.1. 
(Code 1988, § 35-307; Ord. No. 2000-36, § 1, 10-10-2000) 
State Law reference— Tax on telegraph and telephone companies authorized, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3812; exemption for public safety answering point authorized, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3813(E); public safety answering point defined, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3813.1.  
Sec. 35-308. - Application to telephone service. 
The tax imposed and levied by this division on purchasers with respect to local exchange telephone service shall apply to all charges made for local exchange telephone service, except local messages which are paid for by inserting coins in coin-operated telephones; and the total amount of the guaranteed charge on each bill rendered for semipublic coin box telephone service shall be included in the basis for the tax with respect to the purchaser of such service. 
(Code 1988, § 35-308; Ord. No. 2000-36, § 1, 10-10-2000) 
State Law reference— The tax on consumers of local mobile telecommunications service must also be imposed on the consumers of the other forms of local telecommunication services, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3812(I).  
Sec. 35-309. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Political subdivisions. The United States of America, the Commonwealth of Virginia, its political subdivisions, and the boards, commissions and authorities thereof are hereby exempted from the payment of the tax imposed and levied by this division with respect to the purchase of utility services used by such governmental agencies, except where any such governmental agency or body is engaged in an operation for profit. This exemption does not apply to a governmental agency engaged in low-rent public housing, where costs of utility services are paid in whole or in part by the tenant. 
(b)  Bottled water. The tax imposed and levied by this division shall not apply to the purchase of bottled water. 
(Code 1988, § 35-310; Ord. No. 2000-36, § 1, 10-10-2000)  
Sec. 35-310. - Computation when seller collects charges periodically. 
In all cases where the seller collects the charges for utility services periodically, the tax imposed and levied by this division shall be computed on the aggregate amount of purchases during each month; provided, that the amount of the tax to be collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Code 1988, § 35-311; Ord. No. 2000-36, § 1, 10-10-2000)  
Sec. 35-311. - Duty of seller to collect, report and remit.
