(1)  Conviction of any felony involving a crime against the person or conviction of any crime of violence or any offense involving the possession or use of a weapon. 
(2)  Conviction of any felony involving an illegal controlled substance. 
(3)  Conviction of any felony involving a crime against property within the previous ten years. 
(4)  Conviction of any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude within the previous five years. 
(5)  Conviction of any felony or of two or more class 1 or class 2 misdemeanors within the previous 18 months. 
(6)  Conviction of an offense of hit and run involving a motor vehicle. 
(7)  Conviction of a first offense of driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or any narcotic drug or any other self-administered intoxicant or drug within the previous five years or conviction of a second or subsequent such offense. 
(8)  Two convictions of reckless driving or three convictions of speeding within the preceding 24 months. 
(9)  Suspension or revocation of the driver's state driver's license. 
(10)  Conviction of any law or ordinance relating to prostitution, sexual intercourse, pandering, or soliciting for immoral purposes. 
(11)  Accumulation of 12 or more department of motor vehicles demerit points against the applicant's state driver's license. 
(12)  Conviction of any law or ordinance relating to the sale or handling of intoxicating beverages. 
(b)  The chief of police, when he deems it to be in the best interest of the public health, safety or general welfare, may deny an application for a public vehicle driver's permit. 
(c)  Upon denial of the public vehicle driver's permit, the applicant shall wait 60 days before reapplying. 
(Code 1988, § 37-101; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-101.1. - Appeals by certain ineligible persons from denial of certificate of public convenience or public vehicle driver's permit. 
(a)  An applicant who is ineligible for a certificate of public convenience (herein, a "certificate") or for a public vehicle driver's permit (herein, a "permit") because of a conviction of a crime against the person or involving the possession or use of a weapon, as referred to in section 37-64(a)(1) and section 37-101(a)(1); or because of conviction of a felony involving an illegal substance, as referred to in section 37-64(a)(2) and section 37-101(a)(2), shall be eligible to appeal the denial, but only if the conviction occurred at least ten years prior to the application and if the applicant has been of good behavior since the conviction. The appeal shall be made to the chief of police or his designee. 
(b)  In considering the appeal, the chief of police shall consider the following matters: 
(1)  The seriousness of the crime for which the applicant was convicted. 
(2)  The seriousness of the criminal conduct of the applicant which resulted in the conviction. 
(3)  The amount of sentence imposed. 
(4)  Any other relevant evidence, of any type, bearing in any way on the applicant's fitness to hold a certificate or a permit and to transport passengers in the city. 
(c)  After considering the matter, the chief of police may award the certificate or the permit only if he makes an affirmative finding that applicant would not pose a public safety risk and is otherwise qualified, and is not disqualified in any way, from holding a certificate or a permit. If the chief of police is unable to make this finding, based on the evidence presented, he may not award a certificate or a permit. 
(Code 1988, § 37-101.1; Ord. No. 2002-06, 2-26-2002)  
Sec. 37-102. - Revocation—Generally. 
(a)  The chief of police shall revoke a public vehicle driver's permit upon receiving a record of the conviction of a permittee of any of the following: 
(1)  Conviction of any felony involving a crime against the person or conviction of any crime of violence or involving the possession or use of a weapon. 
(2)  Conviction of any felony involving an illegal controlled substance. 
(3)  Conviction of any felony involving a crime against property within the previous ten years. 
(4)  Conviction of any crime involving moral turpitude within the previous five years. 
(5)  Conviction of any felony or of two or more class 1 or class 2 misdemeanors within the previous 18 months. 
(6)  Conviction of driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, any narcotic drug, or any self-administered intoxicant or drug. 
(7)  Two convictions of reckless driving or three convictions of speeding within the preceding 24 months. 
(8)  Conviction of hit and run involving a motor vehicle. 
(9)  Conviction of violating any law or ordinance relating to prostitution, sexual intercourse, pandering, soliciting for immoral purposes or permitting the occupants of a public vehicle to engage in such practices or to the transporting of passengers to houses of ill fame, assignation or prostitution. 
(10)  Willfully charging and collecting fares in excess of the lawful rates prescribed by this article. 
(11)  Accumulation of 12 or more department of motor vehicles demerit points against the state driver's license of the permit holder. 
(12)  Continued failure to comply with the provisions of this article or any other laws or ordinances. 
(13)  Violation of any law or ordinance relating to the sale or handling of intoxicating beverages. 
(14)  Suspension or revocation of the driver's state driver's license. 
(b)  The chief of police, when he deems it to be in the best interest of the public health, safety or general welfare, may revoke a public vehicle driver's permit. 
(Code 1988, § 37-102; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-103. - Same—Notice. 
Upon the revocation of a public vehicle driver's permit, the chief of police shall cause a notice in writing of such revocation to be given to the permittee. The notice shall be sent to the address shown on his application for the permit and a copy of the notice shall also be sent to the public vehicle owner employing the permittee. Compliance with this section shall constitute good and sufficient notice of the revocation. 
(Code 1988, § 37-103; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-104. - Same—Return of permit. 
After the revocation of a public vehicle driver's permit, and notice of the revocation, the permit shall be returned to the chief of police within 24 hours of receipt of the notice. 
(Code 1988, § 37-104; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-105. - Issuance of new permit to person whose permit has been revoked. 
No person whose public vehicle driver's permit has been revoked under the provisions of this chapter shall again be issued such a permit unless, upon the written presentation of reasons satisfactory to the chief of police, the chief of police may order such new permit to be issued. 
(Code 1988, § 37-105; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-106. - Records. 
There shall be kept in the office of the chief of police or such other place as the chief of police may designate, a complete record of all public vehicle driver's permits issued under this division and of all renewals, suspensions and revocations thereof. 
(Code 1988, § 37-106; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-107. - Collection and disposition of fees prescribed by division. 
The fees prescribed by this division shall be collected by the chief of police and paid over to the city treasurer to be used as provided by law. 
(Code 1988, § 37-107; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-108. - Board of appeal for hearing appeals from revocation or suspension of public vehicle driver's permit—Established; composition; appointment of members; etc. 
(a)  For the purpose of hearing appeals as provided for in section 37-109, there is hereby established a board to be called the "public vehicle board of appeals." The public vehicle board of appeals shall consist of five members and shall be composed of one member from the city convention and visitors bureau, one from the city commissioner of revenue office, one from the city traffic engineering office, one from the city personnel office, and one member who shall be a representative of those persons holding a public vehicle driver's permit, hereinafter referred to as the taxicab drivers. 
(b)  Each member of the public vehicle board of appeals shall be appointed at random by the city manager. The members of the public vehicle board of appeals shall be appointed for terms of 12 months. No member of the public vehicle board of appeals shall serve more than one term in any five-year period. Vacancies shall be filled for any unexpired term in the manner in which original appointments are made. The member from the city convention and visitors bureau shall serve as chairperson of the public vehicle board of appeals. 
(c)  The board shall abide by the guidelines established in the public vehicle board of appeals operational manual. Three concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision by the board of appeal at any meeting of the board. Three members shall constitute a quorum of the board of appeal. 
(Code 1988, § 37-108; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-109. - Same—Appeals to public vehicle board of appeals. 
(a)  Whenever it is the decision of the chief of police that the public vehicle driver's permit or a certificate of public convenience and necessity should be suspended or revoked for good cause shown, the person whose permit or certificate has been suspended or revoked may appeal the decision of the chief of police to the public vehicle board of appeals. Notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed with the chief of police within ten days after the initial decision of the chief of police. The chief of police shall forward the notice of appeal, along with a copy of his decision and all papers pertaining thereto to the public vehicle board of appeals within five business days after receiving the notice of appeal. 
(b)  The public vehicle board of appeals shall hear the appeal and render its decision within 30 days of its receipt of a notice of appeal. The public vehicle board of appeals shall conduct its hearing in a closed forum and shall allow only material witnesses directly involved in the process to appear before it. 
(c)  The public vehicle board of appeals shall consider only whether the decision of the chief of police complied with the requirements of this article. The public vehicle board of appeals shall not consider nor shall any decision be based upon sympathy for any of the parties or upon any hardship which may be created as a result of the application of the requirements of this article. The public vehicle board of appeals may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the chief of police only in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. Any decision of the public vehicle board of appeals shall not have the effect of amending or waiving any of the requirements of this chapter. Every decision of the public vehicle board of appeals shall be final; subject, however, to such remedy as either party might have at law or in equity. The decision of the public vehicle board of appeals shall be in writing and shall indicate the vote on the decision. Every decision shall be filed in the office of the chief of police or at another location designated by the chief of police and shall be open to inspection. A copy thereof shall be delivered to the appellant. 
(d)  In the event the public vehicle board of appeals modifies or reverses the decision of the chief of police and recommends issuance of a public vehicle driver's permit or a certificate of public convenience and necessity, the permit or certificate shall be signed by the deputy city manager responsible for oversight of the police department. 
(e)  Unless otherwise provided by law, it shall be a class 2 misdemeanor for any person to attempt to influence, coerce, intimidate or communicate a threat in any fashion to any member of the public vehicle board of appeals. 
(Code 1988, § 37-109; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-110. - Appeal of denial of issuance of permit or certificate. 
(a)  An applicant for a public vehicle driver's permit or a certificate of public convenience and necessity who is denied such permit or certificate by action of the chief of police shall have the same right of appeal to the public vehicle board of appeals as one whose permit or certificate is suspended or revoked by the chief of police. The applicant shall file written notice of appeal with the chief of police within ten days after notice of a decision denying a permit or certificate. The chief of police shall forward all papers and documents to the public vehicle board of appeals within five business days after such appeal is filed. 
(b)  The right of appeal granted by subsection shall not be available to an applicant who is denied a public vehicle operator's permit or a certificate of public convenience and necessity where such denial is a mandatory denial within the provisions of section 37-64, 37-71, 37-101 or 37-102. 
(Code 1988, § 37-110; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Secs. 37-111—37-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - FARES 
 
Sec. 37-131. - "Waiting time" defined. 
As used in this division, the term "waiting time" shall include the time consumed while the taxicab is stopped or moving at a speed less than 12 miles per hour at the request of the passenger. "Waiting time" shall also include the time when a taxicab is not in motion, beginning with the time of arrival at the place to which it is called but excluding time consumed by the premature response to calls. 
(Code 1988, § 37-131; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-132. - Rates established. 
(a)  No person owning, operating, driving or controlling a taxicab within the limits of the city shall charge an amount to exceed the following rates of fare: 
(1)  For the first one-sixth mile or fraction thereof: $2.15. 
(2)  For each one-sixth mile or fraction thereof in addition to the first one-sixth mile: $0.40. 
(3)  For each piece of baggage other than one handbag per passenger: $0.25. 
(4)  For each package unless passenger transports package to and from cabs and holds package on lap in transit: $0.10. 
(5)  For each footlocker or trunk: $0.50. 
(6)  For each one minute of waiting time or fraction thereof: $0.30. 
(7)  For use of a tolled facility, a round trip fee per vehicle of two times the one-way EZ Pass rate established by the Virginia Department of Transportation or other tolling entity for the trip's time of day. 
(b)  If hired on an hourly basis, the rate of $18.00 per hour or fraction thereof shall apply. 
(c)  Taxicabs licensed in another city or county bringing passengers into the city or picking up passengers in the city and delivering such passengers to the city wherein such taxicab is duly licensed shall charge the rates prescribed by the city or county in which they are licensed. The rates are per vehicle charges and shall not be multiplied by the number of passengers carried. 
(Code 1988, § 37-132; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998; Ord. No. 2001-42, § 1, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 2001-48, § 1, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 1, 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 2006-11, § 1, 1-24-2006; Ord. No. 2008-436, § 1, 10-14-2008; Ord. No. 2014-16, § 1, 2-11-2014 )  
Sec. 37-133. - Rates binding upon owners, operators; overcharging. 
The rates and charges set forth in this division shall be binding upon all owners and operators of taxicabs and the collection of fares in excess of such rates shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1988, § 37-133; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-134. - Display of rates. 
The rates of fare established by this division shall be conspicuously posted in each taxicab. 
(Code 1988, § 37-134; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-135. - Advance payment. 
Owners, operators and drivers of taxicabs may require the lawful fare to be paid in advance before undertaking the transportation of any person. 
(Code 1988, § 37-135; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-136. - Multiple passengers. 
When two or more passengers engage a taxicab to the same destination, the charge shall be made as if the vehicle were hired by one passenger. 
(Code 1988, § 37-136; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-137. - Returning charge. 
No returning charge shall be made by the owner or driver of a taxicab where the taxicab was engaged in the city or the naval shipyard and the passenger discharged in the city or naval shipyard. 
(Code 1988, § 37-137; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-138. - Receipts. 
The driver of any taxicab shall, upon request, deliver to the person paying the fare a receipt in legible type or writing showing the date, amount of fare paid, the names of the owner and of the driver and the taxicab's certificate of public convenience and necessity number. 
(Code 1988, § 37-138; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-139. - Refusal to pay. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the lawful fare required to be paid for the use of a taxicab. 
(Code 1988, § 37-139; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Secs. 37-140—37-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - TAXIMETERS 
 
Sec. 37-161. - Required. 
No motor vehicle shall be operated as a taxicab without a taximeter. 
(Code 1988, § 37-161; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-162. - Use. 
Taximeters shall be in use at all times within the city limits when passengers are being transported except when the taxicab is hired on an hourly basis or when the taxicab is engaged within the city for a trip to a destination outside of the city. Such exceptions shall be entered on the driver's manifest. 
(Code 1988, § 37-162; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-163. - Condition. 
All taximeters shall be kept in accurate and proper condition and repair and sufficiently lighted when in use so that the figures thereon shall be plainly visible to the passengers therein. 
(Code 1988, § 37-163; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-164. - Identification light. 
Whenever a taxicab is engaged there is to be conspicuously displayed an identification light connected to the taximeter, operated mechanically by throwing the meter flag and which shall show light when the meter is in operation. Such light shall be located, and in such form, color and size as shall be prescribed by the chief of police. 
(Code 1988, § 37-164; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-165. - Operating broken meter. 
It shall be unlawful to operate a taxicab with a broken taximeter. 
(Code 1988, § 37-165; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-166. - Police to be notified when meter broken; withdrawal of taxicab from service. 
If any taximeter shall break down or get out of repair, notice of such breakdown shall be given immediately to the police department, and such taxicab shall be immediately withdrawn from service. 
(Code 1988, § 37-166; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-167. - Police to be notified when meter repaired; return of taxicab to service. 
When any taximeter has been repaired, notice thereof shall be given to the police department. The taxicab shall not be returned to service until the police have approved the repairs to the taximeter and authorized its return to service. 
(Code 1988, § 37-167; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Secs. 37-168—37-215. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - EMPLOYEE HAULERS 
 
Sec. 37-216. - Defined. 
For the purposes of this article the term "employee hauler" shall mean any person operating a passenger bus for transportation of persons employed by one common employer from various points within the city to their place of employment within the city. 
(Code 1988, § 37-216; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 37-217. - Compliance with article. 
The operation of passenger buses by employee haulers upon the streets of the city shall be subject to the conditions, regulations and restrictions set forth in this article. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated within the city any such bus unless such conditions, regulations and restrictions are complied with by the owner, operator and driver of such bus. 
(Code 1988, § 37-217; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-218. - Violations of article. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 37-218; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 37-219. - Certificate required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an employee hauler bus within the city without having obtained a certificate of public convenience and necessity from the chief of police. The provisions of division 2 of article II of this chapter pertaining to certificates of public convenience and necessity for taxicabs shall apply to employee haulers, except where in conflict with provisions of this article. 
(Code 1988, § 37-219; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-220. - Expiration, renewal of certificate. 
Certificates of public convenience and necessity except temporary certificates issued under this article shall expire on December 31 following the date of issuance and all certificates shall be renewed annually thereafter. 
(Code 1988, § 37-220; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-221. - Sale or transfer of certificate. 
Certificates of public convenience and necessity issued under this article shall be sold or transferred only with the consent and approval of the chief of police. The person making the sale or transfer shall state under oath, if the city manager requires it, the selling price of the certificate of public convenience and necessity and the bus operated thereunder. If the chief of police shall find that the proposed sale or transfer is other than bona fide, he shall refuse his consent to such sale or transfer. 
(Code 1988, § 37-221; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-222. - Revocation of certificate. 
Certificates of public convenience and necessity issued under this article may be revoked at any time for good cause shown or by repeal of this division. 
(Code 1988, § 37-222; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-223. - Liability insurance. 
No employee hauler bus shall be operated on the streets of the city unless the owner and driver are protected by liability insurance issued by a company authorized to do business in this state in such amounts as are required by the state corporation commission and the Virginia Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act. 
(Code 1988, § 37-223; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Secs. 37-224—37-245. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - TOW TRUCKS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate certain tow services, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1217. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 37-246. - Violations of article. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1988, § 37-246; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 37-247. - Identification. 
Any person engaged in the business of providing the services of one or more wreckers for hire or used to tow, transport or move motor vehicles on public streets or on or from private property by way of streets, shall display the name and address or telephone number of the business on both sides of the tow truck in letters large enough to be readily legible, but in no case, less than one inch in height. 
(Code 1988, § 37-247; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-248. - Duty to notify police of removal of vehicle. 
(a)  Prior to or simultaneously with the removal of any vehicle by a tow truck operator or any person or entity repossessing any vehicle as allowed by law, the operator of the tow truck or the person or entity repossessing the vehicle shall notify the police dispatcher of such removal. Such notification shall include the following information: 
(1)  The complete license number and state of issue; 
(2)  The year of expiration of such license; 
(3)  The complete vehicle identification number; 
(4)  The make, model and color of the vehicle; 
(5)  The person or entity requesting the removal; and 
(6)  Any other information that may be required by the police. 
(b)  If any of the information provided is found to be incorrect, the tow truck operator, or person or entity responsible for the removal of the vehicle, upon notification by the police, shall provide the correct information. This provision shall not apply to disabled vehicles towed at the request of the vehicle's owner. 
(c)  In all matters where vehicles are towed or removed at the request or direction of any person or entity other than an agency of the city, the city shall have no liability for any cost associated with such removal. 
(d)  Failure to comply with the reporting or notification requirement as described in subsection (a) of this section constitutes a traffic infraction and shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $100.00. Such failure to report shall limit the amount which may be charged for the storage and safekeeping of the towed vehicle to an amount no greater than that charged for one day of storage and safekeeping. 
(Code 1988, § 37-248; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-249. - Assistance of police in obtaining tow truck service. 
Whenever it shall be necessary to procure a tow truck to render services at the scene of any traffic accident or traffic hazard, any police officer present shall assist the operator or owner of a distressed motor vehicle in obtaining tow truck services. Police communications facilities may be used as necessary to contact tow truck operators. If the owner or operator concerned requests that a specific tow truck service be called, such request shall be honored unless the officer in charge determines, in his discretion, that the operator requested is located at too great a distance or is otherwise actually unavailable to furnish the required services in a timely manner. 
(Code 1988, § 37-249; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998)  
Sec. 37-250. - Tow book to be maintained by chief of police; additional fees. 
(a)  The chief of police shall maintain a register of tow operators who shall be called in sequence to provide services at the scene of accidents or traffic hazards. The book shall be utilized only in those cases where the owner or operator of a distressed motor vehicle does not, for any reason, provide the police officer in charge with the name of a tow operator available to perform the required service in a timely manner. A tow operator desiring to be included in the tow book shall make application to the chief of police. A processing fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall accompany each such application. 
(b)  The tow book shall be maintained and administered by the chief of police. The chief of police may prescribe conditions for tow operators who apply to be included in the tow book, and he may also establish rules and regulations which must be obeyed by tow operators who are listed in the tow book. An application processing fee of $20.00 shall be charged to each applicant for inclusion in the tow book. In promulgating such conditions, rules and regulations, the chief of police may provide for the following matters: 
(1)  Compliance with minimum safety standards. 
(2)  Ownership or possession of all equipment and facilities deemed necessary by the chief of police to provide essential towing services. 
(3)  A fee schedule promulgated by the chief of police providing for the maximum fees to be charged by a tow truck operator for services rendered. Such fee schedule shall include a charge of not less than $22.50 for basic towing services and additional charges for necessary services in particular cases. 
The chief of police shall determine whether additional services were necessary in each particular case and approve all fees charged therefor as follows: 
A $105.00 maximum towing fee may be charged for all tows. 
If a call requires more than one wrecker, the fee per wrecker shall not exceed the single wrecker fees set out herein. 
A storage fee of $20.00 per day may be charged commencing 24 hours after the tow and any fraction of a day thereafter. 
Additional charges may be assessed for tows involving unusual circumstances and written on an approved tow bill. Unusual circumstances include, but are not necessarily limited to: 
Use of dollies. 
Vehicles that have driven completely or partially off a bridge or overpass. 
Vehicles stuck in mud or water. 
Vehicles requiring extrication from a tree, utility pole or other comparable object. 
Vehicles that are on their sides or roofs and which require being righted. 
Additional charges shall not exceed $85.00 per hour plus the initial fee. 
These fees shall only apply to tows within the City of Portsmouth. 
(4)  Maintaining of a business office accessible to patrons during reasonable business hours. 
(5)  Keeping accurate and complete records of all transactions governed by this section. 
(6)  Maintaining proper custody of towed vehicles and their contents. 
(c)  Separate listings for those tow operators who will perform services only during daytime hours on regular weekdays and for those tow operators who are willing to perform services during night hours, weekends and holidays. 
(d)  Reasonable sanctions against operators who violate the rules and regulations, including suspension and removal from the tow book; provided, that the operator in question shall receive notice of his delinquencies and shall have an opportunity to respond before any remedial action is taken. 
(e)  All other rules, regulations or conditions which are incidental to the guidelines promulgated herein or which are necessary and proper to implement these guidelines. 
(f)  Tow operators called pursuant to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall be called in sequence; after performing their services or being unable to respond for any reason, they shall go to the bottom of the list. When a tow operator registers with the chief of police for the first time, he shall be placed at the bottom of the list. 
(g)  The chief of police shall have the authority to remove any tow operators or tow companies from the wrecker service list for violation of any provisions of this chapter, or any rules, regulations, or conditions established by the chief of police. 
(Code 1988, § 37-250; Ord. No. 1998-13, § 1, 4-14-1998; Ord. No. 2001-42, § 1, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 2002-44, § 1, 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 2006-35, § 1, 4-25-2006)  
DIVISION 2. - TOWING ADVISORY BOARD[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to appoint an advisory board, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1217. 
 
Sec. 37-251. - Creation; composition. 
(a)  There is hereby established an advisory board to be known as the "towing advisory board." 
(b)  The towing advisory board shall derive its authority from and be administered by the city council. 
(c)  The towing advisory board shall be appointed by the council and shall consist of the following: 
(1)  The chief of police or his designee; 
(2)  The director of general services or his designee; 
(3)  The director of planning and inspections or his designee; 
(4)  Two representatives from the towing and recovery operator community; and 
(5)  Two residents of the city. 
(d)  The members of the towing advisory board shall be appointed for terms of three years. However, the first appointed members shall have staggered terms with one member from subsection (c)(4) of this section and one member from subsection (c)(5) of this section being appointed for two-year terms and the balance of the membership being appointed for three-year terms. All subsequent appointments shall be for three-year terms. The council shall fill all vacancies on the towing advisory board for the unexpired portion of the term. Members of the towing advisory board shall serve until their resignation or their replacement by the council. 
(e)  The members of the towing advisory board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1988, § 37-251; Ord. No. 2002-27, § 1, 6-11-2002)  
Sec. 37-252. - Removal of members. 
The city council may remove any member of the towing advisory board at any time if it finds that the best interest of the towing advisory board would be served by such action. 
(Code 1988, § 37-252; Ord. No. 2002-27, § 1, 6-11-2002)  
Sec. 37-253. - Election of officers; adoption of bylaws and rules of procedure. 
(a)  The towing advisory board shall elect annually a chairperson, a vice-chairperson and secretary from among its members. 
(b)  The towing advisory board shall establish its own set of bylaws and rules of procedure. 
(Code 1988, § 37-253; Ord. No. 2002-27, § 1, 6-11-2002)  
Sec. 37-254. - Date of meetings. 
The towing advisory board shall hold regular meetings on such days and at such hours as may be fixed by the towing advisory board. Special meetings may be held at such other times as may be fixed by the towing advisory board or upon the call of the chairperson or, in the chairperson's absence, the vice-chairperson, or upon the call of a majority of the members of the towing advisory board. 
(Code 1988, § 37-254; Ord. No. 2002-27, § 1, 6-11-2002)  
Sec. 37-255. - Duties and purpose. 
The towing advisory board shall act in an advisory capacity to the city council with regard to issues affecting the towing or storage of vehicles. The city council shall not adopt any ordinance or enter into a contract involving the towing or storage of vehicles until it has been advised by the towing advisory board concerning such matters. The city council may assign such other related duties to the towing advisory board as the council shall deem fit. 
(Code 1988, § 37-255; Ord. No. 2002-27, § 1, 6-11-2002)  
Chapter 38 - WATER, SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of city as to waterworks, § 2.10. 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 7; erosion and sediment control, ch. 11; fire prevention and protection, ch. 13; flood protection, ch. 14; water supply and toilet facilities for restaurants and other food establishments, §§ 15-62, 15-63; housing and community development, ch. 17; mobile homes, ch. 21; water supply and sewer connections in mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions, §§ 21-29, 21-30; special assessments for local improvements, § 32-251 et seq.; subdivisions, ch. 33.1; swimming pools, ch. 34; zoning, ch. 40.1. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to acquire, establish, maintain and operate waterworks, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-2109—15.2-2114, 15.2-2143, 15.2-2146; authority of city to establish, maintain and operate sewage disposal systems, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2122; authority to regulate sewage disposal, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2157; sewage disposal generally, Code of Virginia, §§ 32.1-163—32.1-166; water supplies generally, Code of Virginia, §§ 32.1-167—32.1-176. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. 
When used in this chapter, the word "director" shall mean the director of public utilities unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning. For the purposes of this chapter, the term "city sewage disposal service" or "sewage system" means any appurtenance of that integrated regional system of sewage collection, transmission or treatment, whether located within or without the boundaries of the city, which has been, or is intended to be, installed, operated or maintained by the city, or in the installation, operation or maintenance of which the city has participated, is participating or intends to participate financially. 
(Code 1988, § 38-1; Ord. No. 1988-87, § 2, 9-13-1988) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 38-2. - Violations of chapter. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor and shall constitute cause for termination of both water and sewer service. Each day of violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to criminal penalties and other specific relief set forth in this chapter, the city may seek injunctive or other appropriate relief, in addition to any nonjudicial relief set forth in this chapter. In any judicial action of a civil nature, the city may recover any actual damages sustained, including any expense, incurred by the city in the investigation, correction or preventative action taken for the purposes of protecting or restoring the integrity and/or the quality of the public water or sewer system and the environment. 
(c)  The city may recover reasonable administrative costs, attorney's fees, court costs, and other expenses of litigation from any person found to be in violation of, or in noncompliance with this chapter or the orders, rules, regulations or permits issued hereunder. 
(Code 1988, § 38-2) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 38-3. - Depositing filth, etc., on property of department of public utilities. 
No person shall deposit, directly or indirectly, any debris, yard waste, rubbish, garbage or filth of any nature on the property, in the waters, into the sewers or upon the facilities of the department of public utilities. No person shall deposit, directly or indirectly, any contaminant, including microbial substances, oils, greases, nitrates, nitrites, synthetic organic compounds, volatile organic compounds, radioactive compounds and inorganic compounds, regulated by the state department of health, state department of environmental quality, Hampton Roads Sanitation District or the United States Environmental Protection Agency on the property, in the waters, into the sewers or upon the facilities of the department of public utilities. 
(Code 1973, § 38-51; Code 1988, § 38-4)  
Sec. 38-4. - Damage to property and unauthorized use prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall damage in any manner, remove, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any pipe, apparatus, appurtenance, meter, meter box, tool, fixture, facility, structure or property of the department of public utilities. 
(b)  No person, except the duly authorized agent of the city, shall open any public fire hydrant. 
(c)  No person, except those properly authorized by the director shall tap or make any connection with the water and sewer mains and pipes of the department of public utilities. 
(d)  No person, except a licensed plumber or those properly employed by the city to engage in this type of work, shall be permitted to do any work in connection with the water or sewer service to any premises. 
(e)  No person shall obstruct or cover any fire hydrant, meter, valve box or sampling station or commit any act tending to obstruct the use and access thereof. 
(f)  No person shall break, remove, move, destroy, deface or tamper with any safety light, barricade, signage or other safety, warning or delineation device placed either for the public or workers' protection or notification during the construction, repair or maintenance of any public water or sewer facility. 
(g)  No person shall tamper with or attempt to tamper with or attempt to or bypass the meter or meter box of the department of public utilities. Failure to conform to this standard shall constitute cause for the immediate discontinuance of service. When such failure necessitates shutting off the water service at the tap cut-off valve, the owner of the premises shall pay the cost thereof and the cost of restoring service before the department of public utilities shall restore service. Such cost shall be set by the director to reasonably cover the average cost of the shut-off and restoration including any street, curb or other repairs involved. 
(Code 1973, § 38-15; Code 1988, § 38-5) 
Cross reference— Authority of city manager to offer reward in cases involving damage to city property, § 2-167; damaging city property generally, § 24-318.  
Sec. 38-5. - Pollution of wells or springs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to willfully or negligently pollute any well or spring belonging to another. 
(Code 1973, § 16-9; Code 1988, § 38-6)  
Sec. 38-6. - Requirement for approval method of disposal of human excrement. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any house used as a place of human habitation, any warehouse, any public building or other place where human beings congregate or are employed in the city to use, occupy, rent or lease the same for the use or occupancy by any person or for any person to use or occupy the same unless such house or building is equipped or supplied with an approved method of disposal of human excrement of such construction as will comply with the requirements of this chapter, the building code and other applicable ordinances. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, an approved method of disposal of human excrement shall be one that does not allow untreated human excrement or septic tank effluent to be deposited upon the surface of the ground or, by means of any public or private sewer, into any stream or body of water, unless such public or private sewer is being maintained and operated in accordance with a valid certification issued under the provisions of the State Water Control Law (Code of Virginia, § 62.1-44.2 et seq.), or otherwise disposed of in a manner that it may endanger a source of drinking water, or which allows flies to have access to human excrement; and, shall be deemed to be either a flush toilet connected to a public or private sewer meeting the above requirements or a flush toilet connected to a septic tank system meeting the requirements of article VII of this chapter. If a public sewer is available to the property, the owner will be required to connect to the public sewer as provided in article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-87, 38-88; Code 1988, § 38-7) 
Cross reference— Building code, § 7-96 et seq.  
Sec. 38-7. - Devices for disposal of human excrement to be kept sanitary. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner, tenant or lessee of any premises supplied with a flush toilet or other approved device for the disposal of human excrement to misuse or neglect the same, so as to allow or cause it to be unsanitary. 
(Code 1973, § 38-93; Code 1988, § 38-8)  
Sec. 38-8. - Applicability of rules and regulations. 
All applicable rules and regulations of the state department of health, state department of environmental quality and the Hampton Roads Sanitation District (HRSD) shall apply to water and sewer service. 
(Code 1988, § 38-9)  
Sec. 38-9. - Fee for review of plans of development. 
In addition to any charges imposed pursuant to section 40.1-2.2(c) of this Code, the department of public utilities is authorized to assess a fee for site plan (plan of development) review of water and sewer components. The amount of the fee for a specific review shall be determined by the director based on the size and scope of the development and the impact of the development on the city water and sewer systems, but shall in no event exceed the amount specified in appendix A to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2020-34 , § 21, 5-12-2020)  
Secs. 38-10—38-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER CONNECTIONS AND SERVICE GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 38-31. - Definition. 
The word "premises," as used in this article, shall mean a building under one roof by one party and occupied as one residence or business, or a combination of buildings owned by one party in one common enclosure and occupied by one family or business, or each division of a double or tenement house having a vertical partition or wall, or a building of more than one apartment and having one or more entrances, or a building having a number of apartments or offices or both and having one or more entrances. 
(Code 1973, § 38-18; Code 1988, § 38-31) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 38-32. - Mandatory connections generally. 
(a)  The water distribution and drainage system of any building in which plumbing fixtures are installed shall be connected to a public water supply and sewer system, respectively, if available. Where either a public water supply or sewer system or both, are not available, an individual water supply or individual sewage disposal system, or both, shall be provided. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, a public water supply system or public sewer system shall be deemed available to premises used for human occupancy if such premises are within 200 feet, measured along a street, alley or easement, of the public water supply or sewer system and a connection conforming with the standards set forth in this chapter, the building code and other applicable ordinances. 
(Code 1973, § 6-11; Code 1988, § 38-32)  
Sec. 38-33. - Mandatory water connection for premises connected with sewer system. 
All premises connected with the city sewer system shall be connected with a city water main and supplied with water through such connection when the premises are occupied. 
(Code 1973, § 38-16; Code 1988, § 38-33)  
Sec. 38-34. - Mandatory sewer connection for premises on public sewer line. 
(a)  The owner of every building occupied or to be occupied for any purpose whatsoever shall cause the same to be connected with the city sewer system, if the building or premises is on the line of a public sewer, unless it can be shown to the satisfaction of the director of public health that there is no necessity for such connection. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, all buildings and premises, whether situated on public lanes or courts or on such lanes and courts as have not been accepted by the council as public, when the same open into a street on which the city sewers are laid, shall be considered on the line of the city sewer system. The owner of buildings and premises on such lanes and courts not accepted as public shall run, at his expense, a lateral to connect with the city sewer and shall be subject to this chapter and regulations made in pursuance thereof. 
(Code 1973, § 6-14; Code 1988, § 38-34)  
Sec. 38-35. - Abatement of nuisance resulting from failure to connect to public sewer. 
(a)  In the event the director of public health determines that a public nuisance exists as a result of a building not being connected to a public sewer which is operated and maintained in accordance with a certificate of compliance issued under the provisions of the State Water Control Law (Code of Virginia, § 62.1-44.2 et seq.), he shall cause such public nuisance to be abated. If the occupant or owner of the building fails to abate the nuisance, the director of public health shall authorize the director to do whatever is necessary to abate the same. 
(b)  All costs incurred by the city in abating a nuisance under this section shall be transmitted to the city treasurer who shall docket the same as a lien against the real estate in the nuisance abatement lien docket book kept in the office of the city treasurer, which lien shall exist until removed by payment of such costs. 
(Code 1973, § 38-96; Code 1988, § 38-35) 
Cross reference— Nuisance abatement lien docket book, § 23-5.  
Sec. 38-35.1. - Removal of obstructions from or repair of damage to wastewater facilities caused by drainage or discharges. 
If the drainage or discharge from any establishment or premises, whether residential, commercial or industrial, causes a deposit, obstruction or damage, or contains characteristics which add unduly to the cost of maintenance and operation to any of the city's wastewater facilities, which includes but is not limited to manholes, and water and sewer lines, and the surfaces including streets and rights-of-way above, below and around such facilities, the city may commence an action for appropriate legal or equitable relief to assure the abatement of such drainage or discharge. In addition thereto, the director shall cause the deposit or obstruction to be promptly removed or cause the damage to be promptly repaired. The cost of such work, including materials, labor, overhead and supervision, whether such work is performed by the city or by an outside contractor, shall be borne by the person causing or contributing to such deposit, obstruction or damage, or by the owner of the premises which causes such deposit, obstruction or damage. Payment of such actual costs does not relieve that person from criminal prosecution or other liability that may be imposed by other applicable law. 
(Code 1973, § 38-83; Code 1988, § 38-35.1; Ord. No. 1988-87, § 3, 9-13-1988)  
Sec. 38-36. - Separate water tap and service pipe for each premises. 
Where more than one premises having different owners are supplied with water by means of a single tap, this condition shall be remedied promptly and each premises shall be connected with a separate tap and service pipe by the owner. 
(Code 1973, § 38-38; Code 1988, § 38-36)  
Sec. 38-37. - Separate sewer connection required for each building; exceptions. 
(a)  The plumbing and draining system of each new building and of new work installed in an existing building shall be separate from and independent of that of any other building, except as herein provided, and every building shall have an independent connection with a public or private sewer when available. 
(b)  When one building stands in the rear of another building on an interior lot and no sewer is available, the house drain from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole will be considered as one building sewer; and where a building is a combination of several occupancies, there may be one connection with the public sewer, provided all of such property is under one ownership; and when there is more than one unit of occupancy, the owner shall, in making application for a sewer connection permit, agree to supervise and at all times maintain the premises in a sanitary condition; and provided further the number of fixtures on each such connection shall not exceed the number permitted by the building code. 
(c)  In any case where, in the opinion of the city manager, it is impractical to carry out the above provisions of this section or deemed to be to the interest of the city to change it, or that an unnecessary hardship would result to the property owner if carried out, it may be lawful, with the written consent of the city manager, to connect a block of houses to one lateral sewer line in a lane in the rear of such houses, provided such lane is dedicated to the joint use of all houses in the block. Such dedication shall be recorded in the clerk's office of the circuit court of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 6-14; Code 1988, § 38-37)  
Sec. 38-38. - Contract for water connection—Required. 
Whenever a service connection with a city water main is requested, the owner of the property to be connected with such water main, before such service connection is made, shall be required to sign a contract prepared for the purpose and kept in the office of the department of public utilities containing the provisions as set forth in section 38-39. A separate contract shall be required for each premises. 
(Code 1973, § 38-19; Code 1988, § 38-38)  
Sec. 38-39. - Same—Form. 
The contract to be signed by the owner for a service connection in the street main for the purpose of supplying water to the premises shall be substantially in the following form: 
Contract by Owner 
for Service Connection. 
Form No. _______ Account No. _______ 
Service No. _______ 
_______ Va. _______, 20_______ 
I hereby apply for a service connection between the street main and the meter for the purpose of supplying water to premises No. _______ Street, between _______ Street and _______ Street, and agree to be bound by the rules, regulations and ordinances now or hereafter established by the Council of the City of Portsmouth governing conditions of water supply. 
It is understood and agreed that the City of Portsmouth shall not be liable in the event of the stoppage of the supply of water or if water is wasted on account of leaky pipes or fixtures or any cause. It is also understood and agreed that the City of Portsmouth shall not be liable for any water discoloration or any damage resulting therefrom. 
If public service bills are not paid at the proper time or if any violation of any city ordinance or other rules or regulations of the department of public utilities occurs pertaining to public services, the department shall have the right to cut off the water at anytime. 
I agree to give prompt notice in writing to the department of public utilities of all changes in occupants. 
PORTSMOUTH DEPARTMENT OF 
PUBLIC UTILITIES 
_______Director of Public Utilities 
_______Owner 
_______Plumber_______Witness 
(Code 1973, § 38-20; Code 1988, § 38-39)  
Sec. 38-40. - Charges for ownership and maintenance of water connections. 
(a)  Whenever application is made pursuant to section 38-39 for the installation of a new water service connection within the city or within the Suffolk service area, the applicant shall make the payment hereinafter specified. The size and location of any such water service connection shall be determined by the director. Such payment or deposit shall cover the following services, materials and labor: installing the water service connection between the water main and meter, shutoff valve at the meter, outlet fitting on the meter or master meter, meter box and meter, and restoration of city right-of-way area disturbed by the installation, all of which shall be owned and thereafter maintained by the department of public utilities. Except that in a new residential development requiring the installation of three-quarter-inch services, upon the approval of the director and incorporation of the work into the development's bond and warranty, the developer may perform, provide and install the following services, materials and labor in accordance with departmental and city standards: Install the water service connection between the water main and meter, shutoff valve at the meter, outlet fitting on the meter, meter box (meter to be furnished/installed by the department), and roadway subbase, base and pavement installation/restoration all of which shall be maintained by the developer until acceptance of the development by the city and then shall be owned and thereafter maintained by the department of public utilities. 
(1)  For the various sizes of service connection, the charge set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be paid in advance. 
(2)  The director shall estimate the charge and the applicant will deposit such amount before the work is done. An accounting shall be made of the cost of such installation. If the deposit is less than such charge, the applicant shall pay the difference within 30 days, and if the deposit is more than such charge, the difference shall be refunded promptly. Failure of the applicant to pay any difference between the deposit and the actual charge shall cause the applicant to be denied water service as provided for in section 38-88. 
(b)  Whenever application is made pursuant to section 38-39 for the installation of a new water service connection outside the city and the Suffolk service area, the charges shall be 1½ times those specified in subsection (a) of this section and set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(c)  Any existing water service connection, between the water main and the meter, which was installed prior to July 1, 1962, shall be owned by the owner of the premises served thereby and maintained by the owner or tenant of the premises, until such water service connection lying between the main and the meter shall require repair or replacement as evidence by leakage or failure of the meter cut-off valve. At such time that leakage or failure of the meter cut-off valve occurs, permission for the department of public utilities to repair or replace the water service connection, between the main and the meter, shall be presumed and ownership and maintenance of the water service connection, between the main and the meter, shall pass to the department of public utilities upon completion of their actual repair or replacement of the water service connection, between the main and the meter. There shall be no charge to either the owner or tenant of the premises for the department of public utilities' repair or replacement of the water service connection, between the main and the meter. 
(d)  As provided in section 38-5, no person, except the duly authorized agent of the city shall damage in any manner any pipe, apparatus, tool or fixture of the department of public utilities nor shall any person tamper with or attempt to or actually bypass the water meter or meter box of the department of public utilities. Failure to conform to this standard shall constitute cause for the discontinuance of service. When such failure necessitates shutting off the water service at the tap cut-off valve, the owner of the premises shall pay the cost thereof and the cost of restoring service before service shall be restored by the department of public utilities. Such cost shall be set by the director to reasonably cover the average cost of the shut off and restoration including any street, curb or other repair involved. 
(e)  Whenever the owner or developer of any subdivision, not to include minor subdivisions, desires to have new water service connections installed to facilitate the paving of said subdivision streets, he may pay in advance in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, or may elect to furnish the department of public utilities a surety bond or irrevocable letter of credit in an amount equal to the total water service connection charges, plus an additional ten percent of the amount of the total water service connection charges, guaranteeing payment of the total charges within a time period prescribed by the director not to exceed two years. This surety bond or irrevocable letter of credit must be furnished prior to the execution of a water service connection agreement and must be in a form deemed satisfactory by the city attorney. 
(f)  When water connections are not performed by the city, inspection fees shall be charged at the rates set forth in appendix A. 
(Code 1973, § 38-48; Code 1988, § 38-40; Ord. No. 1989-37, § 1, 5-15-1989; Ord. No. 1990-85, § 1, 7-24-1990; Ord. No. 1994-36, § 1, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 1995-89, § 1, 7-25-1995; Ord. No. 1997-60, § 1, 10-28-1997; Ord. No. 2002-26, § 1, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2020-34 , § 16, 5-12-2020)  
Sec. 38-41. - Permit for and inspection of sewer connections. 
The plumbing inspector shall issue permits for and make inspections of connections to the city sewers. A record shall be kept of all sewer connections and inspections. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 38-41)  
Sec. 38-42. - Sewer connection charges—Generally. 
(a)  When connection is made with the city sewer, the following charges shall be made for each connection: 
(1)  Residential; trailer parks: 
a.  An availability fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be made for each dwelling unit and each common laundry room or like common facility which generates sewage in the case of apartments, condominiums or other multifamily structures. 
b.  When the city performs the installation and connection, a connection fee equal to the greater of the actual cost of such connection plus 25 percent or as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be made for each point of connection. The director shall estimate the connection fee including any applicable survey, design and restoration components, and the applicant shall deposit with the city the estimated connection fee before the work is done. An accounting shall be made of the cost of such installation. If the deposit is less than the actual connection fee, the applicant shall pay the difference within 30 days or have service denied until payment of any balance due is made. If the deposit is more than such charge, the difference shall be promptly refunded. 
(2)  Commercial, office and institutional: 
a.  The availability fee for commercial, office or institutional developments shall be computed by dividing the estimated rate of flow as calculated pursuant to criteria for such development as set forth by the state sewage regulations by 280 gallons per day. The result thereof shall be multiplied by an amount as set forth in appendix A to this Code to determine the total fee for the development. 
b.  The connection fee for commercial, office and institutional applicants shall be the same as set forth in subsection (a)(1)b. of this section. 
(3)  Industrial: 
a.  All industrial connections shall be in accordance with applicable state or federal pretreatment and categorical standards for the particular type of industry. 
b.  The availability fee and connection fee for industrial applicants shall be as set forth in subsections (a)(2)a. and (a)(2)b. of this section. 
(b)  Where an existing lateral is available to the property, the applicant shall pay an inspection fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code to have the director determine if the existing lateral is of adequate size, material and condition in accordance with city standards. The inspection fee shall be credited toward the payment of the availability fee. If the existing lateral is found to be inadequate in accordance with city standards, the connection fee set forth in subsection (a)(1)b. of this section shall be applicable. 
(c)  When a building has been removed from a site, the appropriate charge will be made under this section whenever the new connection is made. This will apply to any connection whether or not it has been in use before. 
(d)  When one or more connections in addition to existing connections or standard connections as specified in this section are made to a residential, commercial or industrial building, the cost for each such additional connection installed by the city will be the actual cost, as computed by the department of public utilities, plus an additional 20 percent thereof, or the minimum charge applicable to the type of building served, whichever is greater. 
(e)  When a sewer does not exist in the street adjacent to a building site, sewer lines may be installed by the city to serve such site, for which the owner of such site shall pay the actual cost plus 20 percent. 
(f)  When in the ordinary course of business a portion of a sewer collection system is replaced, as part of routine maintenance and there occurs no improvement to the sewer collection system, no sewer connection fees shall be charged. 
(g)  When a substandard sewer collection system connected to a treatment facility is taken out of service and a new collection system connected to a treatment facility replaces such substandard collection system, a sewer connection fee shall be charged in the appropriate sum at the time improved service is made available, but not to be less than the amount as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(h)  When sewer connections are not performed by the city, inspection fees shall be charged at the rates set forth in appendix A. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 38-42; Ord. No. 2002-26, § 1, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2020-34 , § 18, 5-12-2020)  
Sec. 38-43. - Same—Notice of availability of service and payment of charges. 
(a)  Where the city installs sanitary sewer improvements, the director shall give notice to affected homeowners of the availability of sewer line service upon completion of the lines. Homeowners shall then have 30 days from the date of the giving of such notice to apply for a sewer connection and pay the sewer connection fees established by section 38-42. 
(b)  Any homeowner who fails to apply for a sewer connection and pay the requisite fee within the time limits established by subsection (a) of this section shall, if he thereafter seeks to obtain a sewer line connection, pay a sewer line fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code. Such sewer line fee shall be in addition to the sewer connection fee established by section 38-42. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions, the sewer line fee established by subsection (b) of this section shall not be charged where a new home is constructed. 
(d)  All notices required by this section shall be deemed sufficient if published one time in a newspaper having general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 38-82; Code 1988, § 38-43)  
Sec. 38-44. - Persons permitted to make water connection or perform work in connection with water service. 
(a)  No person, except those properly authorized by the department of public utilities, shall tap or make any connection with the mains or distributing pipes of the department of public utilities. 
(b)  No person, except a licensed plumber or an employee of the city, shall be permitted to do any work in connection with the water service to any premises supplied by the department of public utilities. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-44, 38-47; Code 1988, § 38-44)  
Sec. 38-45. - Point of connections. 
Building sewers and water service pipes shall connect to the public sewer and water main at a point designated by the director. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 38-45)  
Sec. 38-46. - Sewer connection cleanout. 
All sewer connections shall be provided with a cleanout at the curb or edge of the pavement or as near thereto as is practicable. 
(Code 1973, § 6-8; Code 1988, § 38-46)  
Sec. 38-47. - Installation, maintenance, etc., of water meters. 
(a)  The department of public utilities will furnish, install and maintain, at its expense all water meters except those installed for fire protection. 
(b)  Only one meter shall be allowed for each premises and only one premises can be supplied through one meter, unless, in the judgment of the director, multiple meters will afford better service. 
(c)  All water meters must be approved, tested and sealed by the department of public utilities before being available for service. After being installed, no meter shall be removed or tampered with by any consumer or other person, and all meters shall be under the exclusive regulation of the department of public utilities. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-36, 38-39, 38-40; Code 1988, § 38-47)  
Sec. 38-48. - Application for water service; fee for establishing or transferring account. 
(a)  Any person desiring to secure water service shall file a signed application therefor at the office of the department of public utilities on the prescribed form, stating the location and character of the premises for which service is desired. 
(b)  When a person applies for initial water service, there shall be a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code charged for establishing a new account and turning on water at the new residence. When an existing customer moves from one residence to another, there shall be a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code for transferring the account and turning on the water at the new residence. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-17, 38-43; Code 1988, § 38-48; Ord. No. 1994-36, § 2, 5-10-1994)  
Sec. 38-49. - Service contracts generally. 
(a)  The owner of any premises desiring water to be supplied to such premises shall be required to sign a contract prepared for the purpose, containing the provisions and in the form as set forth in section 38-50 or 38-51. A separate contract shall be required for each premises. 
(b)  Whenever a tenant shall make a deposit pursuant to section 38-86, he shall be required to sign a contract substantially similar to the form as set forth in section 38-50. Such contract and deposit may be transferred by the director to cover any other premises to which the tenant may move. 
(c)  If the same service pipe supplies more than one premises, or if one premises is occupied by more than one tenant, the charges for water supplied such premises shall be contracted for and paid for by the owner. 
(d)  The owner of a premises occupied or to be occupied by a tenant may sign a contract for water to be supplied such premises, and by so doing he assumes responsibility for the payment of charges for water supplied the tenant. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-22, 38-24, 38-27, 38-28; Code 1988, § 38-49)  
Sec. 38-50. - Service contract form—When owner not responsible for water used by occupant. 
The contract for water and sewer services for particular premises, when the owner is not responsible for water used by the occupant, shall be substantially in the following form: 
Contract for Water and Sewer Service 
by Nonowner Occupant of Premises 
Form No. _______ Account No. _______ 
Service No. _______ 
_______ Va. _______, 20_______ 
I hereby apply to the Portsmouth Department of Public Utilities for a supply of water for Premises No. _______ Street, between _______ Street and _______ Street. 
I agree to pay for all water furnished on said premises at the rate now or hereafter established, and all sewage disposal charges assessed against the said premises in accordance with the ordinances governing sewage disposal charges, and that the water shall be used on the premises only, and without waste, and to be bound in all things by the stipulation and conditions of water supply now or hereafter embraced in the city Code, and the rules which may be from time to time adopted; and to permit the agents of the department of public utilities, at all reasonable times to visit and inspect the described premises. 
It is understood and agreed that the City of Portsmouth shall not be liable in the event of the stoppage of the water supply or if water is wasted on account of leaky pipes or fixtures or any other cause. It is also understood and agreed the City of Portsmouth shall not be liable for any water discoloration or any damage resulting therefrom. 
If public service bills are not paid at the proper time or if a violation of any city ordinance or other rules or regulations of the department of public utilities occurs pertaining to public services, the department shall have the right to cut off the water at any time. Otherwise this contract shall continue in force until cancelled in writing by me. 
PORTSMOUTH DEPARTMENT OF 
PUBLIC UTILITIES 
_______Director of Public Utilities 
Consumer Witness 
___Consumer 
___Witness 
(Code 1973, § 38-30; Code 1988, § 38-50)  
Sec. 38-51. - Same—When owner responsible for water used. 
The contract for water and sewer services for particular premises when the owner is responsible for water used shall be substantially in the following form: 
Contract for Water and Sewer Service 
When Owner Responsible for Water Used 
Form No. _______ Account No. _______ 
Service No. _______ 
_______ Va. _______, 20_______ 
I hereby apply to the Portsmouth Department of Public Utilities for a supply of water for Premises No. _______ Street, between _______ Street and _______ Street. 
Being the owner of the premises, I agree to be responsible for payment of all water furnished said premises at the rate now or hereafter established, and all sewage disposal charges assessed against the said premises in accordance with the ordinances governing sewage disposal charges, and that the water shall be used on the premises only, and without waste; and to be bound in all things by these stipulations and conditions of water supply now or hereafter embraced in the city Code, and the rules which may be from time to time adopted; and to permit the agents of the department of public utilities at all reasonable times to visit and inspect the described premises. 
It is understood and agreed that the City of Portsmouth shall not be liable in the event of the stoppage of the supply of water or if water is wasted on account of leaky pipes or fixtures or any other cause. It is also understood and agreed the City of Portsmouth shall not be liable for any water discoloration or any damage resulting therefrom. 
If public service bills are not paid at the proper time or if a violation of any city ordinance or other rules or regulations of the department of public utilities occurs pertaining to public services, the department shall have the right to cut off the water at any time. Otherwise this contract shall continue in force until cancelled in writing by me. 
PORTSMOUTH DEPARTMENT OF 
PUBLIC UTILITIES 
_______Director of Public Utilities 
_______Owner 
_______Witness 
(Code 1973, § 38-31; Code 1988, § 38-51)  
Sec. 38-52. - Notice as to changes in tenants when water furnished on application of tenant. 
If water is supplied a premises on the application of a tenant, the owner of the premises or his agent shall give prompt notice in writing to the department of public utilities as to changes in tenants. 
(Code 1973, § 38-29; Code 1988, § 38-52)  
Sec. 38-53. - Right of entry and access to premises. 
All premises connected to the water and sewer facilities of the city shall at all reasonable hours be open and accessible to the duly authorized agents and employees of the departments of public utilities, permits and inspections and public health for the purpose of installing, removing, repairing, maintaining, measuring or sampling the facilities of the city or for inspecting the premises, fixtures and appurtenances thereto, which are connected to the facilities of the city. If the owner, occupant or agent refuses to allow access to the premises; or if the director is not able to contact the owner, occupant or agent for the purpose of obtaining access, the director may after ten days' written notice to the owner, occupant or agent, terminate the water and sewer service. In cases where the director has reasonable cause to believe that a hazard exists in the premises that may jeopardize the integrity of the quality of the city water or sewer system, the director shall immediately terminate the water and sewer service to the premises and provide written notification to the owner, occupant or agent. 
(Code 1973, § 38-45; Code 1988, § 38-53)  
Sec. 38-54. - Unauthorized persons not to turn on water after shut off by city. 
When water service to a premises has been shut off by the department of public utilities for any reason, no person except a representative of such department may turn the water on again. 
(Code 1973, § 38-43; Code 1988, § 38-54)  
Sec. 38-55. - Water service for fire protection. 
The following provisions shall apply to water service for fire protection other than public fire hydrants: 
(1)  There shall be no connection with any other service from city mains or with any other water supply. 
(2)  The owner of the property to be protected shall sign in the office of the department of public utilities the contract for fire protection service. 
(3)  For a supply of water for sprinkler system, where there is no opening through which water may be taken except through sprinkler heads, a horizontal swing check valve with bronze working parts, bypass and meter and also a shutoff gate valve shall be installed between the curb and the building, all to be accessible for examination and repair. The check valve, bypass meter, connection with the city main and service pipe from the main to the check valve will be installed by the department of public utilities and paid for in advance by the owner of the property to be protected. 
(4)  There will be no charge for water used to extinguish a fire or for sprinkler heads, nor ready to serve charge for bypass meter. 
(5)  The use of water from such connection for any purpose, except through the sprinkler system to extinguish a fire, the attachment to the service pipe of any connection or fixture, except the usual sprinkler control valves and heads will operate to render void the contract for the connection, and the water will be shut off at the main by the department of public utilities. 
(6)  For a supply of water for private fire hydrants or hose connections, or both, with or without a sprinkler system, such connection shall be supplied through a fire protection meter to register all water used, the size of connection and type of meter to be determined by the director. 
(7)  For fire protection meter, gate and check valves, connection with the city main and service pipe from the main to the meter will be installed by the department of public utilities and paid for in advance by the owner of property to be protected. There shall be no ready-to-serve charge or minimum applied to meters used exclusively for fire protection services, nor any charge for water used through such meters to extinguish a fire. Water registered by such meters, not used to extinguish a fire, will be paid for at the rates prescribed in article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 38-65; Code 1988, § 38-55) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 13.  
Sec. 38-56. - Use of public fire hydrants; annual charge. 
(a)  Public fire hydrants shall be used for the extinguishment of fires. Such hydrants may also be used for other municipal uses with the approval of the city manager. Prior to use for other than the extinguishment of fires, an agreement covering conditions of use, including provisions for payment for water and other costs where applicable, shall be executed. 
(b)  Public fire hydrants within the corporate limits of the city shall be paid for at the rate as set forth in appendix A to this Code each per annum. Public fire hydrants located in a city or town other than this city, shall be subject to contract, or if no contract is entered into for such fire hydrants, they shall be paid for at the rate as set forth in appendix A to this Code each per annum. Rates for public fire hydrants shall be payable quarterly. In addition, a fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be charged for the observation of fire hydrant flow tests. Bills for public fire hydrants shall not be subject to discount. 
(Code 1973, § 38-66; Code 1988, § 38-56; Ord. No. 1988-45, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 2020-34 , § 14, 5-12-2020)  
Sec. 38-57. - City not liable for damages caused by bursting of water mains or pipes, shutting off the water or failure of water supply. 
The city shall not be liable for any damage, including water discoloration or any damage resulting therefrom, resulting from the bursting of any water main, service pipe or cock, from the shutting off of water for repairs, extensions or connection or from the accidental failure of the water supply from any cause whatsoever. 
(Code 1973, § 38-49; Code 1988, § 38-57; Ord. No. 1991-57, § 1, 6-11-1991)  
Sec. 38-58. - Right to restrict use of water in emergencies. 
In cases of emergency, the city shall have the right to restrict the use of water in any reasonable manner for the protection of the city and its water supply. 
(Code 1973, 38-49; Code 1988, § 38-58)  
Secs. 38-59—38-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WATER SERVICE CHARGES[2]
