Sec. 38-81. - Definition. 
As used in this article, the word "premises" shall have the meaning ascribed to it in section 38-31. 
(Code 1988, § 38-81) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 38-82. - Meter charges. 
The meter charges as set forth in appendix A to this Code, based on meter size, shall be paid by water consumers for each premises the occupants of which take water from the service pipe. 
(Code 1973, § 38-33; Code 1988, § 38-82; Ord. No. 1988-45, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1993-28, § 1, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 1996-27, § 1, 4-23-1996; Ord. No. 1998-16, § 1, 4-28-1998)  
Sec. 38-83. - Meter rates for water supplied. 
The rates for all water that passes through meters to customers within the corporate limits of the city and to customers in the Cities of Chesapeake and Suffolk shall be as set forth in appendix A of this Code, and any amendments thereto. 
(Code 1973, § 38-34; Code 1988, § 38-83; Ord. No. 1988-45, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1989-35, § 1, 5-15-1989; Ord. No. 1990-34, § 1, 5-15-1990; Ord. No. 1991-38, § 1, 5-14-1991; Ord. Sec. 38-84. - Charges when consumer supplied by more than one meter. 
If any water consumer is supplied by more than one meter, each meter shall be considered as a separate service both as to the meter rates prescribed in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 38-37; Code 1988, § 38-84)  
Sec. 38-85. - All metered water to be paid for. 
Subject to the provisions of section 38-92, all water passing through a meter shall be paid for by the consumer at the prescribed rates, whether used, consumed or wasted. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-32, 38-35; Code 1988, § 38-85)  
Sec. 38-86. - Deposit to assure payment. 
(a)  Whenever the owner of a premises elects not to sign the contract described in section 38-50 or repudiates or cancels a contract previously signed by him, no water shall be supplied at the premises until the owner or tenant applying for the water shall deposit with the director a cash deposit equal in amount to the estimated bill commensurate with the size of the service and the normal billing period for the premises, including charges for water service and utility taxes based thereon, if any. 
(b)  A deposit made under this section shall be held by the department of public utilities until the occupant of the premises moves from the same, at which time any portion of the deposit due shall be returned without interest to the person by whom it was made, provided the meter has been read and the balance of charges or fees to date deducted from the amount of the deposit. If the deposit is not sufficient to pay all charges and fees up to the date on which the tenant vacates the premises in question, the tenant shall pay the balance due. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-23, 38-26; Code 1988, § 38-86)  
Sec. 38-87. - Permit and deposit for water for building purposes. 
Permits for water for building purposes will be issued on application and the payment of a deposit of not less than the amount as set forth in appendix A to this Code. This water shall be supplied through a meter to be furnished by the department of public utilities. The owner or contractor shall pay in accordance with bills submitted. When the work is completed and water service for building purposes shut off, and all payments have been made for water supplied, the deposit will be returned to the person who made it. 
(Code 1973, § 38-41; Code 1988, § 38-87)  
Sec. 38-88. - Balance due for prior service to be paid prior to acceptance of deposit or furnishing of service. 
If an owner or tenant fails or refuses to pay for water service supplied such owner or tenant as shown by the balance due on the books of the department of public utilities for a premises, no deposit will be accepted from and no water supplied such owner or tenant for the same or any other premises for his own use until such balance is paid. 
(Code 1973, § 38-25; Code 1988, § 38-88)  
Sec. 38-89. - Owners not required to pay for water furnished tenant; exception. 
An owner shall not be required to pay for water furnished to a tenant, unless the owner has signed a contract agreeing to pay for such water. 
(Code 1973, § 38-22; Code 1988, § 38-89)  
Sec. 38-90. - Unauthorized use of water to avoid payment of charges. 
No consumer shall permit others, not members of his family, to use water from his pipes to avoid the payment of charges for water service, and no person shall thus obtain water. 
(Code 1973, § 38-46; Code 1988, § 38-90)  
Sec. 38-91. - Estimate of charges when meter fails; testing meter upon complaint of consumer. 
(a)  In the event of a meter failing to register properly or being removed for testing or repairs, public service bills will be rendered for an estimated amount based on the average consumption of the previous three periods when the meter was registering properly. 
(b)  In the event of a complaint by a consumer as to the accuracy of a meter, it shall be removed and tested by the department of public utilities. If it is found to be correct, the consumer shall pay the cost of removing, testing and replacing the same. If found incorrect, such cost shall be borne by the department of public utilities. Such complaint shall not justify or be used as an excuse for delay in the payment of bills rendered for water supplied the same consumer through any other meter. In determining the accuracy of a meter, two percent slow or fast shall be the maximum allowance for over or under registration. 
(Code 1973, § 38-40; Code 1988, § 38-91)  
Sec. 38-92. - Rebate of charges in case of leaks. 
If underground or inside leaks occur in water pipes on premises receiving metered water, and if the owner or occupant of the premises or the water consumer: 
(1)  Has all necessary repairs made promptly; and 
(2)  Furnishes the director with documentation certifying that the repairs have been made and giving the date of completion of the work; 
the director may make rebate to such owner, occupant or consumer of the water charges in excess of the average consumption for the premises during the last six months. A maximum of 50 percent credit on excess water charges over the average will be allowed. In unusual circumstances, the director may make additional adjustments. Only one adjustment credit may be allowed for leaks within 12 consecutive months. 
(Code 1973, § 38-35; Code 1988, § 38-92)  
Sec. 38-93. - Billing and payment generally. 
(a)  All bimonthly water accounts shall be billed on a cycle of approximately 60 days. All monthly accounts shall be billed on a cycle of approximately 30 days. Bills for public services supplied in each division, including charges for water service, sewage disposal service, refuse disposal service and utility taxes based thereon, if any, are due and payable upon presentation. If the payment is not received by the due date set forth on the bill, a late charge of 1½ percent per month will be added to the bill. 
(b)  Payment of bills rendered under this section shall be made at the office of the department of public utilities on the days and during the hours the office is open for business, or such payment may be made at any collection agency established by the director for that purpose on the days and during the hours such collection agencies are open for business. The method of payment of such bills at collection agencies and regulations and accounting procedures pertaining thereto shall be prescribed by the director. Each collection agency shall be bonded in the amount of $2,000.00 and the bond and contract of appointment shall be approved as to form by the city attorney. 
(Code 1973, § 38-42; Code 1988, § 38-93)  
Sec. 38-94. - Discontinuing service for failure to pay and other remedies. 
(a)  If a bill rendered pursuant to section 38-93 is not paid within 15 days from the due date set forth on the bill, services to the premises may be discontinued without further notice, and in addition any and all past due bills, charges and interest thereon may be recovered by the city by action at law or suit in equity, and shall, in those cases where the unpaid bill or charge was incurred by the owner of the premises and not a tenant, constitute a lien against the property, ranking on a parity with liens for unpaid real estate. Additionally, the city may recover its administrative costs and reasonable attorney's or collection agency's fees associated with any collection action at law or suit in equity, in accordance with section 35-3. Such administrative costs shall be in addition to all penalties and interest. Attorney's fees shall be added only if such delinquency is collected by action at law or suit in equity. Nothing in this subsection shall preclude the city's use of the office and the powers of the city treasurer in the collection of unpaid utility bills. 
(b)  If water service to a premises is shut off pursuant to this section at the meter cutoff valve, the amount due and a field service fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be paid before the service will be restored; provided that, in the event water service to the premises has been turned on by an unauthorized person, there shall be an inspection fee as set forth in appendix A to this Code to cover the cost of the requisite inspection. Such fees shall not apply to shutting off water service at the tap cutoff valve, but the provisions of section 38-40(d) shall govern. 
(c)  When water or sewer use without execution of a contract for service or without payment of applicable rates, fees and other charges is discovered at a premises, a charge for the use together with an additional charge for detection shall be levied against the owner, occupant, or tenant occupying the premises. The owner of the property shall be responsible for payment of such charges for use and the additional charges for any period of time when a tenant does not occupy the property. For purposes of this section, evidence of occupancy by a tenant shall be a valid, dated, and properly executed lease between the owner and tenant provided to the department of public utilities. The charge for water and sewer use shall be set by the department of public utilities based upon the actual metered water usage at the premises. Should no metered water usage be available at the premises, the charge for water and sewer use shall be set by the department of public utilities at a level equal to recover the estimated use for the time period in question. An additional charge as set forth in appendix A to this Code shall be charged to recover the cost of detection. Additionally, should the water or sewer use involve the use of an unauthorized meter, the unauthorized use of a city-owned meter, or any type of unauthorized connection to the city water or sewer system, then the inspection fee in subsection (b) of this section shall be applied. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-42, 38-43; Code 1988, § 38-94; Ord. No. 1991-57, § 2, 6-11-1991; Ord. No. 1994-36, § 4, 5-10-1994; Ord. No. 1994-58, § 1, 6-28-1994; Ord. No. 1998-6, § 1, 2-24-1998; Ord. No. 2002-26, § 1, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2003-44, § 1, 7-22-2003)  
Secs. 38-95—38-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SEWER SERVICE CHARGES 
 
Sec. 38-116. - Imposed. 
Any person contracting with the city for sewage disposal service or the owner, lessee or tenant who uses or occupies any real estate which directly or indirectly is or has been connected with the sewer system of the city, or from or on which originates or has originated sewage, industrial wastes or other wastes which directly or indirectly enter or will enter the sewer system, shall pay to the city for the use and services of such system the charges prescribed in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 38-77; Code 1988, § 38-116)  
Sec. 38-117. - Rates. 
(a)  Charges for the disposal of sewage discharged into the city system will be based upon the water delivered to the premises as measured by meters used for this purpose at the rate set forth in appendix A of this Code, and any amendments thereto. 
(b)  The minimum charge for a premises or groups of premises containing two or more dwelling units served through a single water meter or connection will be determined by multiplying the minimum charge set out in subsection (a) of this section by the number of dwelling units so served. 
(c)  Charges for sewer service for dwelling units in premises with unmetered water connections shall be $15.44 per month. 
(Code 1973, § 38-77; Code 1988, § 38-117; Ord. No. 1988-45, § 1, 5-16-1988; Ord. No. 1991-39, § 1, 5-14-1991; Ord. No. 1992-30, § 1, 5-12-1992; Ord. No. 1993-29, § 1, 5-11-1993; Ord. No. 1996-28, § 1, 4-23-1996; Ord. No. 1997-30, § 1, 5-6-1997; Ord. No. 1998-16, § 1, 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 1999-10, § 2, 4-27-1999; Ord. No. 2000-10, § 1, 4-25-2000; Ord. No. 2001-20, § 1, 5-22-2001; Ord. No. 2002-26, § 1, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2003-30, § 1, 4-22-2003; Ord. No. 2004-27, § 1, 6-15-2004; Ord. No. 2006-36, § 1, 4-25-2006; Ord. No. 2007-52, § 1, 4-24-2007; Ord. No. 2008-30, § 1, 5-13-2008; Ord. No. 2009-40 , § 1, 5-12-2009; Ord. No. 2011-21, § 1, 5-4-2011) 
Editor's note— Sec. 3 of Ord. No. 2008-30 states that this ordinance shall take effect July 1, 2008, and shall be applicable to all bills rendered after July 1, 2008. 
Sec. 3 of Ord. No. 2011-21 states that this ordinance shall take effect July 1, 2011, and shall be applicable to all bills rendered after July 1, 2011.  
Sec. 38-118. - Charge where service available but not used. 
The owner, lessee, tenant or other occupant of any dwelling or other structure fronting on any street in which sewer mains have been laid and to whom the sewage disposal system of the city is available for use, although the premises in question are not connected with the city sewer, shall pay to the city the rates and charges as set forth in section 38-117. 
(Code 1973, § 38-78; Code 1988, § 38-118; Ord. No. 1998-16, § 1, 4-28-1998)  
Sec. 38-119. - Reduction when all water not discharged into sewer. 
Premises not discharging the entire volume of water into the city sewers will be allowed a reduction in the sewer service charge, provided the customer installs facilities satisfactory to the director for measuring the volume either discharged or not discharged into the sewers. 
(Code 1973, § 38-77; Code 1988, § 38-119; Ord. No. 1988-45, §§ 1, 2, 5-16-1988)  
Sec. 38-120. - Rebate in case of water leaks. 
Where the charges for sewer service are based on metered water consumption, the director may make rebates of such charges in the case of underground or inside leaks in water pipes in the same amount and subject to the same conditions as rebates are granted under section 38-92 for water service charges, except that a 100 percent credit will be allowed for excess sewer charges where it can be proven that the leaking water did not enter the sewer system. 
(Code 1973, § 38-35; Code 1988, § 38-120)  
Sec. 38-121. - Billing and payment. 
Charges prescribed by this article shall be included on the public services bill rendered pursuant to section 38-93 and shall be paid in accord with, and shall be subject to, the provisions of such section. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-80, 38-81; Code 1988, § 38-121)  
Secs. 38-122—38-140. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - FLUORIDATION OF WATER SUPPLY 
 
Sec. 38-141. - Required. 
The department of public utilities shall introduce sodium fluoride into the city water supply in such quantities as are required to maintain throughout the pipe distribution system a fluoride ion concentration of approximately one part per million. Water containing natural fluoride may be used in lieu of sodium fluoride. 
(Code 1973, § 38-57; Code 1988, § 38-141)  
Sec. 38-142. - Records. 
The department of public utilities shall keep an accurate daily record showing, for each supply of sodium fluoride, the number of gallons treated and the fluoride ion concentration of the water before and after treatment. 
(Code 1973, § 38-58; Code 1988, § 38-142)  
Sec. 38-143. - Determination of fluoride ion concentration. 
The department of public utilities shall determine the fluoride ion concentration in the water distribution system at such points and at such intervals as may be deemed necessary or as directed by the state department of health. 
(Code 1973, § 38-59; Code 1988, § 38-143)  
Secs. 38-144—38-165. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - WATER BACKFLOW PREVENTION AND CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 
 
Sec. 38-166. - Purpose and definitions. 
(a)  The purpose of this article shall be to establish a cross connection control and backflow prevention program as required by the Virginia Department of Health's Waterworks Regulations, article 3. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Air gap means the unobstructed distance through a free atmosphere between the lowest perimeter of a water outlet and the flood-level rim of any receptacle. This distance shall be minimum of two times the diameter of the outlet. (In case of near-walls, this distance shall be three times the diameter of the outlet.) 
Approved means the term as herein used in reference to air-gap separation, a double check valve assembly, a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly or other backflow prevention devices or methods shall mean an approval by the director. 
Auxiliary supply means any water source or system other than the public water supply that may be available. 
Backflow means the reversal of flow from its intended direction as a result of backsiphonage or backpressure. 
Backflow prevention means an approved assembly or device that prohibits the backflow of water. 
Backpressure means a pressure, higher than supply pressure, caused by a pump, elevated tank, boiler, air/stream pressure, or any other means, which may cause backflow. 
Backsiphonage means a type of backflow caused by a negative or reduced pressure in the supply piping. 
Contamination means any introduction into potable water of chemicals that are not part of the water treatment process, gases, microorganisms, wastes or wastewater. 
Cross connection means any connection or structural arrangement, direct or indirect, to the waterworks whereby backflow can occur. 
Director means the director of the department of public utilities or the director's designee. 
Division means the Commonwealth of Virginia, Department of Health, Division of Water Supply Engineering. 
Double-gate/double-check valve assembly means an approved assembly of two internally spring-loaded, specially designed and independently operating check valves, together with a tightly closing resilient seating shutoff valve on the upstream and the downstream side of the check valves, equipped with four properly placed female-threaded test cocks. 
Existing ground level means the level above which surface water will not accumulate under normal conditions. 
Flood-level rim means the top edge of the receptacle over which water could overflow. 
Hazard means any condition, device or practice in the water usage system and its operation which creates or reasonably tends to create a danger to the health and well-being of the water consumer. 
Owner means the person having legal title to the property or who is in charge, care and control of the property where the facilities in question are located; also, the tenant of such property; also, the customer who signed the water service agreement for such property. 
Pollution means the presence of any foreign substance (chemical, physical, radiological or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute an unnecessary risk or impair the usefulness of the water. 
Reduced pressure principle backflow preventer means an approved assembly of two independently operating spring-loaded check valves with a pressure differential relief valve and tightly closing resilient seating shutoff valves on the upstream and the downstream side of the assembly with four properly placed female-threaded test cocks. 
Service connection means the terminal end of a service line from the waterworks. If a meter is installed at the end of the service, then the service connection means the downstream end of the meter. 
Service line means that portion of the water line from the consumer's side of the water meter to the first water outlet. 
Toxin means any substance of solids, or liquids or gases harmful for human consumption. 
Vacuum breaker, atmospheric, means a device that consists of a float check, a check seat and an air inlet port. This unit may never be subjected to a backpressure condition or have a downstream shutoff valve, or be installed where it will be in continuous operation for more than 12 hours. 
Vacuum breaker, pressure type, means an assembly consisting of an independently operating internally loaded check valve, an independently operating loaded air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check valve, with two properly located test cocks and tightly closing resilient seated shutoff valves. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.2; Code 1988, § 38-166; Ord. No. 1990-111, § 1, 10-9-1990; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 1, 1-11-1994) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 38-167. - Inspections generally; notice to correct defects. 
The director shall inspect the plumbing in every building or premises in the city as frequently as may be necessary to ensure that such plumbing has been installed and is maintained in such a manner as to prevent the possibility of pollution or contamination of the public water supply. The director shall notify or cause to be notified in writing the owner, occupant or authorized agent of the owner of any such building or premises to correct within a reasonable time, set by the director, any plumbing installed or existing contrary to or in violation of this article and which may create the risk of pollution of the city water supply or otherwise adversely affect the public health. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67; Code 1988, § 38-167)  
Sec. 38-168. - Inspection to be at reasonable hours, etc.; warrant to enable inspection; termination of service to uninspected premises. 
(a)  The director shall inspect all premises or buildings during reasonable hours and under such circumstances as to minimize the inconvenience to the owner or occupant of the premises or their agents. Should any owner, occupant or agent refuse to allow the director access to the premises for the purpose of conducting an inspection; or should the director not be able to contact the owner, occupant or agent for purposes of obtaining permission to inspect; the director shall have the right to apply immediately to a magistrate or other judicial officer for a proper warrant to carry out the necessary inspection. The provisions of this section shall apply to all initial inspections and to such follow-up inspections as may be necessary. 
(b)  In addition to the warrant procedure set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the director may commence administrative proceedings to discontinue water service to uninspected premises. Except in emergency cases involving the imminent risk of pollution of the city water supply, the director shall give ten working days' written notice to the owner or occupant of the affected premises or to a responsible agent of the intention to terminate the water service. The director shall afford to the owner, occupant or agent a hearing on the question of whether water service shall be terminated. This hearing shall be scheduled and conducted in a manner so that, to the maximum extent feasible, the inconvenience and burden on the owner, occupant or agent shall be minimized. The hearing shall take place before the director or a designated principal assistant. The director shall not terminate the water service to the premises in question if it is determined that: 
(1)  The owner, occupant or agent has presented clear, convincing and credible evidence that there are no actual or potential cross connection hazards within the subject premises; and 
(2)  No purpose of this article would be served by conducting an on-site inspection of the premises. 
In all cases, the hearing provided by this subsection shall be scheduled within the ten-day period immediately following the giving of written notice to the owner, occupant or agent. Upon a showing of good cause, the director may grant a reasonable continuance of the hearing so scheduled; but the director, nevertheless, shall retain the right to terminate the water service at the expiration of the ten-day notice period if, public health considerations require such action. The director shall, in all cases, render a decision immediately after taking of all evidence at the hearing or as soon thereafter as may be practicable, but in no case later than 24 hours following the termination of the taking of evidence. The director shall cause the findings of fact and disposition of the case to be reduced to writing and shall preserve the same for a period of one year. The hearing itself before the director shall be tape recorded or preserved by other appropriate means. Should the owner, occupant or agent desire a copy of the tape, the director shall cooperate in undertaking to reproduce the same at the expense of the owner, occupant or agent. In all cases, the director shall exercise the utmost care to preserve the integrity of the original tape. 
(c)  In emergency circumstances where the director has reasonable cause to believe that a cross connection hazard exists in the subject premises and such hazard jeopardizes the integrity or the purity of the city water supply, the director shall forthwith terminate the water service to the subject premises. The director shall thereafter immediately afford the owner, occupant or agent the notice and opportunity to be heard pursuant to the procedures set forth in subsection (b) of this section. In all cases where the director shall summarily terminate water service as provided under this subsection, the director shall act with dispatch in notifying the owner, occupant or agent and shall exercise the utmost diligence in scheduling a prompt hearing on the matter. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the director shall not terminate any water service in cases where there is reliable information indicating that actual or potential cross connection hazards do not exist in the premises to which access for inspection cannot be gained. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.1; Code 1988, § 38-168; Ord. No. 1990-111, § 2, 10-9-1990; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 2, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 38-169. - General design, installation and maintenance standards for potable water supply system. 
A potable water supply system shall be designed, installed and maintained in such manner as to prevent contamination from nonpotable liquids, solids or gases, either harmful or benign, from being introduced into the potable water supply through cross connections or any other piping connections to the system. This shall be accomplished by protecting every water outlet from the potable water system which poses a possible cross connection. Wherever such outlets cannot be protected in accordance with the minimum air gap, a mechanical device shall be utilized to prevent backflow from backsiphonage or backpressure as appropriate according to the degree of hazard. In cases where water usage is sufficiently complex or the severity of the hazard warrants, the director may require an air gap or backflow preventer device immediately downstream from the service connection or at a point approved by the director and the division. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.3; Code 1988, § 38-169; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992)  
Sec. 38-170. - Unusual or extraordinary hazards. 
Where investigation discloses that unusual or extraordinary hazards require more stringent means of protection, the director shall have the authority to require the installation of the same. The director shall in all cases specify the facts constituting the greater hazard found to require more stringent protective measures. The more stringent protective measures shall be related to such unusual or extraordinary hazards and shall be no more burdensome than is necessary to alleviate or guard against such hazards. The director shall specify in writing to the owner the manner in which the more stringent protective measures alleviate or guard against the unusual or extraordinary hazards. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.4; Code 1988, § 38-170; Ord. No. 1990-111, § 2, 10-9-1990; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 3, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 38-171. - General prohibition against cross connections. 
No person shall interconnect a privately owned water system to the city's water system. Direct connections to toxic or nontoxic substances subject to backpressure shall be protected by approved backflow preventers. Low inlet connections, except those connected to domestic water tanks, shall be protected by approved backflow preventers. Potable water connections to flush valve toilets and urinals shall be protected by approved backflow preventers. Toilet tanks shall be protected by approved anti-siphon devices. 
(Code 1973, § 38-50; Code 1988, § 38-171; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 4, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 38-172. - Potable connection to boilers. 
Potable water connections to boilers shall be made through an air gap or provided with an approved backflow preventer. Potable water bypass arrangements on boilers shall be protected by a backflow preventer. If continuous service is required, two backflow preventers of the same type may be installed in parallel. Systems containing chemicals shall be protected with an air gap or a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.5; Code 1988, § 38-172; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 5, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 38-173. - Potable connections to refrigerating units, etc. 
Potable water inlet connections to refrigerating unit condensers, cooling jackets, heat exchangers and air conditioning cooling systems will be air gapped or provided with an approved backflow preventer. Systems containing chemicals shall be protected with an air gap or a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.6; Code 1988, § 38-173; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 6, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 38-174. - Protective devices for fire service systems. 
(a)  Fire service systems having direct connections from waterworks with no pumps or storage facilities, no fire department pumper connections, no connections to other water supplies, no antifreeze or chemicals added to the fire system, and all sprinkler heads discharging to the atmosphere are not required to have positive protective devices. 
(b)  In systems such as those listed in subsection (a) of this section which have booster pumps installed in the connection from the waterworks, provision shall be made to avoid lowering the pressure at the connection to the waterworks below ten psi. 
(c)  Systems with direct connections to the waterworks, which have an auxiliary supply within 1,700 feet of the pumper connection, must provide an air gap, a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer or a double-gate/double-check valve assembly, depending on the quality of the auxiliary supply. 
(d)  Systems having direct connections to the waterworks and interconnections with auxiliary supplies such as pumps taking suction from raw water sources, exposed storage tanks, industrial water supplies, connections to unapproved groundwaters, or where antifreeze or other chemicals are added must provide an air gap or a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. 
(e)  Systems having direct connections to the waterworks from buildings having combined industrial and fire systems either with or without storage tanks or pump connections must provide an air gap or an approved backflow prevention device. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.7; Code 1988, § 38-174; Ord. No. 1990-111, § 2, 10-9-1990; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 7, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 37-175. - Vacuum breaker for hose outlets. 
Where hose outlets are concerned, vacuum breakers are required. The director may waive this requirement if, upon examination of all facts, the hose outlets are designed and constructed so as to substantially eliminate the risk of pollution or contamination. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.7.1; Code 1988, § 38-175)  
Sec. 38-176. - Backflow preventer between hydrant and hose used to flush new water mains, storm drains and sewers. 
A backflow preventer device between hydrant and hose shall be installed before using a hose for flushing new water mains, storm drains and sewers. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.8; Code 1988, § 38-176; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992)  
Sec. 38-177. - Backflow preventer for irrigation and sprinkler systems. 
(a)  A backflow prevention device shall be installed on all irrigation and sprinkler systems. 
(b)  Systems having direct connections to waterworks serving lawn sprinkler or irrigation systems must provide an approved air gap, pressure vacuum breaker or a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. If the sprinkler or irrigation system is also connected to an auxiliary source, an approved air gap or reduced pressure principle backflow preventer must be provided to prevent backflow. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-67.7, 38-67.9; Code 1988, § 38-177; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992)  
Sec. 38-178. - Low-pressure cutoff for booster pumps. 
A low-pressure cutoff shall be installed on all booster pumps on water pressure booster systems in such a manner as to maintain a minimum pressure of ten psi on the suction side of the pump. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.10; Code 1988, § 38-178)  
Sec. 38-179. - Containment policy. 
(a)  Service line protection. An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed at each service connection to a consumer's water system where, in the judgment of the director or the division, a health, pollution or system hazard to the waterworks exists. 
(b)  Special conditions. When, as a matter of practicality, the backflow preventer device cannot be installed at the service connection, the device may be located downstream of the service connection but prior to any unprotected takeoffs. 
(c)  Conditions requiring backflow prevention devices. A backflow prevention device shall be installed at each service connection to a consumer's water system serving premises where any of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  Premises on which any substance is handled in such a manner as to create an actual or potential hazard to a waterworks. This shall include premises having sources or systems containing process fluids or waters originating from a waterworks which are no longer under the control of the director. 
(2)  Premises having internal cross connections that, in the judgment of the director or the division, may not be easily correctable or intricate plumbing arrangements which make it impracticable to determine whether or not cross connections exist. 
(3)  Premises where, because of security requirements or other prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a complete cross connection survey. 
(4)  Premises having a repeated history of cross connections being established or re-established. 
(5)  Whenever continuous service is imperative, a pair of backflow preventers may be installed in parallel. 
(d)  Facilities requiring backflow prevention devices. An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed at each service connection to a consumer's water system serving, but not necessarily limited to, any of the following types of facilities: 
(1)  Hospitals, mortuaries, clinics, veterinary establishments, nursing homes, and medical buildings; 
(2)  Laboratories; 
(3)  Piers, docks, waterfront facilities; 
(4)  Sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations or stormwater pumping stations; 
(5)  Food and beverage processing plants; 
(6)  Chemical plants, dyeing plants and pharmaceutical plants; 
(7)  Metal plating industries; 
(8)  Petroleum or natural gas processing or storage plants; 
(9)  Radioactive materials processing plants or nuclear reactors; 
(10)  Car washes and laundries; 
(11)  Lawn sprinkler systems, irrigation systems; 
(12)  Fire service systems; 
(13)  Slaughterhouses and poultry processing plants; 
(14)  Farms where the water is used for other than household purposes; 
(15)  Commercial greenhouses and nurseries; 
(16)  Health clubs with swimming pools, therapeutic baths, hot tubs or saunas; 
(17)  Paper and paper products plants and printing plants; 
(18)  Pesticide or exterminating companies and their vehicles with storage or mixing tanks; 
(19)  Schools or colleges with laboratory facilities; 
(20)  High-rise buildings (four or more stories); 
(21)  Multi-use commercial, office or warehouse facilities; 
(22)  Others specified by the director and/or the division when reasonable cause can be shown for a potential backflow or cross connection hazard. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.11; Code 1988, § 38-179; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 8, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 38-180. - Determination of degree of hazard. 
Premises with one or more of the following conditions shall be rated at the corresponding degree of hazard: 
(1)  High hazard: 
a.  The contaminant would be toxic, poisonous, noxious or unhealthy. 
b.  A health hazard would exist. 
c.  A high probability exists of a backflow occurrence either by backpressure or by backsiphonage. 
d.  The contaminant would disrupt the service of piped water for drinking or domestic use. 
Examples: Sewage, used water, nonpotable water, auxiliary water systems, toxic or hazardous chemicals, etc. 
(2)  Moderate hazard: 
a.  The contaminant would only degrade the quality of the water aesthetically or impair the usefulness of the water. 
b.  A health hazard would not exist. 
c.  A moderate probability exists of a backflow occurrence either by backpressure or by backsiphonage. 
d.  The contaminant would not seriously disrupt service of piped water for drinking or domestic use. 
Examples: Food stuff, nontoxic chemicals, nonhazardous chemicals, etc. 
(3)  Low hazard: 
a.  The contaminant would only degrade the quality of the water aesthetically. 
b.  A health hazard would not exist. 
c.  A low probability exists of the occurrence of backflow primarily by backsiphonage. 
d.  The contaminant would not disrupt service of piped water. 
Examples: Food stuff, nontoxic chemicals, nonhazardous chemicals, etc. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.12; Code 1988, § 38-180; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992)  
Sec. 38-181. - Backflow protection where minimum air gap cannot be provided. 
Devices to protect against backpressure and backsiphonage shall be installed at all fixtures and equipment where backflow may occur and where a minimum air gap cannot be provided between the water outlet to the fixture or equipment and its flood-level rim. For connections not subject to backpressure, a vacuum breaker shall be installed on the discharge side of the last valve on the line serving the fixture or equipment. For connections subject to backpressure, an approved backflow preventer shall be installed on the line serving the fixture or equipment. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.13; Code 1988, § 38-181; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 9, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 38-182. - When double-gate/double-check valve assemblies permitted. 
The director may authorize the installation of approved double-gate/double-check valve assemblies with test cocks as protective devices against backflow in connections between a potable water system and other fluids which, in the judgment of the director, present no significant health hazards. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.14; Code 1988, § 38-182)  
Sec. 38-183. - Standards for backflow prevention devices. 
Devices for the prevention of backflow shall be tested and certified to meet the standards of one or more of the below-listed agencies: 
American Society of Sanitary Engineers (ASSE). 
American Water Works Association (AWWA). 
American National Standards Institute (ANSI). 
University of Southern California Foundation for Cross-Connection Control. 
Commonwealth of Virginia State Board of Health. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.15; Code 1988, § 38-183; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992)  
Sec. 38-184. - Location and installation requirements for protective devices. 
(a)  Backflow prevention devices shall be accessibly located, preferably in the same room with the fixture they serve. In all cases, installation will be in accordance with the director's specifications. 
(b)  Atmospheric vacuum breakers shall be installed with the critical level at least six inches above the flood-level rim of the fixture they serve and on the discharge side of the last control valve to the fixture. 
(c)  Pressure vacuum breakers shall be installed with the critical level at least 12 inches above the flood-level rim of the fixture they serve and/or 12 inches above the highest outlet in an easily accessible location for testing and maintenance. These devices shall not be installed in pits or areas subject to flooding. 
(d)  Reduced-pressure principle backflow preventers and double-gate/double-check valve assemblies shall be installed a minimum of 12 inches above existing ground level in an easily accessible location for testing and maintenance. These devices shall not be installed in pits or areas subject to flooding. 
(e)  Any device that has an opening that may vent to the atmosphere shall not be installed in pits or areas subject to flooding. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.16; Code 1988, § 38-184; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992)  
Sec. 38-185. - Responsibility of owner as to inspection, testing, repair, etc., of backflow prevention devices. 
(a)  The owner of any premises where backflow prevention devices are installed shall have such devices inspected and tested at time of installation and annually thereafter. Inspection and testing shall be accomplished by backflow prevention device testers certified by the director. The date of annual testing shall be within 30 days before or 30 days after the anniversary date of installation. If the director concludes that more frequent inspections are required, the director shall notify the owner of the premises in writing of such finding and shall further specify the basis for such conclusions. The director shall also promulgate a schedule for more frequent inspections. 
(b)  Backflow prevention devices shall be tested, repaired, overhauled or replaced as necessary at the expense of the water user or owner. Records of such tests, repairs and overhauls shall be kept by the owner and a copy forwarded to the director. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.17; Code 1988, § 38-185; Ord. No. 1990-111, § 2, 10-9-1990; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 10, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 38-186. - Certification of prevention device testers. 
(a)  Plumbers, mechanical contractors, maintenance personnel, employees of owners or owners of backflow prevention devices may become certified by the director to test and repair such devices. Certification shall be obtained by completing a written and performance examination to the satisfaction of the director in a school approved by the state department of professional and occupational regulation or a Virginia state-issued backflow prevention device worker license. 
(b)  A certification to test and repair devices in the city may be revoked by the director at any time upon sufficient written sworn charges filed with the director showing the holder of the certificate to be then incompetent or guilty of a willful breach of the rules, regulations or requirements of the director, or the provisions of this article or other causes sufficient for the revocation of his certificate. The holder of such certificate shall have written notice of such charges and shall have the right to be heard. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-67.18—38-67.20; Code 1988, § 38-186; Ord. No. 1992-3, § 1, 1-14-1992; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 11, 1-11-1994)  
Sec. 38-187. - Notice of violation of article; failure to correct violation. 
(a)  The director shall notify the owner or authorized agent of the owner of the building or premises in which there is found a violation of this article, apprising the owner of the facts of such violation. The director shall set a reasonable time for the owner to have the violation removed or corrected. Upon failure of the owner to have the violation corrected by the end of the specified time interval, the director may, if an actual or potential health hazard exists, cause the water service to the building or premises to be terminated. 
(b)  Any owner or authorized agent of the owner responsible for the maintenance of the plumbing systems in the building who knowingly permits a violation of this article to remain uncorrected after the expiration of time set by the director shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. Each day of failure to comply with the requirements of this article after the specified time shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1973, § 38-67.22; Code 1988, § 38-187; Ord. No. 1990-111, § 2, 10-9-1990; Ord. No. 1994-3, § 12, 1-11-1994) 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 4 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Secs. 38-188—38-310. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - SEPTIC TANKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate septic tanks, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2157; state septic tank permits, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-164 et seq. 
 
Sec. 38-311. - Permit required for installation or repair. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to install or repair, have installed or repaired, allow to be installed or repaired or contract to install or repair a septic tank for another person before the owner of the property on which the septic tank is to be installed or repaired obtains a permit from the director of public health. 
(Code 1973, §§ 6-14, 38-90; Code 1988, § 38-311)  
Sec. 38-312. - General installation and maintenance requirements. 
All septic tanks shall be installed and maintained in accord with the then current regulations of the state board of health on the subject. 
(Code 1973, §§ 6-14, 38-88; Code 1988, § 38-312)  
Sec. 38-313. - Location, capacity and drain tile. 
The director of public health shall approve the location of a septic tank system and decide the minimum capacity thereof and amount of drain tile to be used therein. In no instance shall the capacity thereof be less than 200 feet. The permit issued under section 38-311 shall specify the minimum capacity and amount of drain tile and designate the approximate location of the septic tank. 
(Code 1973, §§ 38-89, 38-91; Code 1988, § 38-313)  
Sec. 38-314. - Prerequisites to covering and use. 
No part of any septic tank system shall be covered or put into use until completed and until inspected and approved by the director of public health. 
(Code 1973, §§ 6-14, 38-94; Code 1988, § 38-314)  
Sec. 38-315. - Disposal of contents. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of the contents of a septic tank at any place in the city, except at the place provided for such disposal at a sewage treatment plant in a manner approved by the department of public utilities. 
(Code 1973, § 38-92; Code 1988, § 38-315)  
Sec. 38-316. - Notice to correct violations of article. 
If, upon any inspection, the director of public health shall find any violation of this article or the provisions of a permit issued under this article, he shall direct the person to whom the permit was issued, by written notice, to make the necessary corrections, within such reasonable time as shall be specified therein. 
(Code 1973, § 38-95; Code 1988, § 38-316)  
Secs. 38-317—38-340. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - RESERVOIR AND WATERSHED PROPERTIES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 38-341—38-360. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 38-361. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Person means any individual, firm, owner, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, unincorporated association, governmental body, municipal corporation, executor, administrator, trustee, guardian, agent, occupant or other legal entity. 
Reservoir means any body of water owned by the City of Portsmouth and used for drinking as listed: Lake Cohoon, Lake Kilby, Lake Meade, and Lake Speights Run. 
Water system of the City of Portsmouth means lakes and reservoirs, wells, water treatment facilities, intake, storage, pumping, transmission, distribution and related equipment and appurtenances. 
Water tap means the service line that runs from the water main to the city water meter. 
Watershed means that land area that surrounds the Portsmouth lakes and reservoirs and that acts as a drainage basin into the lakes and reservoirs.  
Sec. 38-362. - Protection of watershed. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to pollute, threaten, jeopardize or render impure, turbid or offensive, the water supply of the City of Portsmouth, including the reservoirs and tributary to the reservoirs located within the City of Suffolk. 
(b)  No person shall put any filth, animal or vegetable matter, chips, compost, construction debris, shavings, yard waste or any other substance or pollutant, whether solid or liquid, and whether buried or not, within the City of Portsmouth's watershed property or place or dispose of any such substance in an area which drains into the watershed property or the lakes and reservoirs of the City of Portsmouth. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct any sewer, privy vault, cesspool, septic tank or facility for the containment or treatment of domestic and household waste on any part of the watersheds surrounding the water supply of the city, without first securing a permit from the City of Suffolk. 
(d)  The director of public utilities shall have the right to develop and enforce policies and procedures for the protection of the city's water system lakes and reservoirs, including the Portsmouth watershed property located within the City of Suffolk.  
Sec. 38-363. - Compliance with state fishing and boating laws. 
Any person fishing in any of the lakes owned by the city shall comply with the regulations set by the state department of game and inland fisheries as well as city regulations as published by the director of public utilities.  
Sec. 38-364. - Permit required for boating on city-owned lakes. 
(a)  No person shall be extended the privilege of boating, including canoeing/kayaking on any of the city-owned reservoirs unless a boating permit is obtained for the boat or canoe/kayak and the following fees are paid therefore: 
(1)  Annual permits for privately owned boats beginning April 1, shall be issued for the period April 15 to April 15 of the following year at the charges as set forth in appendix A to this Code for the following: 
Nonresidents. 
Portsmouth residents. 
Sixty-two years of age or over. 
City of Portsmouth employees. 
(2)  Accompanied guests of the permittee are not required to have a separate permit. 
(3)  Daily permits shall be issued for each day at a cost as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(b)  The permit is nontransferable. 
(c)  The director has the right to issue boat permits for law enforcement, special events, contractors and other situations as deemed appropriate. 
(d)  Boat identification decal. 
(1)  A boat identification decal will be issued with each permit at no extra cost. The decal shall be securely attached to the right (starboard) bow of the boat in plain view and easily recognizable. Should a decal become mutilated so that its numbers cannot be read easily, it is to be removed and a new decal will be issued. The boat owner will report a defaced, lost or stolen decal to the watershed manager. 
(2)  All boats moored or stored on watershed property must display a decal. Owners must purchase an additional permit for each boat kept on watershed property. 
(e)  No boats will be allowed on the lakes before sunrise and all boats must return to shore before sunset. Boats launched from the Lake Cohoon Fishing Station must leave the property by the time posted at the bait shop.  
Sec. 38-365. - Regulations applicable to city lakes and shores. 
Every permit issued pursuant to this article shall be subject to the following regulations, and all other regulations which may be promulgated by the director of public utilities from time to time, which are hereby established for the use of all city lakes and city-owned land adjoining such lakes: 
(1)  All city lakes and adjacent city-owned property shall be open during hours designated by the director of public utilities and posted at major entry points. Persons are allowed on the city-owned lakes only for fishing/boating and such persons assume the risk attendant with water activities and agree that the department of public utilities, the City of Portsmouth and its employees are relieved of any and all responsibility for accidents, injuries and drowning. 
(2)  No person shall operate a sailboat or houseboat or use jet skis, water skis, wake boards, sailboards, surfboards, tubes, rafts, or similar devices on any city lake. Fishermen may use float waders only in the area of the Lake Cohoon Fishing Station. 
(3)  No person shall permit stagnant water to accumulate in such person's private boat on any city lake. 
(4)  No person shall swim in any city lake. No skin diving or scuba diving is allowed in any city lake except as practiced by game wardens, law enforcement officers or members of a rescue unit in the performance of their duties. 
(5)  No person shall go on any city lake unless such person is equipped with a U.S. Coast Guard approved personal floatation device. Boats of 16 feet or more also require at least one throwable device buoyant cushion or ring buoy on board. 
(6)  No person shall fish from any city-owned land adjoining any city lake, except on property designated therefore at Lake Cohoon unless authorized in writing by the director of public utilities. 
(7)  No person shall take any fish from any city lake except with rod, line and hooks baited with natural or artificial bait unless authorized by the director of public utilities or if such person is a game warden acting in the performance of their official duties. 
(8)  No person under the age of 16 years shall operate any boat unless accompanied by an adult on any city lake. 
(9)  No person shall use any boat having an internal or outboard motor exceeding ten horsepower on any city lake. The use of four-cycle outboard motors and/or electric motors is encouraged. Boats with overcapacity motors may be used so long as the illegal motor is obviously disabled, i.e. a removed prop or fuel tank, and a legal capacity engine is used for propulsion. 
(10)  No mechanically propelled boats shall be used on any city lake except for the purpose of fishing. This prohibition shall not apply to law enforcement personnel, game wardens and city employees in the performance of their official duties. 
(11)  No person shall launch any boat exceeding 18 feet in length. Boats shall be launched only from areas designated by the director of public utilities. 
(12)  Any boat operated on city-owned reservoirs must comply with the Code of Virginia boating operation requirements. 
(13)  All fishing, daily boat launching and other permits issued pursuant to this section and the state code pertaining to freshwater fishing must be produced for inspection when requested by any law enforcement personnel, game warden, or other persons authorized by the director of public utilities. 
(14)  All boats on the city lakes must display the City of Portsmouth Public Utilities current year boat decal on the righthand (starboard) bow section, except those boats which purchase a daily permit at the Lake Cohoon boat landing and those boats operated by law enforcement personnel, game wardens, rescue squads and city personnel in the performance of their official duties. 
(15)  Boats found on the city lakes or on city-owned property adjoining the lakes and not displaying the City of Portsmouth Public Utilities current year boat decal shall be removed and detained by the Portsmouth Department of Public Utilities. Upon confirmation of ownership, purchase of a boat decal and payment of the amount as set forth in appendix A to this Code, the boat shall be returned to its owner. 
(16)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating any motorboat to: (i) pass under any bridge on a city lake at a speed in excess of five miles per hour, or (ii) travel at any speed that creates more than a minimum wake. 
(17)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motorboat or other vessel on any city lake in a reckless manner so as to endanger the life, limb, or property of any person. Notwithstanding the above provision, upon the trial of any person charged with reckless boating where the degree of culpability is slight, the court, in its discretion, may find the accused guilty of improper boating. 
(18)  Any person who, having received a visible or audible signal of a flashing light or siren or hail from any game warden or other law enforcement officer to bring his motorboat or other vessel to a stop, fails to do so promptly shall be in violation of these regulations. 
(19)  Boats are to stay outside and clear of warning buoys and/or booms around intakes, dams, spillways, etc. and clear of areas marked by buoys as closed or restricted.  
Sec. 38-366. - Regulations applicable to city owned land adjoining city lakes and shores. 
(a)  No person shall go on any city-owned land adjoining any city-owned property outside of posted hours unless he is a warden, law enforcement officer, member of a rescue unit, or other authorized personnel. 
(b)  No person shall bring, possess, or drink any alcoholic beverage or possess or be under the influence of any drug or intoxicant of any kind while on the city lakes or on any city-owned land adjoining any city lake. 
(c)  No person shall camp, hike, bicycle, motorcycle, or use all terrain vehicles or any type of recreational vehicle on city-owned watershed property without the prior written permission of the director of public utilities. 
(d)  No person shall kindle, build, maintain or use a fire on city-owned property except in grills and fireplaces located in areas designated by the director of public utilities. 
(e)  No person shall carry or possess any BB or pellet gun or paint-ball gun on a city lake unless expressly authorized by the director of public utilities in writing, unless such person is a state, local or federal law enforcement officer or game warden acting in the performance of their official duties. 
(f)  No person shall willfully throw or discharge or cause to be discharged any arrow, stone, missile or other projectile by hand or from a bow, crossbow, slingshot or by any other comparable device on any city lake or city-owned land adjoining any city lake. 
(g)  Automobiles and trucks are allowed on city-owned watershed property only to launch and retrieve boats at designated city-owned boat ramps except for those automobiles and trucks used by law enforcement officers, game wardens, forest wardens and city employees in the performance of their duties. 
(h)  No person shall use city-owned watershed property for storage of any sort or for unauthorized vehicular parking. 
(i)  No person shall cause any loud, disturbing or unnecessary noise through the use of any sound amplification equipment, radio or other means on any city lake or on any city-owned land adjoining any city lake. 
(j)  No person shall have a special event, which shall include parades, processions, or performances of any kind on city-owned watershed property unless they have received authorization in writing from the director of public utilities prior to such event. 
(k)  No person shall hunt or trap on any city-owned lake or on any city-owned land adjacent to any city-owned lake unless such person has been authorized in writing by the director of public utilities or is game warden acting in the official performance of his duties. 
(l)  No person shall bring, ride or drive a horse or pony or cause or permit any other animal owned or under his custody or control to enter any city-owned lake unless he has received written authorization from the director of public utilities. 
(m)  No person shall sell or rent any goods, bait, fishing tackle, food and soft drinks except as authorized by the director of public utilities. 
(n)  (1)  No person shall dump or otherwise dispose of trash, oil, chemicals, herbicides, pesticides, paint or paint related products, refuse, garbage, waste, debris or other material, including but not limited to construction materials, tires, appliances, ashes, grass cuttings and other yard waste on any city lake or on any city-owned property adjacent to any city-owned lake. Each day that such trash, oil, chemicals, herbicides, pesticides, paint or paint related products, refuse, garbage, waste, debris or other material remain on any city lake or on any city-owned property adjacent to any city-owned lake shall constitute a separate offense. The city shall be entitled to reimbursement of reasonable costs associated with mitigation, cleanup, investigation and litigation associated with such acts. Prosecution and/or conviction under this provision shall not bar the city from prosecution of this offense under other applicable state and federal statutes. 
(2)  When a person is convicted of a violation of this provision, the court may suspend the imposition of the sentence, on the condition that the defendant remove or cause to be removed the trash, oil, chemicals, herbicides, pesticides, paint or paint products, refuse, garbage, waste, debris or other materials, and pay for any damages and extra water treatment expense caused by the dumping, and upon payment of the city's reasonable costs of investigation and litigation, if any. 
(o)  No person shall dispose of any litter on any city lake or on any city-owned property adjacent to a city lake except in litter receptacles provided by the city expressly for this purpose. The term "litter" as used in this section shall mean paper, food wrappers, bottles or cans, but shall not include garbage, refuse, trash, oil, chemicals, pesticides, herbicides, construction debris, paint or paint products or other materials. 
(p)  No person shall withdraw water, for any purpose whatsoever, from the lakes owned by the city or lay or place any pipes or lines that could withdraw water from the city lakes or city-owned property without the prior, written consent of the director of public utilities. 
(Ord. No. 2009-114, § 1, 11-24-2009)  
Sec. 38-367. - Permits required for construction, maintenance, clearing of property or encroachment on water supply reservoirs and city-owned land. 
(a)  The director of public utilities is hereby authorized to promulgate regulations and set fees and enforce regulations governing the issuance of permits authorizing: 
(1)  The construction, maintenance and use of bulkheads and/or piers, landings or similar structures made into the water supply reservoirs owned by the city; 
(2)  The clearing of city-owned land to gain a better view of or access to the reservoirs; and 
(3)  The encroachment of other structures upon city-owned property. 
(b)  No person shall construct boat piers, bulkheads, decks or similar structures or shall remove trees, soil, shrubs, ground cover or plants on a city lake or any city-owned land adjoining any city lake without first obtaining a permit from the director of public utilities and the City of Suffolk and any applicable state and federal agencies. 
(c)  Certain original landowners and their immediate families have fishing and/or pier construction privileges on Lake Meade and Lake Speights Run as provided for in their deeds. Said original landowners shall be required to apply for permits under this section however no fees shall be charged. 
(d)  The requirements of this section shall not apply to the city and it specifically reserves the right to use and improve its reservoir property, as it deems proper. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person except an authorized employee or agent of the department of utilities to perform any of the following acts without first obtaining a permit from the director: 
(1)  Plant, prune, trim or remove any tree or portion thereof or damage, cut, tap, caulk, paint, attach any rope, wire, nail, sign or any manmade object to any tree or shrub, or dig a tunnel trench or otherwise excavate or place any dirt, rubble or debris within the drip line of any tree or shrub. 
(2)  Place any material of any sort, including, but not limited to, dirt, soil, tires, organic wastes and other materials including herbicides and growth regulators that either prevent or hinders the establishment of vegetation or is detrimental to the environment beneath the drip line of any tree or shrub except as authorized by permit. 
(f)  When a tree is removed, destroyed or damaged beyond recovery in violation of this section, the director may require that they be replaced on the basis of one tree with a minimum 2.0 inches in caliper for every 2.0 inches diameter of tree removed, destroyed or damaged. Failure to replace or replant as directed shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(g)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to exempt any person from the requirements of obtaining any additional permits as required by law.  
Sec. 38-368. - Permit revocation. 
In the event of the violation of any of the foregoing regulations by any person holding a permit issued pursuant to this chapter, the director shall have the right, in addition to any other remedies herein provided or otherwise allowed by law, to revoke such permit and to deny such person access to the city reservoir and city-owned land adjoining any city reservoir for a period deemed appropriate.  
Sec. 38-369. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any city law enforcement officers, the director of public health, the fire marshal, employees, and others designated in writing by the director of public utilities are authorized to enforce all provisions of this watershed ordinance and regulations, and state laws governing fishing, boating, and general sanitation on all properties owned by the city. Any duly designated sworn police officer has the authority to issue summons as specified in the statewide uniform summons procedures to persons violating this article. Prepayment of violation fines may be allowed. 
(b)  In the event of the violation of the watershed regulations by any persons holding a fishing permit or other permit issued pursuant to this section, the director of public utilities shall have the right, in addition to any other remedies herein provided or otherwise allowed by law, to revoke such permit and to deny such persons access to the city lakes and city-owned land adjoining any city lake for period of one year.  
Sec. 38-370. - Violations of article. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specifically provided, any violation of the provisions of this article shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. Each day's continuance of such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Violations of the provisions of this article shall be prosecuted in the courts of the city.  
Secs. 38-371—38-390. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - STRUCTURES ON RESERVOIRS 
 
Sec. 38-391. - Permit required; prior permits validated. 
The director is hereby authorized to set fees and issue permits authorizing the construction, maintenance and use of bulkheads and/or piers, landings or similar structures made out into the waters of water supply reservoirs and adjacent property owned by the city from property adjacent to said waters owned by the city.  
Sec. 38-392. - Permit exemption. 
Permit requirements shall not apply to the city or any of its departments, and the city specifically reserves the right to use and improve its reservoir property, as it deems proper.  
Sec. 38-393. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Application for a permit shall be made in writing and shall set forth the proposed location of such structure and the purposes for which it is to be used, and shall be accompanied with plans and specifications for the construction thereof. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued unless the director approves the prescribed application with plans and specifications, and the requisite fee is paid in full. 
(c)  The director shall approve, and provide public access to, standards for the type and characteristics of the materials from which such structures may be constructed, for the dimensions or ranges of dimensions thereof, for the placement of such structures with regard to the water line and any other relevant topographical features, and for any other aspects of such structures for which he deems standards necessary to preserve and protect the waters of the reservoir and/or the purity thereof. Such standards shall be mandatory upon all persons applying for permits, and shall have been set forth in documentary form on or before the effective date of this section. Documents for the construction of piers, bulkheads and similar structures shall be made available and shall set forth the standards for construction on the reservoirs.  
Sec. 38-394. - Qualifications for issuance of permit. 
Only those persons owning real property in fee simple adjacent to real property owned by the city upon which such structure is proposed to be located may be issued permits pursuant to this article. Structures must be placed within the extended sidelines of the property extended to the shoreline. Any person making application for a permit shall state in writing as part of said application, that he meets all the requirements of this article.  
Sec. 38-395. - Insurance; hold-harmless agreement. 
(a)  Issuance of a permit pursuant to this article shall be conditioned upon the person applying for and holding said permit obtaining, paying for and keeping in effect public liability insurance with the city as named insured, in the minimum amount of $1,000,000.00 per person injured and property damage per incident combined. 
(b)  Any person applying for or holding a permit pursuant to this article shall agree in writing to hold and save the city harmless from any and all liability of whatsoever nature, and to indemnify the city against any loss whatsoever, incurred by reason of the existence or maintenance of the permitted structure.  
Sec. 38-396. - Permit dependent upon obtaining other permits. 
The granting of any permit pursuant to this article shall be conditioned upon the applicant's obtaining all other applicable permits, licenses or permissions required by any local, state or federal government agency having jurisdiction. Failure to obtain all required permits, licenses or permissions shall constitute grounds for denial of a permit or revocation of the permit issued pursuant to this article.  
Sec. 38-397. - Revocation of permit. 
The director may revoke any permit issued pursuant to this article at any time upon reasonable evidence satisfactory to him that any of the conditions of this article or of the standards have not been complied with or have been violated or should the requisite fee not be paid.  
Sec. 38-398. - Transferability. 
No permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be transferable. However, subsequent purchasers of property having such permit shall be allowed to apply for a new permit if they do so within 30 calendar days after purchase and upon payment of the requisite fee.  
Sec. 38-399. - Existing structures. 
(a)  The owner of any existing bulkhead and/or pier, landing or similar structure for boats made out into the waters of city-owned water supply reservoirs from property adjacent to said water owned by the city, shall make application to the director for a permit as provided in this article. 
(b)  Upon such application, such structure shall be inspected by the director as to its suitability and compliance with the provisions of this article and the standards established pursuant to this article. If such structure is found to be suitable and in proper repair, a permit shall be issued as provided in this article. If such structure is not found to be suitable and in proper repair, the owner thereof shall be notified in writing by certified mail, return receipt requested, as to what is to be done to make such structure comply with said standards and requirements of this article. If the matters required to be done, as set forth in said written notification, have not been accomplished and completed within 60 days after the date such notification is mailed to said owner at the address given on said application, the director shall cause such structure to be removed at the cost and expense of the said owner. Ten days prior to the removal of such structure as aforesaid, the director shall post a notice upon such structure that it will be removed and demolished at the expense of the owner upon the date to be stated in the notice. If for any reason the notice cannot be posted upon such structure, the director shall cause such notice to be mailed to the owner at his last known address by certified mail, return receipt requested.  
Sec. 38-400. - Rights of permittee. 
In granting a permit pursuant to this article, the city grants the same only insofar as it is authorized by law to do so; and it does not in any way guarantee to any permittee or any other person any rights or privileges with regard to constructing, maintaining or using any such bulkhead and/or pier, landing or other similar structure.  
Sec. 38-401. - Prohibitions and restrictions. 
(a)  No such structure shall be used or permitted to be used for any commercial purpose, nor for building, constructing or repairing any boat. No charge shall be made for the use of any such structure. 
(b)  No vessel fitted for use as a dwelling or residence or occupied as such shall be permitted at any pier, bulkhead or similar structure allowed pursuant to this article. 
(c)  The person making application for a permit pursuant to this article shall at all times keep the permitted structure clean and in good repair. No changes or additions to such structure shall be allowed subsequent to issuance of the permit therefore. 
(d)  The person holding a pier permit pursuant to this section may keep and tie up a boat at the permitted structure, and may place such boat upon the structure from the water; such permit holder may not place such upon land owned by the city or transport such boat across such land, or cause or allow such placement or transportation. Any such boat shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the city pertaining to boats upon waters owned by the city, as the same now exist or as they may be amended in the future; except that such boat may be kept, tied up and placed as provided in this section. 
(e)  The person holding a pier permit pursuant to this article shall be permitted to fish from the pier provided all applicable regulations related to fishing are adhered to. For purposes of this section, the term "person" shall mean all occupants of the property and immediate family members.  
Chapter 39 - WETLANDS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Vegetation, ch. 36. 
State Law reference— Wetlands, Code of Virginia, § 28.2-1300 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 39-1—39-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WETLANDS ZONING ORDINANCE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— General zoning ordinance, ch. 40.1. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to adopt ordinance from which this article is derived, Code of Virginia, § 28.2-1302. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 39-21. - Intent. 
The city council, acting pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 28.2-1300 et seq., for purposes of fulfilling the policy standards set forth in such chapter, adopts this article regulating the use and development of wetlands. 
(Code 1988, § 39-21; Ord. No. 1988-30, § 1(40-300), 4-26-1988; Ord. No. 1994-12, § 1, 3-22-1994)  
Sec. 39-22. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person who knowingly, intentionally, negligently or continually violates any order, rule or regulation of the commission or of the wetlands board or violates any provision of Code of Virginia, § 28.2-1300 et seq. or of the provisions contained in this article or any provision of a permit granted by the wetlands board or the commission pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 28.2-1300 et seq., shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Following a conviction, every day the violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to, and notwithstanding the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 28.2-1300 et seq. or any provisions of this Code, upon petition of the wetlands board to the circuit court of the city, the court may enjoin any unlawful act referred to in subsection (a) of this section and may order the person so acting unlawfully to take such steps as are necessary to restore, protect and preserve the wetlands involved. 
(c)  Without limiting the remedies which may be obtained in Code of Virginia, § 28.2-1300 et seq. or of the provisions contained in this article, any person who violates any provision of the aforementioned chapter or of this article or who violates or falls, neglects or refuses to obey any commission or wetlands board notice, order, rule, regulation or permit condition shall, upon such finding by an appropriate circuit court, be assessed a civil penalty not to exceed $25,000.00 for each day of violation. Such civil penalties may, at the discretion of the court assessing them, be directed to be paid into the treasury of the city for the purpose of abating environmental damage to or the restoration of wetlands therein in such a manner as the court may, by order, direct; except that where the violator is the city itself, or its agent, the court shall direct the penalty to be paid into the state treasury. 
(d)  Without limiting the remedies which may be obtained in Code of Virginia, § 28.2-1300 et seq. or the provisions contained in this article and with the consent of any person who has violated any provision of the aforementioned chapter or of this article, or who has violated or failed, neglected or refused to obey any commission or wetlands board order, rule, regulation or permit condition, the wetlands board may provide, in an order issued by the wetlands board against such person, for the one-time payment of civil charges for each violation in specific sums, not to exceed $10,000.00 for each violation. Civil charges shall be in lieu of any appropriate civil penalty which could be imposed under subsection (c) of this section. Civil charges may be in addition to the cost of any restoration ordered by the wetlands board. 
(Code 1988, § 39-22; Ord. No. 1988-30, § 1(40-315), (40-316), 4-26-1988; Ord. No. 1990-67, § 1, 6-26-1990; Ord. No. 1994-12, § 1, 3-22-1994) 
Editor's note— Code of Virginia, § 28.2-1318, declares a violation described above to be a "misdemeanor." Pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 18.2-12, the violation is punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. 
Cross reference— Penalty for class 1 misdemeanor, § 1-11.  
Sec. 39-23. - Definitions.
